<question>



What should i do.....? what is the most likely outcome do u think?



i have some work-type information that another person wants. i need information from them too. they have given me some info in the past, but i need more for it to be effective. HOWEVER, if i give them the info they ask, it could help them enable them to leave their job early and not give me any more info at all.



of course it may make them take me more seriously and stay to help me with the info i need as they are grateful.
they could also just choose to leave their job early if they are determined, anyway despite it being more difficult/risky if i dont tell them what they want to know.



which is the most likely outcome? should i tell them or not?



</question>



<additional details>



if i tell them this info, it may also gain me credibility for my "expertise" and my arguments for them to delay leaving, and with our other discussions of info i need, of course it assists in opening the door they need to go tho, WHAT TO DO?



</additional details>

2-4-View
Member since: 10 October 2008

</question from>



<question>



Do people who were sexualy abused as a child have little respect for their lives?



Clearly a generalization, but I know a few people who have experienced this and they drink and sleep around - with very little care for what they should do with their lives.  they can't maintain relationships and hang around with some very loose moral people.  What are your thoughts on this?



</question>



<answer from>



BeautyBl...
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 4947 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think sexual abuse affects each individual differently.  While some may drink and sleep around others become a victim, and remain a victim throughout their entire life, never really taking any responsibility for their actions because they were harmed as a child.  They see it as a "get out of jail free" card.  Some are able to rise above the abuse and have a normal and happy life.  I wish it were that way for all the victims.



</answer>



<answer from>



fmahon69
Member since: 02 November 2008
Total points: 170 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i agree with beautybl.



but when that happens it makes your world topsy turvry.



an adult is to protect and show love and show how you are meant to act. when they abuse you, you are taught that this is how people show you affection, even though you dont like it.



this is all you know unless you have shared it with someone who has taken time to make you understand that this is not true.
you also numb your feelings anyway you can to cope. then the wall you build around yourself becomes so strong that you never allow anyone to truly love you as you were meant to be love. and even if you atart taking bricks out of the wall the pain starts to come back. imagine how vulnerable you would be again with no wall at all!!
people tend to carry on sleeping around because that is how they feel they are loved even if it does make them feel even crappier. its inbuilt.
i wouldn't say they use it as a get out of jail free card, it may seem that way but it isn't that easy.



</answer>

<question>



I have been hospitalized for depression and suicidal thoughts. What should I do when I go back to school?



I am really nervous right now because I haven't been in school for 3 weeks because I was hospitalized for depression, anxiety, and suicidal thoughts. I have been away from everyone at school for a long time and I don't know what to say when I get back. Like if they ask why I was gone for so long. It seems like they know I've been really derpressed the week brfore I went to the hospital. I'm just really nervous and I don't know what to do. I'm 13 years old in 8th grade and the kids make fun of me a lot. I have to leave for school in 1 hour! Please help!!!



</question>



<answer from>

</answer>



<answer from>



fmahon69
Member since: 02 November 2008
Total points: 178 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



you have less than an hour to ask jesus to come into your life! go to school with him and you will be able to cope. he will never leave you, ever. you will never be lonely again. he will be your own personal friend and brother and will introduce you to his father who will adopt you as a son. the creator of everything wants you to be his son. ask and the door will open. you will feel peace and love.

</answer>



<answer from>



LisaHW
Member since: 25 July 2006
Total points: 18928 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi, Derek.  I almost wonder if the person you should ask about this is your doctor or other mental health worker.  They deal with people in your situation all the time, and they probably have tips for dealing with something like going back to school and having people ask.



If, for some reason, you can't ask your doctor (or other professional), I suppose what I'd say would be something like, "It turns out I have some kind of chemical imbalance, and I was too tired to be able to come to school."  (or, if you feel more comfortable and are with closer friends), you could say, "...and I had to wait until my prescription started to work".



I think the way I'd aim to handle it would be to tell a few of my closer friends whatever I wanted to tell them (don't tell people all your business; they don't need to know that - just tell the basics, such as above).  If you have to, you could say that it turns out you have a chemical imbalance that made you depressed.  Anyway, just tell a couple of closer friends and tell them you won't mind if they answer anyone who asks about you.



Also, make sure you tell your parents (if you haven't) and a counselor at school that people are making fun of you.  Tell the counselor (or have your parent tell him/her) that you're struggling with an issue right now, and you need some ideas on how to stay out of the situations where  you're made fun of.  Maybe someone can suggest something you can to do to help at school (like work in the library or something) that could get you away from some of the kids for a while.  In any case, talk to your parent(s) and the school counselor.



You're at a very, very, hard age; so try to keep in mind that you will grow past this difficult age.  It's not an easy age for anyone.



</answer>



<answer from>



Hummingb...
Member since: 15 February 2007
Total points: 1 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



just be confident and tell them you were physically ill.



best of luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



Famus Jamus
Member since: 09 October 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



You can admit to being in hospital, but not the reason. Lie if you need to (e.g. say it was a broken bone or something). If people keep asking you, ignore them.



</answer>

<question>



How do i make myself a better person?



I was intimidated, harassed and violated emotionally and physically by my biological mother as a child. This has had



a seriosly negative impact on my life. I am now in my 20s and i need to know how to get over this.



</question>



<answer from>



Famus Jamus
Member since: 09 October 2008
Total points: 858 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, you've taken the first step by accepting that you want to be better... Well done!



You can look for help (e.g. a psychiatrist), if you need it. Or just treat yourself well and know that you deserved better than what your Mum gave you.



</answer>



<answer from>



jmnpc@ve...
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 107 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



My mom did the same thing to me growing up and as i became an adult she realized what she did and wanted to help me.  The thing was is she wasn't helping me she was trying to do everything for me and it got really annoying.  So just last week I decided to distance myslef form her and take time away from her for myself.  This is the best thing I have ever done I feel so much better without that weight of my mother on me.  You just need to find yourself and live for yourself.  You can't let anyone else make your choices for you, or let her negative impact affect the rest of your life.  Live your life for yourself and make yoruself happy!!!!

<question from>



LiteNite

</question from>



<question>



What are ways to commit suicide?



I know someone who's thinking of suicide. I need to know what to watch out for to see if they'll do it.



</question>



<answer from>



Shannon
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 1359 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Resume



Razors pain you;
Rivers are damp;
Acids stain you;
And drugs cause cramp.
Guns aren't lawful;
Nooses give;
Gas smells awful;
You might as well live.



-- Dorothy Parker



</answer>



<answer from>



Generic Person
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 317 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Unless you live in their house, there's practically no chance of you catching them by method of suicide. You need to look for the symptoms instead.



By the way, we can tell that you're the one trying to commit suicide here.



</answer>



<answer from>
Member since: 06 May 2008
Total points: 1202 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I dont know....check their arms for cuts?



</answer>



<answer from>



tracy
Member since: 12 September 2007
Total points: 1572 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The first thing you do is to tell that person's parents if they are underage, and you try to get them help.  There is no way you can be vigilant enough to stop this if this person is intent of committing suicide.  Get them help.  NOW



</answer>



<answer from>



Perspekt...
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



There's probably hundreds of ways to commit suicide, and I highly think you're wasting your time trying to look at methods.



The method is irrelevant, anyways. Shouldn't the fact that they're actually trying to take their lives be alarming enough?



You should be focusing on symptoms that are far more obvious instead.



It's like trying to tell if your car's brakes are worn by glancing at your tires as you get out of your car, as opposed to listening out for sounds, or them "crying out to you", giving you an obvious hint something is wrong.



</answer>

<question from>



2-4-View
Member since: 10 October 2008
Total points: 363 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How can you help someone become a responsible person?



From my experience there are some people who run from responsibility at the first sign of it.  Become depressed and upset when they have to be in the real world.  Is there any way to help this kind of person?



The kind of person who, when starting a new job or relationship, gets lost in the moment of it - and once the novelty wears off gets depressed and moves on.  Keeps drifting through their whole life, but never really drifts anywhere worthwhile, typically being the same lifestyle their whole life.



Any thoughts?



</question>



<answer from>



BeautyBl...
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 4953 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are some people who can't be tethered to responsibility no matter how we try.  But that is the beauty of the world we live in.  There are millions of different kinds of people, and these are among them.  You can no easier teach them responsibility as teach a responsible person to be irresponsible or teach a fish to fly.  They are who they are.



</answer>



<answer from>



fmahon69
Member since: 02 November 2008
Total points: 178 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



it comes from fear, not being good enough, being able to live up to expectations, never finding contentment and cant deal with their emotions.



a lot of this comes from rejection by others, self rejection which also harbours rebellion. they feel disappointed a lot.
they need to realise where it started what first brought that feeling into their life. it is like having a tiny hole and a wasp gets in there and starts building a nest. you can get rid of a wasp at a time but you need to find where it is getting in. you need to heal the hole.



some people are so used to living with these things they just see it as normal and not a problem.
i'm afraid until they see the problem and want rid of it, it will be very difficult. stay patient and understanding with them.
www.deeprelease.org.uk are very helpful and interesting.



</answer>



<answer from>



CJ
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 390 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think there are a couple of things here.  Firstly are you living a responsible lifestyle?  In order to reach anybody you have to demonstrate in your life that you have something that they want.  When your life becomes desirable people will then just naturally start asking you for advice.  Lead by example.



Secondly setting goals and have a defined outcome with help with this problem.  If you don't have goals then you operate on feelings.  As soon as something stops feeling good you move on.  I have a website you might find useful that deals with this more.



http://www.dream-life-coaching.com



Goo luck



</answer>

<original file>11505.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk101092.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



reality_...
Member since: 01 March 2008
Total points: 798 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



So how are you today?



Just feel free to rant, rave and complain. Get it all off your chest.



</question>



<answer from>



Amanda :D
Member since: 13 July 2007
Total points: 6829 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Okie dokie. I feel like ranting.



I hate, hate, hate, HATE the wanna-be attention seeking 'emos' at our school. They all used to be momma's girls, wearing unicorn shirts and shirts with kittens on them, but now there is a group of kids who think they are emo just because they wear the clothes.



I'm not emo whatsoever, but it still really annoys me when they go on bragging about cutting and suicide attempts and such, and the are total LIES. They are just looking for pity and attention. Sure enough, today a girl in the group decided she would go on and on about how she tried to kill herself, and everyone was buying her stuff, and sitting with her and doing all this garbage for her.



I just thought it was really sick how she used something as horrible as suicide to get attention. And it's not like she's a loner who wants any kind of attention, she was just milking it for all it was worth.



Maybe the reason why this is so touchy for me is because I do have a problem with depression and cutting and suicidal thoughts, but you would never know it, because I don't go using it as a way to get attention. No one would ever guess that I would be that type of person, I'm the girl who wears pink, all bright and bubbly and I'm practically a total opposite of emoness.



For me, my depression actually comes from growing up in an abusive environment. My dad is a crazy jerk, who yells at my siblings and I, calling us 'Lazy *** s***heads' and that he wishes he never had us, and calls us 'fat asses' and 'stupid little sonofabitches' and he's passed his abusive personality to my older sister, who uses me as her personal punching bag.



The thing about growing up in an abusive family is that you don't think twice about being hit, yelled at, shoved, pushed or anything like that. It was when I was 13, and read a book for school about an abusive dad that I realized that I had an abusive family. Before that I always thought it was normal and that all families were like that.



My mom isn't as bad as my dad at all, it's just that she's always at work and isn't around all the time to see what our dad does. She knows what he does, but she always says 'I've had a long day at work, I've done ____ and ____ and I don't want to hear about what's yesterday's news'



It's really confusing, because my parents and sister aren't always abusive. Sometimes they can be the best people in the world, and you think that you would never trade them for anyone, it's just that when they ARE abusive, it get's REALLY bad.



My sister is the worst bully out there. Two years ago, I had to wear long sleeves every day to cover up all the scars she gave me on my arms from clawing and scratching at them. I would constantly have to retan my body to cover the scars, but she always replaced them once they disappeared.



We used to share a room for all our lives, except for the past summer when she moved into the office room. It was HELL living with her. She would make me do my homework in the bathroom when it would be only 8 at night insisting that she was 'tired' she would steal my stuff and if I ever tried to get something back, she would rip it, break it, stain it, or do whatever to it so that it was unusuable.



She's knocked me out before, like when I was sitting at my computer and she told me that our dad had taken away her internet for screaming at him, and she told me to let her on mine. I told her no and she kept insisting that I let her on, and then finally, she grabbed my hair and slammed my head against the wall next to me. I was knocked out for about two minutes.



Another time she and I were in a screaming fight, and she slapped me, so I tried to kick her, and she grabbed my foot and pulled my other one out from under me so my head hit the tile. Only knocked out for a few moments.



She's taken the small plastic rod that you use to turn curtains with and whipped me with it until I was bleeding, and I was screaming, but when I went to show my mother, she scolded me for being so loud because my aunt was at the house.



She's learned all of this from my dad. When I was six or so, I remember sitting on my bed crying and looking at a hand print shaped welt on my thigh where my dad had smacked me. He hit me so hard that there was literally a popped up, swollen ring around the area he smacked me.



He's punched a hole through the bathroom door after I had thrown a plastic fork at him once, and he had hit it so hard that the doorknob smashed into the wall, even though there was one of those protector thingys, and it made a huge hole.



But it's REALLY confusing. My dad, like today, was the absolute best dad to be around. It's 85% of the time that he is the world's best dad, but the other 15% percent are the worst kind of times to be around him.



So it really upsets me when people fake trying to commit suicide because it is something that I have seriously considered before, but I would never be dumb enough to do. I do have a problem with cutting but, like I said you would never know. I only do it on my thighs and just tell everyone the cat was too wild.



It's really a touchy subject for me, because I don't think that depression should be worn as a style when it is actually a real problem.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you for being honest, I agree I hate those people to. I hope things get better for you.



To all those who asked, I was feeling pretty crap when I posted this, but now I think I'm in love



</asker's comment>

Confidence is often what really makes us tick, whether said subject be positive or negative. Some find determination through something they must overcome, something negative, or it can come through something we want so bad, we will stop at nothing to get it

<answer from>



Struggling with Identity/society
Member since: 12 October 2008
Total points: 138 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think it comes naturally.  First of all, think about your family and how they raised you.  If they were empathetic and led by example, punished by explaining what you did wrong, and encouraged you when you did right, your self confidence was created healthily.  If your parents neglected you as a child, how can you embrace the world with comfortability as yourself, when your parents don't seem to love you?  If your parents were just plain mean, your confidence towards yourself and your view of the world will start out skewed.  This is just the START, however.  As you progress through life, different events and situations mold you into who you are and how high your esteem/confidence is.  It's hard to switch from low cnfidence to high... sorry for the crappy answer.  bye



</answer>

Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



T
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 4 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Dating a BIPOLAR person? Best friend one day, stranger the next?



Please tell me your experience dating (or being friedns with) someone who is bipolar?



My friend is 16 and is on medication (Seroquel) for Bipolar/Schizo.



Even though he's on medication I'm having "communciation" problems. It's like he's my best friend one week then a total stranger the next month.



Is this the normal way bipolar people act?



His behavior was making me paranoid because I felt like he hated me when he wouldnt return my emails or messages when he use t ocall me every day.



My friends saying hes likely acting this way because hes bipolar. But then how do you know if he really likes/hates you or if its the "bipolar?"



I hate waking up each day not knowing if I'm a "friend" or if I'm on his s*** list for reasons I have no control over.



Please tell me your experiences with bipolar people and if you feel it's worth hanging in there?



I love him but even friendship has to be a two way street.



</question>



<answer from>



omgithin...
Member since: 10 March 2007
Total points: 12988 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



We don't mean to be the way we are, there is an imbalance in us that causes extreme mood swings, manic depression, racing thoughts, voices in our head, sometimes it's like living with other people knocking around in our head.  I have so many roles to fill in my life, I think I was bi-polar years before my diagnosis.  Medication helps, but is not a cure all.  We need compassion, understanding, sometimes a reminder that we need to stop and take a deep breath, several, then begin again.  We need someone to talk to, someone that cares enough to work through the bad times with us and not judge us in the process.  You must be thick skinned to run with us, it may be bumpy, but never a dull ride.  Consistently taking the medications and keeping yourself leveled out is the only help for this disease, but we don't like being level, so we must be encouraged to take the medication.  Check on your friend, pat him on the back during a manic stage and lift him up when he gets depressed.  Friendship is a two way street, but in the end, we are our brother's keeper.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thnks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Sara H
Member since: 02 October 2008
Total points: 240 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



bio-polar People have a lot of things going on in there heads. I don't think that he's not your friend.Sometimes they can talk about things and some times they stay to themselves just to think things throw. His medication may not be the right one. It takes trial and error to get the medications right. Just be open with him and tell him how you feel.
he may not know he is doing this and that it bothers you.He does have highs and lows even on the medication.On the high days its like nothings wrong, but 0n the low days sometimes its hard to talk to anyone. Just give him a chance.



Source(s):



Bio-polar



</answer>



<answer from>



random_p...
Member since: 08 August 2007
Total points: 740 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



My ex was bipolar and taking Seroquel. He had to go off because he had no insurance and couldn't afford it (it was like $700/month) and I won't lie; things got pretty bad. He ended up getting involved with street drugs and we broke things off on really bad terms.



That was just my experience. Not everyone who has bipolar will end up like he did, especially if they stay on their medication.



Stick with it a little longer if this relationship means a lot to you. Your friend's behavior might just be part of their personality, because I've known a lot of normal people that are just fickle that way. If it drives you nuts after a while, gradually decrease the time you're spending with this person and don't stress out about it.



</answer>



<answer from>



WithTheL...
Member since: 08 January 2008
Total points: 1672 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is exactly why I get to know someone really well before telling them I'm Bipolar. Your friend is taking medication for a reason, he has an imbalance in his mind he cannot help. I'm not alluding that this gives him a "pass" to treat you like dirt that's just wrong. But he must have shared that sensitive information with you for a reason. Being Bipolar myself I can tell you there is a stigma in society on us it's sad, so he trusts you to tell you that.There will be times yes this illness will make him more sensitive or more irritable, but if you know (or get to know him well as a person not just an illness) you will be able to tell that apart from times he is "not himself". Like everyone else we have our "normal" good and bad days, when he is not well you will clearly see that as a pattern. It's something I wouldn't wish on anybody.



</answer>

<answer from>



wiu_stu

</answer from>



<answer>



"Sigmund Freud again."



Water in a dream means a desire to be reborn or rebirth. Most likely there is a particular instance in your life of which you're having trouble with, after you confront this source then the dreams will become more understanding.



</answer>

There could be two reasons..  either your sister is nice because she wants something from you.. a favour.. or this could be severe.. if she acts totally out of character and is not her usual self and this goes on for any lenght of time.. she may be suffering from depression.. if a person changes their usual behaviour drastically .. that is a red alert.. unless she wants a favour as I say..  but if she is now becoming a loner,. that indicates she may be depressed.. tell your parents about this.. she may need help.. she may be depressed.. it's an alarm sign if a person changes a lot in the way they usually act...just mention it to your parents and let them decide what to do... it's not your responsibility but you are definitely right that you want to understand and you seem a responsible person and you love your sister even if you don't get along often.. so do the right thing..  mention this to your parents if this continues with her acting against her true nature...xx

<answer from>



elpiri17...
Member since: 01 November 2007
Total points: 1827 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The greatest salesman in the world.  by Og Mandingo



this book has a very suddle hint about God but does not use the word and yes it has scrolls you have to repeat but they are not about God, very helpful stuff, here I attached one of the ten so you get a clue.  good luck.



I will persist until I succeed.



In the Orient young bulls are tested for the fight arena in a certain manner.  Each is brought to the ring and allowed to attack a picador who pricks them with a lance.  The  bravery of each bull is then rated with care according to the number of times he demonstrates his willingness to charge in spite of the sting of the blade.  Henceforth will I recognize that each day I am tested by life in like manner.  If I persist, if I continue to try, if I continue to charge forward, I will succeed.



I will persist until I succeed.



I was not delivered unto this world in defeat, nor does failure course in my veins.  I am not a sheep waiting to be prodded by my shepherd.  I am a lion and I refuse to talk, to walk, to sleep with the sheep.  I will hear  not those who weep and complain, for their disease is contagious.  Let them join the sheep.  The slaughterhouse of failure is not my destiny.



I will persist until I succeed.



The prizes of life are at the end of each journey, not near the beginning; and it is not given to me to know how many steps are necessary in order to reach my goal.  Failure I may still encounter at the  thousandth step, yet success hides behind the next bend in the road.  Never will I know how close it lies unless I turn the corner.



Always will I take another step.  If that is of no avail I will take another, and yet another.  In truth, one step at a time is not too difficult.



I will persist until I succeed.



Henceforth, I will consider each day’s effort as but one blow of my blade against a mighty oak.  The first blow may cause not a tremor in the wood, nor the second, nor the third.  Each blow, of it self, may be trifling, and seem of no consequence.  Yet from childish swipes the oak will eventually tumble.  So it will be with my efforts of today.



I will be liken to the rain drop which washes away the mountain; the ant who devours a tiger; the star which brightens the earth; the slave who builds a pyramid.  I will build my castle one brick at a time for I know that small attempts, repeated, will complete any undertaking.



I will persist until I succeed.



I will never consider defeat and I will remove from my vocabulary such words and phrases as quit, unable, impossible, out of the question, improbable, failure, unworkable, hopeless, and retreat; for they are the words of fools.  I will avoid despair but if this disease of the  mind should infect me then I will ignore the obstacles at my feet and keep mine eyes on the goals above my head, for I know that where dry desert ends, green grass grows.



I will persist until I succeed.



I will remember the ancient law of averages and I will bend it to my good.  I will persist with knowledge that each failure to sell will increase my chance for success at the next attempt.  Each nay I hear will bring me closer to the sound of yea.  Each frown I meet only prepares me for the smile to come.  Each misfortune I encounter will carry in it the seed of tomorrow’s good luck.  I must have the night to appreciate the day.  I must fail often to succeed only once.



I will persist until I succeed.



I will try, and try, and try again.  Each obstacle I will consider as a mere detour to my goal and a challenge to my profession.  I will persist and develop my skills as the mariner develops his, by learning to ride out the wrath of each storm.



I will persist until I succeed.



Henceforth, I will learn and apply another secret of those who excel in my work.  When each day is ended, not regarding whether it has been a success or a failure, I will attempt to achieve one more sale.  When my thoughts beckon my tired body homeward I will resist the temptation to depart.  I will try again.  I will make one more attempt to close with victory, and if that fails I will make another.  Never will I allow any day to end with a failure.  Thus will I plant the seed of tomorrow’s success and gain an insurmountable advantage over those who cease their labor at a prescribed time.  When others cease their struggle, then mine will begin, and my harvest will be full.



I will persist until I succeed.



Nor will I allow yesterday’s success to lull me into today’s complacency, for this is the great foundation of failure.  I will forget the happenings of the day that is gone, whether they were good or bad, and greet the new sun with confidence that this will be the best day of my life.



So long as there is breath in me, that long will I persist.  For now I know one of the greatest principles of success; if I persist long enough I will win.



I will persist.



I will win.



</answer>



<answer from>



Shaman
Member since: 11 August 2006
Total points: 8630 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



There are various techniques and processes one can use....  Meditation, keeping a thought journal, using a religious phrase, even forms of hypnosis, etc.



I even had a coach have us use a rubber band on our wrist.  (Every time we had a negative thought like "I can't do" something, we were to snap the band on the inside of our wrist using a form of negative reinforcement to alter the behavior.)



The point is to reorient your thinking in a way that avoids the negative thoughts and promotes positive thinking.  But to make such an attitude permanent, you're really gonna have to examine some of your core beliefs about yourself.  Expose the negative thoughts you have about yourself deep in your psyche.



Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ruby
Member since: 19 September 2008
Total points: 295 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You are lucky you can identify the source of your problems - negative thinking, now you have to get yourself out of this pattern. I highly recommend cognitive behavioral therapy - it is all about changing your patterns of thinking and behavior to more constructive means.



</answer>

<answer>



The way to keep your motivation going strong is to make sure that you are centered and that you keep your positive spirits going. Every time that you hear something that is negative, you have to turn it into a positive. That includes the negativity that you may encounter by not reaching your aim. However, if you learn to find the strength to keep trying you will find the motivation to keep your aim high.



You need to respect who you are and also accept yourself for who you are. You may be able to talk your feelings out with someone who is close to you and they will help guide you, but if you only knew just how great it feels to motivate yourself. If you would like to find a way to help with the way that you feel about yourself you may want to think about seeking counseling. It's not a bad thing to see someone about your feelings, in fact, it can be a good and solid way to go about your lack of motivation. Once you are able to work on yourself, you will be able to unblock all your channels and find true motivation to go for something.



</answer>

<answer>



I don't want to look myself in the mirror when I can get myself to NOT care about people. I go for something closer to a reality check: Just how much power do I have to make someone I love less difficult?



Accepting them as they are and giving them room to be who they are gives me room to take the focus off them and pay attention to my own needs. From there it starts becoming much easier to know what I, myself, am going through and to see and act on the early signs. I don't love them less. I love myself more.

<answer from>



Amy R
Member since: 31 August 2007
Total points: 17172 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Easy - you just need to remember that the problem is typically that they are insecure or upset about something else.  Any time someone is particularly nasty, it just means that someone has hurt them - sometimes a long, long time ago, but it was bad for them and it left an emotional hurt they cannot resolve - so they try to take it out on other people, which will not work because it only increases their feelings of self-loathing.



So when someone is being nasty - just wonder who hurt them and try to be sympathetic.  I had one guy being just mindlessly wicked to people, including me, until I looked him in the eye and said "Look, I can tell that someone hurt you, really bad, when you were small. But no one here has done anything to you, so I am not willing to let you take things out on us."  I will never know what happened to him and I probably would not want to know, but he shut his mouth that second and did not rip anyone involved with the group again.  Now some people might not be ready to realize their own demons - I was direct with him because he was so vicious he needed to be corrected fast, but you can safely assume that people who are emotionally cruel have learned cruelty somewhere else.  Don't bother telling irate people that you pity them or anything like that - just know in your own mind that they are suffering on some level.  Also know that a verbal assault is pretty much like a physical one, the person is trying to leave a mark - but whether it does or not is entirely your choice.  Just tilt your head at them as if you are curious and say "hmmm - that was an interesting comment" and walk away.



The other thing is that on some level, the person has framed the situation in their mind so that what they are thinking and saying seems reasonable and correct to them - so perhaps they are afraid of you or feel threatened emotionally by your social or intellectual status - sometimes just imagining what strange thoughts could be going through someone's head that would make their point of view seem reasonable is enough to let them off the hook.  You do not need to agree with how they see the situation, just try to figure out that this looks like from their mind's angle that makes their point seem to be correct to them - it can be enlightening about a host of motives they operate with on a day-to-day basis.  Show a little understanding for someone and it usually takes the wind out of their sails in terms of trying to fight with you about something.



</answer>

<answer>



LOL....  First step, make sure YOU aren't the "non-logical, emotional person".



Sorry, but when you use words like "immature" and "warped thinkers", you are being judgemental... not logical.  And when you come from a somewhat condecending position to think you are superior enough to change others, you are coming from an emotional thought process at best.  At worst, you're coming from a logically flawed thought process.



Second step, accept that ppl think how they think.  You may be able to persuade them to a particular point of view (salesmen do it everyday), but you cannot "change" someone who's personality and thought processes lean to a more emotional process than "logical" one.



However, if you are trying to learn how ppl think and how to persuade them effectively....  Check out this book:



http://www.amazon.com/Art-Speed-Reading-...



"Wisdom ceases to be wisdom when it becomes too proud to weep, too grave to laugh, and too selfful to seek other than itself."



--  Khalil Gibran



</answer>

<answer from>



Daisy
Member since: 11 June 2008
Total points: 11938 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is inevitable that in certain parts of your life that you will be facing problems and having trouble. But there is a very important thing that you must know. How you react to the problems will show you what kinds of results that you will get.



What goes in your mind when you are facing problem? Is the trouble that I am facing a permanent problems or it will go away with times? The best question that you can actually ask yourself is: “So what if I have this trouble, I will be able to find ways to solve it.” This is a simple method that works whenever I face problems.



Instead of getting worried over the problems, I will start to ask question and tell myself so what if I have this problem. When you start to use this simple method, you will realize that you have stop wasting time getting worried over the problem. You will instead be using the time to look for solutions to solve that problem. When you are able to solve it, you will start to adopt a positive attitude. You will soon realize that you are able to overcome all obstacles in life.



A problem is never permanent. If you are willing to have a positive attitude and never give up, you will soon realize that problems will seem to go away and you seem to have a much smoother journey in your life. So start to ask yourself this effective question and you will be able to overcome all your future obstacles.



</answer>



<answer from>



jamie_02...
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 136 (Level 1)

<answer>



Ok, Im no medical expert, but, let me tell you what helped me when I was going through something that sounds similar.  I reached a point in my life about 8 years ago (I was 19), where I felt that I could not deal with any of my issues, mainly because I had so many and I didnt know where to start.  I was depressed, big time, and had no idea how to make it better.  I couldnt make my life better until I FELT good enough to actually do something about it...BUT, I couldnt do anything because I just felt like a complete failure.  So, without giving too many details, I ended up hospitalized and talked to a great therapist during my recovery.  With a little "mental health" guidance and a prescription for antidepressants, I was able to take my life one step at a time and deal with my issues.  I was able to wean myself off the medication about a year later and have felt great ever since.  Hope this can give you some direction.  Good luck!



</answer>

<answer from>



Shaman
Member since: 11 August 2006
Total points: 8636 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



Okay, PandaBear....  This is not as complicated as you may think.



First of all, you have accepted a flawed premise.  That being that "everything in your life" is "getting worse".  That thought alone can become a self-fulfilling prophecy, because you believe it to be so.



Second, I'm going to go with an assumption (a dangerous practice, but my intuition is leading me that way).  The introduction of the bf happened just before you started "losing close friends".  Either that or you latched onto him after you started losing friends.  But your statement that you "feel he is different than what everyone else says" leads me to think it's the former.



Could it be that YOU have begun to change how you treated your friends because of the bf?  I hate to be one who dumps water on the fire of passion, but sometimes we choose relationships that are more harmful than healthy to us.  And in doing so, we can do harm to all facets of our lives.



You may want to take a good hard look at how much the boyfriend is benefitting your life.  Because if you stated exactly the same question and description in your question as you did, but instead of "boyfriend" you said "recently I started drinking" or "recently I started taking drugs" or "recently I started gambling"....  Then, I'd say you have an addiction that is harming your life and suggest you get help.



Could the bf be a harmful addiction that you need help with?



Just a thought.  Be well and good luck.



</answer>

<question from>



Aragorn
Member since: 09 April 2007
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How would I overcome my shyness?



</question>



<answer from>



Macrocom...
Member since: 07 December 2007
Total points: 5673 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



This question is very open to different kinds of answers because of the lack of more information.



If your shyness is due to lack of confidence, then the answer is to make a serious effort to get about more and to mix socially in groups and societies that are not of real interest to you, but can provide you with the need to converse and join in.



</answer>



<answer from>



GJ
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 111 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



That depends. Do you want to ? It sounds like you feel that you have an "affliction" of some sort - shyness is not necessarily a bad thing perse unless it is preventing you from furthering an ambition or is because of a fear of rejection.  As you develop your skills over time, confidence will come and you will grow in strength and be able to communicate what you feel. I was very very shy as a kid and life experiences brought me out of that shell - but don't rush it ! Write down a list of 5 things that shyness is preventing you from doing and then map out a plan for each of those.



</answer>

<original file>15134.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk105124.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



Dazed & Confused
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 125 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I need help changing myself (if that's at all possible)?



I'm a very introvert person and I'm sick of always analyzing myself. It's hard for me to relax in public because I'm constantly wondering what others are thinking about me. I can't socialize very well, even with my best friend. There probably is no way to fix this but it can't hurt to ask...



</question>



<answer from>



walking through life
Member since: 15 October 2008
Total points: 116 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I've been the same way. I have found it is possible to change. Try to make a list or find positive things about you, and try to put less power to the negative. Try to take the negative things you think about yourself and find a reasonable solution to take little steps at a time to change them instead of looking at them as something that can't be dealt with.



I also found if I quit analyzing everything, or most things, my stress level has gone down and I'm more relax and able to do things like you have described such as socialize. I have found that constantly analyzing myself is not always the most healthy thing even though it is useful in life.



My advice is to try and relax, try to just let things go and slowly but surely quit analyzing a little bit at a time. Just be yourself and give it your all without worrying about what other people think. When you feel confident about yourself because of who you see in the mirror not what other people see, then you will be more confident and have a much better chance of changing. Although what others think of you, the altimit choice is yours.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks that really helps me a lot.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Alice A
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, people who over-analyze are usually over critical of themselves, too. You should just step back, look yourself in the mirror, and say, okay, this is what I don't like about myself and what I want to change. However, you should also list out things you *do* like about yourself. You won't be able to change over night, believe me, but over a period of time, you can change things about yourself you are uncomfortable with. But most of all, you should learn that you are who you want to me, this is your decision, and if you want to change, it's all you.



</answer>

Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 84 (Level 1)

<original file>15439.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk105462.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



Simba
Member since: 27 September 2008
Total points: 42 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is hypnosis?is that true that we can achieve any goal by the process of hypnosis?



</question>



<answer from>



Magnun S
Member since: 24 April 2007
Total points: 874 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hypinosis is the domination of a being by another. You are able to dominate another person's brain to get an answer that the person wouldn't give if he/she had control of their brain.



</answer>



<answer from>



Macrocom...
Member since: 07 December 2007
Total points: 5677 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hypnosis is the process whereby a person who is semi-conscious is able to accept instructions from somebody else who is more awake. These instructions are likely to make an impression on the mind of the semi-sleeper so that he feels compelled to act on them in the specified circumstances and in the specified way.



You cannot be hypnotised to do something that in full awareness you would find to be harmful to yourself. Nor is it likely that any goal can be achieved, because many of them are impossible to reach in every case. People simply do not respond to hypnotic instructions to murder, for example.



</answer>



<answer from>



Shaman
Member since: 11 August 2006
Total points: 8638 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



Do not listen to Magnun....  Hypnosis is not anything like what he described.



Hypnosis is a state in which and a process by which a suggestion is accepted by the subconscious which can influence our thinking and behavior.  However, it is a completely voluntary acceptance by the subject.  You cannot be "hypnotized" into a trance without your consent.  You cannot be "dominated" into doing something against your character.



My new favorite book on the subject is entitled, "Monsters and Magical Sticks:  Or, There's No Such Thing As Hypnosis?" by Steven Heller.  Check it out if you're really interested in the topic.



</answer>

drheave

Shaman

Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



Here's the secret....  Are you ready?



Stop being greedy.



Greed for security, for control, will cause you to lose that which you desire.  His love.



See him as a blessing that has come into your life and be thankful for the gift of his love and friendship.  Stop looking at him as a possession that you must constantly hold onto so you don't lose it or a pet that you must train to behave in a manner that suits you.



When you can embrace this point of view, you will find greater satisfaction and less worry in the relationship.



Be well.



</answer>



<answer from>



tominhou...
Member since: 18 June 2008
Total points: 363 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Instead of trying to control him, control yourself.  Ask yourself the same questions.



You're reading a book, you're at a critical point in the story, would you want to stop and explain to him what you're doing.
You're having a true personal private girl heart to heart with one of YOUR friends, you're on the edge of a breakthrough,  do you want to stop and explain just because he wants to know.



You are two different people with two different lives.  As live your life and he lives his, SHARE your lives with one another to the extent that you may choose.  He doesn't owe you an detailed explination of the events in his life and you don't owe him one.



</answer>

<question from>



Tokio_Ho...
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 212 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How does the brain hold memory?



I heard because of something and something the thought like burns into the Hippocampus or something.



</question>



<answer from>



Dinkha D
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 29 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



God made you not Humen
ask your Jesus God then you know



</answer>



<answer from>



Macrocom...
Member since: 07 December 2007
Total points: 5681 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



The basis of memory is chemical change associated with electronic movement and charge. To burn in a memory is far too strong an expression for it. A well established memory is one that has been removed from the mind-store, reviewed and then put back intact in the store again. This process is in no way a burn-in.



</answer>

<answer from>



Holly K
Member since: 22 October 2006
Total points: 133 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



"Out of Sight out of Mind"
It depends what part of your daily life they are in.  If they are at work, change hours or departments.  take their number out of your phone.  Date someone else.  If they are in ur classes, take different classes next time.  The best thing i've alway done when i'm addicted to someone or somthing is to stop.. then fill the time u would spend doing it with somthin else.  Get your independence back. if you still want them in your life, make plans with them once a week, or every other thursday, or somthing like that.



Source(s):



psychology major. personal experience.



</answer>

<original file>17289.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk107517.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



freddypi...
Member since: 25 April 2008
Total points: 369 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What do these dreams mean?



Ok so my ex and i broke up like a month ago, and i have basically gotten over it. I dont think about her much at all and when i do its usually random and lasts a very short amount of time. The wierd thing is a dream about her almost every night. And the dreams are really random, sometimes will talk about getting back together, sometimes were still together, and like last nights sometimes we get in huge fights in which i will feel good about myself at the end. It is very frustrating waking up every morning with her on my mind, especially because i feel i have moved on and want to move on. Do these dreams mean anything, and if possible is there anyway to stop myself from having them?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Sorry to say this but you can't stop your dreams. They are what they are. Dream interpretation is not a science. You dream about your Ex because you have a history together. Your subconscious is bringing up good and bad feelings about the relationship. This is perfectly normal. Perhaps you've been dwelling on the breakup or maybe you're a bit obsessed with your Ex. Even though you say you're over your Ex, you may still harbor some feelings over the breakup. Perhaps you are still in love with your Ex. Perhaps you're angry at your Ex because of the break-up. Perhaps you're not sure how you feel about your Ex so you ponder about it quite often. It's hard to say why we dream. Sigmund Freud believed that our dreams are showing us in our subconscious world what we don't confront in our conscious world. Take a good look within yourself and be honest about your feelings.



Source(s):



www.sandrawestrope.mysite.com
Counseling Psychologist



</answer>




<original file>17290.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk107519.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



hdebross...
Member since: 28 May 2007
Total points: 1037 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Ideas on differences between Pessimism vs. Realism?



I have this discussion with my friends and my husband from time to time. I believe that realism is always peppered with pessimism. My husband thinks I am just being negative when I say I am just being a realist? What are your thoughts or definitions?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Realism is the act of reaching a conclusion based on facts and safe assumptions.



Pessimism is the act of reaching a negative conclusion regardless of facts and safe assumptions.



</answer>

<question>



What does my dream mean?



I was flying in a small airplane sitting on the left side.  My ex husband (Scott) who looks a lot like my current boyfriend was piloting the plane and sitting on the right side.  There was no cover on the cockpit.  Other planes were coming past us very close which was scary but in a fun way.  I was sitting uncomfortably with my legs hanging over the side but then sat back in the seat and felt more secure.  I noticed Scott sitting on the edge and then things not looking right and it became obvious we were going down.  We ended up landing softly in grass without getting hurt and I woke up.



</question>



<answer from>



canttuch...
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 45 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



nothing your probably just think to much about ur ex husband



</answer>



<answer from>



Hands resist Her
Member since: 02 June 2008
Total points: 1859 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



To see an airplane in your dream, indicates that you will overcome your obstacles and rise above to a new level of prominence and status. You may experience a higher consciousness, new-found freedom and greater awareness.



Your dream falls under the category of "flying dreams", in which however you are not flying under your own power. Such dreams are associated with a major change in your life, a rise in status or a transitional phase.



</answer>

Mike H

<answer>



You don't have to feel alone with this problem it is shared by many. I think it starts when we are small and we don't have the success we see others having at, for instance, baseball or subjects in school. We might have something that we don't like about our looks. My ears are too big or I hate having freckles. We all know how cruel kids can be to each other. When we are wounded psychologically  it takes time to heal. We may not get the positive support that we need from our family or teachers. We start to believe the negative things that we or others are  imprinting on our mind. Sometimes we carry the feelings of inferiority into our adult years. Some people never get over them. The best thing to do is to find someone you trust and talk these feelings out. Usually by doing this we can get to the root of the problem see how unreasonable we are being to ourselves and move on with our lives. We need to realize that no one is perfect. We all have strengths and weaknesses. Try to focus on your strengths. Forgive others for the wrongs they did to you. Forgive yourself.
Enjoy your life!

<answer from>



agrona
Member since: 14 October 2008
Total points: 123 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



We define what is funny by what we hear and listen to and by what we see. Some things can be funny to one person and other things are not funny. Everyone has an individual sense of humour, yes? For example, my 5 year-old son has a toilet sense of humour at the moment and thinks that farting in his class is really funny. He even has burping contests with his class-mates!
On the other hand, my 16-year old can´t see the funny side of anything except when he´s with his mates. Mum just can´t understand him! So he says!



And me? Yeah, sometimes I laugh. But it takes a lot to make me laugh these days.



</answer>



<answer from>



Cynthia LY
Member since: 04 April 2008
Total points: 29139 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Homework Help



Words & Wordplay



Quotations



</answer from>



<answer>



Most laughter is not about something being funny.  Laughter is something we humans do as part of bonding with other people, (relatives, friends, etc.)  It's a way of communicating.  For example, when you ask a friend how he did on a test and he responds with a laugh, or you ask someone you know how they've been and they laugh - that's not a joke.  We tend to use it as a form of verbal puncuation.



Curious thing is, apes do it too, except their "laughter" is a type of panting.  They have the same laugh reaction when playing and interacting with each other as we humans do. Other animals have their own sounds of laughter too, and for the same reason.



Another reason we laugh is because we hear other people laugh.  Laughing is contagious and involves multiple parts of our body.



We do most of our laughing when we are around other people vs by ourselves.  And laughter is definately triggered by our brain.  Genuine, hardy har-har, and ha-ha-ha-feel it in the gut laughter is not something you can force or control.  You can try to stop laughing, but you cannot control when genuine laughter starts.



And - you do laugh when your brain reacts to something as being funny.  What is funny to some isn't funny to all.



Very interesting reading about why we laugh here:
http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/3077386/



</answer>



<answer from>



steve
Member since: 18 January 2008
Total points: 11254 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



no we laugh besause we find it funny



</answer>

<question>



How can i get over the Wimbledon final this year?



ive been devastated by it ever since it happened. sometimes i cant sleep because of it. i had so much emotionally invested in Federer breaking the record for consecutive titles. ever since 2005 when he got his 3rd straight i was thinking about 6 in a row. the worst part is that he was so maddeningly close to it. he pushed it to a 5th set and had a break point to go to 5-3. then at 7-7 he was broken by a bad line call. which he didn't challenge.  it could have been the quintessential fairytale comeback. but stopped heart breakingly close. and now even when i try to be optimistic and think about him getting revenge next year, im going to think how this could have been his 7th straight if he'd just played 1 point differently i 2008. i know it's really unhealthy and i want to get over it, its been months, what's wrong with me?



</question>



<answer from>



singlegr...
Member since: 12 August 2007
Total points: 893 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Imagine yourself sitting in a chair, in an imaginary plastic bubble, place a stick of dynomite in your hand and push it thru the plastic bubble.  Invision the match and stuff it into the stick of dynomite, light the stick throw it into the air and watch it explode.  Sounds crazy but to rid yourself of a thought that won't go away...you have to blow it up!



Good luck!



Source(s):



This truly works for me...



</answer>



<answer from>



active open programming
Member since: 10 May 2007
Total points: 9083 (Level 5)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>

It is common for many sports enthusiasts to think about their favorite stars, but at least there isn't any true tragedy in losing the tournament as far as biological well-being goes. If you are feeling unwell on a consistent basis due to the results of the tournament then you might want to talk to your physician about solutions.

<question from>



Melanie
Member since: 08 November 2006
Total points: 977 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Shy and escaping boredom?



One of your friends is very shy and quiet young woman in her late 20's.  She usually keeps to herself but is a diligent and hard worker.  You don't know much about her though.  You were at a boring meeting and you glanced over and saw her doodling.  Then she started to play games like tick-tack-toe and hangman.  She then started to draw dots and apparently it became a game where you had to make boxes.  Only one other person around you decided to play along with her.



What would you think about this shy woman's methods of escaping boredom?  What would you conclude about her?



</question>



<answer from>



Ertai2
Member since: 08 April 2006
Total points: 1786 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Very interesting question. This is one that will make you think ...



My point of view ... because this is a psychology question and I am against psychology in all means as one can not understand the human mind as if we could, Im sure some mad scientist would find a way to control us all. Thank God for that. Although psychology does have some pinpointers to the simple minds ;)



My views of this lady would be ...



1) She is a free spirit. Likes to express herself in certain ways such to keep her mind occupied. Its more of a ways to nurture herself.
2) She may not take her job seriously. This is the obvious but if she was hired in the first place then she had to have some resume to convince the employer. So you can not discredit her.
3) she likes playing hang man and competes in tournaments world wide so she is spending this time at work to train herself =)



... personally I think she is introvert. Opposed to communicating with the rest of the group she prefers keeping herself solitude. This is not a bad thing by all means. Communication, learning and understanding the present material at work is required by the job but if she feels happy doing what she is doing then let her be. As long as she can complete the work assignment then that is all that is needed to be understood. If this work assignment is NOT completed to a certain standard THEN she can be discredited by her workplace as to paying more attention to herself rather than the work she was employed to do.



... the point is do not pre judge an individual. Let her be. If she does not complete her work assignments then you have proof to judge her behavior. This proof in return however, can have a logical excuse. Which is why you shouldnt pre judge.



... it would be best to focus on yourself and your work at hand rather than somebody else, as they will be judged by the employer who will have a better understanding. Basically, dont matter much about them unless its a real problem, like disturbing your own work HABITS, etc.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thank u



</asker's comment>

<original file>18876.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk109280.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



coffeefr...
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Can somebody please explain the Id, ego, and super ego?



I want to know as much as possible about this subject, i dont know what they are really, and i am looking for somebody to explain them indepth.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



According to Freud, we are born with our Id.  The id is an important part of our personality because as newborns, it allows us to get our basic needs met.  Freud believed that the id is based on our pleasure principle.  In other words, the id wants whatever feels good at the time, with no consideration for the reality of the situation.  When a child is hungry, the id wants food, and therefore the child cries.  When the child needs to be changed, the id cries.  When the child is uncomfortable, in pain, too hot, too cold, or just wants attention, the id speaks up until his or her needs are met.



The id doesn't care about reality, about the needs of anyone else, only its own satisfaction.



Within the next three years, as the child interacts more and more with the world, the second part of the personality begins to develop.  Freud called this part the Ego.  The ego is based on the reality principle.  The ego understands that other people have needs and desires and that sometimes being impulsive or selfish can hurt us in the long run.  Its the ego's job to meet the needs of the id, while taking into consideration the reality of the situation.



By the age of five, or the end of the phallic stage of development, the Superego develops.  The Superego is the moral part of us and develops due to the moral and ethical restraints placed on us by our caregivers.  Many equate the superego with the conscience as it dictates our belief of right and wrong.



</answer>

I've been wondering that I can personally recall my childhood days but some of it were just episodes or like that!! If I was not misinformed or something... I can see myself standing as I recall my past.. I see myself that I was doing something like that.. Another case or impression that I see is that I just see it with my own two eyes!! I can remember a certain picture of my life which is not eventful to me.. only a yellow wall with stairs and I met a kid who I knew years later would be my cousin.. I think I was three years old at that time since the next year I remembered that I asked his age that he was 3 and he asked me too, I was four.. we were one year gapped!! There are really things I remembered when I was a kid starting at 3 but not clearly and until the rest of those childhood days!!

it was white color cub and i was playing with it.

<answer>



First off, it is completely natural!  Don't ignore your emotions because they are what guide us and tell us how we feel.  I cry when something gets really confrontational and I feel threatened or angry.



Now, in order to help:  You have to focus on prevailing when you are in a situation like this.  Focus on what you want and don't let anybody step all over you.  You probably are simply getting frustrated with whatever the other person is saying.  Just stay strong and do your best to be yourself!



Also, if you're at an age when your hormones are all out of whack, this could be to blame.  Hormones have a huge effect on our emotions.  So, if this is the case, it will all pass.

<question>



I think I majored in the wrong thing for my life goals, and it's too late to change now. What are my options?



I'm a college student majoring in Fisheries and Wildlife Science, and even though the subject matter is perfect for me, the potential job locations aren't. I have this feeling I can't ignore, that I want to move to Minneapolis, MN after college. I love that city, always have, and I don't feel like my life is complete living anywhere else, not to sound cheesy, but honestly. Have I completely effed up my chances? I'm far too late along in my college career to change now. Please tell me there's something in a metro area for a major like mine... could I be an agriculture teacher, work in the DNR office there, anything? Please give me some ideas, or tell me if I've completely blown my dreams. Thanks.



P.S. Would going back to school (grad school) in a different area be possible? I was thinking of going to get a M.S. in geography to work in scientific mapmaking... or would I also need the undergraduate in geo.



Sorry, I know wrong section, but the psych people always have the best answers.



</question>



<answer from>



Dr. Bob
Member since: 23 January 2008
Total points: 19533 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



I see no reason why you could not seek a masters degree in something other than your college bachelors degree. People do it all the time. The questions are whether you can find the school and program you like, whether you can get accepted, whether you can afford it...and assuming that, have enough background in the subject to start the degree. Regarding the last, you may have to take one or two undergraduate classes in the subject, which you could "short-circuit" a it by taking such classes now.



And yes, Minneapolis is a nice town. I have several relatives who live or lived there, I think the Walker Art Institute is GREAT, Minnehaha Falls is pretty, and of course the U of Minn. is a terrific school. I lived a few years (as a young child) in Thief River Falls ('way up north, and cold!), moved to a small town for a year in Wisconsin (Baron), then moved (4th grade) to another small town in North Dakota (Valley City), where I lived until I came to Boston for grad school.



So I know the cold winters (30 below!), the snow, the HOT summers, the lakes (makes relatives in Pelican Rapids, fergus Falls, etc.). And I miss it all, even after having lived in New England for 50 years.



Best wishes...I hope you get what you want ! ! ! !



-- Dr. Bob



</answer>

<answer from>



J.
Member since: 21 March 2008
Total points: 13984 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



Depends on the type of terrorist. They obviously don't think of themselves as bad people. And they probably think of themselves as soilders. They probably have the same mindset as any fanatic prepared to die for a cause. And from some terrorists points of view, they might feel justified (look at it from their understanding, which may well be flawed. They see our army in their country killing their people (and no, that is not the objective facts of the case, but it's what they see) and they want retribution. That's one example.) So basically, you have to look at their motivation to understand their behavoiur.



And it's important not to let bias cloud your understanding. Just because you find the act heinous or terrible, does not mean it stems from unpleasant charictoristics like cowardice. Terrorists are not cowardly. Cowardly terrorists would be much easier to deal with, in fact. This is like the myth that bullies are cowards or weak or that they hate themselves - it's a nice story, but not necessarily true.



There are various theories, as outlined in the source below:
frustration-agression model (lack of movement or satisfaction in political or social spheres causes people to act out against their perceived oppressors)
Narcissistic rage (which takes the viewpoint terrorists are mentally ill, not a viewpoint held by all. It's probably wrong to assume every extreme behavoir stems from psychological disturbance.



Source(s):



The below is a reliable source and overview, and the psychological discussion of terrorism appears to start on page 27, you can probably jump right there without bothering with the earlier bits if you wanted. It gives sources if you want to follow things up.



http://www.futurebrief.com/Soc_Psych_of_...



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Dad, Bob G. Jordan molested me, now my mom is injured, what do I owe her?



when I was young I told my mom about getting physically and sexually abused by my father, but she never listened to me or did anything to keep me safe.  (Once my mom had caught him molesting me with a knife, and he lied about what was happening. It was the only way he could defend his behavior -she believed him!!!!)



As an adult I have been shunned by my family because they made me out as the scapegoat, which is painful, but OK. It is better for me to avoid them then getting all of their hate and blame heaped upon me. I don't see or talk to anyone in my family, my mom emails me a few times a year, and I inform her every time that the reason why we aren't close is because she has blamed me for "tearing the family apart" and though she demands forgiveness from me, she has never apologized or tried to give me restitution. She is still married to my dad, and pretends like everything was OK, except for me.



I never took illegal drugs and alcohol like many survivors do, and I have not gotten the help from my parents that my brothers and sisters got because I didn't go along with the abuse and accept that it was my fault. And I have turned out to be a pretty decent person as well, despite my parents and family.



Then my mom broke her leg and hip, she's in her 70's I feel so sad for her, and wrote her immediately to show her my support.  In the past, I have been sick many times and told my mom about  my intense stomach problems, she hasn't even offered to bring over soup. Although one time she did take me to the ER, and I am grateful for that.



There is a big part of me that wants to mother my mom. I think I am obligated to do something, send her a box of chocolates or something. How do I separate between my feeling of obligation, or if this is something I want to do?



I do wonder what do I owe her?



If you feel inclined to just blame me for not 'forgiving' her and my father then know that she and my father have never asked me to forgive them, in fact they dismiss that I was abused. Don't bother writing me if you want to blame the victim and tell me I need to forgive and forget.



</question>



<additional details>



I should say that I went into the foster care system later, that and therapy did help me a lot.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Keith C
Member since: 02 May 2007
Total points: 252 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

I respect my grandmother because she is my grandmother and don't really care about her since she took our home away, years ago.  I know it pales in comparison to your sad story and I'm sorry this happened to you - like it happens to so many people.



In this case, I believe you have the right to ignore her totaly if you want.  Otherwise I'd simply give her a get well card if you feel inclined and then ignore it.  If you feel you shouldn't HAVE to, then dont!  You'll end up hating that you did that.  And it seems the whole coals of fire idea in being a nice to those whom are asses to you won't work here.
