</answer>



<answer from>



I voted for Obama and Biden!
Member since: 20 April 2008
Total points: 1516 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Forgiveness?
Jean Rosenfeld, LCSW



“I’m having a really hard time forgiving my father, she proclaimed in her first session.  “I know I should forgive him.  I heard it on Oprah and I read it in a magazine - forgiving is something you do for yourself.  I don’t know why I can’t forgive him!”



I’ve been hearing this more and more in my office.  Why should she forgive him when he hurt her and the harm continues in her depression, anxiety and poor relationships?  He has no empathy or understanding of how he hurt her; he feels no remorse; he’s never apologized; he’s never tried to make amends.  And, added to her pain and confusion is now the guilt that she cannot seem to find it in herself to forgive him.



I wonder, what this “forgiveness” might mean for her – perhaps an enormous act of suppression that may give her a brief respite of relief?  Or perhaps it would become twisted into self-blame, to which so many victims of abuse readily turn.



Forgiveness can be psychologically dangerous, further enshrining a passive stance that may take away the empowerment that comes with understanding that others shouldn’t take advantage of her. Forgiveness may leave the victim unprotected from the next person who may hurt her in the same way.  Too quick “forgiveness” is a defense against doing the therapeutic work.



So, this client and I begin a multi-faceted therapeutic journey.  She tells her story, starts to shed her secrets and shame, learns to have empathy for herself, undergoes a difficult period of mourning significant losses, begins to own and tolerate a vast array of feelings, and comes to understand that now is not then and that she has more choices and power.  She becomes skilled in self-soothing and reframing negative self-talk, she practices handling relationships differently – and she even begins to understand how her father’s family history could have influenced his behavior.  As therapy moves along her rage at him greatly lessens; she no longer obsesses about what happened; and she moves on in her life, focusing more on the present and future.  But she hasn’t forgiven.



Of course, true forgiveness can occur, but it comes out of an interaction between two people:  The one who harms expresses genuine remorse, sadness and guilt that s/he has caused the other pain.  S/he accepts the other’s pace and boundaries of addressing the issue. Without making excuses or blaming others s/he listens with empathy to the negative effects that s/he has caused. S/he may offer to correct the situation, make restitution, or aid in a reasonable way to ameliorate the situation.  And s/he promises to make a strong, genuine effort to behave differently in the future.  Then, perhaps, the one who is hurt may truly feel forgiveness.  In couples and family therapy we frequently help our clients engage in this process.  Programs that re-unite sex offenders with their children, 12-Step Groups, and the Restorative Justice Program that helps convicted criminals and their victims encounter each other, are examples of formalized programs that incorporate these concepts.
But what shall we call that other experience that our clients want – that sense of  relief from being exhausted and trapped by rage and obsession with the other person?  What is the word to use that expresses the feeling that comes with going through the process in which one person (without necessitating the input of the other) finds resolution and feels more freedom to positively engage in life?  Terms like “letting go” and “moving on” do not convey the depth and healing embodied in this experience. And it has little to do with “forgiveness.”



Jean Rosenfeld, LCSW, BCD has been in private practice in Carmichael for over 20 years, treating adults individually and in couples therapy.  She is the managing editor of The Clinical Update.



</answer>

<question>



Does being good looking really help you gain success? Is there research on this?



I am blonde, thin and busty naturally. Recently a friend of mine (who is always complaining she is ugly) claimed that if she looked like me she'd be a lot more successful. She is always making comments like "Oh yeah, that's easy when you look the way YOU do!" and stuff like that. It's almost like she tries to downplay everything I do and chalk it upto me being good looking!



We are about equal as far as financial status goes and the comment kind of pissed me off, honestly. It was almost as if she was implying that I don't have to work as hard or that I am not trying hard enough and 'using' my looks to my advantage! She says things like this a lot.



She is always commenting that I am 'lucky' in the looks department and seems to put a lot of emphasis on this. Truly, I have my good points genetically but A LOT of my appearance is maintanance. I work hard to go to the gym, take care of my skin, get my hair done regularly, wear cute clothes, eat healthy etc. She could look as good as me if she made the effort but she doesn't! We make the same amount of money and yet she seems to think I have some huge advantage.



I also work hard on the job. I have worked very hard to be the person I am and I really resent her suggesting that I somehow got a 'free ride' because I happen to be born with genes people find pleasing and I do a lot to highlight this. I personally can't see how it gives me so many advantages. I still have to work hard like everyone else.



Do good looking people really make more money? Get better jobs? Are they really happier people in life? Is there any research to support this? If so is it really a major advantage in life? Or is my friend just suffering from 'Grass is greener' syndome?



</question>

<question>

<answer from>



Mark T
Member since: 29 November 2006
Total points: 11047 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, I work in a pretty technical field so you have to have a certain level of adaptability and "fitness" to work in my field.



That said, I read ALOT, mostly I avoid fiction, and stick to history, anthropology and lately economics and geopolitical stuff, but its largely a function of what is going on in my life.



Otherwise, I find I'm doing alot of remedial stuff to keep fit.



That means while I had advanced forms of calculus, linear algebra and such I have forgotten much of it, and have had to start over again with very simple stuff. In this way it's definitely a use it or loose it proposition.



Physical exersize is also wonderful for keeping sharp, it tends to get the blood flowing and get thing unclogged and uncluttered.

<answer from>



AL R
Member since: 14 June 2007
Total points: 13786 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



The first two will help the brain by assuring sufficient nutrients and oxygen. You can keep yourself mentally fit by exercising the brain through game play and puzzle solving.



</answer>

<question>



Is America turning into the land of the lost and hopeless? Fear, loathing and cyncism in America?



This country is just turning bad.  People are fearful, distrustful of one another, secretly and some outwardly loathe one another, are cynical about life, about themselves, about EVERYTHING, and so many people are just lost and hopeless.



Our land is turning into some....has-been, post-apocalyptic, weird place where people aren't even acting human anymore, but like they're some hurting war veterans, hurting mentally and spiritually for the most part.



I know this is a totally cynical take on it but, that's because I read between the lines, I see things for how they REALLY are.



Most of you just continue to lead your lives without even looking/disecting society at all and putting it under a microscope. That's fine I guess if you want to lead your lives in total ignorance but,



the America I see through my microscope is not a good one, and it paints a very black picture of how humans really are.



Selfish, greedy, want power/control, all sorts of things.



I know America hasn't always been like this, but nowadays I can't even go out and drive a nice car and feel good about my life because there are always others out there who want to ruin that.



It's disguisting.



</question>



<additional details>



Now you're probably thinking, okay this is totally left-field, or just too vague/negative....it can't be right. Oh, but it really is.  Even if I were to get detailed, and talk about the complications of it all...right down to the very last bit,....it's not that good, I'll tell you that much.



</additional details>

<answer>



You may be right about all the negative things you see. What you are wrong in is assuming they are in any way new or original... even to the degree you see them today. America, along with most other major countries, has always been like this. And worse, in fact. However cynical you find them now, they are not officially allowed to keep slaves anymore, for example. The class systems are rapidly decreasing. No, it's not perfect, but neither was the past, dispite how nostalgics like to describe it. People forget the negative things much easier than the positive.



</answer>

Certain people will always remain ignorant, fearful and loathing. These are people who cannot rise above their lesser instincts, but I don't think that all people are like this. What you are seeing is a self-fulfilling prophecy: you're looking for the lesser and (wow) you're finding it. There is a mixture of qualities in all of us. All of us have the ability to hate, it's how we choose to act upon this that defines us as people.



Man will never understand the true nature of God, and as long as man continues to dwell on this, he will never truly understand himself.

<answer>



What would cause such a loathing. A fear for the economy, and losing the things which bring us comfort. Imagine a society of capitalists where the supplies were scarce. If that isn't an issue of concern then I don't know what is. <question from>



murderxr...

</question from>



<question>



How can i stop myself becoming depressed again ?



About half a year ago, i was depressed (atleat i think i was depressed) for about 4 months, i'm starting to feel the same as i did before, how can i stop myself from becoming like that again?



</question>



<answer from>



Tripathi
Member since: 18 October 2008
Total points: 193 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



it is state of mind not the situation... if you keep thinking of depression you will shourly land up in that.... think positive.... when ever you are alone and negative thoughts are around you.... do somthing different which you like .... loke games..... you should believe in yourself or else why people will believe of you....



</answer>



<answer from>



omni
Member since: 07 July 2007
Total points: 1624 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, you have the experience of that depressive episode to catch the signs that you're prone to them again in the future. There is situational depression, and there is chronic depression - age and life circumstances are huge contributing factors to this...for example, people in their twenties often report the highest cases of depression. It's often a bi-product of age. In answer to your question - how do you stop yourself from becoming like that again -- increase your physical activity, eat well, get proper sleep, write in a journal, increase social activities, etc.



</answer>

<answer from>



Shannon
Member since: 27 October 2007
Total points: 340 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



To put it simply, I live for the hope of tomorrow -- that tomorrow might have something extraordinary in store that I could never have foreseen.



To put it more specifically:



1. I live that I might one day graduate college and be able to start doing what I love: practicing archaeology and studying ancient Egypt.



2. I live so that I can someday travel and see all the wonders this world has to offer.



3. I live because my friends and family want me to live. They've done so much for me; the least I can do for them is stay alive.



4. I live for love. It may be fleeting sometimes, and it may always be painful; but it's still worth it, every time.



5. I live for knowledge. I love learning. Who knows if I'll learn something tomorrow that changes my outlook on life? It's happened before.



There are plenty more reasons to live, and if you sit down and plot them out, you'll realize it for yourself too. Try taking a trip somewhere; change your scenery a bit, stir things up. It always helps me feel refreshed and eager to face whatever comes next!



</answer>

<answer>



I was feeling the same way for years. What I did was find the good and beauty in all the little things. I also started listening to upbeat, uplifting music more often. I didn't let small problems get to me and as I learned I started handling bigger and bigger problems with more and more ease. That makes you feel pretty good, makes you worry a lot less. If you're open to all of the positive that life has to offer I'm sure great things, and people will come into your life.



And about school.. maybe you should take a roadtrip and let loose. As you explore other places as well as yourself while you're alone, you'll find things that you really love and enjoy, which can help you find a better, more fulfilling subject to get into.

<answer from>



jupudi
Member since: 08 January 2006
Total points: 1712 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Each day your life starts with a blank slate.



What happened yesterday is over and everything you are faced with is new and unknown.



Who is in charge of the future before you? You and only you.



How will you CHOOSE to create this new day?



How will you CHOOSE to react to the circumstances that come your way?



Will you CHOOSE peace or drama, happiness or anger, success or failure, love or hate? All the choices are yours to make.



How often do you react to a situation unconsciously or by allowing your ego to dictate the appropriate reaction as a result of someone else controlling your feelings and emotions. What would happen if you and only you control your feelings and emotions and you can determine yourself how you want to feel and how you want to react to any situation. Would your life be lighter, happier, more peaceful.



You can in fact consciously decide in any minute how you CHOOSE to think, react, feel about anything happening in your life. When you feel yourself beginning to react, stop yourself and breathe, then take a moment and determine how you CHOOSE to react for your own better good.



Maybe you decide not to take something personally. Maybe you decide to come down a notch and communicate at a more controlled level. Maybe you just choose peace and let it go.



So don't be short sighted with yourself or others.



Try to open your mind to new possibilities.



Relax, breathe and allow your imagination to move outside your conditioned self.



Each day is a new day in your life, live the life you CHOOSE



</answer>



<answer from>



Nice Planet- I'll Take It
Member since: 02 June 2006
Total points: 17345 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



you are right about not needing another person. For years, I beat myself up about not being able to keep a happy relationship, and never being able to find the "right" one. Well now I know I am happier to live alone, and work on my own projects, without someone whining about everything, and putting the blame on me for them not being happy. Now i live for Working on my house, and making the yard nice, and playing my music and trying to be more creative.



I am learning new things about gardening and relearning and reviving old methods of living, like canning, and making my own soap, and brewing beer, etc. I just want to be able to take care of myself, without relying on other people, because there always seems to be a high price for accepting help from someone. I have brains enough to invent someway to do it myself, rather than ask someone to help me. Being a little lonely is a lot better than living with someone going out of their way to make me miserable. So, I guess I live for learning to be self-reliant.



</answer>

<answer from>



Kelly S
Member since: 13 April 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



If you feel like crying (even if you cannot) over something which is in the past, it means you have not dealt with it.
It will keep coming up and hurting you until you deal with it.
You may not even realize what it is that lies in your past.
I would strongly suggest you speak to a therapist.  By speaking about your childhood and your life in a private and secure environment, you will be opening up the wound and then it can be treated.
Please don't hesitate.  It works.



</answer>

<answer>



as an acting major, this is something I pay 6,000 dollars a year to correct lol.



this is really common for me during performance. physically, my body is holding somewhere (i.e muscle tension) and it subconsciously protects myself from being vulnerable.



what I always do is go to a safe place for you where you can be by yourself or with someone you trust completely, and watch a sad movie. take notice to how your body responds during emotional stress and the muscles that tense. for me I always lock up in my shoulders and my abdominal muscles, and when this happens, I actively think about keeping them relaxed and released. and, the most important thing is to keep breathing. have you ever noticed that when you feel you are about to cry youhold your breath? the breath lets the emotion evolve. a buddhist belief is that the holding of breath is the unwilling to budge, and the act of digging your heels in and refusing to evolve with the universe is a great detriment to the mind and spirit. if you can't let an emotion evolve after 16 breaths, that feeling will stay with you forever.



I know how you feel, and sometimes it's hard, even terrifying, to allow yourself to be so exposed. I promise you'll feel a million times better if you try any of these techniques.

<question>



What does it mean when you get deja vu?



I never had de ja vu until I was 16. Now I am 19  get it all the time.



What does it mean?



</question>



<answer from>



active open programming
Member since: 10 May 2007
Total points: 9134 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



In my opinion, deja vu is more probable in more mature people because more mature minds have a larger attention span, and an attention span is required for anticipation. A person might anticipate a number of scenarios and when they finally do occur(if they do) then the sense of deja vu is similar to a preparation for the likely occurence of the event. Your attention span is increasing.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thats believable.
And no mike im not drunk tonight lol.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



ko
Member since: 10 October 2008
Total points: 438 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Deja vu or to see again means that you believe that you have seen or heard something before which you actually never have. It is because your neurons fire twice in response to a certain stimuli. Since your neurons fire twice, your brain reads it twice. So you think you saw something before but you really hadn't, it was just a tiny malfunction with your neurons and your brain. It could also be because you have been in a situation which is similar to the one that you experienced "deja vu" in. Your mind remembers the past experience subconsciously and you experience hind sight bias or when you think you experienced something you had not.



Source(s):



Couple psychology classes



</answer>



<answer from>



RKH
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are three explanations for deja vu:



1. Parapsychology



Déjà vu is associated with precognition, clairvoyance or extra-sensory perceptions, and it is frequently cited as evidence for "psychic" abilities in the general population. Non-scientific explanations attribute the experience to prophecy, visions (such as received in dreams) or past-life memories.



2. Dreams



Some believe déjà vu is the memory of dreams. Though the majority of dreams are never remembered, a dreaming person can display activity in the areas of the brain that process long-term memory. It has been speculated that dreams read directly into long-term memory, bypassing short-term memory entirely. In this case, déjà vu might be a memory of a forgotten dream with elements in common with the current waking experience. This may be similar to another phenomenon known as déjà rêvé, or "already dreamed." However, later studies on mice indicate that long-term memories must be first established as short-term memories.



Kevin Heady suggested that a feeling of remembering occurs in a sense that he might realize that what he had dreamed is now a relevant present action that is taking place right here right now.



"I was once sitting down in the kitchen noticing that my plate seemed well too familiar, it seemed as if my head motions were foreseen, and that every move would trigger a continuation to happen or so, I had many déjà vus as a child but this was extraordinary, I knew from the bottom of my heart that I had dreamed this situation years ago, as a little boy, that amazingly an entire piece of memory was regained and I finally understood when and where I was dreaming and how long this dream was, and most importantly how many years ago did I dream." -John Lennon



3. Reincarnation



Those believing in reincarnation theorize that déjà vu is caused by fragments of past-life memories being jarred to the surface of the mind by familiar surroundings or people. Others theorize that the phenomenon is caused by astral projection, or out-of-body experiences (OBEs), where it is possible that individuals have visited places while in their astral bodies during sleep. The sensation may also be interpreted as connected to the fulfillment of a condition as seen or felt in a premonition. For further cases of remembering information from past lives, see Ian Stevenson.



Source(s):



Wikipedia



</answer>



<answer from>



JD
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 168 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Deja Vu is the experience of feeling sure that one has witnessed or experienced a new situation previously (an individual feels as though an event has already happened or has happened in the near past). The term was coined by a French psychic researcher, Émile Boirac (1851–1917) in his book "L'Avenir des sciences psychiques" ("The Future of Psychic Sciences"), which expanded upon an essay he wrote while an undergraduate. The experience of déjà vu is usually accompanied by a compelling sense of familiarity, and also a sense of "eeriness," "strangeness," or "weirdness," The "previous" experience is most frequently attributed to a dream, although in some cases there is a firm sense that the experience "genuinely happened" in the past.



Source(s):



Wiki



</answer>



<answer from>



Elise L
Member since: 11 June 2008
Total points: 941 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Deja Vu, when translated means 'already seen'. It's when you see/hear/experience something that you know has happened before. It's like a memory is happening all over again, even though you know it couldn't have happened before.

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



Intimacy or Lust



?



According to Sullivan what is lust? Why is it that individuals involved in relationship often confuse lust and intimacy?Be cognizant of the general well-being of a person, i.e. physiological and interpersonal.



</question>



<answer from>



longstem...
Member since: 18 August 2008
Total points: 255 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



wikipedia says that lust is a heightened state of sexual desire or arousal. intimacy can be physical, emotional or spiritual. Physical intimacy and lust can go  hand in hand if your sexually aroused. But, if your still can be Intimate with someone your deeply in love with because you want that person to feel the same intimacy that you feel. Lust is more selfish, whereas love is more giving.



</answer>



<answer from>



jupudi
Member since: 08 January 2006
Total points: 1720 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The relationship rules influence how you and your partner relate to one another: how emotions are expressed, the way in which needs are communicated, how family and friends are dealt with and how intimacy is expressed.



Ideally, you and your partner will openly communicate and negotiate the different rules that are important to each of you. But this isn't always the case: Couples are often guided by powerful rules that remain unspoken. Because you learned many of these rules as a child, you may not even be aware of the impact of your relationship rules.



There may be times when your relationship proceeds smoothly under the influence of the unspoken rules that guide you and your partner--this is usually the case when your rules do not conflict with your partner's rules. But when these rules remain unspoken, your relationship or marriage becomes a game of chance. Becoming mindful of these hidden, powerful rules will increase the control you and your partner have in strengthening your relationship.



</answer>

<question from>



Melissar...

</question from>



<question>



I'm really scared of the paranormal?



and I would like some advice on overcoming, or at least alleviating my fear. I'm terrified of the dark. Every night I have to sleep with two lights and my TV on. I'll sleep on my back with my head turned to the side so one ear is covered by a pillow, then I cover the other ear with a blanket. If I'm having a bad night sometimes I'll even sleep with my main light on. I turn almost all the lights on in my house if I'm moving around at night, and I'm constantly looking around for things behind me or near me. I'm scared to be home alone because I think every noise is something that's going to come attack me. I've never had any paranormal experiences, and I hope I never do, but I'm still scared of what might be there.



After I finish my undergraduate studies, I'm moving away from my family to go to another school, and my partner won't be able to come with me for year after that. I don't know how I'm going to manage alone, or with a roommate who probably won't want me to cling to them all the time. The only time I feel safe at night is when I'm in my boyfriend's arms.



Please, I don't want to hear any paranormal stories. It gives me the creeps just to hear them. I just want to find a way to get over my fear and not be a bother to other people.



</question>



<answer from>



active open programming
Member since: 10 May 2007
Total points: 9134 (Level 5)

Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer>

<answer from>



drivn2ex...
Member since: 11 March 2006
Total points: 3896 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The mind can be a wasteland of thoughts, memories, and fantasies.  Sometimes the fears we have actually stem from some type of memory of a past experience.  What type of TV shows do you watch, books do you read, video games you play, or conversations do you have with your close friends?  Something on the outside of you is feeding that fear and your mind is having a field day with it.  Ever hear of the saying "Mind over Matter?"  Well in your case it might take a few mind exercises to retrain your brain to accept your reality over those fantastic thoughts you have of the paranormal.  You say that you have never had a paranormal experience but somehow you haven't really accepted that as pure truth for you.  If you purely accept that you have never seen or experienced anything paranormal, then you will be able to fortify your real state of mind on a premise of "No paranormal experience = no basis for paranormal fear."  You could tell yourself that your fear of the paranormal doesn't have a leg to stand on, not even in theory.  Every night take a look around your room with the lights on and say to yourself what you see.  Then turn the lights of and repeat what you saw.  Then turn the lights back on to affirm what you said.  Then turn the lights off and try to lie in your bed affirming that truth over and over.  Do this every night until you are able to lie in the bed with the lights off until you go to sleep.  It will take some time because you have to accept the truth (no paranormal experience = no basis for paranormal fear) and believe it without doubt.  Once you are able to do that you should be able to turn the lights off, knowing what and where everything is in the room, know that none of it is paranormal, and finally sleep with the lights off.  I only add that this truth must be practiced all through out your day and believed to the full!  I hope this helps.



</answer>

☆ShiNe☆

<question>



Do dreams come true? or do have dreams to let us know what is going to happen on the future?



Has anyone experienced a dream come to reality? if so can you tell it to me?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



dreams are just our subconscious working things out for the day. Even our experiences from the past can be triggered by what we see during the day. If we can't handle it, then we dram about it, so we can deal with it somehow. dreams don't necessarily mean it will come true. It's our own problems, desires, plans, ambitions being worked out so we can deal with the next day.



</answer>

<answer>



It's natural - just as men have the urge for sex, women have the urge for babies (that's how we come together, after all!) It's peaking now because you're in your prime reproductive years, and it will peak again in your thirties, because your time is running out. It's your biological clock you can hear ticking. Why not make a plan to have a baby in your twenties and work towards getting your life in such a shape that it can happen? I find that helps. It's an odd taboo these days for a woman to say her body is crying out for a baby, but rest assured, it's natural and you're normal. Good luck!



</answer>

<question>



Have you ever been really depressed?



Today, I feel really depressed and pathetic. I'm 19, and I feel like I'm going nowhere in life. Everything that I do seems to fall short of other peoples expectations, mainly to the ones that I love. When I'm feeling good, there's always someone or something that makes me feel worthless. Has anyone ever experienced this?



</question>



<additional details>



And yes, people have told me before "Just do what makes you happy, it doesn't matter what others think", but in reality, it does matter what other people think. What others think determines your life, basically. If someone doesn't like me (For any number of reasons) they could not hire me for a job, attempt to make my life harder, etc.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Emily R
Member since: 22 April 2007
Total points: 246 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, it is very true that it matters what other people think, but only certain people matter. You're probably just going through a random phase or if a recent change has occurred you could be suffering from that. <answer from>



eeege
Member since: 19 January 2008
Total points: 1658 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



Actually, what you're feeling is very normal.  According to Erikson's theory, people in their late teens to early twenties are trying to figure out who they are and what they are doing.



You'll probably spend some time in introspection and use that time to work out what you want in life and how you can make it match up with who you are.  Don't get worked up over missed marks and keep your eye on the long term goal.



No one can make you feel worthless unless you let them.  Their problems are about them, not about you.



I hope this helps.  Good luck!



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erikson%27s...



</answer>

<original file>23121.html</original file>

<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



ashnasax...
Member since: 18 October 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is a real life example of conditioned suppression?



what is a real life scenario where the psychology concept of conditioned suppression is operative in affecting behavior. also, how do you figure calculate the level of suppression?



</question>



<answer from>



psyc210
Member since: 06 November 2008
Total points: 112 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



the calculation, I THINK, is:



CS-responding / (CS responding + pre-CS responding)



the lower the ratio, the higher the strength of suppression.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thoroughly answers the second part of the question.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



secondti...
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 130 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

Member since: 06 November 2008
Total points: 103 (Level 1)

<answer>

<answer from>



norobiza...
Member since: 26 April 2006
Total points: 310 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Bed bugs are a pest and really hard to handle..



I once had a bed bug problem too.. So I called the professional to come out and get rid of my bed bug problems. They had stated that bed bugs do not go away in just one treatment it usually takes 3-4 different treatments so they had recommend several different products that i could purchase online and use to treat the bed bugs.



One of the products I found that was very useful is call Steri- Fab you spray it almost anywhere mattress, clothes and even carpets. Also using natural products such as rest easy is a good idea too, taking these types of product when your traveling so that you don't bring them back with you. Also getting box spring and mattress encasements is a good idea it not only helps eliminate but help prevent them. If you try to cover your mattress and box spring with plastic the bed bugs will just chew right through it. Spraying the mattress and putting dust into the holes in the sides of the mattress before covering the infested mattress is a good idea.



I was able to find a lot of products and info at this site they have a reasonable price to why don't you check it out...



Source(s):



www.pestmall.com



</answer>

<answer>



Get a new mattress. It sounds like you have tried to make yourself feel better by cleaning and making it so anything in your mattress can't get you...but if it isn't working, you may have to get a new mattress to get over it completely. Mattresses can be expensive, but if you are not picky, you may be able to find a nice one in your price range.



If you continue to have issues and you don't have the means to replace the mattress, I would talk with a therapist or psychologist. They could help you to overcome your problem. A psychiatrist on the other hand, will try to prescribe you medicine, so I would not go there unless you have tried counseling. Good luck!

<answer from>



David Salti
Member since: 11 June 2008
Total points: 1757 (Level 3)

<answer>



In respect to the issue of homosexuality and choice, given the existence of ex-homosexuals and given the existence of human cultures where homosexuality has apparently not existed, the position that homosexuality is ultimately a choice in individuals or at the very least can be a choice in individuals has strong evidential support. In addition, given that the homosexual population has significantly higher rates of many diseases and the homosexual population also has significantly lower rates of various measures of mental health it can be strongly argued that engaging in homosexual acts is a bad choice for individuals. Another other factor that makes engaging in homosexual acts a bad choice for individuals is the significantly higher rates of domestic violence in homosexual couples. In addition, according to experts homosexual murders are relatively or quite common and often homosexual murders are very brutal. Also, the homosexual population has a greater propensity to engage in illegal drug use.



In addition, a distinction is made between choosing to have homosexual desires and choosing to engage in homosexual sex acts. And there are other aspects of choice to homosexuality. One can decide the following aspects: whether or not to believe that homosexual acts are detrimental to one's immortal soul, emotional well-being or physical health and one can also obviously choose whether to enter into a homosexual relationship or not. Obviously one must use wisdom and also do diligence in regards to these matters. For example, the Bible condemns homosexuality and sound Bible exegesis reveals this matter.

<question from>



empathic...
Member since: 01 November 2008
Total points: 141 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How do i get over being molested?



i feel nasty living with this secret i was molested by my two brothers and a cousin at age 6 or seven . now im a confused guy that feels like im not good enough to be with a girl im borderline gay btw i think. the first women to give me a bonner was serena williams shes hot im so confused by the way i want a wife and kids ahhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh! i dont kno help me what should i focus on im 19 btw



</question>



<answer from>



sweeta :
Member since: 22 October 2006
Total points: 4700 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



These events that took place have so much meaning you added to them with story that you live by.  The events were real.  But whatever meaning you put to them have owned your whole life...your past has set your future up to be limited.  The best way to overcome this is to go back to when you first were being stopped in your life.  You could get complete with it by facing the people involved and really talking about where it left you in life. This route may not work, so you cannot do that, then there is another way let go/forgive. You would be giving yourself service by this.  It means that you are letting go of all story of those events, giving up the resentment/sadness...whatever feelings, and giving it all up so that your whole being can be rid of it.  You will feel lighter, and you will be free, and most of all you will have complete personal power.  After you can accomplish this part, then you create for yourself who you truly want to be in life.  Don't focus on what you want to "do"...but who you want to see yourself being.  This is called "possibility"  An example would be "the possibility of "freedom and full exrpession".  For myself it's "presense and self acceptance".



You will constantly be tested with this, and your patterns of old behavior will want to come back.  But if you stay focused on who you truly want to be in your life, and not hang on to past, then your future will always be limitless of possibilities.



I had a heck of a traumatic childhood that included molestation, to name a few.  I took courses that helped me to really give up all the stories of the past that I was allowing to own me and claim me victim.  It's no longer owning me.  You'd never think I endured these things.  Life is life, and we will continue to be living it every moment.  It does not ever have to own us unless we allow it.  You choose how your future will go as long as you let go of the past.  You will then be more present in your life, thus being fully alive like you deserve.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thank you



</asker's comment>

<question from>

<question>



What are things that people have to overcome in life?

<original file>24111.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk115099.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



Thinksal...
Member since: 10 May 2007
Total points: 394 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Life after college:  I'm very unhappy?



I'm 22 and back home living with my parents (I recieved a BS in business this past May).  The job market is brutal right now, and after 2 months of searching, I'm finally nearing a job offer with this one company.  So what's the problem?



1.) I don't like this job.  I'm faking my interest just because I'm desperate and it offers a decent salary, but I know I'll inevitably be unhappy with it.



2.) I want to move out of my parents house.  This job is local, and I know if I get it I'll be living home and won't have a very good social life.  Most of my friends aren't even in my hometown anymore.



3.) I want love.  I want to be in more social settings where I am around the pretty, friendly girls (I admit I'm awfully picky) so that I can find a new love.  To make it harder, no prospects live in my hometown; just some old buddies.



I feel like I'll only be happy if I have a good social life, a girlfriend and a job I enjoy.  This is something I've been picturing in my head since high school.  Ultimately I'm scared I'm setting myself up for disappointment, and all I want is to find happiness.



What should I do?



</question>



<answer from>



Chris!
Member since: 23 September 2007
Total points: 366 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



First of all, i just want to say that i think it's great you've spent so much time determining what will make you happy, and came out with some pretty reasonable ideas.  This is more than most people ever manage.  Good for you.



Moving on, i think you need to just chill out.  A rash or rushed decision has much more potential to be a bad decision.  It is quite possible that you'll have to make some sort of compromise.  You have a series of goals her, and personally i think you should try and take on one at a time.  Trying to juggle too much at once will make you stress and even more likely to make a bad decision in the midst of being rash, imo.  Not that you necessarily make bad decisions, of course, but i think you get where i'm coming from.



I cannot say for sure which goal is best for YOU to complete first.  Only you can do that, and from what i can tell,  you likely already know which is the smartest / most important for you to go with first.  So do it.  Don't rush other aspects, you DO still have a lifetime ahead of you.  Happiness is not just something you can walk into in any event, it usually requires some level of hardship first.  If you can take your time and keep your focus on what will/can be rather than only what is... i have no doubt in my mind that you will reach your goals.



Good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



1. Maybe the job is not your dream job, but as you say, it offers decent pay and it seems nobody else was interested in taking you on. Sorry for being so straightforwards, but that's how it is. Accept that. Apart form that, think positive. Maybe you'll meet the nicest colleagues in the world and you won't even mind the less-than-perfect job after a month.



2. Be glad you have the chance to save money by not having to pay rent. Be grateful for the support you get from your parents. If you get the job, maybe you'll be able to afford a flat after a promotion/payrise - for the time being, accept what you have. Why would you not have a good social life just because you still live with your parents? What did you do when you were in high school and still living at home? If your friends moved (too far) away, get to know new people; do not break off contact, but don't expect to be friends with the same group of five people for the rest of your life.



3. The girl situation is the same as your job situation. You haven't even started the job, you have no idea what kind of people will be around you every day - keep your eyes open during lunchbreaks. If you want "more social settings", get out there and set them up! If you think only pretty girls are worth getting to know, you'll miss out on a bunch of great friendships and maybe even relationships - your choice. You are currently not coming over as picky, but as superficial and impossible to satisfy with anything.



Sorry for appearing so negative towards you, but you need to wake up and stop moaning. You have a degree, you will start your first job, you will have a decent salary, you'll meet new people.... Hate to break it to you, but elsewhere in the world, babies are starving to death. Sorry again, but sometimes it helps to put things into perspective.



You are looking backwards rather than forwards, you desperately cling on to your "old" life. You are, as you noticed yourself, indeed setting yourself up for disappointments, but the only reason for that is your attitude - not the circumstances. Think positive - easy to say, but at least give it a try and start your new job with a smile. :)



</answer>

<original file>4503.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk117762.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



Denzel Washington
Member since: 23 November 2006
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is your theory on why we experience déjà vu – that feeling you've been somewhere or met someone before?



This is the real Denzel Washington.  Read the blog for further details:



http://uk.blog.360.yahoo.com/blog-qT1KKP...



Check out the movie at http://uk.movies.yahoo.com/features/deja...



</question>



<answer from>



Philbomo...
Member since: 11 October 2006
Total points: 987 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The electrical signals that allow us to store memories in our brains can take a number of different routes to arrive at their final destination. If a 'memory' in the form of an electrical signal takes a couple of different routes at the same time, it is possible that if one route is longer than the other, it arrives in the memory part of your brain only to find that the same memory has already arrived by a shorter route. This would make you think that you had already experienced the event on a previous occasion. A bit like hearing an echo when a sound wave has been reflected via different paths.
Thats my theory, and I'm happy with it.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Answer chosen with help from the Yahoo! editorial team.



</asker's comment>

Overall - this answer does make sense if you really think about it.  Kudos to Philbomoog and the Editorial Team.



♥Brown Eyed Chef in Training ♥

<answer>



For many years,it has been known that the two hemispheres of the brain are slightly out of step,althought they work in unison,there are sufficient differences in chemical changes to allow one half to percieve things before the other half is fully aware,the result of this is that the "slow" and "fast " halves of the brain percieve it differently,one as an immediate experience and one as a memory.I dont understand why people keep harping on about deja vu when this has been know for so long



</answer>

I believe that it's possible you HAVE been there before - maybe in another life-time! If you feel connected to someone and you've only just met them, it's also possible that you knew them from a previous life. This is sometimes called Soul Groups!
I have heard several scientific explanations about deja vu but none of them have satisfied me as much as the idea that we are reincarnated into new life experiences and something from our "mind" and by this I don't mean brain, is carried with us into the new carnation (body). I believe that it's also possible that talents are also 'transported' in the mind/soul of the person and that is why some people have a natural flair for singing, acting, art etc... Some people feel that they are able to remember incidents from past lives in their 'now' life. Knowledge and skills can also be transferred in this way and all we are doing is REMEMBERING an experience. When we think we've seen and done something before.. maybe just maybe we have... but on another level within a different existence and snap shots of that experience are returning to us!

dennis_l...

Total points: 187 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is a 6th sense.  Some people are psychic, they have full control of retaining information of what they see in the future, however most of us do not have such abilities.  At one point we catch a brief glimpse into the future, usually an insignificant event.  That glimpse is stored somewhere in the deep recesses of our mind.  When that event actually happens, déjà vu occurs, it triggers the memory of that momentary glimpse, however because of it's brevity and how deeply it is stored in our mind we do not remember having it in the first place.  It is familiar, but not recognizable.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



deja vu occurs when the electrical impulses in our brains "jump" from one side of the brain to the other, at the synapse...sometimes the impulse rate of speed slows down and...while we are looking at something or doing something our eyes see what we are doing and our ears hear what's going on around us but, the brain takes a moment to register it.  That's when we think...hey, I've done this before.



</answer>



<answer from>



st.abbs
Member since: 24 November 2006
Total points: 7147 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



When I was about 16 I decided I would go to London and seek my fortune. I traveled overnight on the bus from Edinburgh and arrived in Victoria at 6.30am I bought a paper to look for a job and went to the cafe for a coffee and look at the jobs, unfortunately there were no adverts for jobs I felt emberrassed sitting too long in the cafe on my own and I was too shy to ask anyone what paper was best to find a job so I thought i'd go to Downing street and visit the London Paladium then Buckingham Palace. Having never been any further south than Edinburgh I walked straight to The London Palladium, I then made my way to Downing St and along to Buckingham Palace, I never asked anyone directions, I did not get lost I seemed to know how to get to each place by instinct. I ended up getting the 4.30 bus back to Scotland as London was just too scary for me.
Over the years I have passed people or met people in company
and when I have looked them in the eye and for a second I felt a connection.One woman in particular she was about 10 feet away from me in other company our eyes locked for a second and I felt her pain,sorrow and hopelessness I was sure I knew her but I knew that I had never met her, I heard she was found dead 3 days later her name Betty Blue Lips.
I was regressed by a Scottish Newspaper over a few weeks and lo and behold under regression my name was Nanelle Rodgers and I lived in London had a florist my father was missing in India he was in the Army.
Two weeks later I looked up whos who and there was a Captain Rogers who had dissapeared in India.
Was that the reason I knew London so well? is there life after death? I don't know, my Mother before she died said she had a funny feeling she was going to die and if she did she would come back and let me know what it was like then she said maybe we cant because most people would eventually commit suicide. My Mother was killed in an acciden shortly after this conversation,that was 28 years ago so far she hasn't come back not even in a dream.
Some people say it is one part of your brain working quicker than the rest but this does not apply to my experiences.
Maybe dejavou is just that we are useing the part of the brain which is surpressed.Have you never met someone and knew instinctively that they were allright or all wrong.
Best regards.



Source(s):



Past experiences.



</answer>

<question>



How would I go about contacting a psychiatrist online?



Either to chat with them (IM) or to email them..for free..
I realize this probably isn't something that you can do on the internet but thanks anyway..



</question>



<answer from>



Mike
Member since: 06 July 2007
Total points: 822 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



megan, are you actually considering confiding your deepest thoughts and problems to an absolute stranger on the internet? You are setting yourself up for an experience that can go in dozens of directions, and none of them - in my opinion - are good. You've emphasized ...for free. When it comes to mental health there are no freebees. That is excepting when an individual really makes up their mind to to take control, and by themself do something to create a more acceptable life style. Chat with an unknown psychiatrist.  Well megan I wish you luck if you make the kind of contact you are  asking about. Just be careful.  Internet communication can be harsh and unforgiving. Post something you may regret, and it hardly ever goes away. Mike



Source(s):



Experience



</answer>

<question from>



Ellie E
Member since: 28 August 2007
Total points: 559 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Organise your day? Tips and motivation needed ?



I have had a problem with organisation all my life. It's really messed up a lot of opportunities for me. I'll get excited about something, start it, carry it mid way through but always fail to finish things completely. My confidence has gone because It's like I don't trust myself to complete what I set out to do. (I know this won't make sense to a lot of people, especially if you have no problems getting things done). I'm not afraid of working hard and I'm quite creative so I really don't know why this is such a problem? PLEASE HELP. If you could give me tips or lend ideas that would be great xxx Thanks



</question>



<answer from>



Geri9394...
Member since: 21 September 2007
Total points: 6615 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your problem might simply be immaturity.  What helps me to be organized and accomplish everything I want to get done during the day is to make a list.  It doesn't have to be a long or detailed list, but make a list.  Then, don't go on to the next thing until you've completed what it is that you're working on.



What I have on my list for tomorrow is very simple:



lab
lunch with Sandy
car (take it to get serviced)
super market



That's it.



Source(s):



Life experience



</answer>



<answer from>



nickipet...
Member since: 04 May 2006
Total points: 64074 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



there is a great book for this



"How to get control of your time and your life"



it is an oldie, maybe from the early 80s, or even late 70s
but it is really good.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jess
Member since: 06 August 2008
Total points: 299 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hmm, well im sort of the opposite, i cant stand leaving things unfinished! it just feels so... gah! Maybe you should try and set yourself to that, you might just be getting lazy? You should make more goals, try having a peice of paper on your table or fridge or something with a to-do list, and write on it something like.. 'I WILL finish this list by -/-/-' And that can be your main priority.. Make sure you start off with enjoyable things so you wont get sick of it straight away.. If you find yourself writing more and more things on the list then you are getting more confident and you should be fine! :)
Just an idea, hope it helps Goodluck!



</answer>



<answer from>



John D.
Member since: 22 July 2006
Total points: 402 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dont organize your day. Let your mind guide you.
Decide 1 important thing for each day that will make a difference.
Do that 1 thing and let the other stuff revolve around it.



When its done, Celebrate the rest of the day.
Simple, Shut up & do it.



</answer>

<question>



Is it pedophilish for a 42 year old to fall in love with a 18 year old and vice versa?



Im not a freak...or a pedo. its a questions just out of pure curiosity.
do you think its pedophilish or is it completely natural?



</question>



<answer from>



mademois...
Member since: 11 October 2008
Total points: 88 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



to most of society, yes it's ''pedophilish'' for a 42 year old man to be with an 18 year old [barely a] woman... most people view it as an older man looking for a hot little chick to be with... but that may not be the case at all, age can be JUST a number, perhaps the 18 year old girl is very mature, and the 42 year old is young at heart, whatever the case, it's still an age gap.. and age gaps tend to be not as important once you reach late 20's and so on, because you're on the same path.. but 18-25 you're just experiencing being free and wanting to experiment and find out who you are, not likely to want to be tied down.. while a 42 year old typically is ready to settle down with someone... catch my point? but there can be exceptions to every rule, so brush off what society thinks, if a 42 yr old wants to be with an 18 yr old and vise versa then go for it ;)



</answer>



<answer from>



All-One
Member since: 05 January 2007
Total points: 9446 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



My dad was 20 years older than my mother. I have never seen two people more in love.
The problems however did come as they grew older. They both became alcoholics. The relationship terminated when my father passed, he was 64.  She remarried and remained a alcoholic for the rest of her life.



So to answer your question, no it is not pedophilia, but is something I would not recommend.



</answer>



<answer from>



Darth M
Member since: 07 October 2008
Total points: 325 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Pedophilia is describe by law. If the age of 18 is legal for consent it is not pedophilish. But socially it is a big age difference that can raise an eyebrow or two.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kuve
Member since: 18 August 2006
Total points: 8660 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



"Pedophilia" is an attraction to pre-pubescent children, if she's post-pubescent but still underage you'd be an ephebophile.  An 18 year old, who's legally an adult in sexual matters, wouldn't fall into either category.  A lot of men prefer younger women, that's quite common, as is an attraction to older men in younger women, so I wouldn't worry about it unless there are other factors you haven't mentioned.



</answer>



<answer from>



mj_puce
Member since: 22 June 2007
Total points: 6325 (Level 5)

</answer>

<question>



How can I be more loving, positive, compassionate and graceful to me and others?



Since attending college 3 years ago, I've noticed how different of a person I've become. I've done everything to losing weight (though I still need to lose more), change my outward appearance, rededicated my life to God/brought Christianity back into my life, get psychiatric help and so forth. Though I'm glad I've been proactive in getting my life on track, I'm starting to see how I've hurt and push people away and I know I can't get many of those people back.



I've also noticed I'm still not very loving, trusting, positive or accepting of others, myself and God. I've been accused of being too critical, serious, over analytical, a perfectionist, controlling and mean. I allow my emotions to get the best of me at times. I mix up being too guarded and too vulnerable at the wrong times with the wrong people. I easily beat myself up and sometimes others as a result. I don't have a community and don't feel I can go on.



I'm trying to change, but I just can't adjust quick enough for everyone and everything.



How do learn to achieve the above question? Thanks.



(I'm in group therapy, but it doesn't allow me to open up like I need it to. And, I don't qualify for any more individual therapy sessions at my school's health clinic.)



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Make a conscious choice, announce your intent, and do it. How difficult is that? Your life, your choice, be what you want.



</answer>

although it may sound rude - if u just invite yourself to one of the outings then they start nviting u later on aswell oz uve kinda joined their group - well it worked with me
or u can organize sumthing and invite them out and then theyll start inviting u 2 things that they organise :D good luck xx



</answer>



<answer from>



akyinnar c
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 192 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have to say that my youngest brother is exactly like you. He has no social life and all he does is study.. he doesn't even talk to anybody except during lunch or dinner. He would just stay inside his room all day long and study.. he has no close friend. He doesn't go out at all.. he doesn't socialize with anyone. Eventhough he doesn't have depression, i always worried what if he becomes depressed one day..
well, for your case, if you become depressed, that means you are getting bored of your daily routine life which is just studying and not doing anything fun.. Making a small amount of time for other activities and socializing will be great. Otherwise, it can even effect your academic performances. So, take some time off, and go out with friends for a drink or spend some time with family, watching a movie or having family dinner... and do some sports like 30mins a day.. this will regulate ur blood flow and it will keep you back on track. Believe me, being extreme is not good even if it is for something good. You need to have some time for other things too. Balance your time. You can do it. You can still score 4.0. All the best.



Source(s):



my brother



</answer>

<answer from>



Vic
Member since: 20 October 2008
Total points: 354 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have a relative that attempted suicide unsuccessfully, not through a lack of effort mind you.



There would have to be no lower point you could reach. I can remember my relative feeling ashamed, embarrassed, worthless, and quite often people attempt suicide because they feel they are a burden to their family/loved ones, and the fact that they survived brings them to feel even more of a burden. All this is, of course, on top of all the depression.



A good family will always be supportive. My family still worry a lot, mostly that it will occur again.



</answer>



<answer from>



debbie79
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 84 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Every person is different in how they would react.  However, it depends on the circumstances i.e. did the person really want to kill him/herself or was it an extreme cry for help, are they now glad they didn't kill themselves, do they wish they had killed themselves etc.
I would say that it would be a mixture of feelings.
Guilt on seeing their family and friends so upset at their attempted suicide and seeing how this act effects those around them. (whether they had really wanted to kill themselves or not.  when people try to kill themselves they are convinced the world will be better with out them so they don't want to see the way loved ones would be upset as they believe, or convince themselves, no one cares)
Regret at what they had done or not been successful in doing...intense regret!
They would be really detached and withdrawn.  and i think tears would be saved for when they are in private.
Absolute despair.
Probably thinking can't do anything right...not even kill themselves.
The family would also be in total shock.  They would feel guilty that they hadn't been there to support their loved one and hadn't realised how bad things were to be able to help and stop the suicidal thoughts.
hope this helps
good luck
x



</answer>

1. My friend posted a myspace bulletin which said he got a new job at mcdonalds, and he posted the exact location.



2.  Naturally I was thinking he posted the bulletin , which gave the exact location of his employemnt to ALL his friends,  for a reason...because he wants his friends to visit him at mcdonalds.



3. I visited him at mcdonalds to surprise him and say hello.



4. He basically gives me the cold shoulder and ignores me



5. I write an email apologizing for the unnannounced visit



6. He accepts my apology with a two word email: "It's cool."



7. Ten days later when i dont hear from him i send an email saying " i miss you" and i ask "are you mad at me?"



8. He writes back "We cant talk anymore", then blocks me from his myspace , and removes me as a friend.



9. He ignores all my attempts to fix things (email, messages, text, voicemail, calls) for over a full month, a total of 35 days



10.  We're friends again.



11.  He claims the reason he gave me the "silent treatment" was because his new "boyfriend" was going to call the COPS on me for "stalking" him because I visited mcdonalds ( a public restaurant) just ONE time and for only 5 minutes.



11.  It's not stalking if you only see someone ONCE and never do it again. Plus I apologized for the misunderstanding and he accepted my apology.



12.  So it begs the question: Do you think he gave me the REAL reason why he gave me the "silent treatment" for 35 days?



</question>

<question>



How do we feel right before we die?



Everyone will die eventually. No can can run away from it and I see no point of running away from it. (Live your life fully). Anycase.. So, I'm asking you a question about how we feel in the moment just right before we being completely expired. You can go in order, like, suffocated, blackout, headache, dizzy, muscles stiffness, cold, cold from where, getting numbed, ... stuff like that. It's stupid to waste oneself's life. So don't waste your time trying out real experience or telling me to go try for myself neither, because that's a very stupid answer.



JUST TELL ME WHAT YOU THINK OR BELIEVE.



</question>



<additional details>



Thank you for the first answer!! And I'd like to hear more about the "physical feeling". Cuz I've thought if I have to suffocate until death in the "moment of truth"... or my mind just go "wooohhh I'm so sleepy now *yawn*" then..I am gone... is it that awesome? or terrible like the first case?



</additional details>



<answer from>



fourthit...
Member since: 18 October 2008

<question from>



V Aletheia
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 1115 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



How do I handle my mood swings?



I go through pretty rapid mood swings mainly between feelings of ambitious motivation and discouraged depression.



They affect me on a day-today-day basis and I would like to be able to control them to some extent (without going to any therapists).



Does somebody have some suggestions or advice?



Note:
I am twenty-one-years-old.



</question>



<additional details>



TYPO: I meant *day-to-day not "day-today-day"



I have often worried that I may have bipolar disorder.
I have ADHD and I read that it can sometimes be misdiagnosed, and really be bipolar disorder instead.
Sigh..



</additional details>



<answer from>



Ledger
Member since: 07 April 2008
Total points: 1185 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Your rapid mood swings sound a bit like bi-polar disease... you should see a doctor... if you cannot afford to go see a doctor you should attend a free clinic or even go to the hospital.



They will asses you and decide what's the matter and why you're having these mood swings and then decide on treatment.



Obviously, I am not a doctor, I do not know your history and can only make a snap judgment.



There's nothing wrong with being bi-polar and many many people have this disorder, including Ben Stiller. They keep it all in check with meds.



Good luck.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks hun



</asker's comment>

<answer from>



Drinking...
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 122 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The only way to overcome feeling lonely is to meet you people.  It sounds obvious but if you join some clubs you will achieve 2 things:



1.  You will be keeping busy so less time to reflect on feeling lonely and depressed.



2.  You will actually start to meet new people, it won't happen straight away but over time friendships/relationships will grow and your circle of friends will grow with it.



Chatting on line won't make you feel any less lonely - in fact it will probably make you feel even more lonely.



Be brave! get out there and join some clubs.



</answer>

<answer>

If his fixation grows into something more bizarre, I think you need to communicate your reluctance and ask him to explain why he does it.

<original file>8839.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk122578.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



icedtea
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the difference of analytical and critical?



We usually associate these to words and think that they are one and the same, but they're not... Does anyone know the difference?



This was a question asked by our philosophy professor.



</question>



<answer from>



AskCharl...
Member since: 05 June 2007
Total points: 368 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Analytical means searching, discerning, scanning, determining something about a subject. If I read your sentence and I am analyitcal about it, I am trying to figure out what you wrote. If I read it and I am critical about it, I am saying, "Hey! You spelled associate wrong!" ( you spelled it right though :P) So to analyze is to observe or look into something, criticizing means to critique, which means to tell how to correct something, to say how something could be better.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sweet D
Member since: 05 December 2007
Total points: 199 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



To analyse is to consider in detail and subject to an analysis in order to discover essential features or meaning.



To criticise is to judge or discuss the merits and faults.



Source(s):



I'm a Psychology Student



</answer>

<answer from>



Steven P nb tx
Member since: 13 December 2007
Total points: 669 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I understand your question.  You know how to write English.
Your friends don't judge you for making a small mistake when you speak English.



Most native english speakers will notice a mistake as soon as you make it.  They usually won't call attention to it, though.



If you are able to communicate your ideas, most people won't ridicule you for a small mistake in language.



Consider this:  You can speak English, plus another language.  The person you are talking to can speak English, but cannot speak your native language.
If someone were learning your language, you would try to understand them when they spoke with mistakes, right?



Source(s):



Native english speaker who tried to learn spanish.  I have marveled at phone conversations in Hindi and Arabic at American convenience stores.



</answer>

<question>



Why does it feel like this election...?



Has cast a gray cloud in my life? Now I'm fearful more than ever with like, bad thoughts and having the urge to cry. Is this normal after people attack each other in every election?? It's been like that for a couple days now. Maybe it's this board lol...maybe it's my reverse sleeping schedule(stay up at night, sleep during the day) haha... :/



Please, be nice...has anybody had the same feelings? Thank you :)



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I'd say it's because you have fear of the unknown or uncertain.  So many people have blindly put their faith in that a single man or party can save them during these uncertain times.  The fact is nothing will change tomorrow and not for a while after Obama takes office.  Who knows how that change will effect the average Joe or Jane?



This election was like a huge fight, there is definitely a lot of negativity in the air.  There is a hatred between Republicans and Democrats.  This hatred comes to light in every election.  Thanks to the media, you've been spoon fed that negatively for several months.  And now that we've witnessed this hatred, how can we expect our government to work together?  That's why every acceptance speech includes something like, "We have to set our differences aside and work together to make this country great again...blah blah blah."



Yeah, it's normal to feel that gray cloud.  You're just not being foolish to believe that everything's gonna be better over night.  The election is over.  Let's all think positive and continue to work hard.



</answer>

<answer from>



Executive Producer2000
Member since: 26 May 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)

<answer>



Your Question: "Who makes you happy and why?"



ANSWER:



No one makes you happy.  The happiness that you feel is inside of you and it is entirely your choice as to whether you want to feel happy or not.



Yes, you can feel happy with others around you, family , friends and more, but to keep feeling happy, you need to have happiness inside your heart.  That happiness will sustain you when others are busy or not around.  Learn how to be happy under all circumstances.



Everyone, and I do mean everyone, has the ability to be happy under almost any circumstances. You can have the whole world falling apart in front of you and you still have the ability to be happy  because there is always something to be grateful for.  Remember the good things that you have, remember the best parts of life and think good and positive thoughts.  Any of those thoughts can bring happiness in your life.  You have the ability to do it.  But to do it, you need to choose it.



So, choose happiness. Wake up in the morning and decide to be happy --no matter what happens.



Yes, things happen, people die, people get hurt, stuff happens, people lose money, others lose fortunes, some get sick, and some wind up in the hospital, but the difference between those who suffer more and those have some joy in their lives is that those joyful people excercise their happiness muscle.  And that muscle is in your heart.



Think of others, do for others, get the concentration and focus off of yourself.



That is how you can find happiness if you are not happy right now.



Your question sounds as if you are looking for answers on how you can be happy.  Here is how:



Volunteer. Go help someone either officially as a registered volunteer or unofficially by just doing something nice for someone you know or by doing something nice even for a stranger.



See a parking meter expired? Put a quarter in the meter for some stranger.  Smile!



See someone needing help with packages? Help them , but ask first, do not just grab their packages.



Open doors for people.  And this will open doors for you!



Source(s):



My source is the joy inside my heart.  Share your joy. Share your information, your expertise, share your joy, and you too will overflow with happiness. Life is the best source of all experience, emotions, strength, and everything else in between.



http://www.youtube.com/superbooks7



</answer>

<answer>



Some psychologist or psychiatrist (pseudo-sciences) made up the term. You really lack self control.

A very bright lady once told me, "You are where you are doing what you want to do. No matter how much you complain or whine about it.
