<answer from>



Shiphrah K
Member since: 29 September 2007
Total points: 4106 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Gender & Women's Studies



</answer from>



<answer>



It's really difficult to quit an addiction, but it is possible and people do it every day.



The main things are that you really have to want to quit, and you have to believe you can.



It helps a lot if there are people in your life who can be supportive and can encourage you when you're tempted to give in and eat/smoke/drink/whatever.

It also helps if you find ways to reward yourself.  For example, if you quit smoking, save the money you would have spent on cigarettes, and every week buy yourself a treat with the money - some CDs, or books or whatever interests you.

Also, a healthy diet and daily exercise make quitting an addiction *much* easier.

Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Empathy
Member since: 01 July 2008
Total points: 281 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Find a good therapist that can help. Therapists usually deal with people who have "adjustment to life" issues and don't really work with people that are mentally ill. They should be able to see how you think, what triggers you have, and recommend some changes you can integrate slowly into your life.



Another thing I would recommend is to find some things that you like that are good for you and keep yourself busy. Having a lot of time or being bored makes it easier to indulge. Get involved in things where you have to be somewhere, or you have to produce something, so that you are occupied and can't easily get out of it if you just don't feel like it. You can even make a mental game of it where you make goals that if you do xyz that is productive and healthy, then you will allow yourself to have a "treat". In the end though, we all fight with urges to do what we want vs. what we have to.



If you're not addicted physically, then it will come down to how badly you want it, what actual (practical) steps you are willing to take to make it happen (not buy something anymore vs. bringing it in the house), steps you are willing to take to find other more productive and healthy things to occupy your time. etc. But be realistic... do you really want to change? If so, you will more likely commit to doing better things and you will get more of a satisfaction out of them. There are many people who say they would like to be different but inside, they know they are really not willing to do anything to disrupt the status quo. You first need to decide if you are serious about it and then start making actual goals.



One thing that will not work is if you do something half-assed by saying "oh I want to do this and that" but you make no plans, no phone calls, contact no people, or you just do a little bit of it, and then when you fail, you will think you're not good at it and lose confidence. Don't attempt it unless you want to actually do the work because then it will drain your belief in yourself. I've done the same with diets where I tried them half-assed and then wanted to think "diets don't work for me" but the truth was that I wasn't sticking to it like I should and it wasn't the diet but my engagement in it. Be honest with yourself and with your efforts.



Also, people in your life are paramount!! Who you surround yourself with is important. Find friends that don't do the crap you don't want to do and hang out with them. In other words, if you don't want to drink, don't go to the bar. Maybe you liked scrabble as a kid... find a scrabble club. Too boring? Something else good you enjoy. Surround yourself with the kind of people and activities that are positive and then the more you live it the more it will become second nature and you will not miss it as much. Unfortunately there isn't one easy way to do it - it takes preparing yourself mentally for the fact that it will be hard, that you will have to do it when you don't feel like it, and that it's up to you and nobody else (you can't blame others). Taking responsibility is very important in order to conquer something.

Being from another country where strict discipline was practiced in school and at home, I am very taken aback with the permissive American attitude in schools and in parenting. There is little power coming from adults to try to shape kids to have self discipline and self regulating abilities. Excess is everywhere (look at the ice cream cones!) and marketing targets kids specifically and parents rarely set strict boundries... I see many kids today growing up without a lot of self discipline, goal setting, time manatement skills, etc. Sometimes they seem unprepared for the temptations of the world (first credit cards marketed to college kids) and the ability to delay gratification. Not saying anything has happened to you, just saying it's not necessarily an addictive personality - I see many people with problems like this where proper structure and discipline wasn't taught early on and then people struggle. Good luck and if you have kids don't hesitate to be FIRM with them. You have the power and it's up to you to help your kids develop a sense of balance and the ability to say no to fun until the work is done. Don't give in because they cry or complain or raise a fuss. The more you stick firm by the rules you make the more your kids will learn how to set firm boundries and stick to them, even when it's hard. But the younger that's learned, the better, because then these skills can be used earlier (college, etc.) and lead to success more than failure.

Good luck!



Source(s):



Former Child Protective Services Case Manager and Counseling Psychology PhD student.



</answer>



<answer from>



i dont know who i am?
Member since: 15 February 2008
Total points: 11221 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



go to your GP/doctor and ask for help there, they will know what to do



</answer>

UK Oldie

<question from>



Snow Angel

Total points: 1461 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



How can I get my boyfriend to understand my Social Anxiety?



I have been with my boyfriend for 6 years and he has always known that I have a 'shy personality' but he doesn't realise the extent of my social anxiety... i can cover it pretty well but it makes me come across as hard and uncaring when I can't talk with his friends at social gatherings because of my anxiety.  He finds it so easy to chat to people that he can't understand why I find it so hard to socialise and he thinks I'm lazy and can't be bothered.  He leaves me alone at parties to talk to other people but I freeze and don't know what to say.



I tried to explain social anxiety with him yesterday but he just said that if I can't overcome it then maybe he is the wrong person to be with.  He just doesn't understand that it is not that easy and I want to be more outgoing and make friends.  SA is like a huge barrier I cannot overcome alone.  He has always been confident and outgoing and really can't understand the anxiety I go through when talking to people... how can I make him understand it when he's never experienced it?

We have another party to go to on Friday and I've said I'll do everything I can to try and be more outgoing at this party but I'm so worried about it... if I freeze up again I think he will leave me.

Do you have any advice?



</question>



<answer from>



Mr&MrsD
Member since: 25 February 2008
Total points: 727 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Im sorry to hear of your issue with anxiety. If you have sat down and explained your condition to him then it sounds as though he doesnt want to understand.  If this is the case then you should re-evaluate if he's worth sticking with.  If he doesnt sympathise/understand your concerns with socialising after 6 years, then it doesnt seem he will change now.  Ask him to be more patient and try to understand that not everyone has confidence.  If he doesnt change, show him the door, you deserve better.
Hope things improve for you.



</answer>



<answer from>



justcall...
Member since: 20 August 2006
Total points: 361 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If he leaves you over that, then he isn't the right person for you. I know that's hard to hear, but it's the truth. I would describe with him the physical symptoms that you experience. Compare it with something he really hates to do. Have him imagine feeling the tense symptoms along with the irritation he experiences when he does his pet peeve. 
You could also tell him you are willing to work on it, but he has to work with you. That he can't just leave you hanging on your own, if you start with a few friends at your place so you are comfortable, have him lead the conversation within the whole room, focusing on things where you can chip in so that it will be easier.



</answer>



<answer from>



CuriousC...
Member since: 31 January 2008
Total points: 560 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



aww poor thing. First of all this is a long term, ongoing relatonship. i suggest that you should try and talk to him again and make sure he listens, with tv off and no distractions. you have already sat him down and explained to him how you feel. if he isnt going to listen and accept you, then there is something wrong. he needs to listen, help you and work together to overcome this social anxiety. it takes time to overcome this and can't (i dont think) be resolved overnight. you have to tell him that you can't be pushed with this sort of thing, tell him he needs to be patient. the least he could do is support you, and be with you when either you or him are talking to people and not leave you by yourself. you should slowly let him go so he can talk to other people and gradually you'll gain the confidence to talk to people by yourself. as i said it takes a lot of time and work to overcome this, he needs to support you every step of the way and im sure wants to, but just doesnt know what to do. talk to him more and work out a plan as a TEAM that will help you gradually over come social anxiety. 
all the best with friday and the future. x



</answer>



<answer from>



Something or Other
Member since: 16 May 2006
Total points: 701 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



They say never answer a question with another question, but How can I get you to realize that you feed your social anxiety, in turn it becomes stronger thus making you less social? Wow thats a tough nut to crack. I am not refuting that Social Anxiety has its implications, but they say admitting the problem is the first step to solving it. So we can try that or I can tell you not admitting a problem is the first step to not creating the problem, ya get me? Anxieties and phobias are perpetuated by acknowledging they exist. Once they exist we feed them until they go from a minor problem, and then they become counselor worthy, so here is your therapy.

In an Anxious state of mind you have a reduced sense of self, reduced sense of control. Understanding your limitations is the first step in the journey. For example if you know you can't outright talk to a group of people, then why try. One has to walk before he/she can run. You are your worst enemy when it comes to expectations, your demands are worst than his, why? Because people create their own anxieties, sorry my dear, you react differently and you create the anxiety, tough truth.
So let me be raw, stop using your social anxiety as an excuse, its a crutch, you have tried and failed and now you'd rather hide behind something than bear the burden of taking chances socially. Look at it this way, I can be anxious about having a small penis, and I can tell myself that any girl who sees it will think its small, but if I think like that how am i ever going to get some action? Crude I know, but it should make it clear that anxiety holds you back from obtaining what one desires, in the above case its sexual interaction, in your case its friendships. I know you understand this, but do you really? Understanding is something that emmanates change, when you understand you are not the same person. Your boyfriend doesn't have the social anxiety because he understands something you don't. You want to get what he has. Its cute that you think you can't do it alone, but you alone are making yourself incapable. Now that I bashed ya a bit, lets look at some solutions

Your bf is your social side, where he goes you need to go. In the beginning listen to others, don't worry about speaking. You need to know who your talking to, what they like, what they don't like. I know when you walk in and start speaking without knowing anyone you seem kinda in your own world. Its almost the opposite of social anxiety in some regard. When someone says something reply with a quick remark if you feel you would like to contribute input. The intentions is not about what you say, its about showing the person you are listening to what they say. We are given two ears and one mouth so that we may listen twice as much as we speak. Being social is not all about talking. In your case being scene is the jumping point. Your goal is to not be left alone, your bf is not helping in that scenario, so explain to him you want to be escorted. Really when I am with my gf, I am her escort, my eyes are on her, if she needs me I am there or she is close. The party is secondary, gf is primary.
Secondly, at a party, everyone notices you, but no one sees you if that makes sense. If your anxiety stems from personal insecurity, trust me they don't see it. Its like a game of Poker, you bluff, someone calls your bluff, you wait for the next hand. Thats an idea, get your bf to organize a card game, something to occupy your mind while you listen to others. I worry about you doing this by friday, but I know the more exposure you get the greater your strength, so long as you don't hide in yourself. Heck if you feel insecure, get an elastic around your wrist and when your in too deep, whack yourself, your goal is not to be driven by your anxiety, only to drive your anxiety out. 
Lastly, if he leaves ya for not being social, your not losing much. You can't spend your life worrying, thats no life at all.



</answer>



<answer from>



Karen C
Member since: 30 January 2008
Total points: 795 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



He has decided after 6 years that it is perhaps time to move on?  Perhaps you are better off without him if he does not understand or has not tried to understand.  Have you explained it to him only through your perspective or is he aware that you are not just different than he is or strange or imperfect but there are millions who suffer from this and studies have recently pegged social anxiety disorder as the third largest psychological disorder in the country.  Perhaps doing some research on the Internet and providing him with good sites that provide educational information would help him understand better.  On the other hand, have you just accepted this and decided just to learn to live with it or are you actively seeking therapy in an effort to better deal with it.  Please read at this site and get some help even if your boyfriend decides he does not want to deal or understand this better.  At least you can move forward in an effort to get a better handle on things for a better future for yourself.

http://www.socialphobia.org/social.html#...



Source(s):



http://www.socialphobia.org/



</answer>

<question from>



Denzel Washington
Member since: 23 November 2006
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is your theory on why we experience déjà vu – that feeling you've been somewhere or met someone before?



This is the real Denzel Washington.  Read the blog for further details:



http://uk.blog.360.yahoo.com/blog-qT1KKP...

Check out the movie at http://uk.movies.yahoo.com/features/deja...



</question>



<answer from>



Philbomo...
Member since: 11 October 2006
Total points: 953 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The electrical signals that allow us to store memories in our brains can take a number of different routes to arrive at their final destination. If a 'memory' in the form of an electrical signal takes a couple of different routes at the same time, it is possible that if one route is longer than the other, it arrives in the memory part of your brain only to find that the same memory has already arrived by a shorter route. This would make you think that you had already experienced the event on a previous occasion. A bit like hearing an echo when a sound wave has been reflected via different paths.
Thats my theory, and I'm happy with it.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Answer chosen with help from the Yahoo! editorial team.



</asker's comment>

Rhythm *

<answer>



Deja vu could be attributed to premonitions in ones dreams. I often have vivid dreams, but forget about them almost the instant I wake up - most people are like this. If we did what some psychologists advise and put a pen and pad by the bed to jot them down, we would notice some interesting premonitions which may not be 100% correct coming to light.



I had 2 scary premonition dreams, I know the majority of you won't believe this, but I have my wife to vouch for me, and I honestly don't care if I'm believed or not. I woke up on the morning of the London tube bombings with a fright, as if waking up from a nightmare. When my wife asked me what was wrong, apparently I replied: "London is burning..." before rolling over and sleeping a bit longer. I remembered nothing until my wife brought it up. I was also 3 tube stops away from the Edgware road bomb when that bomb exploded.

Other theories are attributed to so-called parallel universes colliding at that one particular instant, where you feel as if you've done this before, and perhaps you may have, in another existence, or perhaps in a different time.



</answer>

chopchub...
Member since: 30 November 2006
Total points: 3023 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



My pet hypothesis on deja vu is that it is a filing malfunction in the brain.
I will try to elucidate.
Ordinarily perception is stored in short-term memory, and only through conscious effort, repetition or emotional significance is it committed to long-term memory.

In deja vu (so my theory goes), perception is simultaneously stored in short-term and a random area of long-term memory.

Long-term memory carries with it some temporal information, i.e. it has a TIME associated with it.  For example I remember having a car accident a few years ago.

When your immediate perception is filed in a random area of long-term memory, it has a random time association.  The result is:  "Hey, I remember this".
In fact you are perceiving it for the first time, but because of the filing malfunction you have a long-term memory of it and hence you "remember" it.

This is all simply conjecture.  I have no empirical evidence to qualify it.

Cheers.



Source(s):



Hang on, I remember this from somewhere...



</answer>

h&pm

Total points: 2845 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Our brain is constantly cross referencing incoming information with stored information in order to help us make rational decisions that in essence help us survive.

My theory is that deja vu is our sub-conscious nudging the conscious, saying we've done/seen something very similar to this before. I don't necessarily think that it's the same thing/person but a bit like a fingerprint analysis, a 3 or say 5 point match on the basics throws up a hit-even if it's not 100% accurate with further thought.

Take people for example, realistically we see hundreds of people a day and of those hundreds we consciously 'see' only a very small proportion of those faces. Is it really any surprise that at some point we run into someone on a more one-to-one basis that we've walked right past, or not noticed on the television days, months maybe even years before?

I don't think so.

I'm certainly not dismissing the afterlife and all it's associated possibilities but I think for the more mundane day to day deja vu that we all experience that my theory pretty much covers it, psychic experiences and paranormal activity, in my humble opinion fall under a different heading altogether.



</answer>

<question from>



VT♥Angel in Disguise♥
Member since: 01 November 2007
Total points: 0 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Does hypnosis involve letting someone control your thinking processes a bit and in essence program you ??



what is the purpose of this and how many times may it be necessary?

and is it necessary for the person to be in a semi concious state , where their logical thinking is nada , so to speak?

why and how so?



</question>



<answer from>



Peanut'J...
Member since: 01 February 2008
Total points: 1227 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I dunno. But now I'm hungry!



</answer>



<answer from>



Allen B
Member since: 18 April 2008
Total points: 5366 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Have you ever been so involved with a task that you have lost track of time? Have you ever driven from one place to another and arrived safely, but not remembered the journey? Have you ever read a book and become so involved with the plot you can see scenery and hear characters speak? Have you ever day-dreamed? These are everyday examples of an altered state of awareness. Hypnosis is another example of an altered state of awareness-one which can be used for self help. It is a perfectly natural state which occurs between being fully awake and fully asleep. In the clinical setting hypnosis is usually accompanied by a pleasant state of physical relaxation which in itself is beneficial, especially in the symptoms induced by or aggravated by stress. The term Hypnotherapy means the use of hypnosis for the treatment and relief of a variety of somatic and psychological symptoms



</answer>



<answer from>



dunrobin...
Member since: 07 April 2008
Total points: 16914 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



No, it doesn't work like that.

Think of daydreaming. Now suppose instead of just random thoughts while daydreaming you could direct your mind to thinking specifically positive thoughts. You have now hypnotised yourself.

Some people have the ability to get someone else into a relaxed state of daydreaming and then present positive suggestions to them



Source(s):



Self hypnotist



</answer>

UK

PattyAnn

<answer>



I don't believe so. Hypnosis for me allowed me to receive someone's
suggestions, but I was never re-programmed. It's said that hypnosis can't make you do anything you don't want to do. I don't even consider it a semi-conscious state. I was always fully conscious. If you are considering hypnosis, talk to a doctor. You can be sure you will not be "programmed" by anyone. Hypnosis is not brain-washing.



</answer>

cessnaxj...
Member since: 06 March 2008
Total points: 235 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hypnosis kind of works this way.

You give somebody permission to tell you what's real and what's not. Then they tell you how your should react to this imposed reality.

For example, theoretically nobody could tell you to jump off a cliff to your death. However, they could convince you that it's not a cliff, but a short step down. You would have no problem stepping down that short step... and you kill yourself.



</answer>



<answer from>



pushy
Member since: 27 January 2008
Total points: 749 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



No all hypnosis does is speak to the unconscious mind whilst you are very relaxed. This can influence behaviour but not to the extent that you would do something against your better interests. We access this very relaxed and receptive state spontaneously anyway throughout the day when very absorbed or very relaxed. How receptive we are varies from person to person and how willing to change our behaviour we are in the first place.



Source(s):



I qualified as a clinical hypnotherapist 12 years ago but I met so many dodgy people on the course (many of them lecturers) that I never practised professionally.



</answer>



<answer from>



chrissyo...
Member since: 20 April 2006
Total points: 181 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You have four levels of consciousness,  beta, alpha, theta, delta(alseep).  Your conscious mind (beta) does the creating and thinking. Your sub-conscious (alpha  or theta) controls behavior and does not create at all - it just listens...think of it as the "driver" in a computer.  It is from this level that you react and feel, not think.

I have been hypnotized several times and of course nobody can control your mind. Hypnosis  is that few seconds right before you doze off (Delta is fully asleep).  If you are dozing off and somebody says, "take all your clothes off," would you do it?  Of course not. You would wake up.

The reason to lower your level of consciousness is to get to a stage that communicates with the "driver" because that is the part that controls behavior.  You are bypassing the thinking/creating part of your mind ( beta, the conscious mind) and going right to alpha to make a suggestion.



You are always in control...you allow yourself to stay in that drowsy state. You remember everything. TV hypnosis is a big joke. That stuff is NOT real.



</answer>

<question from>



VT♥Angel in Disguise♥
Member since: 01 November 2007

<answer>

<answer from>



Olly
Member since: 30 July 2008
Total points: 105 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's hard to say because no one really knows what hypnosis actually is. Even hypnotists like Derren Brown would admit that.

My belief is that you obviously have you conscious mind and your subconscious mind. Your conscious mind is you and your subconscious mind is like that of a child. All you do in hypnosis is distract the conscious mind so that you can 'talk' to the subconscious mind.

For example a hypnotist will often use double negatives or phrases that don't quite make sense. While your conscious mind is trying to work out what's just being said, your subconscious mind will be taking in the information that's said after the distraction.



It mainly works on the principle that in some way or another, some people (not everyones succeptible to hypnosis) actually want to be hypnotised. Or at least their subconscious mind does.The reasons for this differ between people. Someone who's outgoing might like 'taking stage', even if they are just running around like a chicken. Or perhaps a successful business man that - for once - would like to be told what to do as it negates all responsibility.



As well as this, people are often hypnotised to believe completely illogical things, like someone or something is invisible or that they've been turned into a bee. So in many ways, yes I think it does return your thinking to that of a child.



</answer>

<answer from>



Erlyn3
Member since: 29 July 2007
Total points: 435 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your question is vague, but I'll give it my best.
This seems to be a question about learning- specifically how to teach someone to stop an undesired behavior, rather than continue the behavior and try to avoid punishment.
The simplest answer is to changing any bad behavior, is to correct the bad behavior, and REWARD THE GOOD.  A lot of people forget this second part, although it is actually easier to do correctly.
As an example, imagine that there is a child who talks in class.  Punishing them whenever they talk is easy (i.e. scold them), but how do you reward them when they don't?  When they behave properly?
In order to teach a new behavior, it takes an effort on the part of the teacher (or another class member) to reward them- probably by complimenting them on paying attention ("reward" is different from "bribe" because it is not a commercial exchange, "if you do this, you get this" but rather is a positive acknowledgment of proper behavior).  You want the award to be something intrinsic (coming from within) that makes them feel good about acting this way, such as a compliment and not a piece of candy or something which almost turns it into a commercial exchange.
Secondly you must correct bad behavior, which is VERY difficult to do right.  The easy (and wrong) way might be to tell the child to sit in the corner and think about what they did wrong.  But what child would actually THINK about what they did wrong when in time out?  There is a similar problem with almost any punishment, such as spanking.  When you spank a child, they are not thinking about what they did wrong, or learning that it was wrong, they are learning to fear and hate you.  A spanking is only a way to satiate your own anger.
To correct the behavior is difficult, because it is often difficult to address it without emotion (especially without anger or frustration).  The emphasis is not on punishing the child for doing something wrong- the emphasis is that the child has done something wrong and it must be corrected- just as if they were to get a math problem wrong.

The important point is that if someone continues an undesired behavior, it is because they never learned that is was wrong.  You need to teach them, like you would teach them a math lesson in school.  That means praise them when they get it right (or when they cease the behavior) and instruct them when they are wrong.
It's harder than you think.



Source(s):



My experience in professional childcare



</answer>

<answer from>



Aunty
Member since: 20 June 2008
Total points: 1078 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



punishment is not therapy - when people have done something so bad or are deemed be incurable, such as peodophiles, then people want punishment, not therapy.

However if you take young criminals who are embarking down the road to crime I think that these would benefit from confidence building therapy.  A group of prisoners were given the task of helping disabled youngsters swim once a week.  This worked wonders, they felt that they were doing something really useful, it made them feel really good about themselves especially for people far less fortunate than themselves, it made a lot of them really want to change.

I think seeing life from a different perspective, working with people less fortunate can be good therapy.  Being made to feel humble is good, but also what is needed is the tools to make changes as well, such as education and job prospects.



When my hubby was younger and was going down the "wrong" road - he joined the army, the physical training and self discipline required was the making of him and completely turned his life around.



</answer>



<answer from>



Diane M
Member since: 11 November 2007
Total points: 7287 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Depends on the crime or wrong doing, and the person's state of mind.
Some people can learn by having to do things that they normally wouldn't do, like community service. Some can learn from having things that they love in their every day life taken away from them. Some can learn by seeing what their actions have caused other people and try and put themselves in that situation ( I guess that would be therapy).
It really does depend on the person and their mindset to determine  which is the best way to get them to behave differently. But if it is ignored or they aren't reprimanded in some way, chances are that they will continue their behavior, when an act of some type of punishment could change that person for the better.

Have A Great Day!



</answer>

fear of snails and slugs(its not cochleaphobia)
fear of maggots
fear of mold (mycophobia wouldn't be it because that's fear of mushrooms..which im afraid of too, but im talking like mold on cheese and stuff)

<answer from>
Member since: 21 June 2008
Total points: 1794 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



fear of snails and slugs - couldn't find any.
fear of maggots - couldn't find any.
fear of mold - Spermatophobia/Spermophobia
fear of being sick - Nosophobia/Nosemaphobia
fear of dying - Thanatophobia
fear of icy or cold things - Cryophobia
fear of losing teeth - couldn't find any.

Wow that was long. I hope i got them all right. Just done so much research haha.

Hope i could help ♥



</answer>



<answer from>



pinky
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 144 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



phobialist.com has a lot listed



</answer>



<answer from>



rockyroa...
Member since: 21 July 2008
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Cheimaphobia or Cheimatophobia- Fear of cold.(Frigophobia, Psychophobia)



Frigophobia- Fear of cold or cold things



Helminthophobia- Fear of being infested with worms.



Herpetophobia- Fear of reptiles or creepy, crawly things



Monopathophobia- Fear of definite disease



Nosophobia or Nosemaphobia- Fear of becoming ill.



Scoleciphobia- Fear of worms



Thanatophobia or Thantophobia- Fear of death or dying.



i don't know if any of that helped you... but well... here you go!



i hope that helps you :]



Source(s):



http://phobialist.com/



</answer>

<question>



Opinion on this type of memory? Open minded people only, please.?



It's very strange, but this is a weird way of putting it...



Lets say my memory is two boxes. My front box is what i am thinking about directly. The back is what's wandering around the back of my mind, not concentrating on it. I remember things best if both have the same thing, but i'm a little distracted.

With dreams, whatever is in the back box is what i will dream about... if it's also in my front box, i can control the dream; a lucid dream, where you know you know you not in reality.
Thing is, i have a lot of nightmares where i am conscious of the lack of reality, but no matter how much i shout at myself to wake up, i FEEL pain in my dream, but i can also feel my warm bed.  Anyway, back to the memory topic, because they ARE related.

How's this: i went on holiday when i was 6 years old (i am now 14) stood up on a stage, and i can now remember exactly where i was sitting, the pattern of the chairs, lighting, people, and the face, location and name of every person who got introduced on stage (children in a competition). I can remember my entry number, what i said, and how i danced. But other times, NOW i can pick something up, memorise a page, put it down for 5 minutes and completely forget where i put it. I can look at a phone number, 11 digits, and most of the time remember it after 20 seconds. But other times i can write something over and over again and it just doesn't stick... say i'm doing a maths formula, and the teacher writes some problems on the board for homework, expecting us to memorise the formula. I can remember all of the 20 questions, but i can't remember the actual formula.

Does anyone else have this type of memory? It scares me sometimes. Open minded people only please, no abuse because i only want advice...  No i am not insane, i'm perfectly fine, and open about the paranormal ^_^



</question>

<answer>



I have just completed a psychology course and can tell you one thing, when it comes to the mind, memory and dreaming there are more theories and viewpoints as to their nature than would be possible to list here! Some would say that your feeling of a two-part memory is normal and healthy according to their theory whilst others would not. However, despite what they may or may not think, your own mind certainly shouldn't scare you! It is an incredible thing. For example, your description of your holiday sounds like a 'photographic' memory. Many people report being able to remember highly detailed and vivid memories of past events. Were you perhaps very excited or very nervous at the prospect of this competition? Some psychologists argue that high levels of emotion when in a certain situation leads to a stronger memory of it. Others would say something different. In other words nobody can seem to agree on what exactly memory is or how it works and this is the same for dreaming, so try not to worry, you sound perfectly normal to me : )



</answer>



<answer from>



StingRay

world and all its' contents

</answer from>



<answer>



I cannot comment on your dreams because I know nothing about the subject.
What I can tell you is you have a short term memory and a long term memory. The short term memory is smaller than the long term and so it can actually fill to capacity if you are studying intensely over a period of time and that's when putting a book down and forgetting where you put it happens. The long term memory is not as chaotic and only stores things of long term importance, hence you can remember all those when you was 6 years old.
There is nothing abnormal with what you say, the majority of people experience it, some learn to cope with it, some don't even know it's happening and others know they can remember things from long ago but struggle with things they have learnt recently.
I hope this helps with, at least part of your question.



Source(s):



My own experience



</answer>



<answer from>



David H
Member since: 03 June 2008
Total points: 204 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, I am considerably older than you (53) but I think my memory works like yours does.  My family and friends are astounded at how clearly I can remember the most intimate details of my childhood (I can remember my grandmother holding me as an infant - I remember the feel of her skin, the sound of her voice, her scent, and what it felt like to be held by her) but I can't find my keys; I forget what I said to people yesterday, I have trouble putting events in sequence when they happened only weeks or months ago.



My biggest problem is that my dreams are so lucid and detailed, that sometimes I have trouble differentiating between dreams and reality - "Wait - did this happen or did I dream it? "  and I just don' t know the answer.



And yes, like you, there are some details like number sequences or specific things that I will remember forever and ever, and other, seemingly similar things, that I can write down again and again and not know.  I can rememer everyone's cell phone number in my family except my son's - what's that about?



I have no answer except to say that you are not alone, and you are (hopefully) not insane.  Everyone is different - you are who you are and you remember what you remember.



A very wise man once said (and I'm paraphrasing here), "When you fear that you are alone and insane, the discovery of a mind that thinks like yours is nothing short of a blessed event".



I hope I have helped you.



</answer>

<answer>



I'm glad you wrote this...



The exact same thing happened to me... only it was somebody that I worked with who I didn't know long...

I was 18 and REALLY naive for my age cause I came from an abusive past... I didn't know any better when this guy called me in the middle of the night to talk and then told me that he was having a party and that my friend who we both worked with would be there...

He told me to meet him somewhere and he would pick me up (since it wasn't in the same city where I lived)... I went in spite of my older sister telling me not to go that it didn't sound right... I didn't listen...

When I got to his place there was no one there and no party.... my mind wasn't working (it was like numbness or not feeling at all... just not processing - I had a lot of problems with dissociation from my previous abuse and was always vulnerable to people hurting me and using me).... I sat down on the couch and he turned on the television which was "already" set to a porn channel...

I excused myself to another room cause I was scared and didn't know what to do... (I had never been kissed even before that night - I know for "18")... He followed me into the room and started to kiss me and touch me... when I moved away he kept on doing what he was doing and proceeded to lift up my shirt and my bra... I told him I didn't want to but he didn't listen... I told him "not tonight" (because I guess I was trying to be nice)... He just kept doing what he was doing... I never had anyone see me like that before and I didn't want to be seen naked so I just said "turn off the light" (it's funny because after acting like he didn't hear me the first times I said I didn't want to he sure jumped up quickly when I said that and turned off the light).

I felt there was no option... I felt scared (in shock mostly... my brain wasn't working or functioning... I guess that was the best I could do to think on my feet)... After that night I had to wait for him to take me back because I didn't know how to get home because he took me to a city I had never been to before.

After that day... when he saw me at work he kept trying to get me to quit and everybody talked about me like I was a whore and he kept telling people bad things about me.

So yeah... every time I tried to talk about the issue people (mostly other women) would try and call me a liar because they were raped in a violent way by a stranger and I didn't know if I had the right to call it "rape" because I didn't fight back... I just sort of laid there like a slug.

That was my first sexual experience and my first kiss and after that my face broke out in massive acne and everybody knew something was up... I got made fun of for going through puberty at 18...

It was only once that I actually reacted to the situation and had a "real" emotion after being numb for so long... I became angry and full of pain and wanted to cut off all the hair on my head that he had touched... I just stood there in the mirror chopping off all my hair...

Till this day I feel guilty for sharing that with others because I don't want to be called a liar from those who don't qualify that as rape.

After that experience I also began to act out and acted like it never happened that I was fine and it was just another "experience"... (I truly wasn't trying... my body and mind had automatically took away all of my emotions).

It wasn't until later on I heard an episode of Love Lines with Dr. Drew where one of the callers said she had been raped while sleeping and when she woke up to it she just lied there and didn't fight back... Dr. Drew said that it had to come from abuse or dissociating during the experience (like you weren't there... your mind was somewhere else to protect yourself). That made it real to me and something to validate all that happened.



Especially since I was abused all my life which made it easier for people to know how and why to target me...

THANK YOU for validating that it is real and it can happen and that we don't have to be called liars or manipulators of truth.

<answer>



I would not consider this rape in a legal sense. You say you consented but asked him to stop. So did you consent or didn't you? Did you withdraw consent? I think you would have an impossible task proving to a court that he raped you.

Watch what you drink in future.

EDIT, I only just realised how rude, abrupt and insensitive this answer sounds, but I really don't mean it to sound that way. But it is true. Rape is notoriously difficult to prove in an English court, and for good reason. It can put a man behind bars for life and even if he is acquitted, the accusation can ruin his life, so the standard of proof needs to be very high. Giving consent and withdrawing consent can be hard to prove, and your actions as well as your words would have to be considered. I think you need to put this behind you, and seek help to that end if need be.



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=AmdrsB5BqIQiV6IDEPoKQMSxBwxe1ec.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk37228.txt</current file name>



<category>



Social Science



Psychology

<question from>



roulette's fingers
Member since: 24 May 2008
Total points: 1682 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



If a child behaviour displays this kind of behaviour, what does it mean



-the child is aged 3-5, sits in the corner always 
-washes or cleans himself whenever someone touches him
-does'nt say anything and is quite
-always wears the same clothes and whenever someone e.g wants to take the child's hat off or shoes, the child gets very upset. always wears the same.



Any psychology experts know why this kid is behaving like this? is it normal behaviour?



</question>



<additional details>



what type of autism?



the child recently took a holiday with a grandmother some where far away and has'nt seen his parents or house for a while



he does'nt talk to the parents only looks at them like he does'nt know them



</additional details>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Hello,

(ANS) If this is your child we are talking about then I think your worries & concerns are clearly outlined. I would suggest that it would be completely appropriate to have this little boy assessed by a child psychologist.

**At aged 3-5 a child normally starts to interact & learn how to play with other children of the same age. The fact that this little boy stays by himself in a corner is rather unusual & could indicate he feels safer by himself for some reason.

**Compulsive cleaning behavior is odd in that age group.

**Does he communicate when spoken too or asked a question by a parent (by mum or dad or any other adult?). Even something simple like would you like a drink or would you like to hold teddy? It could be that he is quite withdrawn for some reason that is not clear at this point in time? again this is something a child psychologist would be able to understand better than most people.

**Perhaps the same clothes indicates a sense of security & the familiar thus, taking the familiar away for no apparent reason causes the child to feel very insecure & so gets upset by this. It might not make much sense to anyone else but trust me the child knows why. It has its own reasoning here.

**DON'T JUMP TO ANY DIAGNOSIS YET!! until you have the child seen & assessed by a professional child psychologist.

Kind Regards Ivan.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



As an ex child counsellor and mentor i would have to speak first hand with the child's parents as there could be a link with something that is going on in the child's surroundings, these behaviours are signs of withdrawing and to a degree stress. The child would have to also be examined by a child psychlogist to dertermine any mental defects.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Always sitting in the corner, and excessive cleanliness for a 4ish year old is not a "normal" behavior.
Take him to his pediatrician, ask for a child psychologist.

Does your child respond to his/her name?
Can they communicate what they want?
Do they make eye contact?

You may want to get him check for autism..



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



This is worryingly similar to Autism when a child is withdrawn, has communication issues and displays some obsessive behaviours. Also being resistant to any changes and fastidious cleanliness are indicators. This child needs to be assessed by a Child Psychiatrist.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



From this it sounds like the child should be seen by a psychologist. Autism is a possibility but there could be other explanations. Are the parents concerned at all? Is the child able to speak, just chooses not to?

As for your questions about 'types', autism covers a wide spectrum ranging from those mildly affected and high functioning (such as Asperger's syndrome) to more severe and complex.



Source(s):



Background in psychology and speech & language therapy.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Yeah def get him to a doctor, sounds like some type of autism. Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



This is unusual behaviour for a child of his age to be displaying. I would suggest he be referred to your local child development team/ centre for an urgent assessment.
While autism is a possibility, there may be a number of other things going on in his life that his behaviour is a response to. It is not possible to make a diagnosis on the basis of one or two described oddnesses.



Source(s):



I am a home learning/portage worker with disabled children aged from birth to five. Also the parent of a son, now adult, with autism.



</answer>

<answer>



WAITING

Serene I fold my hands and wait,nor care for wind nor tide nor sea,I rave no more 'gainst time or fate,for lo my own shall come to me.
I stay my haste I make delays, for what avails this eager pace?
I stand amid the eternal ways
And what is mine shall know my face

Asleep,awake,by night or day the friends I seek are seeking me,No wind can drive my bark away,nor change the tide of destiny



</answer>



<answer from>



Heidi S
Member since: 18 November 2007
Total points: 2735 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Captains Log ....

I find that keeping a daily journal helps me maintain my patience and keeps me calm.  Its a great way to spill and sort out ones thoughts, feelings and frustrations.



Some of the things I have recorded and looked at again, in retrospect - have been right down hilarious.  Over the years I have written, mused, researched and collected enough materials, situations and characters to write several novels.



BTW .... it's a great way to kill time.



</answer>

Social Science



Psychology

<question from>



chadhage...
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Does the brain always have to run



i heard even when u sleep ur brain never stops thinking or running



</question>



<answer from>



krennao
Member since: 07 July 2006
Total points: 29314 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your brain not only controls your thinking but also it tells your heart to pump, tells your lungs to breath.  etc.



</answer>



<answer from>



shopahol...
Member since: 11 June 2006
Total points: 4472 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It doesnt. It still has to control your heart, lungs, digestive system, kidneys, etc. If it stopped running, you'd die. Certain parts "take a break" when they're not needed, but the part of the brain that controls organs can never rest.



</answer>



<answer from>



Proc em
Member since: 29 July 2008
Total points: 188 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



it's always working. when you're sleeping it still has to remind your lungs to breathe. it still has to ba able to wake up in a second. never stops.



</answer>



<answer from>



DJJD
Member since: 28 May 2007
Total points: 7341 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, its always on the go. Its what keeps everything working while you sleep. Mine is positively wheel-spinning as soon as I open my eyes. It drives me crazy, as I can never go back to sleep after a waking episode like that.



</answer>



<answer from>



kidgamep...
Member since: 25 June 2006
Total points: 265 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes, the brain alwayss goes
sleep or awake
think about it this way
it doesn't just control your thoughts and things you can control consciously 
ok basically, if your brain would stop
youd stop breathing
heart would stop beating
basically, youd die pretty quickly in your sleep
and im assuming you dont want that

so basically, BRAIN CANT STOP!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Nick P
Member since: 22 July 2008
Total points: 108 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The brain rests when you sleep.

There are two things that run though: the hippocampus and the neocortex.

The hippocampus is used as a temporary storage system that is cleared when you wake up so you can store more memories throughout the day.

The neocortex is a long-term memory system that stores things permanently.*

*This is all according to a new study that has been worked on over the past decade.



</answer>



<answer from>



angel.v
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 206 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, because it has to be on "stand-by" as back in the caveman age, we have to be able to get up quickly and run away from the bear when it wakes us in the middle of our sleep.



I guess there are many instances in modern life that we still need to function quickly.  Eg. When we sleep too close to the edge of the bed and are about to roll off.



</answer>



<answer from>



In pursuit
Member since: 26 July 2008
Total points: 1524 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The best way to think of it is a computer; if you look at computers they are modeled after our thought and memory processes anyway.

If you hit the hibernate button or sleep mode it can still maintain itself but on the lowest power possible giving time for all other parts to rest and use less energy.



But yes, it is always running.  If it shut down you would not be able to wake.



</answer>






<original file>index;_ylt=AoWX9_GJSm7EiBFobuUcZx97CAxbfa6.html</original file>

<question from>



Juan P
Member since: 17 July 2008
Total points: 90 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Stutterer in need of serious help



Hello. I need some help. Basically i live in Europe and i have stuttered since i was 8 i think. I have a high-school diploma but i am afraid to go farther. School gave me bad memories and i do not see myself going back there. The thing is, to have a good job i need to have some kind of post-highschool education. I dread job interviews.



So here i am, a young adult that is not even able to be good at a job interviews or simply attend school. I would like to leave my country and start something new elsewhere. I know that going to another country will not take my stutter away, i wanna go elsewhere for my own reasons. My number one dream would be to go to Canada or USA (i am hesitating when it comes to USA as life there can be dangerous at some places) and start a new life. IF not possible (immigration laws will surely prevent me from living in canada or USA), i'll try to go to england or ireland or another european country (it would be very easy to go there, especially London).

By starting a new life in another country i mean find a job there, then save money to pay for speech therapy and college (correspondence courses preferably) as i would like to work in the entertainment industry. I do not care about how much time it will take me to succeed in another country, i just wanna move on. I know i am being naive but i gotta do something and turn my life around.  I do not believe in the american/canadian dream but still i gotta do something.  I am afraid to do something because of my stutter.



Basically if you guys got some tips: for example where i could find a good speech therapist and support group in USA, Canada and Europe (England, Ireland, etc...) or tips immigration wise, etc... please tell me, you can even leave your email adress if you want, well whatever would be cool actually.

Thanks in advance.



</question>



<answer from>



who me???
Member since: 10 November 2007
Total points: 670 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



In addition to speech therapy, singing and acting are supposed to be good ways to overcome stuttering.  Maybe you could join some community groups.



</answer>



<answer from>



steffgwa...
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 146 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



hethetheth hethethetheth cris waddle



</answer>



<answer from>



Insomnia...
Member since: 08 May 2006
Total points: 4242 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi, I used to have a stutter, but I think you just need to shout out and assume a loud and brash personality (I walk around like a Dr. Joh becker from the 'Becker' show) and crank out sardonic cynicism at high volume about most things... it is hard to stutter when you are full of bile at many things in the world!



something that has helped me greatly is I went from being a bedroom guitarist to a party and bar player and singer.  I want to share the songs i love, (not my own, I don't really write) and love to get people singing along with me.  They do, and it is great, like flying!  I was also very self-conscous around girls, I conquered that by learning to dance, started Argentine Tango (one of the most complex dances) over ten years back, and have been helping to teach it for a few years now.  I can talk to a class, can approach a beautiful lady and ask her to dance, make conversation with her, and keep my cool.  I never thought I would be able to do that!



You can send me a message and I will email you back if you like.  You accept you have a problem, you want to conquer it... You are two thirds done already my friend.  One last push, and you have it!



</answer>



<answer from>



AnnOnnyM...
Member since: 04 July 2007
Total points: 15368 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



This might be of interest to you, it's the website of the British Stammering Association but it has a page of international links as well and lots of information and advice:
http://www.stammering.org/index.html



</answer>

<question>



Is it possible to lose common sense with too much complex information in the mind



</question>



<answer from>



Bethy4
Member since: 29 August 2006
Total points: 14626 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



No, "common sense", is the sense that we don't hear to much about these days, sure we have the five senses, and even there "common sense" isn't included, because, unlike the five other senses, once acquired, you can't or should I say, you shouldn't lose "common sense" and still attempt to function, but in time, "common sense" can be acquired.



God Bless.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ariel
Member since: 07 May 2008
Total points: 994 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes. this happens all the time. In decision making people who are experts in their feilds can make stupid mistakes with dire consequences because they are so distracted with all the other complex information thats involved, they forget to get to the basics and and treat the real issue.



Sometimes a novice is better at problem solving than an expert who has had more exposure to complex info for this reason. It's even got a name for it but I can't rememebr it..This may also explain beginners luck...the novice isn't weighed down by all the extra info (coz they don't really understand the rules), which could otherwise overshadow common sense.



</answer>



<answer from>



I'm Hare!
Member since: 03 April 2008
Total points: 8460 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Huh?

Seriously, a little information can be a dangerous thing but a lot of information can become a full hard drive. it may slow things down but it will not delete anything even common sense. Simply get your system wet wired and try to make fewer queries.



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=ArQ87kKJnWUaKQcvHIVfW0CxBwx9192.html</original file>

<question from>



Smiley
Member since: 17 July 2006
Total points: 2764 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Death, dying, bereavement - how do other people cope with these inevitable facts of life.  ?



</question>



<additional details>



Some days  like today, I just get 'set off' for want of a better phrase.  The whole day I just want to burst into tears and I have severe butterflies in my stomach.

Mainly I think about my wee girl (3) and it reminds me when I was her age and I remember when my folks were young and how hard their life was (money wise etc) and it is almost like the whole circle of life malarkey really gets me down.



It is really hard to explain but ultimately I am bereft at the thought of losing my folks, my aunt etc and all their generation of friends.  I also imagine rattling around this house in years to come when my daughter has grown and how ridiculous is this - she is only 3 but already I am just devastated.



I also am so so close to my Dad that I know when he does go I will never ever find someone who loves me that way ever ever again and I cannot imagine a life ever without him.



How silly is it?  It happens to us all and yet I try not to get upset but it feels like I am bereaved



</additional details>



<answer from>



clorox72...
Member since: 30 March 2007
Total points: 176 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The way I look at things may be a bit different than you, however, think of how hard life is for everyone, the pains you get everyday, muscle, headaches, sorrow, and then realize that God has a plan, and that plan includes death of people. This is not a BAD thing, but a Good thing, as people no longer have to suffer anymore, they will be totally and fully taken care of in heaven, and be with others they had also known who had passed away. Yes, you will be sorrowful when your father passes on, but realize he will be taken care of in a way that is impossible on this earth, and that he will watch you grow as well. I also see a nice lesson here in your question, your father taught you unconditional love, and that he loves you that much, return what he has taught you to your daughter, and your daughter will return that to her children as well, continue the good cycle your father has taught you, it's probably the best life's lesson you could ever learn, (most people never learn that lesson).



</answer>



<asker's comment>

<answer>



Twenty-five years ago I became a Buddhist. (Tibetan tradition)  It gave me tremendous insight into living, death and dying.  We in the west are so out of touch with the reality of death it's pathetic.  You may wish to read, "The Tibetan Book of Living and Dying" by Sogyal Rinpoche.

<answer from>



Jo
Member since: 30 April 2008
Total points: 2199 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



If your anxiety interrupts with your daily routine, and/or if  your sleep pattern is erratic, then you may have the onset of mild OCD which is usually due to extremely low levels of serotonin. If it is OCD and it is left untreated, it could progress to panic attacks and depression.



btw, children easily pick up on fear so, for your daughter's sake, I would visit your doctor.



</answer>

<question>



What is vanity? please explain it to me.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Vanity is the excessive  belief in ones own abilities  or  attractivness



An example, believing that you are the  most beautiful  girl in the whole school.



Your vane if you can't pass a mirror without looking at yourself



</answer>

<question from>



moving on

<question>



How can I recover from this emotional abuse?



I'm at my wits end with all this so any advice would be appreciated.



Several months ago, someone totally screwed my brain emotionally and I just can't seem to recover from it.  It's almost as if he set me up for a big fall and I took it all and then went on to tell lie after lie for him in order that he could get back to his real life without too many problems.  So not only did he take everything I had to give and then trash my life and my head, I then went on to make it easy for him to get back to normal and make out what a great guy he is.  I trusted him totally as I have known him all my life and I just should never have let go so easily.
I am just so angry with myself for falling for it all and for helping him get his life back in order whilst my own is under enormous strain.



I have ended up in a major depresssion which is starting to feel like more than I can stand, every time I think I am getting somewhere, something else happens to put me further back again and I cannot see a way forward anymore.  I have several other problems in my home life which is making it seem almost impossible to live.  Please help me out here, what would you suggest, not medication please, so I can start getting somewhere with all this because I am struggling on an minute by minute basis with what has happened.



</question>



<additional details>



Thanks, can't talk to my friends or family as they know or know of the person involved.  No sure how comfortable I feel about counselling but understand this may be my best option.



I do exercise, I do lots of running!



Wow, thanks CLGM for your reply (and everyone else for your helpful responses).  CLGM I do feel crazy and can't concentrate, I have brief spells where I feel I'm ok and that I'm going to be allright, then it comes back in waves and I feel like I'm drowning in the misery of it all again.  I'm definitely keeping too much inside, this happened 3 months ago and I still have not got through a single day without crying, sometimes for hours at a time.  I realise I need to speak to someone about this or else I am never going to be able to move on.  Thank you so much for your sharing your story and no you're not rambling, I understand what you are saying totally.



</additional details>



<answer from>



proud walker
Member since: 19 August 2006
Total points: 19301 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Firstly stop beating yourself up. We aren't programmed to expect people, especially those close to us, to be so rotten.

Secondly, know that you're not on your own. I guarantee there are hundreds of people here on YA that have been where you are right now.

Thirdly, don't expect a quick fix, something that has injured you to the core is going to take a while to get over.

All I can suggest is that you attend to your current problems one at a time to make some kind of order out of them. You can't focus properly when you're trying to deal with so many things at once.

Have you thought of writing a letter to this person telling them exactly how you feel and what you think of them? Write it, then burn it as ceremoniously as you wish.  DON'T post it!  Can't say it will make things alright, but guarantee it will take the top few layers of pain and hurt away.

Good Luck



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you all so much for your great advice and offers of help, it was difficult to choose only one.  I really do appreciate your thoughts, thank you.  I will try and work through things one at a time and see where I am a couple of months down the line. x



</asker's comment>

<answer>



There are a couple of web sites that you might find useful. These are based on Cognitive Behavioural Therapy  (CBT) which is evidence based.

You have to register with the sites however registration is free.

As mentioned above, work on one problem at a time and break that problem down into achievable goals.

Good luck and hope you're soon starting to feel in control of your life.

<answer from>



Cure love, Get married
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



First let me say you are not alone. I ran for my life on June 12, 2008, and had to travel 350 miles before I could lay my head down to sleep. I have since made 2 trips back to deal with protective orders, pre-trial divorce hearings, etc. I am also a healer, and someone who after 49 years of being dissapointed still believe the rest of the world lives by the same moral code I do.



May I suggest you call your local domestic abuse shelter, and ask them about support group meetings? If someone had told me that 2 months ago I would have balked big time. I have attended 6 two hour "empowerment" meetings, and each time I walk out I feel better for at least a little while. You will encounter women who have had the same experiences as yourself, along with women who in far worse situations than you can imagine.



It helps to see what others are going through in order to see your own life in a real time sense as opposed to the bubble you have surrounding you. You are probably dealing with a million different thoughts going through your head all at one time, you can't focus on anything for more than a few minutes, you find yourself trying to say something and the simplest word escapes you. All of these things are normal and to be expected. It is called battered women's syndrome, post traumatic stress disorder, or many other taqs. Whether you experienced physical abuse, emotional abuse, or verbal abuse, each of us are affected differently than others from the same experiences. I am rambling and I know this, but truly want to reach out and help you as best I can.



Know this: It will get better! Today may start off bad, and end great. Tomorrow may start off great and end up sucking. Each day you wake up is a clean slate, so do with it what you can. Set small goals. For now set goals by the minute, then work up to the hour, and so forth. I have also gone to two therapy sessions, and have gained a world of comfort in knowing I am not "crazy." I have a strong need for valedation, but also realize it is not always possible. Those closest to  you will not necessarily be the ones to help you. Today is Sunday, and I have found in the past couple of months there is a great need for shelters, gardens, whatever where women (and men) can go and just "be safe'"



I am sorry for rambling, and I hope you are able to get something out of all of this.



http://mentalhealth.samhsa.gov/publicati...



You can contact me via email  if you want. I will call you if you need someone to talk to right now.
Denise
P.S. Be careful who you trust now, and for the rest of your life. I am not saying to change who you are, just to set boundaries and be sure to keep everyone outside of those boundaries. Physical and emotional boundaries.



P.S. I am living with my overbearing, controlling mother, I can't seem to find a job, I hate cat hair she has 5 cats, I hate being hot, it is hot as H&%^ where I am. I carry a gun, I look over my shoulder constantly, and I have no friends where I am.... so I do understand how you feel, and then some.



Source(s):



Personal experience



</answer>



<answer from>



Jenny
Member since: 11 July 2008
Total points: 38 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Emotional abuse is awful. You tend to think of it and try to make sense of it all. You need counselling and to vent it all out. Try writing it down and finding ways to express how you are feelings and felt at the time.
I was emotionally abused in my teens by a step relative. For years I was full of shame, anger, hurt and confusion. Now I am a performer and managed to use dance to express how I felt and created the whole situation in art form. Also I had counselling, it took a lot but I am over it now and look back and laugh at the abuser.

<question>



Why don't dreams ever make sense?



I had the weirdest dream last night and it made no sense at all. But it was really detailed.



</question>



<answer from>



Skylar
Member since: 16 September 2007
Total points: 2535 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Some of them do, but you have to think a little. Like i had this dream twice where my teeth either fell out or turned all yellow. It was terrifying and the silly thing is that both those nights i forgot to brush my teeth because i was wayyy too tired after babysitting and i guess my dream was warning me.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thats really interesting, I never thought about it like that. I'm gonna start looking for a deeper meaning in my dreams.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



starbuck...
Member since: 17 November 2006
Total points: 821 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



They don't make sense because you don't have any control over them--unlike your waking life, where do you have some control over your daydreams. Dreams are a jumbled mix of all your emotions and experiences, so it's not going to make much sense when put together.



</answer>



<answer from>



bluepill
Member since: 02 June 2006
Total points: 4806 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



dreaming is the result of a clash between conscious and unconscious brain. your thought of being right disagrees about a previous chosen thought or action. In religion term, you just made a sin. it manifest in your dream
its like your memory cells is trying to reconnect, it passes through your stored visual memory, kindof synchronization lost.



</answer>

</answer from>



<answer>



I currently study psychology and read a lot on my own time and in school.  I have the answer to your question, and you are not going to like it probably since most people do not like to read.  I assure you this will fix most if not possibly all of the problems you listed.  There is a science or branch of psychology called Neuro Linguistic Programming which is used by many self help/motivational speakers like Anthony Robbins only he  calls it Neuro Associative programming.  It is a psychotherapeutic approach to the problems most people face in their day to day lives.  If you want to know the science and apply it to your life to fix all of your problems read some Neuro-Linguistic Programming books which I'm sure you can download online.  I am currently reading one called Sleight of Mouth by Robert Dilt very mind blowing stuff.  If you simply want the benefits( fixing all of your problems),  pick up the book Awaken the Giant Within, its an Anthony Robbins book.  It's really good and extremely commonly used by CEO s, professional athletes....etc to improve performance and people's lives in general.  If you choose to read Anthony Robbins book do keep in mind what he is saying is based off science no blind faith is required.  I would recommend the NLP but if you don't have the time at the least read Awaken the Giant Within.

Your problems result from your unconscious or subconscious mind, since you consciously want to stop doing the things that you do but you can't.  So in order to do this, you must change your subconscious mind to do the things you want it to do.  Some NLP (Neuro Linguisitic Programming) techniques will help with this, for example are affirmations.  Affirmations from an NLP perspective is writing down what you want to accomplish twice everyday, in the pass tense as something you accomplished.  For example,  "I studied 4 hours today and ate healthy." Consciously this may seem silly, but remember we are not dealing with your conscious mind we are dealing with subconscious mind and the only way to penetrate it, to get rid of your bad habits and replacing them with good ones, is through different techniques that have been proven to impact/change it. This is one of the more powerful techniques that you should immediately start implementing, I guarantee you will see results within a week if not immediately.  Other techniques deal with viewing tasks in positive ways or different ways then you currently do to change your view or perspective on a situation or task.



All good things take a little time, I strongly encourage you to pickup, or download a book either NLP or an Anthony Robbins one.  The Anthony Robbins book will have most if not all of the things you will need to know for the immediate problems listed, but the NLP books are just so damn fascinating, applicable to your own personal life(the problems you mentioned), business life, social life.....etc. Anyway I hope this helped. Feel free to ask questions. Good luck.



</answer>

<question from>



Colin Strause
Member since: 14 May 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What are your tips for coping with moments of fear?



Watch me asking this question on video here http://uk.video.yahoo.com/watch/2678584/...



</question>



<answer from>



Spacepha...
Member since: 13 February 2007
Total points: 26331 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Drama



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



I reckon Frank Herbert had the answer in his novel "Dune". Just repeat this litany in moments of fear.

"I will not fear. Fear is the mind killer. Fear is the little-death that brings total obliteration. I will face my fear. I will permit it to pass over me and through me. And when it has gone past I will turn the inner eye to see its path. Where the fear has gone there will be nothing. Only I will remain..."

If you replace the word "fear" with the word "pain" in the above, it helps with that as well.



s



</answer>

<answer from>



psycholo...
Member since: 02 October 2007
