<answer>



DSM-IV Definition



Antisocial personality disorder is characterized by a lack of regard for the moral or legal standards in the local culture. There is a marked inability to get along with others or abide by societal rules. Individuals with this disorder are sometimes called psychopaths or sociopaths ...... So, obviously not, when you look at the amount of caring people in society !



</answer>

<answer from>



Ryan
Member since: 11 March 2008
Total points: 300 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



In a typical case where it isn't a chemical imblance, it's usually just that the person isn't emotionally capable of dealing with life. They arn't cowardly, they're overwhelmed. It's not that they're afraid of dealing with life, but that they  feel like they are suffering through their own emotionaly problems every day. A lot of times they feel like it never gets better, and like any good times are overshadowed by the much longer bad times. They may feel alone or isolated because they can't share these feelings with people who are close to them for fear those people will not want to deal with something like that or they will make them get professional help which they may not want. Many suicidal people don't like being rationalized with, because many of their reasons seem rational to them. Often, depressed people don't have good relationships with the people around them including family or spouse, or friends. They may feel empty inside and pain or cold may seem to them like 'the only thing worth feeling'.
They typically underestimate the pain they would cause their loved ones, or feel that in the grand scheme their loved ones sorrows would pale in comparison to what they believe would be a better world without them. Suicidal people often want a lot of attention or affection, and don't get it from their loved ones. They also may feel unapprectiated and need more praise than most people for the things they do. Suicidal people often feel they are horrible people, or others extremely good people who don't fit into the world. Either they feel they make the world worse, or that they are the only good peopled in a jaded world.
Suicide is never the best choice, but for a lot of people it is better than continuing to deal with their lives the way it is. Still, life can always get better if you try hard, and most people have family who WILL help if asked to.



Source(s):



I was suicidal from the ages of 13 to 15.



</answer>



<answer from>



B.BR.
Member since: 05 July 2006
Total points: 2 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<question>



He called me a trophy wife?



I went to a party with my husband, who I am newly married to, and he introduced me to his "good friend" who is supposedly important. The man just looks at me, and then says to my husband "I see you've been doing pretty well for yourself, even got yourself a trophy wife." That made me so mad, and I told him that was such a rude thing to say, and now my hubby is upset with me. Did I overreact or was I right to be insulted? And shouldn't my husband be more upset with him for saying that?



</question>

<answer from>



Publius
Member since: 05 August 2008

<answer>



What a jerk. You're right to be upset.

Your husband has no right to be upset with you. The phrase "trophy wife" denotes that the primary reason that your husband married you was for your looks, which may almost be positive and, if anything, more of an insult to your husband than to you, but it also connotes that you are otherwise unworthy of him and that you're otherwise worthless. You need to have a serious conversation about this with your husband.



</answer>

Joe
Member since: 15 March 2008

Guys usually give these compliments to each other, sometimes more acid than others. If it was indeed a good friend, then it's probable that he didn't mean it in bad spirit. It's not really the kind of compliment I would give, cause I can see how it can be misinterpreted.

<answer>



Pointing out that a friend has a "trophy wife" is a compliment that guys give to each. It is a back-handed compliment that you are good looking, and/or that your husband has achieved such a status that he has "earned" you - much as many professional athlete's have "trophy wife" models for wives. It objectifies a woman, but it's harmless enough. A local radio station even sells "trophy wife" t-shirts made in ladies sizes and they sell out of them each mother's day! I don't think you should be angry and you have taken his friend's joking the wrong way.



I think if I was your husband I might be upset too, as you embarrassed him to his good friend who was actually trying to give him a compliment, in a round-about kind of way. His friend now knows that you do not have a sense of humour due to your reaction, and your husband is probably pretty embarrassed that he was just introducing you and you told his friend off! Awkward!



</answer>

Elmbeard

Contributing In:



Singles & Dating

<answer>



Good on yer girl!

Reminds me of that scene in the film "Shadowlands" where a professor colleague of CS Lewis expounded with a sneer about men having intellects and that women only have "souls".  Joy Gresham (the American writer who became Lewis's wife) squared up to the distinguished professor and asked him if he intended to be offensive or was he just stupid?

I am sure it was said light-heartedly and rather thoughtlessly, and was a bit of small talk to congratulate your husband on his recent good fortune, not said out of malice.

Trophy wife is not really so much of an insult to you (it means you are good looking) as much as it is an insult to your husband (meaning he cannot attract a good woman who loves him, he can only buy a good looker who thinks nothing of him).  You stood up for your husband as much if not more than you stood up for yourself, and you stood up for your marriage most of all.

Pity your husband cannot read this and realise this. My guess was that he has to contend with oafs all the time (especially if they happen to be his boss!), and the best thing to do often is just to ignore their thoughtless comments and get on with life.  That may be his way, but it doesn't have to be yours.



</answer>

</answer from>



<answer>



find some positive outlets of your feelings. for me, writing helps a lot. if not writing, then try drawing, listening to music, reading, or even physical exercise. take care of yourself, eat right,drink plenty of water, and if your really stressed do something active. go on a run, jump rope, anything to get your body moving and your heart pumping. be around people who care about you, people who make you laugh and smile.



Source(s):



personal experience.



</answer>



<answer from>



mannasug...
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 251 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Depression is a state of mind. How did you become depressed? Wake up every morning and tell yourself " I AM HAPPY TO BE ME" Make a list of everything that makes you Happy. Also make a list of everything that you are grateful for. Forget all the things that make you sad or depressed. Do not listen to your sub-conscious mind that tells you, you are depressed, eventually your new understanding of how awesome this world is will dominate your thoughts. This is a beautiful, wonderful place to live and exist! Wouldn't you love to be part of Heaven on earth? The decision is yours.



Source(s):



Unlimited Power, by Anthony Robbins



</answer>

<answer from>



rated_in...
Member since: 21 July 2008
Total points: 973 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm going to give you the same answer I gave someone else for a very similar question a few weeks ago:

"When we first meet someone, a whole series of assumptions are made. There is what is called the 'implicit personality theory' developed by Asch where minimal information about a person can provide us with a coherent idea of what that person might be like since we're already in possession of pre-existing knowledge which evokes more information about that person. Sometimes, the easiest way to do this is simply to size a person up based on what they look like and this does not necessarily provide accurate assumptions.

Asch also maintained that the order you receive information about a person is also important in impression formation. That is, if a person shows positive traits before negative ones (e.g. intelligence, industrious, critical, stubborn), they create a better impression but if they were to show the negative traits before the positive ones (e.g. stubborn, critical, industrious, intelligence) , a worse impression is formed in spite of the person being exactly the same. It is important to realise that looks are often the first thing people recognise in another person and can dictate what they think of the rest of that person.

It is easier to perceive a person superficially. The modern information processing theory of social cognition in psychology maintains that social information processing is effortful and that capacity is limited and so, superficial strategies (or mental-short cuts) are undertaken instead of deep-processing strategies.

The importance of attractiveness is therefore overjustified. People see attractive people as intelligent, successful, happy, 'deserving', well-adjusted, socially skilled etc. = the what is beautiful is good stereotype (This stereotype can be seen everywhere e.g. the the Wizard of Oz Dorothy says to the good witch "witches are old and ugly" and the good witch says "only bad witches are ugly"). This is a self-fulfilling prophecy where because people have these expectations and act in response to these expectations, it comes to be so that attractive people are less anxious, more popular, more sexually experienced etc. All because it's cognitively easier to process a person superficially, meanwhile, people are saving deeper processing for getting to know someone after they've made their initial judgements."



Source(s):



My Social Psychology Course



</answer>



<answer from>



Robert David M
Member since: 26 October 2006
Total points: 13053 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Good question.

Two ideas come to mind immediately.

"categorize".

prioritized order defining how something works or is man-made 
for value constitute how you judge something.

Either way, they're dealing with appearances and
recognition silhouettes--not with the reality of the thing
or person they're supposed to be really understanding.
not irrelevances, appearances, etc.



</answer>

Member since: 24 May 2006

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



While it is alarming, the American populace is one that if they didn't experience with their own eyes or do it first hand, then it didn't happen. Do I think this is wrong? Not really. In school we are taught to question everything. So, why not question if we really did walk on the moon or if it was just a made up event to take our eyes off of the troubles of the world if only for a brief moment? And why not wonder if perhaps 9/11 was perpetrated by the US Government or even the Jews? After all haven't you seen Wag the Dog? Besides, it gives the old timers something to talk about and debate and gives you a question for answers!!



</answer>

<answer from>



fyrecrow...

</answer from>



<answer>



Not sure what your bad thoughts were, but for me, after finding my ex-wife with my best friend, I would replay the event in my mind until I had worked myself up to a frenzy and then I wanted to destroy pretty much anything in sight.  I would think of new and different ways to punish her without physically harming her, but ultimately it was tearing me apart.



I found that when I would get so worked up, the only thing that helped was to physically stop whatever I was doing, take a few deep breaths and say to myself, "this is not solving anything"



It helped me to take a few minutes for myself, and focus on the fact that being pissed off about something beyond my control was counter productive.



Unfortunately, there is no "happy all the time" method. If there was, what would be the point of even being alive. My theory is that if some days don't totally suck, then really great days, would never be really great, they'd just be ok.

Try taking some time to think about you, and what you can contol and what is beyond your control, then focus only on what you can do.



</answer>

If they have Everything that they want...... Maybe they will Leave You Alone!!!! Also, it will help you to Accept it and no Longer Upset you. I have done this and it Works--- Every Time.

<answer from>



johntada...
Member since: 06 March 2006
Total points: 4955 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



If they're bad thoughts about you -- for example: I'm a bad person, I can't do things right, I'm a loser -- try thinking of affirmations instead. Make a list of things you do well or things you're considered good at. Ask yourself the question: If someone asked my friends what good qualities I have, what would they say? Write down the answers. Keep them with you. Whenever you have a negative thought, look at your list of affirmations to remind yourself what you're good at.



</answer>



<answer from>



flutterb...
Member since: 19 May 2007
Total points: 5991 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Three R's: 
Recognise the thought as negative
Reject the thought
Replace the thought with a positive one.

Check out the bible -eg Phillipians 4:8
Whatsoever things are true, whatsoever things are honest(noble), whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things pure, whatsoever things are lovely, whatsoever things are of good report; if there be any virtue and if there be any praise, think (meditate) on these things.



( Phillipians 4:8 )



</answer>

<question>



I recently got raped and I want justice...if not...revenge.?



I got raped a few nights ago. I contacted the cops immediately after it happened, and they're going to have me talk to a detective and see what we can do from there. I've been keeping myself busy to block the images from my head and whenever I remember the scenario I get angry and think of a million ways of killing the guy that did this to me. I know where he lives and where he works, I want to shoot him and watch him suffer, blow up his store, burn down his house. I know that those thoughts aren't options and I'm better than that but I don't know what I would do if the cops don't do anything and let him get away with it. Tonight is my first night at home since that happened and I can't stop thinking about it or how icky I feel. It's finally starting to hit me harder and I know it's only going to get worse. I know that revenge isn't the way to go but I've lost my sanity enough to go ahead and do the things I mentioned...I don't know what to do. If any one's been through this road before I need some advise please before I lose it.



</question>



<answer from>

The memory will never faid, but you can move on.. The police will do what they can, but you cant let it ruin your life!!! dustin4actor09@yahoo.com

<answer from>



NurseKat...
Member since: 30 August 2008
Total points: 790 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am sorry for your situation. It is one that I can not say I have ever been in. You are definately not alone and I can imagine that most people who have been raped have had this same idea/ obsession about hurting the person who did this. Did you not get any referrals to support groups? If not, try reaching out to someone to help you find one, or someone to talk to that has been through the terror that you have endured. This is going to take a LONG time to get over, if you ever do. You need to find healthy ways to deal with your feelings and not bottle them up. I am sure you are still in a state of shock right now, but in time, I think you will be able to attain the coping skills you will need to deal with this. You can not do it alone though- talk to someone!



</answer>

delive_r...
Member since: 09 June 2008

<answer>



I know exactly what you are under going through. I had joined a help program before concerning those abandon and rape young kids in the streets. Rage burned in their hearts to get justice but as you said this is not the best option you have, you are only becoming one of them in the long run. We give advice on how to cope on these present crisis to live again and forget the past, but I know it is easily said than done.

If you want justice, you should have enough evidence like medical report of rape from a doctor. To determine the physical evidence that you are indeed rape by the suspect. Second, filing a rape charges against the suspect, third witnesses or evidence from the crime scene. Killing him will only make you the monster, while here the monster is that guy not you. I too have the same reason, if that happen to me revenge is a sweet answer. But on the second thought killing another person is not the solution to everything. Let the sword of justice fall on those wrong doers not to the victim. Even if you kill him the thought of the rape is still there in your mind, the only consulation you have is that you killed him.  What you need is seminar and therapeutic consultation to ease the pain or burden of these crisis in your life. A person who feels helpless need a hug or a tap on the shoulder, but to you much more is needed of course.



</answer>

sdfdsf43...
Member since: 04 May 2008
Total points: 580 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think music alone is the answer.  Music has never abruptly changed me from being in a bad mood to being in a good mood.  However, I also vehemently disagree with turning to religion to make yourself feel better.  Most religions I have learned about involve suppressing your natural urges in order to steer clear of 'sin' or whatever equivalent.



I think the secret to true happiness is just letting go of the things you cannot change, and enjoying your life for what it is.  Be happy with the cards you are dealt.  Look for the positives in every negative situation, as there are almost always some, at least minor, good things that can come from these situations.



Source(s):



living



</answer>

good luck and BELIEVE in ANYTHING!!!!

<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



Noru.
Member since: 18 July 2008
Total points: 1644 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Singles & Dating



</question from>



<question>



What are some good ways to get into a positive mind-frame?



I hate depression and thinking so pessimistically.



</question>



<answer from>



Mickei A
Member since: 08 September 2008
Total points: 236 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



1. BREAK IT UP

Whatever your goals, whether it is losing weight, writing a book, or getting fit, the key is the same: break it up. A student facing five or more years of med school might think of the task ahead as daunting; how will she ever learn all that stuff! But how many people have done just that? The answer is simple: one day, one chapter, one step at a time.

When I first joined my local gym, I was overweight and totally unfit. I had never done any exercise harder that walking, and I set myself the task to start running. My instructor told me to set the machine so that I would run for 30 seconds, no more. 30 seconds doesn't seem like a lot, but when you're as unfit as I was, it feels like half an hour. So I tried it and yes, it was hard, but I did it, and the small sense of achievement stayed with me a lot longer. Soon I was running for a minute, then five, then ten, and after a while I started measuring my training in distance, not time.

Don't set yourself too hard a task to begin with. Success breeds success, so keep it small, and before long you'll be surprising yourself.

2. THE GLASS HALF FULL

If you encounter a setback, try not to think of it in negative terms. If you can see the positive in a situation, you can learn from it.

So if you didn't get that job you wanted, don't be down, think of the things you learned at the interview that might help you succeed next time.

If you're trying to lose weight, and have a disaster of a day, don't think: "well, I might as well give in". Instead, think of all the good days you've had, and how well you've already done. Everybody has a bad day, but you know what? There's always tomorrow. You can start again.

3. DON'T BE DEPRESSED

Everybody has bad days, days when they can't be bothered, or don't have any energy. The key is to turn bad days into good days. How? Be good to yourself. If you're feeling in a bad mood, put on your favourite music, treat yourself to an ice cream, take the dog for a walk, whatever you know will improve your mood. When you're feeling happy, you can achieve so much more than if you're grumpy and sad.

4. DON'T THINK!

If you're the sort of person who can talk yourself out of anything (I'm one!) the key is not to let yourself do it. I can find any excuse not to do the things I really need to. If I find myself thinking: I won't go to the gym today, instead I'll check out my friends on the internet I stop and start trying to name every state in the USA. Any distraction, TV, radio, even counting the roses on the wallpaper will do! If you don't think about it, you can't talk yourself out of it. And once you've done it, you'll feel a lot better for it, believe me!

5. NEVER SAY "I CAN'T"

We've all done it. We watch people running a marathon, doing a bungee jump, even more everyday things like learning to drive or going for a promotion at work. We think about it and say: "no. I can't do it." Well, my view is how do you know, until you try?

At the beginning of this article I told a story from the days when I couldn't run for a bus, yet now I regularly run five or six miles. If you had asked me back then if I would ever be able to run that far, I would probably have laughed at you. But now I'm doing it, and if I can do it, so can you.

We are all capable of far more than we think we are. So the next time you see that promotion advertised, why not give it a go? Think of it this way: if you try and fail, At least you'll have tried, and you might find your boss is impressed with your ambition and recommends you for another position. If you don't try, you won't get the job, and you might always wonder: 'what if?' And you might get the job!

It's not difficult to start thinking positively. You really have nothing to lose, and a lot to gain. It could even change your life!



</answer>

<answer>



- think about all the things you have accomplished in life.

- focus on the positives in situations, try not to think just negative.

- surround yourself with positive friends who don't bring you down.

- when you start feeling down, listen to some upbeat music, write in a journal, take a jog (exercise has been shown to give you a boost) or call a friend to chat.

best of luck :]



Source(s):



personal experience -- have been through depression & everything.



</answer>

<answer from>



Mesohrny
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



First of all, one must realize that in most cases that the answers to all psychological dilemmas are more often than not already within the mind of the one asking the question. In other words, one must examine themselves and identify the source of the negativity. Is it ones past failures and/or disappointments that cause this negative vibe? Is it an individual's current living conditions i.e. socio-economic levels, relationship problems or intra-personal skills that causes one's lowly state of mind? Once an individual can access their own current reality a goal can be set to create a new reality. Once the goal is set then an individual has to strive to reach that new goal at all cost. You might lose some friends with the new you. Some family members might not like the new you. Co- workers might talk about the new you. However, in spite of all of that you have got to determine you course and set sail for the new you and when you get there recognize that you have arrived “bask in the marvelous sunlight of your liberation". When you realize in your mind that the shackles of depression can be removed, with a mind that is determined to be liberated then my friend you become "Free".



</answer>

<question>



I am scum and I just want to quit?



Quit what, I don't even know.

I have been feeling horribly lately. I suffer from many mental disorders, including bipolar and schizo. My friend recently came out of a drug coma, which is upsetting because he has been to rehab so many times and has overdosed twice. My wife and I have been having horrible marital problems, my fault, and she couldn't take it anymore, so she took ournewborn son and left to stay in a hotel. I'm falling apart.

I am in therapy and on many medications, which aren't doing anything for me right now. I just want to die. I've attempted suicide 4 times. What should I do?



</question>



<additional details>



My wife was diagnosed with depression a while ago. She is so upset, I don't know if she will take me back



</additional details>



<answer from>



Joanne Marie
Member since: 29 January 2008
Total points: 1110 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



We all have those moments of weakness where we feel like we simply can't go on anymore. But truth is, we can. Think about all the people you will hurt and devestate expecailly your wife. You have a son, things may be bad now....but think about all the beauty in watching him grow in man. You were put in  this world for a reason, don't quit. As hard as it may sound you have to find so wat to get you life back in order....this is your life, you only get one....there is so much to see, touch and feel. Im sure you are an amazing person.



Find what you love doing, and go out there an make something of yourself because we are all braver and stronger then we think. Once you find what you love....everything just kinda falls into place. The first step is to learn to love and find youself and also realize that life is gift, its a beautiful one and embrace it.

Show your wife that you can get though this and make a better life for yourself. Just because she left, doesn't mean she doesn't love you anymore or has given up on you. Because as hard as it is for you, it is for her. Don't give up....don't leave your beautiful wife and son alone in this world because as much as you need them, they need you. Family never quits or gives up on each other.



The brave are simply those with the clearest vision of what is before them - glory and danger alike and notwithstanding, go out to meet it.



When there is something that you really want. Fight for it. Don't give up no matter how hopeless it seems. And when you lost hope. Ask yourself if your gonna wish you gave it just one more shot.



Here's my email, just in case you wanna talk more
Joannemarie35@yahoo.com

<question>



How do I stop comparing myself to other people physically and start accepting myself more?



I have had alot of problems with learning to love myself and accept myself for the way that I am over just the past few years.  I'm not sure what led up to this.  Maybe it could be because i'm almost thirty?  Maybe because most people are so stuck on the physicality of someone that I don't give myself credit enough that i'm an attractive person on the outside, therefore i'm always feeling ugly or just "ok" and always wishing I looked different.  I've tried all I can think of to not feel this way, but it's been in vain.  Anytime I see an attractive guy, I feel bad about myself.  I wish I looked like that person OR i'll just get frustrated and not watch tv or go out or read magazines or heck, even get online.  All in the fear that i'll see more beautiful people and feel even worse about myself.  I prepared dinner tonight and right as I was about to sit down to eat, I saw this guy on television and I suddenly lost my appetite.  Not because he was ugly, but because he was so attractive, I looked at myself and felt ugly.  Can anyone help?  I know other people out there know what this is and how it feels.  I guess i'm just hoping someone can give me some great advice to help me deal with it.  Thank alot for all your help.



</question>



<answer from>

<answer from>



Tweed Bunny
Member since: 03 October 2007
Total points: 500 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You know, I felt that way for a long time and it was so bad that I couldn't even talk in front of people because I felt so ugly and stupid. I found the problem was that I was consuming too much media. I was looking at magazines, TV shows, movies, and actresses that get paid millions of dollars a year to LOOK GOOD. And have their hair and makeup done by people that get paid millions of dollars a year to make them look good. And airbrushed models etc etc... I stopped spending so much time looking at that stuff and started working on myself - physically as well as mentally. I read books, took a guitar class, attended the gym. 
My advice is STOP looking at those images that make you feel bad about yourself. DO something to make yourself feel better. Do things that you have always really really wanted to do but haven't for whatever reason.
Much luck! :)



</answer>

<answer>



I would guess that the brain is like a super super computer..although our conscious memory is aware of very very little, our subconscious is super powerful...and is CONSTANTLY processing everything we see and do within the day...and it is running scenarios, scenarios to try and deal with any problems that may arise...or just anything that may arise, not necessarily problems but just situations, like sitting down and watching TV...

Ever notice than when you get a deja vou, it feels like you DREAMT it before? I would guess that you have already...out of the millions of possabilities you subconscious brain pours over (like a chess computer) on occasion it get it right, from all of the experiences you have it predicts what the future outcome will be- and you experience Deja Vou.

It seems almost supernatural, but that's because we use SO little of our brain in everyday life that its surprising that the thing records and processes billions and billions of things everyday, every smell, color, word, etc...Its all in there, we just don't use it. (like our pinky toe)



Source(s):



my subconscious.

<answer from>



CHRIS
Member since: 22 June 2006
Total points: 13117 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Want the honest answer - ? Go out, find and bring home my dead cat. It was one of the hardest things I have ever had to do. It was winter. He had had a heart attack and was frozen stiff under a neighbor's front porch stairs. He had managed to crawl in under there to die alone and in total peace. I was in tears and walking home with him in my arms, holding him as close to my chest as I possibly could, crying my eyes out. His fur was all wet with my tears when I got home. He was the dearest thing on earth to me. It was my turn to have to collect and bury my dear little friend. I had named him Baby Puss and he trusted me utterly. As a small kitten, he had originally been thrown out a car window  at a McDonald's drive through, all hunkered down in a small ball, cars rushing by him and was in total shock when I first got him. He lived a perfectly quality life with me for over fourteen years. He trusted me totally, and would sit beside my big chair in our living room waiting for me to come home from work volunteering at a local charity retail store. Baby Puss. He would wait for me beside my chair. He would always welcome me home again that way without fail. He would sometimes wait over an hour like that until I came home. Loyal...faithful... constant...my little friend.



Source(s):



I have been blessed to own and care for a number of precious cats, all of whom I have loved dearly and with everything in me, but this little orange cat was different. He had been scared to death and I nurtured him back to wellness over those fourteen years. When he died, something got ripped out of the front of my chest. I will never forget him and I will love him and I hope one day to hold him in my arms again. If that were to ever happen it would be my definition of Heaven.



Sent with positive energies from Chris in South Portland, Maine, U.S.A. I am 65, so I have an idea of what love means, and I can honestly say I loved Baby Puss...

That love will never die. Ever. Be well, My Darling, I still love you, as always.  - Chris.



</answer>

K.C.
Member since: 25 August 2008
Total points: 696 (Level 2)

<question from>



The Narrator
Member since: 21 August 2007
Total points: 169 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I feel like ending my life?



I've been thinking about it for a couple of months now but I never get myself to do it, I always think, "maybe next time". I don't even know why I'm on Earth because my life basically sucks and I know that many of you will think that I'm another teenager who wants to kill themselves but I'm not. I'm 16, I live with my mum and dad, I've never had a family other than them because my Dads family are a waste of time and my Mums are in another country. I've never ever seen them, I've never been on holiday either. I’m really ugly, I have buck teeth and I don't really have much confidence either, yet I'm forced to hang around with cool people at college. Nobody wants to be my friend, I'm guessing because of my appearance. I'm short (4"10), I sweat an awful lot... my college is a 25 min walk from where I live and everyday I have to stand 5 mins outside the college before I go in because I'm in a pool of sweat. This really gets me down. I've never really had any friends at primary school and secondary school, I mostly got bullied by my peers, this got worse in secondary school. Me and my mum always argue at home, I don't know why. She says that I have an attitude at home but when I'm outside I'm like a chicken, that's completely true. She can never take a joke, and I joke around a lot because I can't help myself and the way she just shuts me up or blanks me really winds me up so I just snap back and then it goes into an argument. I'm always rude to my Dad but I don't know why he takes it. I'm a loner; I have no friends, no cousins, nothing. Even if I do die, nobody would miss me... probably only my parents. I’m recently getting down because I’m girl; I don’t want to be a girl because it’s horrible. Boobs, other ****, it’s getting worse everyday and I can’t stop hating myself. I can’t stop looking at everybody else and wishing I were them, but they’re not THAT special, so why do I think this? I hate the way people look at me, the way they judge me by my appearance, just because I have buck teeth doesn’t mean I’m stupid. I’m actually moderately clever, I’m doing A levels at college right now but being by myself all the time gets me down. But don’t get me wrong, I am independent. I don’t know what to do… I don’t want to have one to one’s with anyone because I did all that in school when I was getting bullied and it doesn’t work, it’s all bullsh-t. I don’t know if anyone will have time to read what I’ve wrote but… I would appreciate advice.



</question>



<additional details>



Thankyou for the replies everyone, it definitely made me think a lot harder, and made me cry a lot too. I agree with Dodoria, the fact that I haven't till now means something, but each time I tell myself that I'm going to give it another go, something worse happens or I end up feeling shittier. I did make this friend in college who's in two of my classes but whenever class ends she doesn't want to hang with me but go with her friends from her other class, it gets me down. Sometimes I think she's a user, she even have me her appointment letter to give to the teacher today and I did it, I don't know why. I really should stand up to people. I'm planning on ignoring her tomorrow and see how SHE feels about it, my Mum told me once that it's only when you ignore people they want to talk to you. Again, thanks for the replies, it really means a lot to me.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Becky V
Member since: 15 December 2005
Total points: 3383 (Level 4)



</answer from>

Try to volunteer someone in your area and find out what your good at and see that doing for others will make you feel good.

Please don't do anything serious - you're worth it.

<answer>



I'm not going to say "Don't do it". This may sound harsh, but the fact that you have wriiten down the fact that you are taking your own life you probably won't.
My dad phoned me up one night when he found my mum had found a bew partner after her and my dad got divorced. He told me he was stood on Putney bridge and was going to jump.
I know how you feel about being bullied, I was bullied at school, always the odd one out and the more you try to fit in, the worse everything seems to become.
In regards to the sweating, maybe change your deodorant to one targeted for Men. I use Lynx. Men tend to sweat more than women and thus they protect against outbreaks alot better.
Also maybe carry a spare deodorant / body spray in your bag so you can quickly spray some on when you get to school.
In regards to your mum, the fact that your parents seem to be arguing is probably why they seem to be taking things out on you. Things that she would have found funny in the past are more than likely just frustrations and she can not explain this to you which makes her situation worse; hence the shouting.
Have you thought about possibly moving college, start somewhere new where nobody knows you or your past and have a fresh start.
Maybe take some time out to get your head sorted.
You don't sound like your suicidal, you sound depressed, again I do not want to sound harsh. Go and see your GP, explain that you do not want to see a counsellor as you don't think they can help. Maybe he can put you on some anti depressants. If you tell him you might be suicidal then the chances are he / she will not give them to you (overdose potenetial).
All I'm going to say is keep your chin up and remember you are not alone on this world. There are others out there who will be feeling the same as you.
Are there any club / activity groups in your area that you could join?
I hope I haven't come across to harsh, but I'm not going to mollycoddle you and in certain ways make you feel worse.
Just look after yourself, but please try and talk to someone.
Wishing you all the very best x

<answer>



I was suicidal off and on from about 12 to about 35, and the teenage years can be pretty sh*tty at the best of times.

I had a couple of different therapists. The first was for about 18 months and made no real difference to the way I felt about life. A bit like you said about your one to ones.



But I stayed with my second therapist for about 10 years, and he helped me to learn how to love life. So all of the sh*t that had happened to me over the years was all okay.

Talking isn't what it's about. It's being listened to and being allowed to express yourself and be you without other people making fun or having a problem with your attitude. It sounds like you get little of this sort of help in your life right now.

If you want my advice: find a young female GP locally and talk to her. If you don't have one at your local doctor's clinic, try a well-woman centre or drop-in centre.



But if you really want to do something about this, you will have to take advice that you might not like on the face of it. God forbid they'll tell you to take some happy pills and to come back in 3 months if you don't feel better. With any luck they'll give you some good advice you feel comfortable with and...well, that's just the first step.

I wish you well.

Mark...
(ex greasy-haired, braces wearing, introverted, bullied, parentally-controlled and thoroughly miserable teenager)



</answer>

<answer>



Please, please don't talk of ending it all......... I know you said you didn't want one2ones but try two things please........ The Samaritans are really practical people who have listened to people in your situation many, many times.  When you ring them they will keep it private - just you and your contact, so that's a help, and they won't have any silly short term answers.  They are prepared to spend hours and hours talking to you trying to sort out your problems (you don't have to meet them face2face it is all done on the end of a telephone.)  They will definitely not pressurise you into doing anything that you don't want to do.  The best thing they do is to listen to YOU and their aim is to help YOU over this period in your life.  I'm sure they will help so look them up in the phone book and give them a ring, I'm sure they will sort things out for you.

Second, if you don't want to do the above then ring your NHS Direct and ask them if they have a psychiatric department where you can talk to a psychiatrist.  This may not be as private as the Samaritans but I'm sure it will be a help.

The thing with both of these alternatives is that they are not a quick-fix, it will be long a term solution to your problems with an aim of helping you in the long term, which, seeing as you are intelligent and young may not take as long as it would with an old fart like me.

Good luck - hope it all goes well for you

Regards Rick



</answer>

<answer from>



vira
Member since: 30 June 2008
Total points: 1372 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, you should always tell the truth. If it's a painful truth, try to avoid saying it altogether; if you can't then you just have to, well, say the truth.

Although some truths are too painful to be revealed or when revealed, will cause terrible damage. In that case, a little lie might help at first, but the truth will indeed come out at the end anyway.

For example, when my aunt and her family died in an accident, our family lied to grandpa, telling him that she's overseas or something hence her absence. Telling him the outright truth straightaway would have caused irreversible health damage to him and will do no good at all. Eventually, he realised what had happened and took it hard, but I do believe it is better that way than revealing the terrible truth at one go.



</answer>



<answer from>



cmac
Member since: 22 December 2007
Total points: 11560 (Level 6)

fixer of all aka mom

<answer>



One great big red flag is the fact that he does not want your family to know him!!!! The first thing a potential abuser does is separate the intended victim from his or her family. This is because the victim now has no support system. you need to contact your local domestic violence shelter asap. I think you can do this by email. Or, call a friend and have them call for you. Also, try contacting your parents. Yes they may have disowned you, but that in and of itself is not a permanent thing. If the first thing out of your mouth is I love you and need your help to escape, well, it is a cold parent that won't help after that. Start going over in your mind what you will take at a moment's notice. be ready to leave as soon as possible. DO NOT STAY!!!!! He is setting you up to hurt you! First you, then the baby. Even though it is scary, you need to get out now and do NOT go back!!!!!



Source(s):



My own life experiences.



</answer>

<answer from>



Logics bar
Member since: 25 April 2008
Total points: 1313 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You are correct, you are under-going psychological abuse, but the question is why is he behaving in this fashion.



You might want to ask him "What you can I do to help you feel more secure?  "

What can you do to help him feel like you are loyal and with him.  While at the same time you might suggest to him that he is just being paranoid and it's really hard on you but you want to work with him to help show him that he has nothing to worry about.



You need to be more specific please, tell us how he is treating you that is treating you as a piece of trash, and what you are doing in response to or to invite this kind of reaction.  Many people are lashing out because they feel they are being cheated or let down and don't know how to communicate what is bothering them so instead they just act like jerks to the people around them hoping they get the message.



Edit: Fixer of all is correct about creating seperation, I am not certain about something in here, is this man the father of your baby, is did he come after the father of your baby?



Though I disagree about this idea of "setting you up for abuse" this almost seems to imply that his behaviour is designed intentionally to hurt you.  This is doubtfully the case, he is more likely just terribly insecure and well... a fearful coward that doesn't trust outside sources having influence over you.  You of course need to be thinking about you and your child's safety first, but it is possible that with some therapy he will be able to get past his insecurities, though the question is, is that the ideal situation for you and your child?

Space is wrong, do not ignore the situation, no offense space but if she ignores the situation it isn't going to get better.



I don't agree with CeeCee's method of standing up for yourself, but yes you should stand up for yourself and it is possible she is on to something suggesting he may be committing infidelity, for people to act strangely and jealously when they are cheating on you is very common.  It may also be a good idea to reverse the role on him to show him what it feels like to be tormented by a jealous lover, but tell him that's what you are doing so he can understand what it feels like, it may be a good method of making him more sensitive to your feelings.  But you have to tell him that's what you are doing otherwise it may look like you are just being mean and punishing.



</answer>

<answer>



I know it seems impossible to get out, but you must do it! He is showing signs of an abuser. Many women have been killed or permanantly scarred by boyfriends or spouses. They always start out by just being jealous and controlling. Checking the phones and keeping you isolated from family and friends is the first step. Make sure you have a plan to get out safely. I'm sure if you talk to your parents they will help you to get out. They love you. They want what is best for you. If they won't help for some reason,  get a job or get on public assistance. There are also shelters that will protect women and children. In the meantime, tell anyone that calls you to use *67 before they dial you so that he can't trace the calls. Speak to a neighbor that you can trust to watch for your porch light. If you feel you are in danger, turn your porch light on. Tell your neighbor that if they see your porch light on to call the police. Set up a code word with people you talk to on the phone that if you use the code word you need help and to call the police. As soon as you receive public assistance, go to a shelter. Just get out before it gets worse. You need to protect yourself and especially your child.

<answer from>



sunrise...
Member since: 16 June 2008
Total points: 865 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



depression is a long term thing where you constantly feel sad .



you can feel sad for a couple of days and then get over it. but getting over a depression takes more than a few days.



if it's a mild one it could take up to a couple of weeks or few months...but if it's more serious it will take much longer.



</answer>



<answer from>



Babby22
Member since: 29 March 2006
Total points: 1014 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



depression can sometimes be a react after a bereavement, or a tragic event, you tend to act out of character i.e scared to go outside or meet people, you tend to end up not living life but merely just trying to survive
the only way i can describe the feeling for me was like being stuck in quick sand; every piece of bad luck/stress/problem feels like an added layer of sand and you feel like you can't escape.

Whereas as feeling sad you can cry for a bit and feel better after the cry and can move on

personal experience

<answer from>



eeege
Member since: 19 January 2008
Total points: 946 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's perfectly normal.  I went through this at 15 and found that many people begin to realize the difference between real friends and fake friends.  (Erikson's Stage 6 - Isolation vs Intimacy)



A successful person will learn to be selective in those he calls friends and will put others in the 'acquaintance' slot.  Don't fully isolate yourself from the fake friends, but don't let them "in".  This will lead to fuller relationships with the real friends and the ability to make 'small talk' with those who aren't.



Since Erikson's theory has empirical evidence, it's best to keep in mind that at the end of your life, you want to be happy with the decisions that you've made.



(I believe it is also part of Maslow's level 3 and 4 - Finding those you belong with and getting respect from those you find valuable.)



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abraham_Mas...
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erik_Erikso...



</answer>

he's not crazy, but at times i am stricken with curiosity...



list of his traits:
- controlling
- parasitic
- constantly tries to hide his insecurities about his parenting abilities and functional abilities though insecurities obviously present
- doesn't value empathy, values or patriotism

- wants his children to be geniuses (although we're obviously not)
- a bit racist and holds right-wing political views

- not active in much of anything i have no idea what he does with his free times besides eating food and reading books

<answer>



human

<answer from>



eeege
Member since: 19 January 2008
Total points: 968 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



In looking at your description it would be difficult to 'diagnose' him because it appears that you've painted a rather negative picture of him.  This is because either he's a negative person or you are.  (iow, it's not a very objective description.)



In order to get a better view, get to know him better.  You need to have known him as a child, as a teen and as a young adult before you can fully understand why he is the way he is.



That being said, I agree with hopesclan: he's human.



</answer>

<answer>

<question from>



slices_o...

</question from>



<question>



How to get over food phobias?



Off and on I go through bouts of having food phobias, which is really odd and paranoid I know, but sometimes I have to actually stay in the kitchen with someone to make sure of what they're putting in food, and that it's safe, then sometimes I'll buy something at the grocery store, like say a loaf of bread, but if there's a speck on one piece of the bread that looks even slightly suspicious, I cant eat any of that bread.  this phobia makes me feel like a wasteful person, and makes me feel very guilty, also its hard to explain to a friend, when you go out to eat, that all of the sudden you re not hungry (which you are) because the meat has an odd hue, or the potatoes look as though they've been cooked with something else, or any other assortment of lame things that can look wrong with it?
also it makes others feel weird when I cant eat their food at their house and i have no reasonable explanation for this... other than i'm not hungry (which is an obvious lie if they've been with me all day and i've not eaten).
So how to get over it?? I've tried just eating it afterwords, but i'm so afraid of getting sick, that it sometimes makes me feel sick or even be sick, just because it could.



</question>

now its progressed to , 3 :11 , 6 :11 , 7:11 and so on , only in time though .. So today I figured I would type into google to see if anybody else has Experienced this strange phenomenon ..



and find Melinie with this posting



"When I look at the clock at random times,
its usually 1:11, 2:11, 3:11 etc...
Especially 9:11. "



needless to say I was shocked somebody had written the exact situation I was experiencing , down to seeing 9 :11 the most ..now that has to be such long odds of experiencing such a specific thing..



Question is , who else has experienced this odd phenomenon ? And for how long ?



</question>

<answer>



Lots of people experience this. I don't want to burst your bubble, but it is natural of the human mind to notice things that 'mean' something to them. The fact is that 11 is a memorable suffix to an hour, especially with 9/11 in many people's minds as it was drummed into us by the media. Chances are that you look at the clock many many times in a day (I never noticed how often I looked at my wrist without realising it until my watch broke), but because other numbers seem insignificant, you take notice only of 11.



</answer>



<answer from>

<question from>



Eddier
Member since: 07 July 2008
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How can i develop a better character?



Many people call me jerk, and i consider myself a good guy how can i change my ways?



</question>



<answer from>



Ollie M
Member since: 26 January 2008
Total points: 553 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Perhaps they are right. Perhaps they are wrong. Maybe you're delusional.



Do you think you're a jerk? What's a "good" guy? Is this the the "good" guy you think other people may regard in the same positive manner.



If its a girl whos calling you a "jerk", are you being sexist, vulgar, deregatory? Are you messing people around?



Do you treat people with the same respect they treat you. It doesn't matter, you should always treat people will respect even if they dont to you. At least you'll feel the better person.



Its easy to say: "Stop being a jerk". but we haven't even established the problem. It may be that there isn't even a problem. You consider yourself a good guy, but clearly other peoples opinion is important to you, so theres definitely some self doubt there.



Do you think you treat people with dignity, kindness and respect. If you do, then there should be no issue. If people think youre a jerk, then screw them. They are not worth your time. But if you think otherwise, try this:



Imagine every action you make and every word you speak. Imagine that someone is saying that to you. Comprehend your situation, their emotions, their feelings. Empathize with them. Can you ascertain a problem, does something not feel right. IF the answer is yes, maybe you need to change.



As much as i despise having to change, sometimes its necessary, but i certainly dont condone a whole personality "revamp" as it were. And that means you shouldnt pretend to be someone youre not, just to be well liked.



1. Treat Others with respect. Treat yourself with respect
2. Be kind and be fair.
3. Believe in yourself. But dont be arrogant.



Chances are if you follow these tips, people will see you for the "good guy" you really are.



Source(s):



Me



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Lol, u put it down straight thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



sinyorit...
Member since: 07 June 2008
Total points: 2424 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



There must be a reason why people call you a jerk. Evaluate your actions. Ask a close friend or a family member, "Why do people think I am a jerk"....dont ask them if they think you are a one because they might not be honest.



Think about how you interact with other people. Be deliberate with your actions. Would you say you are aloof? You may be a good guy, but the way you present yourself to others or even treat them make them think otherwise.



</answer>



<answer from>



Girl 1984
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 113 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I read this somewhere and have just copied and pasted it. It from an online agony aunt. Hope it is as useful for you to read as it was for me once.



Human beings are uniquely tuned into the world around them. We are born with the capacity to be shaped by our environment. We copy the sounds of our language, imitate the gestures of our family, vibrate with the emotions of others, absorb the feedback we get about how we should be. It's a huge strength, the bedrock of civilised society, the only route to proper togetherness. We call it empathy. Those who lack it are not very nice.
The challenge of maturity is to balance such empathy with a strong sense of self. Clearly, that's a difficult road to travel and none of us makes it entirely. Nor should we. Deaf to the sounds that others make, we become selfish, static, boring and very hard to like. Needing too much feedback, on the other hand, turns us into emotional blotting paper.



Find a balance.



</answer>



<answer from>



Marco M
Member since: 06 November 2007
Total points: 6982 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's hard to be a decent human being if you never had a role model to show you what that means in practice, but I'd suggest these self-imposed rules for starters:



1. Deal in reality. Don't lie to yourself or others.
2. If you make a promise, keep it.



3. Have compassion toward others, especially the weak.



</answer>

<answer from>



Dr. Bob
Member since: 23 January 2008
Total points: 17196 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



Wrong Yahoo site for this.



"Jesus" (Hebrew: Yeshua, or "Joshua") of Christianity and the New Testament is likely not to be an actual historical person, but a made-up religious hero similar to other fictive religious figures throughout history. There is nothing to suggest that he actually existed as a human being.



The Bible (specifically, the New Testament's four gospels, three of which are almost the same, present conflicting stories. There is NO credible evidence outside the four gospels.



Jesus is featured in the four gospels: Mark, Matthew, Luke, and John. None of these people knew Jesus. In fact, we don't know who they were, and the names Mark, Matthew, and John were added later to give the gospels credibility. Luke is likely to have been an actual person (a doctor who was a friend and companion of St. Paul).



Mark contains no birth or resurrection stories. It is the basis for Matthew and Luke; Matthe and Luke each include more than 90% of Mark. When we put the three gospels side by side, we see that they are almost identical. They are called "synoptic" (from the Greek: synopsis = view together) because of this "parallel" effect.



-- Mark appears to be the first gospel, and contains short stories of things Jesus is reported to have said and done. If Jesus actually existed, this gospel comes closest to giving the bare bones of the man and what he said.



-- Matthew includes nearly all of Mark, adds a few thigns, and re-arranges Jesus' life for his own purposes. "Matthew" wrote to convince the Jews of 65 AD that Jesus was the promised Messiah. In many places Jesus is made to look like the other great Hebrew leader, Moses. Thus his "sermon on the mount" is meant to remind Jewish readers of Moses on the mountain getting the ten commandments.



-- Luke is part of a set of two books (the other being "Acts") which gives a history of early Christianity starting with Jesus' ministry. Since Christians had begun to be a force in the Roman Empire, Luke went out of his way to present Jesus as no threat to Rome, and fobbed that threat off on the Jews. Thus Luke had the Jews, not the Romans, putting Jesus to death. It was this anti-semetic flavor that make Luke's gospel the favorite of Adolph Hitler.



So much of the three gospels is obviously "made up" to present a certain portrait of Jesus that we can't be sure what Jesus really said or did...except for the parables. These little stories to illustrate his points are general agreed to be the only true "Jesus words" in the Bible.



Matthew and Luke both have stories of Jesus' birth and resurrection. They are all different, and were obviously added many years after the original gospels were written, to prove something or other about Jesus. The Christmas "Nativity" plays combine them all. The birth narratives are so obviously full of fiction, falsehoods, and contradictions that they are laughable. (King Herod never called for a census. That was added to get Mary and Joseph to the place where the book of Isaiah predicted the Messiah would be born.)



--  John is the fourth gospel, and is entirely different fom the other three. It is aimed at countering the first Christian heresy: Gnosticism. In it, Jesus is a symbol and part of a secret code; only those who knew it would get into heaven. John treats Jesus as "the Word made flesh," or "incarnated." The Word being the cretive word spoken at cretion: "Let there be light."



The only other place the name "Jesus" appears outside the New Testament is in the two histories written by the Jewish historian, Josephus. Unfortunately, he slanted his histories to what those who paid him wanted to hear. When he wrote a history of the Jews for the Jews, he made the Jews sound good. When he wrote for the Roman Emperor, he made the Jews sound bad. There are a few references to someone named "Jesus" but these were clearly added some centuries later to give "proof" that Jesus lived. Since then there have been constant efforts to discover "the historical Jesus" because there is so little to prove that he existed at all.



So you ask: "Do you believe in Jesus?" Which Jesus are you asking about? There are as many views of him as there are Christian groups/churches/believers. And one of the biggest problems of all is that believing in Jesus does not make him "exist" any more than believing in Santa Claus or the Tooth Fairy makes THEM exist!



Source(s):



50 years as a UCC minister, New Testament Scholar, and a second graduate degree in the Jesus of the New Testament.



</answer>



<answer from>



Faerith
Member since: 02 October 2008

<answer>



I do find it strange that he stopped calling so suddenly if he felt anything towards you, either as a friend or more.  But not knowing the guy, its impossible for me to say what might be going through his mind.



You need to first ask yourself what you expected from him.  You ask, "Did I confuse him?".  Well you said you didn't want him to to be friends with you anymore, and now he doesn't ring.  So where exactly is the confusion?  I think, to be honest, that you are the one confused.



Were you hoping perhaps that he would make a decision between you and his girlfriend?  That is how it sounds from where I am standing.  Pehaps you were hoping that he would claim his undying love for you, or even just to carry on ringing and saying he wanted to remain friends anyway.



You need to sort out how you feel first, then plan your next move.  Do you want to try and rekindle the friendship?  Do you want to be his girlfriend?  Do you want to attempt to break up his romance (not recommended cos a real friend wouldnt do that)?



</answer>



<answer from>



eeege
Member since: 19 January 2008
Total points: 939 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Actually, you should stay away from him for the time being so he can evaluate his priorities in life.  He's kinda having his cake and eating it too.



You were right to separate yourself and the relationship he has with you SHOULD be with his gf.  (And I commend you being respectful of his gf's position.)



Chances are you are more valuable to him than his gf.  I seriously question any guy who says he's committed to a gf but then spends all his time with you.  If you mean that much to him, he'll find a way out of the relationship and find a way to be with you.



After all, you deserve his full attention.



</answer>

<question from>



skycat
Member since: 22 August 2006
Total points: 6522 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



Why do so many people worry?



</question>



<answer from>



anaeliau
Member since: 16 November 2006
Total points: 1885 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Because they realise they have only one life and they are trying to make the most of it.



</answer>



<answer from>



zeeshanl...
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 108 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its not only some people worry but i think they are more than some.It is because of your age growth.It is becasue of your home family environment.It is because of how your parents treat you in your younger age.I saw many peaople happy and enjoying even they were in bad times but i always saw smiles on their faces.Your environment is very effective on your feeling and thoughts. There is nothing to worry about short life.Every one knows that every living thing will die.



Source(s):



self opinion



</answer>



<answer from>



Sunflowe...
Member since: 17 December 2007
Total points: 7155 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



People worry because it alerts them to possible negative situations that might happen so that they can adequately prepare for them.



The problem with worrying occurs when it is a situation that they can’t do anything about or when it is a trivial problem or when they already have a solution but they continue to dwell on it.



When nothing can be done about a problem there is no benefit to worrying about it! Worrying brings physical and emotional ailments and damages interpersonal relationships.



In order to stop worrying people should identify the issue they are worrying about and think of resolutions quickly. Pick one and stick to it. Some people worry a lot because they are indecisive. I have found it best to quickly decide on a resolution, forget about it and shift my focus of attention to something else so that the negative feelings associated with worrying go away.



"The secret of health for both mind and body is not to mourn for the past, not to worry about the future, or not to anticipate troubles, but to live in the present moment wisely and earnestly."



Have a great day!



</answer>

<answer from>



Joy S
Member since: 04 November 2007
Total points: 2004 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



coma = unconscious state of being
comma = ,



anyway, Descartes said, "I think, therefore, I am!"



This is a deep philosophical question and cannot be proved one way or the other.  It is not a scientific question and I would ask your chemistry teacher why he asked this question in a "hard" science class.



We have at least 5 known senses.  Everything we KNOW is learned in some way through experiential means.  That is exactly what experimentation in science is...a means of experiencing facts.  The way that we  KNOW is of course based on the first KNOWING...self-knowledge.



God said that His name was/is, "I AM who AM"  God is the one who exists in all places and states at all times.  If God is the ultimate I am then humans created in God's image are also able to say, I am...I exist...



But while there is incredible scientific evidence for creation, the flood, and archaeological and literary evidence for the existence of the cities and ppl of the Bible and logical evidence for the reality of Jesus and His life, death and resurrection; there is NO scientific PROOF of the existence of God.  So no scientific proof for the existence of me and you.



</answer>



<answer from>



Amber
Member since: 04 August 2006
Total points: 371 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Watch the movie "Waking Life".  It is all about consciousness and what it really means to exist.  If you are open minded, it will get you thinking.



And to answer your question, I can't; and if I could I'm not sure if I'd want to



</answer>



<answer from>



WolfSpir...

</answer from>

<answer>

<question>



How to get over food phobias?



Off and on I go through bouts of having food phobias, which is really odd and paranoid I know, but sometimes I have to actually stay in the kitchen with someone to make sure of what they're putting in food, and that it's safe, then sometimes I'll buy something at the grocery store, like say a loaf of bread, but if there's a speck on one piece of the bread that looks even slightly suspicious, I cant eat any of that bread.  this phobia makes me feel like a wasteful person, and makes me feel very guilty, also its hard to explain to a friend, when you go out to eat, that all of the sudden you re not hungry (which you are) because the meat has an odd hue, or the potatoes look as though they've been cooked with something else, or any other assortment of lame things that can look wrong with it?
also it makes others feel weird when I cant eat their food at their house and i have no reasonable explanation for this... other than i'm not hungry (which is an obvious lie if they've been with me all day and i've not eaten).
So how to get over it?? I've tried just eating it afterwords, but i'm so afraid of getting sick, that it sometimes makes me feel sick or even be sick, just because it could.



</question>



<answer from>



Sonia
Member since: 27 September 2008
Total points: 156 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most food is cooked at pretty high temperatures...so most bacterias that could make you sick would die anyway. Maybe the only thing that you can do is to eat it anyway, even if it looks weird/gross, but only if other people are eating it too. Since you don't trust yourself to be able to know if something is okay or not, watch your friend eat it. Then you know that since they can eat it, so can you. So basically order what your friends order, or try to stick to the same foods...and over time you'll get used to eating that and then maybe you'll be able to start eating stuff that your friends aren't eating.



I don't think you should feel guilty. Sometimes I have to eat things that I think look weird or unappetizing..but then I eat them anyway and make sure to drink lots of water afterwards. I think over time you'll just get used to it and hopefully won't have to think about it as much :)



</answer>

<answer>



Philosophy is not giving thought to a question, rather it is like thinking up the questions in relation to the answers.  Finished in advance. Thus, if you say that every decision is perfect, there would be a perfect outcome, and because everybody is perfect, (God does not make rubbish) all outcomes would be perfect. Thus, the world would be perfect.  See the error in the reasoning?  The decision you make, is the one you must make, as you state so clearly.  Not because it is right or wrong, but because that is how you learn.  Some people need the same error 3 or 4 times before they get it, and some only once.  And the rules behind the decision are, nature, nurture, expectation, experience, trust, religion, ethnicity, etc.  All of them combined to a certain degree. What did the extended family, teachers, peers, acquaintances teach the child???  You are worthless!
Peace.

<question from>



the capybara

</question from>



<question>



Why do we worry about things? How can we stop this anxious state of mind? ?



most of the time if you rationalise it there is no need to worry so why do we do it and how can we stop it?



</question>



<answer from>



K B
Member since: 11 March 2007
Total points: 20648 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



There is never a "need" to worry, as worrying in itself can never achieve anything positive, or have any influence over events or other people. Worrying is usually a habitual behaviour, and is driven by fear of the unknown. In order to stop it, you need first to trust that whatever will happen, you can and will deal with it as and when it comes.



</answer>



<answer from>



deadloud
Member since: 08 July 2006
Total points: 3040 (Level 4)

<answer from>



Regina O
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 585 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



DO  NOT  WORRY



Jesus went throughout Galilee and the surrounding regions,  preaching the good news about God's kingdom and healing everyone who was brought to him.  Large crowds followed him, so he went up a hill,  sat down and began to teach them.  One of the lessons had to do with worrying about the daily needs of life.



Jesus told them, "No one can serve two masters;  you will end up hating one and loving the other,  or you will be loyal to one and despise the other.  You cannot serve God and money.  This is why I tell you,  do not be worried about the things in your life.  Don't worry about what you will eat or drink;  or about what clothes you will wear.  Isn't life more important than food,  and the body more important than clothes?  Look at the birds: they do not plant seeds,  harvest the food and put it barns,  yet your heavenly Father feeds them every day!  Aren't you worth more than the birds?  Who of you,  by worrying,  can add one moment to your life-span?



And why do you worry about the fashions or the clothes you will wear.  Take a look at the various wild flowers in the many fields around you.  They do not sew or shop for the latest fashions,  but I tell you that not even King Solomon with all his wealth had clothes as beautiful as one of these flowers.  If God can clothe the fields with such splendor,  which blooms today and is gone tomorrow,  won't he take care of providing the clothes that you need?  What little faith you have!



So do not worry, saying,  'What shall we eat?'  or  'What shall we wear?'  (The people living in the world who don't have any use for God are always concerned about these things)  Your Father in heaven knows all the things you need.



First seek God's kingdom and his righteousness,  and all these things will be given to you as well.  Do not worry about tomorrow's trouble;  live one day at a time and know that each day will bring it's own challenge."



Source(s):



The Bible, Book of Matthew



</answer>

<answer>



There are many psychological theories suggesting why our memories decline as we age. Some are:



Age related factors: with advancing age, the body's central nervous system slows, and information is not processed with the speed and efficiency it once did



Lack of motivation: If an elderly individual is not interested, or does not find something important enough to remember, they will not be as motivated to remember it



Loss of confidence: research has found that 60 -80 year old's were less confident in their memory skill then 18-30 year old's because they do not believe that their memory is as good as is used to be



A decline in memory systems: over time, we have a gradual decline in episodic memory (the memories of personal events). However, there is hardly any decline in procedural memory (our memories of how to do things) and semantic memory (memories of the facts we know about the world).



Measures of retention: it is also shown that as we age, we decrease i our ability to recall (remember information with no cues), but perform the same on recognition tests (like multiple choice tests). This is because recognition does not require the individual to produce the information by themselves, they have cues (a,b,c,d) to jog their memory



Source(s):



year 12 psychology student =)



</answer>

<original file>4844.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk53596.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



DeViE
Member since: 03 July 2008
Total points: 85 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the illusion and hallucination means?



</question>



<answer from>



Bumble bee
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 330 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



well if you mean like a visual illusion, it is a misinterpretation of real sensory stimuli. This means that what our eyes sees, and what we know is real contradict each other, making an illusion.



A hallucination is the brain's reception of a false sensory input. This means that an individual is experiencing an event through one of their senses that isn't actually occurring in reality. This doesn't just have to be visually either, someone can also have auditory hallucinations (hear voices).



Source(s):



year 12 psychology student =)



</answer>



<answer from>



ebenjami...
Member since: 21 April 2008
Total points: 1281 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



illusion:--(n)1a/ a false impression or belief.



b/something that deceives or misleads intellectually.



2/ a misleading image presented to the vision
be under the illusion that-----to have the mistaken belief that.
illusional:--(adj)



hallucinate:--(v) to have hallucinations.
hallucinator:--(n)
hallucination:--(n) the perception of something apparently real to the



perceiver but which has no objective reality,or the



image,object, etc perceived.
hallucinatory:--(adj)



Source(s):



The Penguin Concise English Dictionary.



</answer>
