<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



space
Member since: 23 July 2007
Total points: 304 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What are the benefits of working alone?



What type of advantage do we get while working alone? Does it make us more powerful in our thinking and working styles? Does it bring intuition within us ?



</question>



<answer from>



DC
Member since: 05 January 2007
Total points: 614 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Working alone is good for getting things done. You don't need to explain or consult, just do. Explaining and consulting takes time.



Of course, some jobs are bigger, or trickier, this is when working alone is more difficult.



</answer>



<answer from>



NewDay
Member since: 05 March 2008
Total points: 433 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It helps you connect with yourself and assemble thoughts and ideas in a way that's unique to you. It does raise intuition and cuts out human noise... But on the flipside, you won't have anyone else to communicate with for a second opinion or get an objective view of ideas and plans.



</answer>

Oh, everything's so bad and I need a new job, new car, new  blah" BUT they don't do anything about it, they just go out drinking or do something stupid then go.. Oh my life sucks. They're sucking my life energy! I've tried helping them by listening, tried telling them they're being stupid (nicely of course).. but where do you draw the line to tell them to find another friend or go find help? Also how do you tell them to go get professional help, cos I can't help you.

<answer from>



THinkin
Member since: 03 October 2008

</answer from>



<answer>

<answer from>



dtwarwic...
Member since: 08 July 2008
Total points: 338 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Professional counsellors develop their listening skills and set clear boundaries.  With what little you've described of your friends' behavior, I'd be inclined to say something like, "I'm confused.  On the one hand, you say ...., but then you go and do ...  Why do you suppose that is?"



In this way, and many others, professional counsellors try to help clients solve their own problems.  Of course, some clients don't want to solve their problems either.  With MY friends and acquiantances, I tend to be fairly direct if I think they're just wanting to vent.  I'd probably say something like, "You know, mostly when you start talking this way I feel drained.  I'd rather not talk about all the ways your life sucks.  It's frustrating to try to help you and then see you act in self defeating ways.  I really think it might benefit you to talk to a professional counselor."



Hope that helps.



Source(s):



M.S. in Counseling Psychology



</answer>



<answer from>



toomuch
Member since: 01 July 2006
Total points: 8454 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



options-if not a good friend you may see them less or not at all. Or if good friend direct away from the complaining Allow them to vent for a minute or more if needed, only provide reflective listening-(look it up). then there will be nothing for them to complain about, like "No that won't work", pressuring you to try to "solve" their dilemma. Never offer that advice. When tired of listening, make a transition statement like Looks Like you've got quite a dilemma on you  hands, let's relax and forget about it for now so you can deal w it later on freshly. Then end that conversation and move on ,get up, or excuse yourself to do something else on your own if the person wants to continue to whine. If you wish yu can say,"you know this conversation is not helping you I can see you are just in a mood where you need some time tto be on your own, I'll leave now and chek with you tomorrow to see if we an plan some fun activity for the weekend,. Or suggest they volunteer for habitat for humanity and do some real work to get your mind off your problems. Or get a kid to mentor in a program.
You can offer some books to read(later time when the person is not asking you to listen or fix them) like "feeling good" or other self help books. That is if you feel they would respond, not if that entangles you more. Also schedule more activities together that involve less down time like a movie  when you must leave right afterwards or a sport like biking. The conversation would be less and the activity helps depression.



</answer>

<current file name>yqa_uk55426.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



Inahzi13
Member since: 01 February 2007
Total points: 2676 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



So I was doing breathing meditation and I received a nightmare?



What does this mean ? I did it for 5 minutes .
should I have done it longer ?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Are you having "night terrors"? Like really bad nightmares that takes awhile before you can really calm down or/and after the dream you gasp for air, shakes and cold sweat? "Night terrors" are like panic attacks that happen when you are asleep.
Relaxation techniques like, breathing exercises, are helpful because they release a lot of stress and relax your mind so that you go to sleep with a calm mind, which gives you a peaceful night sleep. But five minutes daily is not enough, you need more like 15 minutes daily.I know that it sounds like a lot, but you can mix it up a little with progressive visual relaxation and breathing techniques. Here's an excellent college website that has links to meditation exercises and had free legal downloads called "Relax with Steve" and "Relax with Bonnie". The "steve" one is breathing and relaxing muscles and Bonnie is more visualization.
http://www.loyola.edu/campuslife/healths...
Also you might want to cut the amount of caffeine that you take in, try not to use your computer or watch tv before sleeping and have a nice warm bath before sleep. A bubble bath with Lavender relaxes you a whole lot, trust me.
If you continue to have "night terror" and losing sleep, you might want to talk to your doctor about, so that maybe he will give some some sleeping aids.
Good luck and I hope this has been helpful:)



</answer>

<question>



How does one get over fear of change?



I desire a new change, yet it scares me?



</question>



<answer from>



Panda
Member since: 07 February 2008
Total points: 116 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You first need to admit your fear and then take out a realistic plan of action for change. Take out a piece of paper and jot down realistic goals for yourself and give yourself benchmarks to follow your goals. You can't change unless your first admit you have a fear of change. Second you need to be committed to your plan of action.



</answer>

</asker's comment>

<answer>



Funnily enough I was talking to my mother about this only the other day.



Ive been going through a rough patch. Work isnt what I expected... Im too busy all the time to have much of a social life. And I gave up on men... I am lucky my parents are still togethr and going strong, so Im confused as to why I feel this way. But then I look at the relationships I have had.



I was 19 when I met my first boyfriend. He was a first in everyway. He moved in after 6months of being together and everything was brilliant. We were together for 3 and a half years... It went very sour, I couldnt stand being around him. He was very feminine and I never felt protected. He always used to mouth of at guys when we were out, but then couldnt loko after himself which would leave me standing there in the middle.



After we split up I met this guy who I thought was AMAZING!! He was a fire fighter from Birmingham and a few yeras older than me. I fell for him hook line and sinker. He was so masculine so fun, and could deffinately look after himself! BAM!!! He was seeing three other girls at the same time as me! - The wrong guy. Even though that was over a year ago now. I still keep in touch with him and still have this love for him, why I dont know. But what I do know is that he was the guy.



That being said I tried again. This time someone a little younger and so not my type but again masculine and could look after himself.. He has a baby but that was fine. We got on really really well, and he kept asking me why I never told him my feelings. - Thats becasue I was worried about what happened last time would happen again. Eveuntually I told him. BAM - "Sarah I think we should just be friends I dont want a realtionship" Wrong guy number 2 - it turns out he was a massive druggie as well!



By this time I started to think that it was a waste of time and I was destined to be alone then I met another fireman he was not my tye again and I really didnt like him that much. But somehow we got together and seemed to be hitting it off really well. We presumed we were both together and it worked. - He was a little naughty for me - but I think that is kinda why I liked him. Anyway then the bad thing happened... I got pregnant! I was waiting for ages to tell him, and I was worried that there would be yet another big BAM!! I told him and I waited for the screaming... But nothing... enfact thte first thing was - Are you ok?! I was gob smacked... We discussed eeverything and we were going to work through it... But then I had to have the baby terminated becasue it was in my tubes. BAM!!!! - The wrong guy... Now he didnt care and was a nasty nasty nasty person!



So at the moment I am on my own and a little worried that I will never find the one, or getting the wrong guy. But you know what. From the first person I went out with to the last person... I have become such a strong person... For myself. Yes yuo go through crap and yes you will meet the wrong people - but it all for a reason... The way I behaved with one guy I would never do again becasue Ive learnt that it gets you hurt or no where.



If feelings fade away they fade away... I thought that me and my first boyfriend would be together forever, but we werent and are not, but it makes room for you - to find out who you really are...



You have to kiss a 1000 frogs before one turns into a prince. - That is just life Im afraid you will get hurt... But it makes you such a stronger person.



Im having great fun at the moment meeting new guys etc. Ill be honest all I want is to settle down with someone I love etc... But  I know who I meet at a club tommorrow night probably wont be him... But then the one in the coat q might. If neither of them are then hey I can say Ive lived!



Sorry to babble on - probably most of this is garbage... But I hope it explains things a little. (It helps me too to write it down ha ha)



Source(s):



Just what ive been through the last few years



</answer>

<question from>



Sean F
Member since: 09 February 2008
Total points: 5310 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



Why does time go by faster as you get older?



Since the day I turned 14, time has just flown by, why?



</question>



<additional details>



Becky - I am 19 now, I was saying that since I turned 14, time has been going fast.



</additional details>



<answer from>



coastal stone bird
Member since: 03 March 2008
Total points: 2385 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Physicists have been saying that time actually has been going by faster over the last 10 years



but the less something moves, the faster time goes by .. or the more inactive you are, the faster time seems to pass



they're also learning that gravity and time effect one another



via an EEG it was determined that my frontal temporal lobe fires neurons more slowly than the rest of my brain, so i translate time differently too



epilepsy though lol



</answer>



<answer from>



Murt Momain
Member since: 18 March 2007
Total points: 697 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



That is a very good question, I wonder if there is an actual scientific neurological explanation!  I have always wondered that.



Sorry I don't know the answer.



</answer>



<answer from>



Becky
Member since: 21 September 2008
Total points: 658 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



LOL! You're 14? Hun, you have NO clue. Just wait until you hit about 30....that's when each year of your life seems like a month. And when you get as old as I am (49) it seems like you just took the Christmas tree down and suddenly you're putting it back up the next day....seriously...lol



</answer>



<answer from>



clstldrm...
Member since: 27 September 2008
Total points: 454 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think it's because as we get older we have more things to take care of, worry about, and feel like we have less time to do it than when we were young with more time for ourselves. I wish I could tell you things will slow down, but they don't, the years seem to pass in a flash. I long for the days when weekends were slower and summer vacations seemed like they would go on forever. The best advice for "time flies" is probably, "don't forget to stop and smell the roses".



</answer>



<answer from>



Christa M
Member since: 23 October 2006
Total points: 211 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's not time that goes faster...so those "professionals" are wrong. ;)



It's your perception. As a child, small things occupy our minds more - and we have less responsibility then, too. The more responsibilities that are heaped on us, the more time flies, because our minds are over-occupied.



I would say that "time goes faster as we get older" because we are no longer as aware that it is passing. As a child, nothing seems to happen fast enough. Once we reach a certain age, though, time never stands still for us. It's just life.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kate
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 400 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



My best guess?



Time doesn't go by faster but I know what you mean. Our perception of time changes as we grow older. Think of time as a... well, timeline. If you have a very long line, a summer's worth is a smaller proportion than if you have a very short line. So a 5 year old will perceive summer to be a lot longer than a 50 year old.



</answer>



<answer from>



survivor
Member since: 23 March 2006
Total points: 6757 (Level 5)

<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Lady WAR is the Boss Lady
Member since: 05 November 2007
Total points: 2106 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You seem to be suffering from a major form of low self esteem. it sounds lame, but I think that could be the cause of your constant obsessing over how you interact with other people. I found this:



There are many basic causes of low self-esteem which can also have ongoing and debilitating effects, but the most significant ones are the following:



1. Guilt. This often takes the form of self-torture. Such people worry about everything they do and tend to regret every decision, often believing they did the 'wrong' thing. They tend to see their actions as unforgivable, their imperfections as permanent and believe improvement is impossible. Thus they are kept feeling constantly inferior to everyone else and totally inadequate.



2. Fear and uncertainty. The hallmark of non-confident people is naked fear which they wear like a welcome sign on themselves. They fear making mistakes, upsetting others or becoming ill. They fear not having material things and not living up to the expectations of someone else. They fear not being liked, being hurt and fear taking any kind of responsibility. They fear even being themselves, because of the risk of disapproval from the significant others they value or wish to impress. Such fears are fed and maintained by negative experiences, lack of self-belief and an absence of trust. People driven by fear are plagued by self-doubt, submissiveness, over-conformity, sensitivity to criticism, feelings of inferiority, being unloved or rejected.



3. Self-Shame. Keeping secrets about themselves which then makes them feel 'awful', 'disgusting', 'weird', 'stupid', 'ugly' or unworthy, especially as they would believe themselves to be the only ones with such experiences. This lowers their self-esteem even further and keeps them from trusting others. They would live in constant fear of what others might find out about them.



4. Trying to be a perfect person. True self-esteem means an acceptance of our being, warts and all, with no desire to be anyone else. But if we keep finding faults with ourselves, we will always miss our strengths. But if we do not accept ourselves, who on earth is going to accept us, either? In such a way we keep feeling inadequate and unworthy.



5. Unforgiving, unrealistic expectation
______________________________________...



To be specific, a person with low self-esteem has the following characteristics: overly conscious about what image they project on other people, unwillingness to take on challenges, blaming everything on themselves, unwillingness to assume responsibilities, less social conformity, lack self-confidence, emotional confusion, anxiety, and depression.



If you have one or many of the mentioned characteristics, you might be suffering from low self-esteem. Though this is neither a decease nor contagious, actions must be done in order to transform your self to a person with healthy self-esteem. Now, how do you do that?



First, you should realize and acknowledge that you have a low self-esteem. A person who could not accept his problem and could not realize that he has low self-esteem would not be able to deal with it.



Then, you have to identify your weaknesses. Which of the mentioned characteristics reside in you? After you have answered this, you know what are the things you can do. How? By simply taking the opposite of who you are. For example, you are the type of person who is afraid to take responsibility. Deal with it by starting to take little responsibility. Start within. Take small responsibility you think



you can do. Once you have dealt with it, take another one, and another. Then, work your way outward. As you take on one responsibility after another, you are gaining confidence, which by the way is something you also lack.



Dealing With the Problem of Low Self-Esteem: Common Characteristics and Treatment in Individual, Marital/Family, and Group Psychotherapy It is also good to set goals. Start with simple goals you can easily achieve. Then, you can set bigger and more challenging goals.



If you happen to have 2 or more of the mentioned characteristics, start by focusing on one. You should realize that all these are interrelated. So if you deal with one, you will surely deal with the rest.



Deal with your low self-esteem by treating yourself well. Never punish yourself with wrong thoughts because most of the time, these are only false impressions you have created on your own. Never focus on the negative things. Instead, focus on thinking positively.



Treat yourself right by getting enough rest, eating regularly and healthily, doing regular exercise, and giving yourself treats after you have done something good. Pamper yourself.



Give yourself the chance to have fun. Do something exciting for the day.



If you think you have deeper problem, seek help from a professional or talk to other people. If you have problem with sharing to other people, start on your closest friends or people who are willing to listen to y



Source(s):



http://www.helium.com/items/999306-cause...



http://www.digitalexcellent.com/Low-Self...



</answer>

uniquech...

Total points: 4452 (Level 4)

Dont become self absorbed - you are operating out of fear of offending people - why do you think you are not good enough and what does it matter what people think. If you have to live your life around what people think about you, you are heading for destruction.  The answer is to recognize that you are great - you are somebody and God made you to be a unique special priceless person who has his own set of talents, gifts and skills.  You are worthy, you are not hopeless and you are able to do far more than you can imagine and have the power to be anything you set your mind to be.  God knew you before you were conceived.  He knows your thoughts from afar.  He knows your comings and your goings.  You cannot hide from him.  he knows what you are choosing right now and that is negative.  Instead concern yourself with pleasing God.  People come and people go but you have to live your life and live it abundantly too.  God says he has come to give you life and in abundance. Get to know your creator. Get to know the way he thinks.  Delight yourself in him and he will give you the desires of your heart. Instead of worrying what people think, you go and do good things for people by being a good listener, by being a friend, by being accountable and being helpful. Be kind, be good, be faithful, be peaceful, be happy and find joy, be wise and understanding and merciful and gracious towards others, be patient, don't be excessive and greedy, be humble and thoughtful, considerate and faithful and loyal. Choose the opposite to negative.  Be thankful for what you have even if it is little. Be content with what you have. Life is about choices. You have to choose and its what we choose that is either constructive or destructive!  Please remember that! SO what are you going to choose?

<answer from>



Sara K
Member since: 06 August 2007
Total points: 1282 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sounds to me like you have some self-esteem issues, although you recognize that you can make good decisions about the big things in life.
The way to stop might be to follow up the inevitable "that was stupid" self-talk with an immediate self-affirmation, like "No, it wasn't stupid, it was the best decision at the time, and I am intelligent and capable of making good decisions."  And, also, stop yourself when you start to think negatively.  Saying "Stop!" out loud might even work.  (When you're by yourself.  Doing that around other people might cause them to look at you strangely.)
Recognizing that you are doing this is an excellent first step.  Changing your behavior will not be easy, but if you try to self-affirm after each negative thought, in no time, you will be forgetting to think the negative thought in the first place.



Source(s):



I am a mental health professional.



</answer>



<answer from>



Susmitha
Member since: 15 November 2007
Total points: 436 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You are just like me :-).



But this happened to me till an year ago. I have a possible solution that you can work out (it worked for me). Thanks to my friend :-)



Small think matter and shatter your emotions.



When you pick up a wrong dress for school,
When you get late to bus,
When you buy something at shop and doesnt like that after reaching home,
when you always think about others much and yourself.



All this kind of situations have one simple formula:



1. Dont let your heart make your mind down for small things.
2. Suppose, if you go for shopping, you like one dress... just keep it aside... and roam in the shop for another few minutes, comeback and look at it again. Look at the negative things in the dress (that we never did before :-) ). Now you will start knowing the dress better and will decide whether to buy it or not.



3. If I buy that what is the purpose... ?
4. This is for simple shopping.



In case, you are talking to somebody, dont just babble. Speak 1 word for 3 words that come in your mind. Select the best word out of three..



Slowly you will be gaining confidence and think correctly and feel proud or atleast happy about your decisions.



All the best!



Source(s):



Myself



</answer>

<answer>



I used to be like that. Anything that I did  I was highly critical of. I also lacked confidence. But one day I was with a colleague, who I considered to be really confident. We had booked a room for a meeting and there were people in there. He was really nervous, but it was something that I had no problem in doing. Since then I have sat back and observed a lot more and I have realised that everyone makes mistakes. Everyone is nervous in certain situations. The moral of the story is - don't be so hard on yourself - if you strive for perfection you will always fail. And as by driving instructer used to say - forgive the mistakes of others, and hope that others will forgive yours.



</answer>



<answer from>



queenb35...
Member since: 11 March 2008
Total points: 5209 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm currently doing a personal development course which has really opened my eyes to how I think about myself and the way it affects how I behave, and i think that what you're doing is called negative self talk. it develops after years of being told these things, by our parents, friends, teachers and other people in our lives who are important to us.



I think it'd be a good idea to write down a short list of things you like about yourself, another list of perhaps 10 things you don't like, and then try and talk yourself out of the negative thoughts and self talk.



i'll give you an example. I have had to listen to various people in my life tell me that I'm stupid. Recently, I decided to tell myself that I am not. I listed my skills and qualifications, and realised that, far from being stupid, I'm actually an intelligent person who makes the occasional mistake.I learnt to accept that I'm not perfect - after all, who is? - and to accept myself as an intelligent human being, and am slowly coming out of my shell (my negative self talk had turned me into a very shy person, who was afraid of letting anyone see how bright and capable I actually was - not any more!!) The shyness is still bubbling under the surface, but I'm not going to allow it to hold me back like it has previously. As the old song goes "Ain't nothing gonna break my stride... I got to keep on moving"



</answer>

<original file>9867.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk59176.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



Amir Ali Tayyab
Member since: 24 April 2006
Total points: 304 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Can you forgive someone like this truly from heart and be free?



The Power of Forgiveness



“When you forgive somebody who has wronged you, you’re spared the dismal corrosion of bitterness and wounded pride. For both parties, forgiveness means the freedom again to be at peace inside their own skins and to be glad in each others’ presence."
Fredrick Buechner



Peace is not possible without forgiveness. Martin Luther King once said, “Forgiveness is not an occasional act; it is a permanent attitude.” The only way children can learn the habit of forgiveness is by seeing us, their parents, forgive others and forgive ourselves.



The freedom to be at peace in our own skins - that’s what forgiveness allows. We relinquish this freedom when we hold onto anger and resentment. Enormous amounts of energy are wasted when we hold back our love, hold onto hate, and harbor acrimonious feelings. The only remedy is letting go, and being willing to forgive.



But how? Here are four powerful steps to forgiveness from one of the world’s foremost experts on the subject, Dr. Fredrick Luskin:



1. Close your eyes, and for about 20 seconds, picture the person who hurt or angered you. Let all your grievances come up. Notice what happens in your body -- acceleration of heart-beat, shallow breathing, tension, etc.



2. Now let go of this image and take some slow, deep abdominal breaths. Focus on your abdomen, and imagine the breath going down into it as you inhale. Expand your abdomen on each inhalation, and deflate your abdomen as you exhale. Take about five breaths and keep your focus on your abdomen. If your mind goes back to the person who hurt you or to anything else, bring the focus back to the rhythm of your breath and the movement of your abdominal muscles as you inhale and exhale.



3. Bring into your mind an image of someone you love very much, or a place of peace and beauty. Allow yourself to be flooded with the positive feelings this image elicits. Now bring those feelings down to the area around your heart. Allow the good feelings to penetrate your heart and soothe you.



4. Lastly, keep breathing the good feelings into your heart. Now take a look again at the person you are angry at. Let the good feelings protect you. The purpose of doing this step is to break the pattern of stress reactions that normally occur in your mind and body when you think of the person who hurt you. When you surround your heart with positive energy, the power the person has had over you begins to dissipate.



Resentment is a habit, and habits take twenty-five days to change. So if you do this exercise each time you think of the person who hurt you over twenty-five days, you will literally change your mental and physical reactions. They will no longer have power to hurt you because you will have reprogrammed your own reactions. And when this happens, you start to become free.



Sometimes we need to forgive without reconciliation: forgiving for the mere purpose of forgiving. Certainly, what we strive for is to reconcile all conflicts, clear the air, and understand one another. But there are times this is impossible - with a parent who has passed away, with someone who has wronged you and is long gone, with someone who is unwilling to communicate. These are the times we must dip deep into our own souls and see if we are willing to forgive anyway.



I have on the bulletin board above my desk a yellowed article written by the scholar and Holocaust survivor Elie Weisel in 1997. In it, Weisel expresses the most profound act of forgiveness imaginable. It is here that Elie Weisel expresses forgiveness toward God for the Holocaust.



In the article Weisel asks God the question he has struggled with all his life: “Where were you, God of Kindness, in Auschwitz?” Weisel had never been able to understand how a loving God could have allowed the Holocaust to exist. But out of the question that has tormented him for fifty years, Weisel gleans a sudden insight: “Watching your children suffer at the hands of your other children, haven’t you also suffered?”



In this moment of compassion, Weisel is finally moved to offer God his forgiveness: “Let us make up, Master of the Universe,” he says. “In spite of everything that happened? Yes, in spite. Let us make up: for the child in me, it is unbearable to be divorced from you for so long.”



This story is a reminder to me that forgiveness and compassion are essential and possible under all circumstances. For the child in all of us, we must learn to forgive. And for the sake of the children we love with unparalleled ferocity, we must model the most magnanimous and humbling of all acts - the act of forgiveness.



Forgiveness Exercise:



- Is there someone you need to forgive? Write about that person and the circumstance below. Are you ready to forgive him or her? If so, go onto the next step.



- Do the process outlined above.



- When you feel ready, complete this forgiveness statement .



I AMIR ALI TAYYAB do hereby grant forgiveness to ANN MASSARO. I forgive you



</question>



<additional details>



I forgive you for:



Abusing, Insulting, Breaking, Destroying, Hating, Lying, Decieving, Defrauding, and Hurting
me, my country, my religion, my feelings, my heart, my body, my money, and my soul.



-Talk to your child about the importance of forgiveness. Ask him if there is anyone he needs to forgive. If so, have him do the 4-step process, then copy the above forgiveness statement, and have him fill it out.



Nelson Mandela once said, “Resentment is like drinking poison and then hoping it will kill your enemies.” You have the power to change that. Peace is built on the decisions we make and the actions we take in the small moments of our life. Deciding to forgive is one more way of creating peace, the most important job any of us can do right now.



The Power of Forgiveness
by Naomi Drew, M.A.
author of Hope and Healing: Peaceful Parenting in an Uncertain World



http://www.learningpeace.com/pages/LP_10...



Before I decided to forgive her truly from heart, here is how I was feeling;



Tonight I want to write something and need the writer inside me to speak so much that I don't have any more desire to speak about love and the pain it may cause. But the moment I start writing or even start pressing the first keyboard button about Love, I get confused. Why? I should never get confused cause love is a universal, simple and so common thing. Yes, it might be but whatever happened to me, it made the love just an illusion that one can only see or talk about in movies or other fictional books. In reality, I tried to love someone but failed so miserably that I wish I did not exist at all. This experience was so awkward and so unbelievably terrible one that my soul, body and experience of life, everything seemed like nothing. I was treated like a piece of trash and thrown away in such a merciless way that I kept wondering what the hell did I do wrong by loving someone?



For more details and the best answer which gave me dignity, power and freedom to forgive her, see my other Question at;



http://answers.yahoo.com/question/index;...



</additional details>



<answer from>



Sean R
Member since: 08 August 2007
Total points: 222 (Level 1)

<answer>



This isn't a question but it is very insightful.  I have told many people that they need to learn forgiveness for themselves...not necessarily the person they forgive.  It takes too much of our lives and too  much energy to everyday living to be bitter and hateful and sorrowful that we were hurt.



Thanks for such a great piece...those that need to forgive need this peice of life and insight to move on and live a happier life.



I too had to forgive and it took me 20 years to do it.  I now have a relationship with my parents...superficial as it is...I can understand them a little more....even though I can't forget what happened...I can forgive them and give them peace along with myself.



They haven't given me any peace or said they are sorry but I can deal with that.  There are blessings .....in everything....if you look for them.  But you have to heal the hole in your heart first.



We all have illusions on love...it is not a fairy tale thing.  It is work...always work and you will always be disappointed because it involves another person that you want to make you happy and you feel SHOULD.  The truth is..no one can make you happy but yourself.  You cannot hand your life over to someone and say make me happy.  It will never happen.  You are putting too much expectation on someone when you do that and it is doomed to fail from that moment on.



Love is work....it IS forgiving and accepting what you don't think is fair or right or changing it.  You have to bend with life or you will break.  There is someone else in the world..not just you so you have to accept the fact that they count too...and it is up to each of us to pick and choose what is important to us in life and what we can live with and what we can't.



It takes maturity and it takes commitment...because you will never have everything your way.

<answer>



If you repress ANGER...yes.  Not desires.  Desires are emotions and you are in control of  emotions..or should be.  If you aren't you need to work on maturity.



In life you grow up and make choices and make them for what is good for you and desire leads your life to what your future will be.



What is good for you isn't good for someone else.



It is anger you need to get out and talk about or it will manifest into other things.



Desire is  to long or hope for : exhibit or feel desire for



You can desire many things....success...love...children...
money....education...clothes..
homes....ANYTHING.



If anything desire should result in a shift in motivation and ambition to get what you want.



I went to Catholic schools all my life (back in the 60's and 70's and I never had a mean nun.  They were soft spoken and kind and loving.



On the other hand I went to public school one year and the teacher threw a desk across the room because he was mad.  Is he any different?  No .. what happens is individual..there are mean people in EVERY WALK OF LIFE...abusers in every walk of life...alcoholics in ever walk of life....you are all generalizing and it is unfair.



If you had red hair would you like it if everyone said you were a angry person...or if you were fat would you like people to say you were selfish and a slob etc?  Get real.



You are talking sex....there is more to a nun's life than that...and it should be more to life than that in YOUR Life too.



When you base life on sex...you are very superficial and you will have problems.



Nuns DESIRE to serve God and God bless those people that have a big heart and a big capacity to love and teach !



</answer>

<question>



What are some things me can do to relax?



</question>



<additional details>



Thanks everyone good tips.



</additional details>



<answer from>



NickyS
Member since: 11 August 2008
Total points: 1667 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Many people are giving great advice on relaxing.Baths,reading,crosswords,music,... favorite) but there is something they missed.Exercise,you can let it out.Go fo a brisk walk,a dance class,aerobics.Get those endorphins up first then relax them with the bath.Getting rid of stress takes some exertion sometimes.I hope you can find that one thing that works,God bless.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Wow thanks.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Alien, Ma'am.
Member since: 27 May 2008
Total points: 232 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



1.) Try breathing deeply. It allows more oxygen into your system which has a calming effect.
2.) Mentally release all the tension from one part of your bod at a time. I know it sounds silly, but it really helps.
3.) Go to your happy place. Visualize somewhere or something that calms you and releases endorphins.



4.) Play with a stress ball. It gets your mind off of the stressor and allows you to relieve built up muscle tension.



</answer>



<answer from>



meep!
Member since: 21 June 2008
Total points: 4179 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Take care of the things that are causing you stress - ie. if you have to get some work done or pay some bills



Give yourself a spa treatment.



Have a cup of tea



Get a good night sleep.



Read a good book.



Put on some comfortable pajamas and watch a funny movie.



</answer>

<question>



Reverse speech experiment?

I talked about my job that year and how much I enjoyed it and gave some details, and things like that. <question from>



My Crayon is Blue
Member since: 15 March 2008
Total points: 1556 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Are you responsible for your happiness or should you rely on others to make you happy?



Topic of discussion this weekend at a get together.  An acquaintance mentioned how she had met a guy who made her happy.  Me having the big mouth I do...said "what you weren't happy before you met him?"..that sparked a discussion....I personally believe that you should be happy with you and rely on yourself for you own happiness.  People (friends/gf/bf) can ADD to that happiness but you shouldn't  rely  on others to make you happy.



In case you're wondering...I'm in my late 40's divorced 13 years and I have dated but am currently single.



After many years I am finally comfortable in my own skin...am content with my life as it is.  Not saying that if someone came into my life i'd push them away...but they wouldn't be my main reason for being happy.  What's funny is that i've found a majority of the folks my age who are single....have the same thoughts...



Any opinions?  Care to share?  Thanks!



I



</question>

Junerose

<answer>



Having children is a big responsibility and I am not surprised your girlfriend does not, at the age of 20, feel ready to commit herself to having children yet.  However, as you are so keen, make sure she does eventually want children. Also, tell her that each baby bring its love with it and it will not affect what you feel for each other.  She has not been given one portion of love which she will have to share with her children and their farther.  Yes, having childen can be painfull, but there is pleanty of help now.  If it was that bad, each couple would only have one child as no woman would want to go through labour more than once!  Nature has a way of erasing the pain from your brain.  Yes, we remember it was painful, but when we feel ready to have another baby we cannot really remember exactly what the pain was like, and anway, the most important thing is that you really want another child. Remember, for every person you see, some mother has gone through labour and there a millions of us. The human race has not died out because of possible painful labour.  Good luck, but make sure you are both really comitted to the responsibilities, and possible sacrifices, that having children brings, and have a bit more time to yourselves beforeyou make such a serious comittment.



Source(s):



Experience



</answer>



<answer from>



psychick
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 1390 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



I met my husband when I was 16 and he was 19.  A lot of people said you don't know what love is yet.  You won't get married, but I knew he was the one and today we have been married 11 years.  So I do believe you can find the one you will marry at a young age.  We never spoke about children or anything like that when we were discussing marriage.  I assumed we would have children, and we did have a child years later.  My point is that if he would have came to me and said I don't want to have children, I would have felt the same way you do.  I would have been broken, and I wouldn't want to leave him to find another that did want children.  I would drop it, and give it some time.  Bring it up again before you decide to get married.  If she still doesn't want children then you will have to make your decision.  Because if she still says no and you decide to marry her anyway, be prepared!  She may follow through with that and you need to realize this before you say I do.  That could tear a marriage apart.
When I was younger I wanted children, but not for a long time.  It hits you all at once, and then you know it is time.  Maybe once she gets older, before your married, she will change her mind.



Good Luck



</answer>

<original file>11125.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk60576.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



lawaan
Member since: 03 March 2007
Total points: 93 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Negative effects and disadvantage of cognitive behavioral therapy?



is there any proven negative effects and disadvantage of cognitive behavioral therapy?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Some say CPT is a model of emotional response, which has no place in behavioral psychology and is based the idea that our thoughts
cause our feelings and behaviors, not external things, like people, situations, and events.



External events need to be looked at -- If practiced correctly,a look at the person's surroundings - how they grew up, how they interact with others, etc.



I think if you Google you question, you will fine predictions, but not proven effects.



Read ABOUT BEHAVIORISM by B.F. Skinner.



</answer>

<answer>

Watching TV isn't all bad. At least watch a documentary or something so you're learning something! Learning something new will make you feel more interested in life again and you may make new friends from it. Perhaps getting yourself a part time job or doing some volunteer work?



I currently volunteer for St Johns Ambulance and have made friends and get to go to lots of different places. People also seem to think more of you if you do voluntary work. At least volunteer work would get you out the house, speaking to people, learning something new and helping others. The good thing about SJA is you get to go watch sporting events and things and gain the knowledge of how to potentially save someone's life. Now that can't be a bad thing, surely?!



Good luck in whatever you decide!

<answer>



Danny I feel like that all the time. You sound like an explorer. Go explore. take one day a week to find some new adventure. Call it your time out day (just for you).

<original file>11128.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk60579.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



Finchy
Member since: 13 December 2005
Total points: 476 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Correlations between physical coordination skills & empathy/self-insight - any data?



Hi



I have a theory, based only on observation, that people who are the most finely coordinated physically also tend to be the most self-aware and empathic.  Those who come up short on physical coordination skills tend to be more ham-fisted interpersonally and lack a little self-awareness.



To the extent that our experience of 'emotion' is (perhaps) largely about our minds sensing signals coming from our bodies, the above makes some kind of sense...



BUT, I have no data.  I could be imagining all of this.  Does anyone know of any research studies which correlate physical coordination skill with self/interpersonal insight in adults of normal intelligence/mental status?



Thanks.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't have any research, but I'd agree partly with you, albeit in reverse.



People who are not finely coordinated, or clumsy, are both less aware of their bodies and less aware of their environment than people who are more self-aware (and usually with a correspondingly higher awareness of the envirnment).



Empathy usually develops as a factor of self-awareness, along with the understanding of the similarity between the self and others. So I'd suggest that self-awareness is the root, rather than empathy being a cause in itself.



All on personal experience and observation.



</answer>

<answer from>



Struan F
Member since: 19 May 2008
Total points: 204 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



What I learned in the year of Psychology that I did is that most psychological theories are just that theories and cannot be proved.  However, we were told that there are three parts to the self concept:



Self Image - How you see yourself and how you think others see you, not just visually but as a person.
Ideal Self - How you would ideally like to be.  This is often influenced by people you look up to in your life.
Self Esteem - How confident you are in yourself and your capability of completingn tasks well.



To me it sounds like your self image isn't close enough to your ideal self.  Think about your ideal self, then go out and take yourself a step closer to it in your self image.  It may well increase your self esteem and you might not hate the mirror so much.



Source(s):



Intermediate 2 Psychology



</answer>



<answer from>



baby8grl...
Member since: 12 March 2007
Total points: 422 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



In all honesty, because you think too much about what others think. I don't know if you're good looking or not, obviously I cannot see you. However, I do know that even good looking people don't always like the way they look in the mirror.



There are several reasons why you are self conscience and generally the most common is low self esteem or lack of confidence. You need to concentrate on what you like and go that route and quite worrying about what others like. You'll never make everyone happy and trying to is obscenely impossible!



Keep in mind those who are quick to judge the looks of other are also quick to judge themselves. Instead of putting others down when you look upon them try looking for something good about them and soon you'll do the same for yourself! Beauty is in the eye of the beholder and if you think you're ugly others will too. You are only as ugly and old as you think and/or allow yourself to be. If there is anything about you that you don't like that can be changed (ex: over weight) start trying to change it slowly, just trying can often boost your confidence.



Be proud you are you and not somebody else and try your best to be happy as you.



</answer>

<question>



Are you responsible for your happiness or should you rely on others to make you happy?



Topic of discussion this weekend at a get together.  An acquaintance mentioned how she had met a guy who made her happy.  Me having the big mouth I do...said "what you weren't happy before you met him?"..that sparked a discussion....I personally believe that you should be happy with you and rely on yourself for you own happiness.  People (friends/gf/bf) can ADD to that happiness but you shouldn't  rely  on others to make you happy.



In case you're wondering...I'm in my late 40's divorced 13 years and I have dated but am currently single.



After many years I am finally comfortable in my own skin...am content with my life as it is.  Not saying that if someone came into my life i'd push them away...but they wouldn't be my main reason for being happy.  What's funny is that i've found a majority of the folks my age who are single....have the same thoughts...



Any opinions?  Care to share?  Thanks!



I



</question>

<answer from>



christy_...
Member since: 10 September 2008
Total points: 371 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think it's an issue of responsibility.  People don't like to be responsible for their own feelings because we like putting the blame on others.  If we are sad or upset or depressed we don't like to reevaluate what is causing us to be that way; instead, we just like to say "he or she did this to me, and it put me in a bad mood."



We are most certainly in charge of our own happiness or our own sadness for that matter.  We should take control of our own life and not choose to allow people to get the best of us.



Great topic of discussion!



</answer>

<answer>



You can't reverse it and you really wouldn't want to, trust me. But you can change the outcome. Ask someone to go with you. Get the details and ask, ask ask away, start with family if you have to. You'lll find that others feel the same way too just never said anything about it.



Some say shyness is a lack of self esteem I disagree strongly. Ithink that they are two different things.

<question>



What does my dream mean?



the dream started out with me bringing my first born home ( a little background, i dont have a baby but i might be pregnant) and i took a shower when i got home and got out because my son was crying... i went to my room and got dressed and herd the front door open, thinking it was only family coming to visit i paid it no mind... i opened my door and there was a man with two children about the age of 8-10 they looked like normal people but the only difference was they had very blue eyes, like glazed over and possesed eyes, they came at me and my child and tried to take the baby away from me and i ran to my neighbors house and they brotected me but the man and children were extremely strong! it seemed as if years passed by as my son was standing in the kitchen with a sippy cup as i was in my room packing my things, he started crying and i ran to him.. there was that man, no children i sight and standing there staring at my child! i grabbed him and ran, a few years passed again and my husband built this beautiful house with secret rooms and doors becasue as he had never saw the man and children, he beleived me! so he built rooms so hide in if i was scared when i saw them again! so my husband was at work and the ma and children showed up- me and my son now 7 ran to the hidden room, but the man found us and we went to a differnt room attched to that room and we went to the next and the next, and as the rooms got smaller and we got further and further away from the man my fear subsided, and when we finally got to the smallest room, to where we could go no farther, i called my husband and he was on his way home, he got home and found us, and we came out shaken and scared, we looked around and it was as if nothing happened, everything was in place and clean as i had left it! and then i woke up!



i was so scared to go back to sleep because everytime i would close my eyes i would see those blue glazed over possessed eyes! i eventually went back to sleep and had another dream that linked to this one, it had the same baby in it, but i do not remember much of it, as the first dream was ver detailed and scary!



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



maybe its your worst fear. or maybe its something similar to something that may happen in the future, or it just might be a dream that will never happen at all. that would be hella scary if something like that did come true though



</answer>

<answer from>



zucchini...
Member since: 25 January 2008
Total points: 5867 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Mental Health



</answer from>



<answer>



Alpha, I don't know about it being inborn or not - the science of genetics hasn't progressed that far yet, LOL.  But a woman's feelings about having children can change drastically over time, and depending on her circumstances.



As a young girl and woman I wasn't "into" babies either, but in my mid twenties this changed and I started to want a child.  I ended up with just one (I never wanted dozens!). From experience I believe the urge to have children is governed by our hormones, although it isn't as simple as people make it sound.  Certainly, once you've been through one pregnancy, the urge to repeat the experience may become strong.



Some women feel this urge not at all, others with overwhelming intensity. Every woman's different and shouldn't be pressured to have children if she doesn't want them.  It's not as if humans were an endangered species...



The other thing is, you can love your own baby passionately without liking other people's children much at all!



</answer>

<question from>



DenLetze...
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 110 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How can I make myself study regularly and seriously instead of doing everything at the last moment?



I always study at the last moment. For instance, when I know that there's a class paper coming, I always put up the work until the last day, and even then I just start working at about 8 or 9 p.m. Actually I do work seriously then, I usually get fairly good marks, but I'd still like to study more and more regularly.



How can I do this? Is there some way of making yourself study even if you know that you still have some time left?



(I always do other, unnecessary things as long as I have time to study later...)



</question>



<answer from>



peter.ju...
Member since: 05 June 2008
Total points: 4349 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Global Warming



</answer from>



<answer>



Create an artificial sense of urgency.



I suggest that you make sure you spend a certain amount of time, and accomplish a certain amount before you do other things that you want to do.



As it's mostly difficult to START doing your work, work yourself into say a solid hour of actually working on your stuff, but begin by costing yourself 10 minutes. (if you get a head of steam, you can stay longer)



This will have you practice at starting it, without thinking about what you're missing elsewhere. Work up to longer periods of time.



It worked for me.



</answer>



<answer from>



Shakira....
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 170 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm a procrastinator too.  What works for me is just stop thinking about it and just sit down and study!  i also trick myself into believing the deadline is sooner to make me do it.  Also if you tell family and friends to make you do it and check in on you if you don't then you usually stick to a study timetable.  Have you tried a study group?  if you study with a group of people regularly you become accountable to them and will feel bad if you don't do the assigned reading/studying in time thereby making you study or complete the assignment in good time and not last minute.  Goodluck



</answer>

Member since: 14 July 2007

<answer from>



toi_fran...
Member since: 25 July 2006
Total points: 2821 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had the same problems.  Studying was just something I didn't want to do.  I started a new study habit by simply studying on and off several times.  I would read over my notes for about 30 to 40 minutes.  Then go do something I wanted to do.  Then I would come back a hour or two later and read over them again.  It worked.  While I was doing the things I wanted to do, I would also have something I was studying come to mind.  It made test a lot easier.  Good luck.



</answer>

<answer from>



kokotxa
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 129 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi, I used to be a procrastinator also but with a little will of power and some tips I now do things in advance.
Doing class assignments was not the only thing that I always left to the last minute, maybe you are the same. I always waited to the critical time if I had to do a something around the house for my parents, if I had to file some papers for registration, etc.
First step is to be aware that leaving things to the critical time bothers you...so you have already taken a step forward if you want to change. Good for you!
Tell yourself that if you can do it today, do not leave it until tomorrow...constantly! Think about how bad you feel when you get stressed out at the last minute, the bad night you have thinking that you haven't given your best, that you could do better in the assignment if you had taken more time thinking about it.
If you start a few days earlier, you have more time to think about things as they come in the assignment. As a resutl, your work will have more insight.
I made a routine for myself. Set aside a specific time of the day to start your projects, rather early than 8 or 9 pm. Always the same time worked best for me. I went into my room, turned off all the lights except the one at my desk (so you have a focal point on your PC or your books. I enjoy music, so I played something that I enjoy but that makes me relax...and I set out to work! I ended up enjoying the time, because when the routine sets in you feel comfortable and happy in that space.
I also had a calendar that I followed. Whenever I was assigned a project or a test, I would mark the date and time in my calendar. Then, I would think about how much time it would take, and I would break it down in 1/2 or 1 hour segments spread out along the days I had left for the assignemt. 1/2 hour working on a task doesn't seem intimidating, and if you set yourself easy, attainable, tasks, you are more likely to finish. The end result is that big projects seem easy when broken into pieces. Just think that you do that 1/2 and hour first, and that's it! you are done with that task for the day!
What happened to me is that once I worked some time on a project, when in bed just before sleeping, I thought about what I would do next day in the project, so when the next day came along I already knew what the 1/2 hour on the task would be used for. Focus is a great ally!



It is an unbelievable good feeling to sleep every night knowing you are ahead of schedule and that you are turning in some homework or going to a test with the certainty that you have worked enough for top grades. Once I had that basis, doing things in time around the house, filing paperwork, etc. came easily.
Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



jez259
Member since: 20 November 2006
Total points: 842 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I use to be like you, hon. Now what I do is I pretend my work is due in before it actualy is..then I do just enough, but then I use the actual time left to make it better..



Source(s):



my school dayz.



</answer>



<answer from>



lordreit...
Member since: 15 June 2008
Total points: 13492 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Other - Careers & Employment



Psychology



Mental Health



</answer from>



<answer>



8 Steps to defeat procrastination:



1.	Pick one area in which you find procrastination most annoying (homework, studying for tests)
2.	Begin small and progress as you experience success. Be patient. Establish your own deadlines. Be realistic in setting a timetable.
3.	Break the project into smaller parts. Chip away at it in small bites. Don’t wait for that “big chunk” of time.
4.	Set a definite beginning time. Yuu must break the inertia of inactivity. If getting started is especially troublesome, set a time for 10 or 15 minutes. Commit yourself to doing something on the project until the timer rings. Then you can decide whether to stop or continue. Chances are you will gain momentum and continue after the timer stops. If not, try another 10 minutes later in the day.
5.	Do the most important things first. Avoid the distractions of the trivial and routine tasks when a higher priority job is waiting in the wings. Examining each task in light of your goals will help you set priorities.
6.	Reward yourself for completing parts of a major task. It may be something as a 10-minute walk, a Coke, or a call. Contract with yourself for a big reward for completion of important tasks. A pizza, sleeping extra late on a weekend, or shopping for something may help motivate you to complete the job. Be nice to yourself.
7.	Avoid perfectionism. Excellence is a sufficient level of performance for most things in life, and for many tasks (a new hobby, cleaning your room) adequacy is all that is necessary. Give yourself permission to be less than perfect. A good garden may have some weeds.  You might double the amount of time spent typing a paper, attempting to get the spelling perfect.  Could that extra time be better spent in another activity which will better help your grades? Probably so.
8.	Procrastination is a learned habit, and can supplanted with a more constructive habit, giving your greater control over your life. If procrastination has limited your achievements, do something about it now!



</answer>

<answer from>



wayfarou...
Member since: 05 April 2006
Total points: 27764 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



To recognize a happy ending, someone has to package the story of your life in a way that points it out to you.  Real life doesn't have a bunch of endings to your stories--so whether your current adventure is prolouge to your 'story' or the end of the first installment (with a sequel to come) is something you really don't know.



I read Glory Road by R. Heinlein--where he tried to prove that there is no such thing as 'happily ever after'.  Basically the hero helped the princess save the universe, slay the baddie, and they were married and returned to the wonderful palace--2/3 of the way through the book.  The rest of the story made the point that any real hero won't be happy lounging around the palace like a playboy, so happily ever after had to turn into something a little different.



</answer>



<answer from>



move on
Member since: 28 April 2008
Total points: 8615 (Level 5)

<original file>1367.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk63402.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



Elf #3
Member since: 24 November 2006
Total points: 15768 (Level 6)



</question from>



<question>



Where do you draw the line between empathy and co-dependency?



What symptoms or behaviors indicate that you've crossed the line from a healthy compassion and feeling to dysfunction?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



That's a really hard question to answer.  Every co-dependency situation is different, even though all of them share common elements.  The addicts use any trick they think will work to get them what they want.  For my cocaine-addicted daughter, it was money.



When I finally realized I was being conned, and shut off the money fountain, she had just given birth to her drug-addicted daughter....at age 42!!  Refusing to give her any more money was the hardest thing I've ever done.



I think what it really comes down to is that you have to use "tough love" if a person doesn't want to give up the addiction.  Nobody will change as long as their "routine" is still working to supply them with the whatever-it-is that they want.



</answer>






<original file>1369.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk63424.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



It's my opinion,deal w/it!
Member since: 31 August 2008
Total points: 3700 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Other - Society & Culture



</question from>



<question>



Why can't other see the signs of DEPRESSION?



Has someone ever mistaken your depression for laziness...?



</question>



<additional details>



Parents are party responsible for their kids emotional well-being.  What's even worse are when the parents are causing the depression...



Why do you assume everyone has a doctor?



If you have a parent that notices their kid sleeps a lot and doesn't seem to be the most emotional person, how can they blame it on laziness?



</additional details>



<answer from>



florease
Member since: 06 August 2008
Total points: 1048 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Depression causes you to become less motivated. Yes, If they don't understand that  been depress is a chemical imbalance which affects a person's whole psyche and the people can't function properly either physically or emotionally. Yes, they may think you are lazy.



Some people might say they are depressed when they are demotivated, tired or a little down, but the debilitating, day-to-day living with clinical depression it can be a nightmare.



Laziness is totally different to clinical depression, but yes it can be mistaken for the one who doesn't understand the Definition of depression.



Good luck!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Yes, this is true...



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Joy
Member since: 08 October 2006
Total points: 3091 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



People do tend to blame depression on laziness and hypochondria. They think you should just snap out of it and stop feeling sorry for yourself. They don't understand it and being around it makes them uncomfortable. Sadly many people are just plain ignorant on the subject. On the other hand a person who is depressed may not realize they're depressed. The fortunate ones have someone (friend or family) who recognize the signs and see they get help. Others recognize the signs themselves and get help. Education is important both for the person suffering the mental illness and the people around them. You can't ignore the symptoms, they don't just go away.



</answer>

<answer from>



Dr. Bob
Member since: 23 January 2008
Total points: 17378 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



It sounds like you may be ready to get into Dr. Alfred Adler (the first psychiatrist to work with Freud, the first to leave him, and cdertainly the first psychiatrist in modern times to be considered a feminist or at least a male/female equalitarian.



When he debated Freud in early 1911, Adler suggested that some of the psychological problems (neuroses) women had in his day (and in Austria) was a result of "macsuline protest," or their unwillingness to remain within the definition of womanhood imposed on them by the men of their society.



Here's something I wrote about it briefly in one of my books on Adler:



"[In the debates] he also offered his theory of masculine protest in which certain symptoms are explained as reactions to society’s definitions of male and female which limit both men and women to definitions by the dominant male culture. Only a few options were available, one of which was to engage in neurotic actions or thoughts. (Today we call these “cognitive disorders.”) Thus the individual’s inability (or unwillingness) to reconcile personal definitions with socially acceptable sexual roles results in neurosis. Adler said hysteria (a woman’s problem because “hysteria” is from the Greek word for womb) could be explained not by repressed childhood sexual memories (Freud) but as a protest against restrictive female role stereotypes in a masculine society. From the beginning, Adler was a believer in, and proponent of, equal rights among the sexes."



For more on this: http://www.lifecourseinstitute.com



-- Dr. Bob, Adlerian Psychologist



</answer>

Total points: 7160 (Level 5)

<question>



People tend to get sad during winter and i guess almost everyone knew. can someone explain scientifically why ?



how do you prevent such and prepare for it mentally emotionally and maybe physically?



</question>



<answer from>



Elf #3
Member since: 24 November 2006
Total points: 15768 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I cannot explain why it happens, but I have experienced this phenomenon called Seasonal Affective Disorder.



My action plan calls for exercise 3-5 times a week in a brightly lit gym, and keeping my home well lit and scented with aromatherapy candles - citrus and bergamot scents lift my spirits.



</answer>



<answer from>



Izzy
Member since: 07 August 2008
Total points: 106 (Level 1)



</answer from>

eeege
Member since: 19 January 2008
Total points: 1182 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



I was always told that SAD was due to less light available during the winter and cloud cover.  One theory was to introduce UV lightbulbs in your house during these months but I think they ended up changing to these other lights that are very bright. (I don't remember the name...I'll see if I can find it.)



I end up doing a lot of exercise in the winter and spending as much time outside when it's clear.



But yeah, almost every light in my house is on during the winter months.  Then I go through a week with it being normal and then back to bright.  I was always told that the 'change' stimulates the brain.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seasonal_af...



</answer>

<original file>14761.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk64615.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



AYAME
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 4314 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



LIFE AND THE HIGH WAY....?



in ur opinion what are the similarities and differences between life and the high way ??



in my opinion :
the high way represents life ..cars represent humans .. similar cars r like soul mates, the different ones r family members, Friends, companions, co-workers and even enemies !! and when a car leaves the high way -in our case- it means death !



what do u think .. share ur thoughts if u don't mind :) and if u have a different way to represent life .. it would be great if u share it too :)



thanx in advance



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



The highway is like a path you take in life to reach a certain destination, and you can either choose to stay on this path or take shortcuts that may be good or bad for you.



Cars are people, some driving faster than others because they think they know exactly what's ahead or they think they're able to grow fast without seeing what's really there beforehand. These would be people who speed thru life, thinking they know everything and want to grow up fast, and then they crash and burn out faster (flat tires, low gas, or car crash represents this).



The cars that go slower (steady people who take their time) who drive the speed limit (they're on the level they should be) have a more safer journey than the ones that speed.



Those who take different paths or shortcuts (quicker and easier ways thru life) could end up at the right place (good life) or the wrong place (bad life), depending on how well they know what locations are where (what life leads to). Those in the wrong path don't make it back (people end up dying or in jail).



It's our (cars) decision to make about what we want to do with our life (what roads you drive on/take to get to the right destination). We have maps and directions (role models, people willing to help us, friends, family) to help us along the way, but it's up to us to make the choice.



</answer>

<question>



Prevent self from being stuckup?



I'm thirteen and I go to a very good private school and I play two instruments right now and am gonna start playing guitar as well soon. I do gymnastics and I am currently asking if I could take hip hop lessons.



I am so blessed to have all these things and I really do want to be kind to everyone and treat everyone nicely. I really want to think positively but I'm scared that all this will go to my head and if I become really good at something I'll.. yea let it go to my head.



I mean it happens to a lot of people. Whether they were already nice or mean. I think personality is the most important thing ever.



You know, beauty is only skin deep but your attitude is to the bone.



I'm very lucky and I know that. But I'm worried that I'll forget and let all this stuff go to my head.



I would try and earn the money to start hip hop lessons myself, but where I'm from, everyones already got maids to do work for them. Dog walking, babysitting, everything.

<question from>



lesson
Member since: 15 August 2007
Total points: 1066 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



How can you tell if you are doing something for you?



whats a good way to tell if you are doing something for yourself or just to follow the crowd.



</question>



<answer from>



move on
Member since: 28 April 2008
Total points: 8633 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



I look around and I don't see a crowd.



</answer>



<answer from>



Forceof1
Member since: 13 June 2006
Total points: 1711 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



If whatever you're doing makes you feel good inside, than you're doing it for yourself.



</answer>



<answer from>



dvcgurl
Member since: 21 November 2006
Total points: 10611 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



u know in your gut that thats what i one and no one else wants it like shp for u dnt go with anyone so u know only u want it



</answer>



<answer from>



SC
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 1220 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you see that you're doing something because you want to fit in, to be accepted and liked by others, you're forcing yourself to do it, and it's going out of your way to help others, you're not really doing it for yourself, but for them.



You do things for yourself when you don't care what others think, when you feel good about it, when it helps you out a lot, and when you don't have to worry about doing the same thing for others.



</answer>



<answer from>



precious...
Member since: 20 June 2008
Total points: 263 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



ask yourself would you do it if no one else was. If the answer is yes, then you're doing it for you. If no, then you're following the crowd.



</answer>



<answer from>



New York Love
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 664 (Level 2)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



I guess it would make sense to simply ask yourself, "Hey, is this something I really want to do or am I only doing it because everyone else is?"  Would it be something you would still do even if you were the only one?



</answer>

<answer>
