<answer from>



Bill
Member since: 08 December 2006
Total points: 14183 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



First, take your time.  You can always "choose a path in life".  Some have done so in their 80s (!), though not many.  Point is, you don't have to do this at any particular point.  Since it is a major decision, take your time.  An except is, if you are in college and facing your 3rd year, you would likely need to decide on a major.
If you are conflicted, and that led to this question ("p.s: in my case i can't choose a mix of both based on my circumstances."), you are not ready.  Give it time, write everything down (all the possibilities, every aspect, and reasons for and against each--that you can think of).  Take time, again, to develop your list.  Wait until you see the way more clearly, AND both your head and our heart give you the go ahead.
You need both, or you could make a major mistake.
A slow decision that is a good one is far superior to a poor quick one.



</answer>



<answer from>



SC
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 1220 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



if you feel that it's something you want to do with your life, something or someone's trying to hinder you from doing it, or you feel that you're willing to sacrifice anything or overcome any obstacle for it, you should follow your heart.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tommy R
Member since: 05 September 2008
Total points: 388 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Unless you are REALLY lucky, your heart will get broken at least once in your life (hopefully that happens before you get married). Your mind is the one that does all the thinking, but the heart brings you more joy and/or pain.



Which one do YOU trust more?  Has anyone asked your gut yet? If it seems like a silly idea, it might just be that. Or not.



Now I am confused. Lol



Or: Always take the path less trodden.



But that's just me. And "follow Jesus" would be my last on my list.... no, it wouldn't even be on my list.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sarah Ray
Member since: 09 March 2007
Total points: 5391 (Level 5)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>

<answer from>



TraumaMa...
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 103 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It could be he has a low testosterone level. This happened with my husband. This is not like erectile dysfunction in any way. With erectile dysfuction the male parts do not work properly but the desire to have sex is still there. With a low testosterone level, all the parts work properly but the desire to have sex is NOT there because of the low level of testosterone. I guess you could say they have a very low libido. After running several blood test the doctor put my husband on testosterone replacement therapy and our sex life got better. Tiredness is also a symptom. Take your husband for a physical and bring this problem up to the doctor. My husbands doctor said this was a common problem with men but they usually don't talk about the fact that they just don't have the desire to have sex.



</answer>



<answer from>



Carol N
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 103 (Level 1)



</answer from>

Is there an age difference between you? He may have become less interested because of that. Some men do!



</answer>

<answer>



first of all its a competitive field that you need a masters and sometimes a phd for. theres 2 types of therapists..psychatrists and psychologists. psychatrists also have their doctors degree so they can counsel people and dispense medications and can sometimes act as a regular doctor.
psychologists deal with more counseling and give out IQ tests and learning disability tests. and do more behavior therapy with people.
so basically what therapists do is they help people and listen to people one on one and you have to deal with people from mild depression to severe schizophrenia. you might do simple chat sessions or intense behavioral therapy. its a tough thing to do but if you know what your doing and your organized it won't be a problem.

<original file>15671.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk65626.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



Hayley G
Member since: 27 June 2008
Total points: 149 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How much does a psychologist make per year?



In London England, how much does a psychologist make per year?



</question>



<answer from>



neema s
Member since: 21 June 2006
Total points: 5341 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Psychologists' Earnings



It varies - depending on location, experience, education, etc.



According to http://www.apa.org/monitor/mar00/facts.h... about $60,000 - $80,000+ - information is almost six years old though.



According to http://swz.salary.com/salarywizard/layou... generally $65,000 - $85,000



According to http://www.bls.gov/k12/social04.htm $1138,000 - $1165,000



Here is more input:



There are WIDE variations in part because psychologist is a fairly broad term - pay is going to vary depending on where one practices and what kind of practice one has, not to mention education, etc. For instance, a psychologist in NY is going to make a lot more money, probably, than a psychologist in a small town in the Appalachian mountains. On the other hand the latter's cost of living is MUCH lower. Also, you don't state what country you are talking about. I just assumed USA, because it was easier. I just went into Google and searched with the terms psychologist and pay. You might also want to check with your local library. Narrow down your question, if possible, for more accurate results.



The median expected salary for a typical psychologist in the United States is $72,487.



There are too many different ranges of psychology to put it simply. But, generally, they get that money flowin'! I'm suggesting around $50,000+ salary. It most definitely could be higher but it depends in what field of study and if the demand is high. However, that's if your willing to spend several years on psychology education. But it all "pays off" and it's definitely worth it.



Most careers in pyschiatry earn up to about $163,144. Due to the fact that psychiatrists are doctoral level professionals you would or should be expecting to make up to more than 100k.



Psychiatry is much different than psychology. A psychiatrist is a medical doctor that can prescribe medicine to his/her patients. Most psychiatrists no longer provide therapy but tend to treat mental disorders by prescribing and managing medication. A psychologist holds a PhD or a PsyD (Doctor of Psychology) and treats mental disorders using psychotherapy. The tend to make much less than a psychiatrist. Depending on where they work...(private practice, hospitals, schools) psychologist salaries range from 20,000 to well, well over 100,000. There is no real median.



Psychologists can be paid very different salaries and rates. Some of the best therapists charge their clients hundreds of dollars per hour. Counselors at clinics and non-profit organizations might make minimum wage. The best income in the field goes to psychiatrists, who have an MD.



Some psychologists work for the state in administrative positions, evaluating people at prisons and mental health facilities. Others may work at state employment service or other state facilities that need psychologists. The specific dollar numbers vary from state to state. Some psychologists work for private industry and some are self employed. The pay scale varies greatly, partially depending on the opportunities that came to the psychologist and partly depending on the skill of the psychologist. Some psychologists who work in a private office can make a very good living, but like most professions, only the best will be able to make the top dollars. If you aren't very good you won't get many customers in a private practice situation. If you ARE very good, you can set your own price and you'll still get people pounding on your door to give you money.



The median salary for a psychologist in Denver, Co for example is $78, 668 per year. Try www.monster.com and you can refine your search to any city in the US. The career section allows you to search for this data and its free.



The range can vary from $20,000 a year to $100,000 a year, depending on what and where they practice. Check out salary.com or the occupational outlook handbook online for all kinds of salaries.



According to the most recent American Psychological Association salary survey (2001), the overall 11-12-month median salary for licensed doctoral-level clinical psychologists was $72,000.
To learn more about clinical psychology, go to the website for the Society of Clinical Psychology:
http://www.apa.org/divisions/div12/about...



The average salary varies according to experience and the location of the practice. Here is the most recent (2003) APA salary survey.
For a doctorate:
College psychology faculty made about $62,000 per year.
Research psychologists made between $78,000 and $95,000 per year.
The average salary for a clinical psychologist is about $75,000.
School psychologists made an average of $78,000.
Industrial-organizational psychologists made an average of $130,059 (this number is misleading..there were a lot of outliers).
Administration of applied psychology positions had an average salary of $143,344 (this number is also misleading for the same reasons stated above).



</answer>



<answer from>



Bill
Member since: 08 December 2006
Total points: 14185 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



That's a very good answer above.
I would only add, to do well (jobs and pay), get a doctorate in psychology or at least be a licensed clinical psychologist or social worker.



</answer>

<original file>16112.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk66117.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



Horse Rider
Member since: 18 April 2008
Total points: 1362 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



I asked a question similar....?



I want to be a doctor but specialize in psychology, do I need physics to achieve this, because I don't need to work machinery or anything like that... Do I? Thanks!



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



You don't typically need physics if you're gonna be a M.D.  Biology, chemistry, anatomy and physiology, maybe some maths (such as statistical analysis).



However, what you need to decide is what career path you want in psychology.  Here's a basic breakdown of "titles":



Psychiatrist - An medical doctor (that means med school, interning and residency w/ specialization in psychiatry).



Clinical Psychologist - That's a PhD kind of "doctor".  No med school, so no ability to prescribe drugs, BUT you pretty much do everything else a psychiatrist would do.



Then, there are the other kinds of psychology specialties which include counseling, forensics, etc., etc. some of which may also offer a PhD level of academic preparation.



So the first question is what kind of "doctor" do you want to be.  Then, research what schools you would be looking to gain such a degree from and what the degree plans at those schools require for completion.



Hope that helps.



</answer>

<question from>



Mike
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 281 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What is the best way to deal with a bully at work?



I work with a fellow who fancies himself as being "open-minded" and "tolerant", but the reality is that he is a smarta** know-it-all who gets a great deal of delight out of being argumentative and verbally abusive.



His idea of a "conversation" is to lecture at people, and when they disagree with him, or simply get tired and get up and walk out, he dismisses them as stupid and unenlightened. His patronizing attitude is really grating.



When you point this out to him, he becomes hysterical and defensive, and says that we "need to lighten up", and that he is "only kidding".



HR and management ignore his tirades, so we are pretty much left to our own defenses. I'd like to think that he really is a good person who just has poor social skills, but the reality is that he is just downright mean, and enjoys being a jerk.



My guess is that he is very insecure, and knows deep inside that his behavior is wrong and that nobody likes him, so he keeps lashing out because he can't deal with his own faults. Still, I'm not sure that is license to be forgiving and "take the high road". Fact is, he's a twerp who needs to have his clock cleaned . . . obviously not physically, because it's not worth losing our jobs for . . . but once-and-for-all in a verbal rebuke that lets him know we are fed up and we are not kidding.



What are your thoughts?



</question>

<question from>



J C
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I can't find happiness, can anyone help me figure out what is going on?



I am junior in engineering at a big 10 school known for the subject. my family has a history of bi polar disorder and addiction to drugs and alcohol, i have been in and out of depression before and I've dealt with it and come back stronger than ever, but this time is different; however mind you i understand my family loves me and would care if i were gone i have no desire to end my life, i just want to be as proud of myself as they are of me. The things I am good at and love to do just don't satisfy me the way they use to. I am paying for school on my own through loans and whatever money i can make over the summer interning. I am good at what i do, i know this, my bosses know this, even though its not comforting knowing that... which it should given the field. I use to love to draw, play hockey, play tennis, hang out with my friends, now i just find myself being unsatisfied with everything as if i am not good enough to do any of it. I understand this is not a simple question, just asking what is wrong with me is an issue in itself in that is not a simple question expecting a simple answer.



</question>



<answer from>



Rottie Mom
Member since: 27 July 2008
Total points: 7167 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think that you're intended to hold a position higher than the one you're preparing for.  Your spirit (if you're a believer) or subconscious is prodding you to move forward to something more challenging.  That's why nothing is satisfying to you now, to challenge you to get up and go find something better.  I've been through that twice.  It's a hard step to take, but now I'm glad I did it.  And it gets easier with practice.



</answer>



<answer from>



Julia
Member since: 31 August 2006
Total points: 1554 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Reading your history, not just medical/family, but how you USED TO love to do things, I really think it is clinical depression.  Fortunately and unfortunately, ant-depressants are available.  However, if you should chose to do so, research shows taking the meds as well as talk therapy is the most effective.



However, having said that, remember that happiness comes from within, not from DOING or receiving from an outside source.



It is no measure of health to be well adjusted to a profoundly sick society. ~Krishnamurti



</answer>



<answer from>



Stiwaaa
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 142 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I recently underwent something similar.



I am med student at Johns Hopkins, 38S on my MCAT, and almost full ride scholarship. Anyone would assume that I was ecstatic, I wasn't.



I became apathetic, loss all of my drive, and just didn't give a damn anymore, like you I wasn't suicidal. I just found it hard to really put meaning to anything in life.



Here is what was wrong: I was bored with life, and the trivial nature of ... everything.



I'm gonna assume that you're an intellectual capable of strong rational and abstract thought with a large helping of common sense. Our decisions come easier and seem more obvious than those around us, we have become so good at what we know that we temporarily forget about adversity and take for granted the concept of 'not knowing'.



My advice: take on activities that are completely foreign to you, something what you will make you challenge yourself again.  It wont be easy to get up, but find something that will light a fire under your ***.



Good luck, and keep on keepin on.



</answer>

<question>



Why do you start losing weight when you think your in love?



Ive noticed whenever i like someone or am in love or even think im in love i start to lose weight. is everyone like this? what causes that? i mean its not a problem for me that i need to get treated for or anything, not depressed. just lose weight. any clues and is it normal?



</question>



<answer from>



European Female
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 384 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It has to do with serotonin. Serotonin has also to do with your feeling of being full. You over-produce serotonin when in love, and thus lose your appetite.



</answer>

very good answer



</asker's comment>

<question>



What role do habits play in the formation of one's personal identity? ?



What role do habits play in the formation of one's personal identity?



</question>



<answer from>



Michael B
Member since: 30 June 2006
Total points: 4022 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It what you learn from when your a child and your habits build you into the person you are today.



</answer>



<answer from>



dolly 16
Member since: 03 September 2008
Total points: 129 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



well a habit is ten natures.



</answer>



<answer from>



Dr. Bob
Member since: 23 January 2008
Total points: 17374 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



A habit is one of the several types of Patterns we develop or create in childhood to manage our lives from then on.



Patterns, habits, memories, etc., all help form our personality...in fact, we could almost say they ARE our personality.



Check this web site and click on the "LEAP" link to see ten patterns we all create, based on the major psychological concepts of Dr. Alfred Adler: http://www.lifecourseinstitute.com



-- Dr. Bob, Adlerian Psychologist



</answer>

I think it might be because you have been very tired lately? Or falling asleep very quickly. This speeds up the transition from awake to asleep and when you fall into a deep sleep, you dont dream consciously anymore.

<original file>2228.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk67093.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



deo
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I'm feeilng jealousy,when anyone do better,what i've to do?plz help me?



</question>



<answer from>



olibobwa
Member since: 03 June 2007
Total points: 959 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



as long as it makes you strive to do better and you don't sabatoge their success it's not called jealousy it's called being competitive



</answer>



<answer from>



eeege
Member since: 19 January 2008
Total points: 1187 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



If you're wishing bad on someone because they did better than you did then your focus is on the wrong person.  (Jealousy stems from low self esteem.)



Don't compare yourself to others' abilities but compare yourself to yours.  When I shot archery, I competed with myself and didn't much care how else other people did.  Pretty soon, I was winning the respect of 300 shooters.



Did you do the best that you could do?  If so, then let it stop there.  If not, figure out what you could do to improve.  But if you live your day based on whether other people do better or worse than you do, then you give them power over your feelings.



The more you are proud of YOUR achievements the higher the self esteem you'll obtain and then you'll genuinely be glad for others' success.



</answer>

<question from>



Miss E
Member since: 06 October 2008

</question from>



<question>



School spirit made me cringe and group work made me want to break my leg... why?



In highschool my friends and I were basically a group of loners who hung out together, listened to nirvana and metal and smoked marijuana. we avoided group work with other peers, we refused to participate in activities on school camps, we didn't join in swimming carnivals or sports days, and we didn't celebrate school spirit. i spent a lot of time studying at nights and on the weekends. on weekends we would go to the cool kids parties and get really drunk. all my friends went on to university and have jobs now or are nearly finished their degrees. i have one degree and im onto my second. i was just wondering what type of people my friends and i were in highschool?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



You were the nerds.  I was a member of the smelly AND nerdy crowd because I lived on a farm and had to help with milking the cows before getting on the school bus.  I also had no school spirit, and I've never figured out the reason for that.



You don't fit into the standard mold.  I'm sure you're having a hard time of it now, but in a few years you'll have new friends in a new place, and you'll be satisfied with your life.



.



</answer>

<question>



Are people born with low self esteem? what causes it?and how to overcome it? ?



Any helpful information about the subject is appreciated. Thank you.



</question>



<answer from>



My name is my business
Member since: 29 May 2008
Total points: 3360 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Elections



</answer from>



<answer>



Some people are born with it, having inherited from a parent. Others develop it in the course of their life.



To overcome, you've got to go the source of the problem. What causes you to have this low self esteem? Finding the root will enable you to do better understand your low self esteem and finding solutions for it.



</answer>



<answer from>



damos92
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 380 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



no i dont think so. i used to be very confident, not shy and in my opinion had a great personality. i was liked by everyone and was just a generally nice person to be around, i know this. but things happened in my life that knocked me for six and i now have a super low self esteem which i need to get back. its hard as i know i can be a good person yet i feel trapped in this situation. i have become extremely insecure about my looks and this makes me conscience in social situations. like as im always thinking about myself and others perception of me then i struggle to communicate properly with people as my mind is never really focused. so to sum up, you devolop low self esteem and i think the way to overcome it is to build up confidence within yourself, as when i feel confident very rarely, i have good self esteem. so just be confident about your looks and stuff and you will feet better, gd luck x.



</answer>



<answer from>



abyloϞiaϞ βaЯbaЯiaϰ
Member since: 25 February 2007
Total points: 2185 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



it comes i believe from nurture , society, the media, their peers, people around them negatively influencing them or undermining them until they feel useless and unworthy.



damos92  summed it up brilliantly.



</answer>



<answer from>



eeege
Member since: 19 January 2008
Total points: 1189 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



No, you aren't born with it.  You get it from your parents.



According to Erikson's theory, you develop it from 6 yrs to teen years and according to Maslow, you develop self esteem after you've had the first two levels of his pyramid met.



Erikson has empirical evidence (which means it has a lot of data to back it up).  That's why I use him in almost all my answers.



And if your parents meet Maslow's level 1 (giving you shelter, food and clothes) and 2 (creating a safe place for you to fail, rebel, etc.) you'll be able to obtain level 3.  Iow, you'll have the objects that you need and the acceptance that you need in order to try new things and develop your own relationships.



BTW, it also helps if your friends give you a safe place to make mistakes but that's a hard thing to find until you get to the later teen years.



Hope this helps.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychosocia...
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maslow's_hi...



</answer>

<question>



Recurring dream... Why do I have it?



I hear the voice of someone I love "and lost" asking me details of things I am unaware---- I wake up then I take comfort in knowing it was just a dream, and again I sleep, to dream................. I hope nonone I Love knows of what what I dream....  for my dreams are simply dreams... I pray that the pain i feel will never effect those close to me but I can't stop these dreams, is there any advice short of medication to make them go away?



</question>



<answer from>



Kassia K
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 137 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



http://findforur.onlinetournamentdaily.c...
you can get much information in this website, kindly stay a minute in website and check anyone link at a time



</answer>



<answer from>



nightowl...
Member since: 27 May 2007
Total points: 5394 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I studied with a psychoanalyst who said that a dream will stop only when you have discovered its meaning. It is the subconscious giving us a message. The person you lost is actually a part of your personality. What characteristics does this person have? That is the part of you trying to speak. Worry less about what is actually being said, but instead how it makes you feel. I don't know the details but you said you felt unaware. In other words you are confused. Is there a decision in your life that is confusing you? The person you lost represents the part of you in conflict and confusion. I hope that helps you think on it a little clearer.



</answer>

<answer>



In the famous bobo dolls experiment, children imitated what they had seen adults on tv do, by violently hitting dolls. This would seem to suggest this. Certainly children are more impressionable then adults. However, i child cant learn to speak from television as it is inherent in the human mind that it isnt real. This would inform us that television is escapism and even children can distinguish it as false. This is a long debate, but tv and video games are a current scape goat for the present moral panic and before this rap, metal, radio have all been blamed. Parenting and peer pressure are bigger issues.



</answer>

<answer from>



trinity_...
Member since: 18 February 2007
Total points: 401 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The majority of studies show short term effects in younger children especially boys when watching violence on tv, but older children and teenagers are less influenced by television.



There was one study, I forget who conducted it, that had children watch either someone hitting or hugging a blow up toy, when put in a room with a similar blow up toy the children copied what they had seen earlier on the screen.



Source(s):



http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob...



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



How can I get my oldest son to help his siblings?



I have three kids, two sons and one daughter. My oldest son who is 32 runs a couple business, own three houses, two business properties, and coach kick boxers and few professional fighters.
He has always been the type who keeps his eyes on the economy, current event, and everything. He have always been very paranoid type, he have been hoarding on precious metals and diamond, investing, and spread moneys in couple different countries ever since he started his business.  Ever since around 2004, he have been freaking out about the economy and telling everyone to start keep their eyes on the economy. But we didn’t take him seriously.
My daughter who is 27 and her husband bought a house three years ago and just opened a construction business about two years ago, they are going through a incredible tough time right now. I’ve never saw my daughter so badly stressed out and upset. They’re seriously considering closing the business down and walk away from the house. On top of all this, they have two children.
My youngest son is 24, just graduated from college but is still living with me and my husband because he was unable to afford to live on his own with the high gas price and trying to find a job. It just got worse for him, his car broke down and he doesn’t have the moneys to afford to repair it. He also desperately wants to purchase a house while the price is low.
My husband got laid off from his job three weeks ago and is still trying to find a job. So we’re very tight on moneys and living off my income and our saving.
We have tried to ask my oldest son for help. He told my daughter that since she and her husband was spending moneys like water and buying bunches of junks then a year after they opened the business, they take a expensive trip to Europe. So he’s not going to help them out unless my daughter sell her car that she adore, close down their business, and her husband to pawn their expensive brand new entertainment system.
He told my youngest son that he’s not going to help with car since it will just cost more moneys in long run, he’ll buy my son a bicycle. As for the house, my oldest son say if my youngest son would have saved his moneys instead of buying a car, throw moneys away all way through college, and listened to his advice, he’d be able to have a house by now.
Normally I and my husband would help our children, but we’re in no position to. We’re shocked by how cold my oldest son is. He has nearly or even around a million of dollars in assets or cash. He could spare just some moneys for his brother and sister and not even feel it a bit and make a big difference for them. But he refused.
I’ve tried to explain that my daughter and her husband have a very tough time with starting business because they have two kids so they want to reward themselves for making it last a year. Especially since my oldest son have been all around the world and talk about it all of the time. They wanted to see what it is like and if what he say is true. My oldest son just say that it is their problem since they never listen to him when he warned them about things or suggest a advice.
He could easily help my youngest son and my youngest son will pay him back. My oldest son knows it. My oldest son may not mind walking or riding bike everywhere, but he’s incredible athletic, even for his age. So it’s unfair for him to use that as a measure stick. My youngest son may make some bad decision in college, but that is normal part of college. My oldest son doesn’t know what it’s like to be in college. He attend a community college and dropped out after a year to pursue a career in kickboxing before he start all businesses.
My oldest son also repeatedly tells us that if we’d have listen to him long time ago, we’d not be in the spot we are now. I’m so offended by this. I don’t like how he expected us all to go through all hassle to do what he did.
I just wish he’d have some heart and help out. I don’t understand his issue with all of this.



</question>

<question from>



traf
Member since: 21 October 2006
Total points: 10272 (Level 6)



</question from>



<question>



How do I develop good people skills?



When communicating with stranger and sometimes family. I feel like my voice sounds crazy to the listener which causes me to have trouble forming logical and fluent sentences. It's like i go brain dead and can't think of what to say.



</question>



<answer from>



aundinea...
Member since: 11 September 2008
Total points: 1297 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It's not people skills you need. It sounds like you need just a touch of confidence. :) Stop paying attention to your voice! Very few people like their voice. (Trust me I know! I am an actress for stage--which is the most difficult place to hide a horrible voice-- and find my own voice almost nauseating, HOWEVER, people tell me all the time that it sounds sexy and adorable! :P I have done several one woman shows, and it is nice to be reassured that my voice is ok, by how well people pay attention to me while I act before them.) If you really don't like your voice in another week, sign up for voice classes. This will teach you how to change your voice to your liking.



Good Luck!



Source(s):



professional stage actor 20yrs.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I always thought voice lessons were for singing. Learned something new today.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



CoolFore...
Member since: 20 April 2008
Total points: 1024 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I know the feeling. I have pretty bad speaking and communication skills. I used to get nervous very easily when people talked to me.



It's one of those things that just goes away with experience. I agree with the above poster that working as a cashier does help develop people skills if you're willing to put forth an effort. For me, going to University also helped me get rid of my nerves because you're constantly meeting and interacting with people.



I know JUST what you mean. Sometimes you can't stay focused when trying to deliver a logical sentence and halfway you sort of lose your train of thought due to nervousness. Even I still have that problem.



</answer>



<answer from>



Abstract Parade
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 2331 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Psychology



Friends



Singles & Dating



</answer from>



<answer>



Don't concentrate on how you sound when you're having a conversation - concentrate on the subject you're talking about and what the other person wants to hear. When you talk, don't think "I sound crazy right now." It will only direct your attention away from the conversation. Relax and realize that people are not judging you and they see you in a whole different perspective than how you see yourself. Before other people accept you, you have to accept and be sure of yourself. Have confidence - everyone wants to talk to that type of person.



Best of luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



danscow
Member since: 24 July 2007
Total points: 114 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The best talkers listen. There's a best seller by Dale Carnegie called "How to Win Friends and Influence People". It should be required reading in school. I would say about 80% of people do not practice the skills in this book, but should.



One trick I do when I feel like you do is to just ask the other person a question. Take the talking burden off of yourself for a few seconds to give yourself a breather. Works great on interviews. Plus people love any evidence that you've listened and processed what they've just said. So, paraphrase what people say. This is kind of cheating but people love it. You basically say what they just said to you back to them but switch up the words a bit.



</answer>



<answer from>



S F
Member since: 03 June 2008
Total points: 1384 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sounds odd, but practice. Focus on the topic at hand....smile when you talk, of course unless it is a gruesome topic... Don't worry about what others 'hear'... worry more about what you are saying, what you are meaning... and just focus on that....their perception of you will be formed no matter what. Make it the more sincere value of what you are contributing, then just the mere sound of what you are saying. What is better then How any day...



</answer>



<answer from>



deasl4fu...
Member since: 24 April 2006
Total points: 439 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Everyone has that problem. Try making a joke out of it. Example you start to say something it comes out backwards or you stutter it laugh about it, and mock yourself. Others will enjoy it too. It won't feel so awkward. When it gets bad for me and I really can't think I usually so "sorry brain fart".



</answer>



<answer from>



laurakat...
Member since: 25 February 2007
Total points: 139 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Go out of your way to make chit chat with strangers. The more you do this the more natural it will come to you.



</answer>



<answer from>



celticag...
Member since: 28 September 2007
Total points: 3218 (Level 4)

Yes, that artwork
Member since: 28 September 2008
Total points: 176 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Observe the emotion, but don't touch it.
Noone wants to have negative feelings, yet when they arise what do they do? They grab onto it and feel a strong burn. Then you ask them why and they say they had a good, rational reason for being upset, so they grabbed the emotion. If they just start using their logic to say "if you attach to this emotion that's arising you're going to get burnt, so just let the emotion be and watch it die on its own" rather than "this emotion's arising and I so have a good reason for agreeing with it that I'm gonna grab it as hard as I can" they wouldn't burn themselves.



Anger, stress, fear etc. are all like a boiling pot of water. They don't care why you're putting your hand it; all they know is to burn whatever touches them. So don't touch them. Practice meditation and you'll learn to avoid putting your hand in because your logic will program you to move away from the pot instead.



</answer>



<answer from>



paul samysudamanisrihariniranjoo
Member since: 22 March 2008
Total points: 1524 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



wait and then decide.



</answer>

<answer>

<question from>



ஜThank you God for everythingஜ
Member since: 03 March 2008
Total points: 5287 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



Are "Slow learning disabilities" for life?



Is it slow then catch up or always going to be behind?



Thanks!



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Generally, it is slow for life - but that does not mean one cannot excel at life.  Memory has a factor here too, as does maturity and personal responsibility, upbringing, and a host of other factors.  It is more noticeable in an academic atmosphere because it takes longer to learn, but with hard work and lots of studying, you CAN learn and even test better than "average" learners who have not studied!



</answer>

<question>



Why did i feel like that everybody hates me when i didn't do anything am serious???????????



i have a feeling like that why is that?????????????



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



You feel bad about yourself.  You feel unworthy, hopeless, disliked anxious, and many other things because of the way you entertain negative thoughts feelings and emotions that are deceiving you into believing this rubbish about yourself.  Your self-esteem is low and you have no confidence in yourself.



You need to stop this because you are going a destructive path and its not necessary.  You need to do the opposite and substitute negative thoughts feelings and emotions with positive thoughts and the only way you will succeed in this matter is to realize that you matter to God and even to the world, because God brought you here for a reason.  You are not a mistake.  You are somebody.  You are unique, priceless and precious.  You have talents, gifts and skills given to you to use.  You have allowed people to dominate and oppress you in the past, possibly a parent or a brother or sister or even people around you have bullied you.  You need to stand up and be accountable to self.  You are worthy and acceptable and you are imagining things that are not there by entertaining presumptuous and assumptious thoughts! You think that people think badly of you when they are probably wondering why you look at them funny because they cant figure you out.  People will treat you the way you treat yourself.  You have to get out of this bad habit.  So from now on begin saying: " Lord Jesus forgive me for insulting you and telling you that you made a mistake with me. Thank you for showing me that you car about me.  Thank you for all my blessings.  Give me the will to will to be positive and remind me every time I get negative that I am totally off the mark.  Father become very real in my life and lead me besides still waters where you say you will restore my soul.  I place my faith trust and hope in you. Help me not to be so self absorbed and to fight the pit of self pity where all the negative things dwell.  Take me to the fields of hope and to the mountains of possibility, opportunity and abundance. Run the race of time with me and pick me up when I fall and also give me strength when paths become too steep for me to carry on. Thank you Lord for rescuing me!"



Go out and be a friend to someone who is lonely, hurting, poor and helpless, do things for your parents, do things for others and when you do this you will forget all about these issues that are trying to break you down.  You have one thing in your favour and that is the freedom of choice.  Now choose the right and positive things and let go all the negative things.  Its something you have to work at all the time until the old bad habit you cultivated disappears and you have substituted it with a better one. You are the master of your own destiny and no one is responsible for what you have allowed to consume you all these years but you.  Rise up and be the person God wants you to be.  God bless you!



</answer>

<question>



What Makes A Person Intelligent?



I have asked a similar question on this before.  But would appreciate advice or views on the following.



Are all people born with the same intelligence level?  Are we all born the same?
Or is it down to how that person takes note in class?



My previous question on the above resulted in an answerer saying that it was not down to genes-as this person was studying at uni.  He was the first person from that family to attend anything like that.  So it’s not down to genes (??)



So if that is true is it down to that person paying more attention in class-hence succeeding in life.



What makes a person intelligent?



Thank you



</question>



<answer from>



RR
Member since: 12 September 2008
Total points: 137 (Level 1)



</answer from>

</answer>



<answer from>



Pro Second
Member since: 21 September 2008
Total points: 262 (Level 2)

<answer>



I think about intelligence this way:



If our brains is like a computer:



Intelligence would be the processor and ram (doesn't change).



Knowledge and experience would be the software (changes).



Although, intelligence may help our processing/rational abilities without knowledge you are pretty much useless.



</answer>

<answer from>



paul samysudamanisrihariniranjoo
Member since: 22 March 2008
Total points: 1526 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Maha
Member since: 28 August 2008
Total points: 2354 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Ramadan



</answer from>



<answer>



I'll have to say a combination of things:



1. Genes: you can't deny the relation, but it's certainly not the only nor the major influence.  I believe genes do have a role because some people need to work harder to understand the same thing despite the education and all other influences being the same.



2. Education: the more you study math as an example, the easier it becomes to understand it!



3. Actually using your brain (i.e. constant training): in the end it's like any other part of the body, use it and it will become stronger, don't use it and it will rust, or even worse - totally die out.



4. Age: unfortunately it's true, younger people still have more brain cells alive, plus, they still have a lot of empty space on their memory chip in the brain (metaphorically of course) to save new stuff and hence understand easier.



5. Food: if you don't eat enough, your brain doesn't either so it's no longer healthy, if you eat too much your whole body will be affected including the brain. And if there is wrong food and right food for the body, then there is some for the brain.



6. Self confidence: if you believe down deep that you are stupid, you make yourself stupid. The thing is, the brain is the quickest part of your body to actually respond to self induced things like this; smart people KNOW they are smart, not only BELIEVE it.



7. Passion: if you want to learn, you become smarter – it’s never the other way round, it’s not “smart people want to learn”. If a high school dropout that worked as, say, a telephone operator suddenly got a passion about leukemia (for some reason, say her son got it), she would want to learn more about it, she would slowly become smarter until she reaches a stage where she can actually argue with doctors and scientists about the subject!



Maybe there are other factors, but this is what I noticed.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sean C
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 104 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's how a person processes and responds to things that he/she has experienced. There are plenty of book smart morons out there as well a absolute foolish and immature people on top of the business world and rich, even running the world.



It's a choice that each individual makes at their own personal age of understanding and comprehension.



Again there are those who have not been groomed by family or school but simply have learned as they have gone alone the things that are worth knowing. Good, evil, right, wrong, life, death what are these things really?



An intelligent person takes the time to ponder, not just correctly answer what is fed him.



And you won't know until the actions show.



</answer>

<answer>



It simply means accept the point of view of somebody who does not see things the way you do.

Tid

<answer>

If others views have non sensical reasoning, I can't agree, or agree to disagree. But if they have a completely different view, but with an objective reasoning, I may not agree, but I respect it.

<question>

<answer from>



Cornish Granny
Member since: 15 June 2008
Total points: 3382 (Level 4)

<answer>



I can't provide a in-depth analysis on this, since i'm not educated in that matter, but as long as you want to understand the basics, you should see the movie Shawshank Redemption - it deals with the problem of institutionalism - when long term prisoners adapt themself to the prison enviroment, they create new values, they climb up the hierarchy latter inside the prison and they learn to survive. They do the same everyone does in the normal world, only in their own given micro-universe. No one wants to lose his home or social status, and neither do they. After releasing they start from zero, often being +60 years old.



Source(s):



http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111161/



</answer>

<question>



Discuss how one can avoid rewarding the wrong behaviors?



Occasionally, people unknowingly reinforce undesirable behaviors. Give and example of thes, discussing the consequences that resulted. Then finally, discuss how one can avoid rewarding the wrong behaviors.



</question>



<answer from>



dostifor...
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 105 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



do gud have gud



</answer>



<answer from>



Maha
Member since: 28 August 2008
Total points: 2358 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Ramadan



</answer from>



<answer>



I'll give you an example:



If I answer your question, you will take the answer and submit it to your teacher and get an A; but this is cheating, so if I answer this question I would be rewarding you for cheating, which is a wrong behavior.



Good luck in your assignment.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tid
Member since: 23 July 2008
Total points: 408 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Maybe for children, which is where it all really begins, undesirable behaviours, such as tantrums, bad language, or general misbehaving, should be nipped in the bud. Set out a punishment, and STICK TO IT. By not sticking to it, it reinforces subconsciously that they can continue to do it, slightly be punished, momentarily, but will effectively get away with the behaviour. By stopping it initially, they will know they should not do it.
By not rewarding the wrong behaviour, you don't give in to the initial punishment, and let it slide. Stick to your guns.



</answer>



<answer from>



lala_poo...
Member since: 21 March 2007
Total points: 1 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



be good



</answer>

<original file>5750.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk71006.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



chio m.
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What are the principles of knowledge retention?



in terms of cognitive psychology



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



well there are three ways to test a persons retention, they are called measures of retention, and are split into three measures - recall, recognition and relearning



Recall is the reproducing of information with the fewest cues to aid retrieval. There are 3 types of recall: free recall (reproducing information in any order with no cues), serial recall (reproducing information in the same order as learned) and cued recall (reproducing information with cues such as photographs to aid retrieval)



Recognition is selecting the correct information from amongst alternatives. For example, the multiple choice section on an exam



Relearning is the relearning of information already stored in memory. When you relearn information, it is much quicker.



Relearning is proven to be the most sensitive, or most effective, measure of retention, followed by recognition, followed by recall.



Source(s):



Year 12 Psychology student =) (this is all on my exam!)



</answer>

<question>



How to stop myself from ?



i have a problem.im an introvert person,and i wud say that i already accepted with who i am.i am comfortable with myself.at leisure time,i always spend myself alone in my room doing my fave thing,which is listening to the music.it is like a must to me everyday. i have seven housemates who get together a lot,like they like to hang out in the living room watching tv together.joking,talking and others.so im kinda feel left out and i also dont want my housemates to think that im avoiding them.the problem is i enjoy what i always do at leisure time alone,at the same time i also enjoy and want to join my housemates,who i can get along with,cause i always have fun being with them.spending time alone is no fun but it is more a like a release to me,after all day long being around with classmates and people,talking,which for most introverts,is mentally exhausting.kind of sick of being in my own world at my free time.i want to get toghter more with people but it's just that i can't stop myself from too being in my own world.how to just talk to people without feeling mentally exhausted?



</question>



<answer from>



Skage
Member since: 16 February 2008
Total points: 273 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



missy moo
Member since: 13 July 2008
Total points: 105 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



im an extravert but there was a time wen i becam introverted because of sum stuff in my life so i can relate......anyways stop thinking about how not 2 be mentally exhausted an go out there n jus hav fun!! dont think.....that never helps!! jus be impulsive!! find sumthing in the conversation n psyche urself up about it n TALK!! or if theres no interesting convo make it interesting!! be impulsive...if u feel shyness or tiredness creeping up on u....turn your back on it and HAVE FUN!! but if u relly r feeling way tired maybe thats the time 2 shut up but listen and laugh.....a erson acn say nothing, do nothing but still b thort fun if they laugh!!

<answer from>



Daphne
Member since: 05 September 2007
Total points: 4028 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I know how you feel. I think the best thing to do is to plan. if you are into a habit of always going to your room, and the usual tensions exhaust you, try planning one new, small, activity into your week. Make it something that involves someone else, and make sure you have some time to yourself that day. If it is something where you do something together, as well as talk, that would be good. Something like physical activity, a movie, or something artistic would be good. then you will have the activity itself to focus on and enjoy, and the talking won't be so hard.
I think that you sound a bit shy, as some introverts are. But we can be valued friends, trust me. I was a lot like you when I was in school, and still feel that way from time to time, but I have made meaningful relationships in my life.



</answer>

<question from>



bedbug
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 78 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Do you think that a confidence based from POPULARITY is wrong? ?



Why??? I was popular back in hs and i really didn't care what other think of me. I did lots of bad things w/c i normally don't do. I criticize people even if its not me. But still i don't care. Coz you know i still have the brains. But even since then i started to have gap w/ some close ppl.. why do you think is that? I really need an answer!



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I think popularity based confidence is perfectly fine if it is because you respect and love yourself, and you respect those around you. Someone who loves being in the skin they are in are infectious and people love to be around them. So that's good popularity.



But if you openly do bad things, and criticize people, well i don't agree with that. Those things don't make you popular. They make people fear you, so become friends or nice to you.



Remember, popularity isn't being the queen of the school. One of my best friends is quiet and hides behinds peoples shadows and lets them take the lime light, yet everyone knows and loves her because she respects each and every one of them and treats everyone equal.



I'd much rather have 3 or 4 really close friends who will stick by me no matter what, then a whole school who are only by me while im 'cool'



</answer>

<original file>6203.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk71510.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



Sameer A
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the correct meaning of psychology?



</question>



<answer from>



Lin-Lin
Member since: 18 July 2008
Total points: 302 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Psychology revolves around human thoughts and emotions.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bumble bee
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 404 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Psychology is the study of the nature and development of mind and behaviour in both humans and animals, including biological structures and processes that underpin and sustain both.



Or if you are looking for the summarized definition:
Psychology is the systematic study of the mind and behaviour.



Source(s):



My year 12 Psychology textbook =)



</answer>



<answer from>



LaJeh
Member since: 26 June 2008
Total points: 3522 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Psychology  is an academic and applied discipline involving the scientific study of mental processes and behavior. Psychologists study such phenomena as perception, cognition, emotion, personality, behavior, and interpersonal relationships. Psychology also refers to the application of such knowledge to various spheres of human activity, including issues related to everyday life (e.g. family, education, and employment) and the treatment of mental health problems. Psychologists attempt to understand the role of these functions in individual and social behavior, while also exploring the underlying physiological and neurological processes. Psychology includes many sub-fields of study and application concerned with such areas as human development, sports, health, industry, media, and law.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychology



</answer>

<answer>



Focus on the positive. make a list of all the things you like about you.
Do something nice for someone else. That almost always works.



</answer>



<answer from>



LaJeh
Member since: 26 June 2008
Total points: 3522 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Mind is the source for all these - never mind about others. Think yourselves as a winner born to win in the world. Why we should underestimate ourselves.



No one is better than you in the world
No one is superior than you in the world
No one is good as you are



These things will make you to feel very better and you do not have any low self esteem from now onwards. Be cheerful.



Source(s):



Personal experience.



</answer>



<answer from>



warm hearted guy
Member since: 03 June 2007
Total points: 3982 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



If there was only a pill we'd all make a fortune. Therapy has helped but I wish there was a cure as if it were a disease. Perhaps discovering what has brought you to this conclusion is something to consider. Have people in the past made you feel low, undesirable, stupid, unattractive,
unintelligent? have you been told that a sibling is more worthy than you?



Any of these things are contributors. Liking yourself when filled with doubts of self worth is difficult. I've certainly been there too. To quote my therapist, "maintain altitude." in other words hang in there. Good luck and wish I could give you a better answer.



</answer>



<answer from>



Daphne
Member since: 05 September 2007
Total points: 4028 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Think of any ability or talent that you have, and then use it to achieve a small goal. Whether it is to learn something, to teach something, to earn something, to give something for yourself, for your family or for your community, it will make you feel better about yourself. We are designed to have active mind, body, and soul, and to be part of a culture or a society. if you are excited about an activity, or engaged in what you do, you will feel more similar to others. You will see that no one is perfect, and we are all in this together.



</answer>

<answer from>



warm hearted guy
Member since: 03 June 2007
Total points: 3987 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's spelled liar.



Examine the reasons you lie. Are you lying so that people will like you more or find you more interesting? Are you doing something so wrong that you need to make excuses for your actions? To quote Judge Judy, it's easier to remember the truth than remember all the lies you've told.



I too told some wild lies when I was much younger and always seem to get caught. Can you imagine if your parents knew all the truths and things you've done. Yikes. I told my teacher I couldn't study because my mother had triplets. (I have one older sibling) i told a girlfriend that I was from California. All went well until she asked in front of everybody if I've ever been to Disneyland. When I said no, she said, you lived in California and you never went to Disneyland? At that time- I never left the east coast. My family's jaws dropped. So did mine.
These are not the same as saying I went to someone else's house instead of where i really was.  PS this all the truth!



</answer>



<answer from>



Shar Pei Lady
Member since: 14 June 2007
Total points: 1842 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You are NOT protecting yourself in lying.You are eating away at your conscience right now.Come forward,be honest,accept the consequences of whatever you lied about to stay out of trouble in the first place.YOU will sleep better tonight.



</answer>

<question>



Finding it very hard not to care about what others think of me.?



All my childhood i grew up in a knit tight group of friends who didnt fight very often and didnt judge others either. But that was then. Now im 16 and everything is so different. Theres always someone bitching about someone else and for some reason people dont seem to always like me even though i try to as friendly as i can. Some of my very good friends just tell me not to care about what others think and to stop being paranoid and stop worrying, but i cant. I actually do care what people think about me and i dont understand how others dont care either.



Thanks :)



</question>



<answer from>



Bell
Member since: 15 February 2007
Total points: 5088 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



i always worry what other ppl think of me and i know i shouldn't but i do..  i also suffer with bipolar =(



</answer>



<answer from>



Nathalia M
Member since: 06 August 2008
Total points: 754 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It won't always be this way for you.



It is quite normal to feel this way at your age. It's a part of human experience.



All you can do is ride it out, and try not to feel too uncomfortable in the mean time.



</answer>



<answer from>



just lisa & proud of it!!!
Member since: 15 October 2006
Total points: 788 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Unfortunately, I cannot offer you proof that this will ever change.  I too have a hard time dealing with this behavior in others.  I cannot stop myself from expecting others to be good.  I expect people to be the best person they can be and I usually find myself disappointed.  I also often find myself being the outcast and not being liked and still have trouble dealing with this from time to time.  I simply cannot understand why people choose to hurt others in their pursuit of personal gain.  It doesn't matter though, because I cannot stop it from occurring.  I can tell you though, that over the years it has become easier to deal with.  I no longer allow myself to believe that I am the one who should change to please them.  I am proud of the person I am and the way I conduct myself and lead my life.  I am very proud of the fact that I can truly say I like the person I see in the mirror because I have not compromised my beliefs or my integrity to satisfy any need or to move up any proverbial ladder.  I have often found myself hurt though by believing that I could change someone who would sacrifice anything or anyone in the process of attempting to achieve success.  You cannot change people.  You cannot make them want to do what is right and you cannot make them like you.  For the most part these people will dislike you intensely because you personify the morals and values that they chose to toss aside long ago.  You are real proof of what they can never be because they choose to step on people to better themselves as opposed to helping people and helping themselves as a result.  You cannot make these people go away no matter how hard you try and you cannot change yourself to suit them.  Just don't allow yourself to give up your ideals because you become convinced that joining them would be a much less difficult road to travel.  Once in a great while you will have the pleasure to meet or cross paths with someone who shares your beliefs and has lead a life that will inspire you and motivate you to remain true to who you are.  It is these people who make a real difference in this world.  Everyone else is a dime a dozen....It is we who are unique.  Hope this helps...good luck!



</answer>

<question>



Why do you think some people become ill and other people don't ?



</question>



<answer from>



Bell
Member since: 15 February 2007
Total points: 5088 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



i for one, have a lower immune system because i suffer from asthma so i tend to pick up colds easily etc.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mizpah
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 143 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Their immune system. The more germs you are exposed to over a period of time, you get stronger and you are less likely to become sick. If people keep away from sick people all the time and have very clean houses, they are not exposed to a consistent amount of germs, so when they do come in contact with a sick person or bad water, their body is so fragile that they can't help but get sick.



</answer>



<answer from>



JOHN B
Member since: 05 February 2007
Total points: 13983 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Lifestyle, simple as that!



</answer>



<answer from>



Shar Pei Lady
Member since: 14 June 2007
Total points: 1842 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Depends on your beginning health and what you come in contact with.Keep yourself as healthy as you can by avoiding ones you know are sick....wash your hands alot.If you are talking more about non  catagious diseases,such as cancer,no one can answer that one.God decides all that.



</answer>

<question from>



bedbug
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 78 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Have you been depressed lately? Do you ever feel this way?



Feeling of cramming or worrying when an event is about to happen? Example, for months you've been thinking about your problem, feeling bad, isolated w/ everyone, and then suddenly you'll be attending a party where your ex-close friends are present, what do you feel in that situation? and why do you have to feel that??



</question>



<additional details>



i mean what do you feel when you feel like cramming about yer thoughts and why do u hve to feel dt?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Lostgrl
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 110 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Yes. It is can be like you are in a room feel of people and feel like you have a bubble around you that keeps you from communicating what you really need to with everyone else. A lot of times it is because someone has hurt you and you are not sure how to deal with it and it can make experiences with that person (or those people) very uncomfortable. Worrying comes, but it is not the best solution. When you are worrying you have to think of something positive like Mathew 6. in the bible. That is what helped me. Also sometime going to an event like the party can help because it helps you face the feelings you are having. It may be uncomfortable at first but just ask yourself where these feelings may be coming and attempt to address the problem, even if it seems hard at first. If you continue to struggle try to find someone that you can confide in and talk the whole situation out.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



:)))))



</asker's comment>

<question>



Why do we get deja vu is it proof of time travel ?



</question>



<answer from>



gembolat...
Member since: 08 July 2008
Total points: 3846 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I've heard it's when one half of your brain recieves the signals slower than the other half. That doesn't explain why I get de ja vu of something happening 3 or 4 times though.



</answer>



<answer from>



Stephen L
Member since: 30 September 2006
Total points: 8270 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



One half of your brain just works a bit faster than the other. The slower half can sometimes think that it is remembering something, when in fact what it is "remembering" is the info' that the faster half has already processed.



</answer>

<original file>7985.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk73488.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



ally
Member since: 19 October 2007
Total points: 542 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Counselling homework help please!?



i have a 2000 word essay to do, title  HOW I BECAME ME..  has to linked to carl rogers person centred theory i just dint know where to start?????



</question>



<answer from>



michele
Member since: 10 April 2007
Total points: 64104 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Psychology



Mental Health



</answer from>



<answer>



To organize your paper, consider using the approach of a well-known developmental theorists such as Erickson or Piaget. Go through your life stage by stage and describe important events.



Best of luck on your paper,
~M~



Source(s):



occupational hazard



</answer>



<answer from>



Rolyn dal yma o hyd!
Member since: 29 July 2008
Total points: 1162 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Neither would I, I've never heard of him...



this might help though :



http://www.person-centered-counseling.co...



or this:



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Rogers



Enjoy....rather you than me.



</answer>



<answer from>



quot;Nice Beaver"
Member since: 11 September 2007
Total points: 1818 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Michelle's suggestion to use Erikson's stages of psychosocial development is a good idea - but you need to do lots of reading of Rogers so that you can link it to your own experiences. Counsellor training essays usually allow more subjectivity than other academic fields but you still need to show how you are applying the theory to personal experience. If you are doing your research on the internet you also need to be very careful about the academic credibility of your citations



</answer>

DesiDani(still waiting for 12am)
Member since: 18 September 2008

</question from>



<question>



Why can you still know where the steps are when carrying something that obstructs your view?



Why don't you trip or miss the steps.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



You can if you don't have muscle memory. If you have used the steps enough than it's already mapped out in your brain you just have to remember it. Adding a big enough box or a heavy enough box will mess with the recall so it's still dangerous.



</answer>

<answer from>



peanutbu...

<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



progress...
Member since: 27 September 2008
Total points: 323 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It just means you're trying to aknowledge your own nurturing qualities. Probably need to let the billy badass routine go and try a more balanced approach.



Cry
To dream that you are crying, signifies a release of negative emotions that is more likely caused by some waking situation rather than the events of the dream itself. Your dream is a way to regain some emotional balance and a way to safely let out your fears and frustrations. In our daily lives, we tend to ignore, deny, or repress our feelings. But in our dream state, our defense mechanisms are no longer on guard and thus allow for the release of such emotions.



</answer>

<question>



When you are not very sure on whether to say "Yes" or "No" to a question....?



..... what comes easier to you to finally say, taking the risk of it ?



"Yes" or "No" ?



Explain why, please.



</question>



<answer from>



IríšhMag †
Member since: 26 December 2006
Total points: 50750 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Then I would answer without a yes or no.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Maybe!!! lol



</asker's comment>



<comments>



† IríšhMag †



Thank you very much.



</comments>



<answer from>



I'm Hare!
Member since: 03 April 2008
Total points: 16986 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



If I am not certain then I will say both and explain both. The one that sounds better to the questioner will help to influence his/her to make up his/her mind.



Better to seem indecisive that to give someone a bad answer and find out later he/she acted upon that advice and was hurt.



</answer>



<answer from>



Cthulhu fhtagn!
Member since: 12 December 2005
Total points: 6447 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



"It depends". For example, answer to your question depends on what are the implications of saying "yes" or "no". E.g. you can ask "Will you vote for McCain?" or "Will you vote for Obama?". "Yes" to one questions means "no" to another.



</answer>



<answer from>



xoxmade...
Member since: 20 March 2008
Total points: 883 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes :]
Because normally it's a question defying their confidence...am i pretty? do you like this dress? do i sound like a good person?



I'd rather make someone feel good about themselves then look down upon themselves.



~Madeline :]



</answer>

<original file>1037.html</original file>
