<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



kosm
Member since: 03 June 2008
Total points: 6062 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



Can you ever learn to life yourself when you are so different?



I have ADHD, I am hyper and different. I hate myself sometimes. I wish I didn't. How can I like myself despite having this defect? I AM SOOO depressed right now and need some serious help, Thanks



</question>



<answer from>



hardboil...
Member since: 11 July 2008
Total points: 728 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I'm depressed right now too.  I pretty much go from trying new hobby to new hobby and don't stick around long.  I feel very different from other people and feel like there's something wrong with me, which cripples my self esteem.  The good thing is that I can take the energy I have and use it to learn anything I want to fast and efficiently.  The bad is that I get bored easily after I get to a certain level.  Plus, I always feel different than other people.



You have a lot you can do in the world and find out what you want to do.  FIND YOUR IDENTITY and what career you'd fit into.  Take the Strong test.  It's great for that.  So develop your beliefs and values.  Get books on psychology, philosophy, and religion and start incorporating beliefs into your own.



EXPERIENCE LIFE and get over your fear of living.  I swear, everytime I do something I wouldn't normally do I feel better.  It's a laugh and fun!  The other day was the 1st time I wrote in drying cement.  It was right in front of a store so people could see me! lol.  Today in class I held the door shut so some classmate couldn't get in.  It was all in fun!  Being hyper I'm sure there are random things you feel like doing.  As long as they don't hurt anybody do it!  Of course going on vacation to places you want to go and see would be great, even just places close by.



Take lessons in things you're interested in.  This is YOUR life so live it.  Rent documentaries and instructional dvds from any subjects that might interest you.



Lastly, KEEP DEVELOPING YOURSELF.  Learn more about confidence, motivation, and relationships through psychology.  You'll get books on ADHD to understand yourself more.  There's one called "The Fire Within."  Basically most the great artists and people of human history had personality disorders, ones like ADHD.  Of course it's speculation because they were not diagnosed, but where else would they get the energy unless they felt all that pain of life more than regualar people did?  So you have way more energy than most people.  You just have to choose what you want to do.  And CHOICE is the greatest thing we have in our lives.



Source(s):



Life



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>

I did whatever was necessary to be approved no matter what the costs.......But I am being cured of my condition! Now I LOVE being different. I have generalized anxiety disorder. <original file>1144.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk75873.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



nobody
Member since: 09 May 2008
Total points: 3985 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



What do I do, I know I have asked similar questions but I need some guidance on the issue? ?



Last time I asked this question, someone asked me if there was anything sexually arousing relating to this. What should one do if there is? In seventh grade, and I know this is kind of weird, but there was something sexual relating to the costume that I just liked about the costume.



BTW: I am a boy and have just graduated high school. This has “plagued” me throughout my life and I feel like it has been a burden on me unfortunately. I don’t want to talk to anyone face to face because I feel so deeply embarrassed about it. Please give me some REAL advice, criticism and making fun of me for this will not be tolerated.



Keep these questions in mind when you read through the details:
1. Do I just watch the episode because I miss my mother, or is it like a “baby blanket” or is it just for comfort?
2. Do I try to suppress the episode from my mind (even though I think that has failed)?
3. Should I make/get a bee costume, why am I so obsessed with the costume to begin with?
4. How do I just let this go, is there a way to just accept this without being so uptight and super embarrassed about thinking about this?
5. Should I keep watching the episode, how do I get myself to stop watching it?



Anyways, let me begin:
When I was really little I loved watching kid television shows with my mom. One of the television shows I watched was called Barney and my mom used to tape the first season episodes for me. One of the episodes in particular, that I loved watching was titled, "I Just Love Bugs." The part I liked the most was at the beginning when the "I'm Bringing Home A Baby Bumblebee" song was performed. During the scene, a girl in a bumblebee costume pretended to sting the 3 other kids in these 3 verses to the song, “I’m Bringing Home A Baby Bumblebee, I’m Going To Swat the Baby Bumblebee, and I’m Running from the Baby Bumblebee.” I used to watch this scene whenever I could when I was little and probably like tens of times per day on some days since the scene was only a couple of minutes long. I used to LOVE the look of the costume and the way it just stood out. I also used to really like the way the scene played out where the girl in the costume stung the other kids even though she was outnumbered and I used to love the little hand motions of victory as well after she pretended to sting them. Anyways, I watched this episode until I was like 7 years old for an ENORMOUS amount of time and when I got to that age I had wanted to put that bee costume on (replica since I loved the costume so much) and perform the song with myself as the bee. I wanted to sting the other kids and be like the bee pretty badly because it looked so fun to do as shown in the episode. I didn’t tell my parents I wanted that type of costume though ever.



I eventually started to forget about this episode after making many new friends at school and experiencing some homework in grade school. Also, a new thing came around called Pokemon and I got into that and played all the original games. I used to collect all the cards as well. Anyways, in like fifth grade or so, my family was going to move to a new house and I for some reason wanted to watch the Barney episode again. I ended up finding it and watching it again. I loved seeing it again and it comforted me as we moved to our new house.



Again, though, I gradually forgot about the episode, I continued on with school, made new friends, and just continued to do well and have fun. In seventh grade though, my life began to become amazingly stressful again when my mother fell ill with cancer. She ended up dying from it and I became very sad. I ended up pulling out the old episode of Barney and watching the bumblebee scene over and over again after school when I could. I must have watched it for at least thirty minutes straight, over and over again. Also, I used to, for the first time, actually imitate the scenes sometimes just by myself, when I was alone. I watched this episode randomly through eighth grade. I never talked to my father about it and just didn’t know how to talk to him about it.



</question>



<additional details>



We moved again when I started high school and, unbeknownst to me, tons of stuff was given away including the Barney tape. Since I didn’t mention anything about it being important it was just given away. Anyways, I eventually found out after searching for it. I thought that my life will be better now that I am not addicted to that Barney episode. In high school, I gradually forgot about the episode and focused again on school work and hanging out with my friends. In Junior year, I somehow remembered it again while thinking about college and stressing about it. It wasn’t at home but, since I couldn’t get it off out of my mind, I decided to check online for it hoping that by watching it once I could appease my mind into not watching it after that. Surely enough, the episode was there and I became almost addicted to watching the opening bumblebee scene.



Anyways, it hasn’t really gone away, and I for some reason like the bumblebee costume more and more and want to wear something like it.



So what do I do now, how can I just phase this episode and the costume out of my mind?



I hope I don't come off as seeming weird to you, I know I might.



Anyways, please give me some suggestions.



This is so embarrassing



</additional details>



<answer from>



active open programming
Member since: 10 May 2007
Total points: 8501 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you truly want to eliminate your fascination for bees then you should watch some programming which is contra to the association made by the episode you watched. Watch some bee-farming documentaries to learn about how bees really behave. Bees are well-controlled insects that are kept in check by the bee-farmers trapping the bees in containment areas where they won't be able to sting anyone.



</answer>



<answer from>



jessica
Member since: 07 July 2008
Total points: 196 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Okay so it sounds like you use the barney video as a comfort, for something stressful happens. Because the seems like that is when the wanting to watch the video comes up. I dont know if you feel anything else while watching it. But it sounds like it is just like when kids have a favorite stuffed animal they cuddle up to and stuff like that. <answer>



Ok - i am so glad you asked this question here and I happened to read it. I know that sounds really weird but I am studying to be a therapist and am going to start applying to become a Sex Therapist and this is really a topic that interests me and I would love to work with people like you.



We studied situations just like this in my Sex Therapy class already. Basically, if you'd like the long story short ... it sounds like you have a fetish. Fetishes can happen with any thing / any object at all. Some people like feet, some people like hair, and oddly enough some may like Barney and bumblebees. It doesn't sound crazy at all to me.



Now about your connections with it - your mom and/or sexually. Two things may have happened. While you were younger and growing older, you may have some how sexually connected yourself to the bumble bee. There is a book I read in high school that reminds me of this, even though that story goes off weirdly at the end, called Equuis  (not sure how that is really spelled but it is the play that Harry Potter was playing nude). What happens is that growing up the boy becomes fascinated with horses. He obsesses over them and starts working at a stall even. He LOVES horses. And eventually, his mind somehow sexually connects the two. The end is not important in your case, but it is really an interesting book/play to read.



So that is what you may have done. And it is completely normal to have fetishes. The only time it becomes abnormal is when you can ONLY get aroused with that object/thing and if it is harmful to anyone involved. So... being intimate with someone and role playing (with costumes) may be fun every so often in your case.



Now why did you watch the video when you got older again and again? I think its important that you have forgotten about it every so often since that shows you havent become too obsessed with it in your lifetime to the point you can't function anymore... but it does show a significance. So in your case, it's a method of coping and dealing and comfort. You did this as a child with your mom who you no longer have and it is your way of bringing you back to those happy times and happy memories. That is completely fine too.



Don't worry so much and don't beat yourself up over it. I know that this could be easily a target for many bad jokes from many Yahoo users and may be... but everyone is unique and likes different things. As a kid its ok to fantasize about playing with friends dressed like the bee that had fun on TV but as you got older, you realized that would not be fun at all (instead you'd be made fun of). And now you are still connected to it in two different ways, it brings you back to old happy times and is comforting, and you may also have a sexual connection to bumblebees because of it.



It sounds like you want to desperately get rid of all this though- so I would advise maybe seeing a sex therapist to talk about how to decrease your fetish (it's like a spectrum and can be from mild to very bad)... or you could just accept it as it is like I have said - because it really isn't anything horrible, in my opinion. Unless it gets to be consuming of your life and mind, then that would be a problem.



My mom died of cancer too when I was in middle school and some of the weirdest things can bring you back to memories of our loved ones. My mom died on Halloween so I obviously am not too fond of the holiday at all - and I have the ritual of always making sure to wear something she gave me as a child (usually a charm necklace). So it is ok to remember the times you spent with her, and to you, the thing that helps the most is a video from you childhood that you loved. And it's ok. :)



</answer>

<current file name>yqa_uk76276.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



kaywood1
Member since: 17 July 2007
Total points: 559 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Does anyone know about the 2 ways the art of recall facitiates the counselling process?



maybe something about the content and expression of the client?



</question>



<answer from>



active open programming
Member since: 10 May 2007
Total points: 8503 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



People who are seeking counseling often can't solve their problems on their own. Why is it so? Because something about their recollection is contradictory. Therefore, a counselor can facilitate solution of a problem by pointing out any inconsistencies in the recounting of the events in question. Second, the counselor can learn about how the client wants to be "cured". People often don't want to change their lifestyles, so it is the counselors job to think of ways to help the client continue their livelihood in their current state of mind.



</answer>



<answer from>



sphinx
Member since: 23 October 2006
Total points: 485 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



practical and theoretical



</answer>

<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



Nobody L
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 29 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What's the difference between the three emotions?



Annoyed
Irritated
Angry



</question>



<answer from>



king david
Member since: 23 October 2008
Total points: 124 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



i think it really depends on the person who uses them...



in my opinion, irritated is less severe than annoyed or angry. its like when you go to the store looking for a specific brand of candy but they don't have it. you are a little upset but you get over it quickly.



annoyance is more like when you are starting to get bothered by something that is continuously getting on your nerves. its a stronger feeling and doesn't go away as quickly.



Anger is when you are upset with something having not gone how you wanted it, or something getting in the way of something you wanted or what have you, and you are consumed by the feeling of being upset over it. you don't get over being angry overnight, it takes a while.



this is how i see the three emotions, but like i said, its really up to the person using them. some people see irritation as a stronger feeling than annoyance.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



k



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



irelandh...
Member since: 11 December 2007
Total points: 521 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Annoyance is an unpleasant mental state that is characterized by such effects as irritation and distraction from one's conscious thinking. It can lead to emotions such as frustration and anger.



Irritation or exacerbation, in biology and physiology, is a state of inflammation or painful reaction to allergy or cell-lining damage. A stimulus or agent which induces the state of irritation is an irritant.



Anger is an emotion, "subjectively experienced as an aroused state of toward someone or something perceived to be the source of an aversive event



</answer>



<answer from>



asdjfklö
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 167 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



annoyed is when youre sick of something. angry is when you really care about something and it's not how it's supposed to be. irritated is when there's something that you didn't expect or that you don't know how to cope with.



this is just rough, of course there are many many more possibilities how to define these terms.



</answer>



<answer from>



sun+E
Member since: 19 November 2007
Total points: 727 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Annoyed is when something ticks you off, right there, right away.
Irritated is when something keeps scratching at your nerves.



Angry is when you're full-blown mad, when all the worst feelings come bubbling to the surface.



At least, that's how I've always thought of these three terms. Was that any help?



</answer>



<answer from>



Chris
Member since: 23 June 2006
Total points: 1468 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The degree of intensity. They are all forms of being mad, Annoyed being the lesser and easier to get over, Irritated comes next and last longer, and then Angry, which typically lasts many hours (if not all day) and can result in headaches.



</answer>

BELIEVE®

Each one of the words has a degree of emotion that is put into it.



1-10 scale
Annoyed: degree of emotion 2-3 slightly ticked



Irritated: degree of emotion 4-6 moderately peeved



Angry: degree of emotion 7-10 I may hurt you

<original file>3642.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk78648.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



PaiMei
Member since: 14 February 2008
Total points: 700 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What is the name of the complex/syndrome related to feeling prosecuted and/or paranoid? ?



I know there's a clinical name for this, but can't come up with it. Please help.



</question>



<additional details>



Also, feeling people are out to get you?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Ricky A
Member since: 15 October 2008
Total points: 528 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



schizophrenia



</answer>



<answer from>



cfc1902
Member since: 22 November 2006
Total points: 404 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Paranoia - the noun from the adjective paranoid. It is a feature of many mental illnesses including bi-polar disorder, certain types of schizophrenia, and personality disorder. Some types of obsessive compulsive disorder and autistic spectrum disorder include feelings of paranoia. Thinking about it, nearly all types of mental illness can include feelings of being persecuted, even "simple" depression.  So it's a very broad syndrome.  Sometimes whole countries are afflicted with it. But it is always worth remembering that quite a lot of people really are being persecuted and they are not mentally ill to believe so - the authorities love to dismiss people as paranoid because they think someone is out to get them.  Plenty of examples of people who have said the secret police are out to get them, and then the secret police have done just that, got them.



Source(s):



There is evidence of conspiracies.



</answer>






<original file>3714.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk78728.txt</current file name>




<category>

</category>



<question from>



Species:...
Member since: 30 October 2008

</question from>



<question>



Why won't my head stop hurting?



I know this might be long, but I'm trying to give the full details.



It has been going on for over 10 years now (i'm 19). I know that it is psychologically related because I saw a medical doctor for my headaches 2 years ago and had many tests done (nothing medically wrong with me). Even going on a very dangerous drug that my doctor gave me because it just would not stop (I threw it out, I was beginning to have heart problems). And now it is just getting worse because it has brought some new wonderful problems with it. I daydream, think, have "inner conversations", get extremely lost in my thoughts even worse now, to the point I find myself just sitting on my bed for maybe 30min -1 hour at a time. And everything in my head feels so real I actually have to shake it off. I can't pay attention to anything or anyone for that matter long enough to comprehend what they are saying. I just drift in and out of everything. I will be talking to someone for example and all of a sudden I will hear a word or think of of something and I am gone. My head also feels dizzy and fuzzy all the time. I can't even read anymore. I can't stay focused long enough. The only thing that I can pay full attention to are the clouds and sky. When I look at them, I just feel peaceful. It is affecting me in all areas of my life. In gr. 9, I used to be able to write, read and think at a 3-4th year university level (confirmed by school). But everything is just getting worse. I have so many thoughts and it is preventing me from having a "normal" life. My short-term memory is practically gone. ALL because I can't pay attention. I sleep all day.



Please Help me, I am so very desperate and I am completely lost. I cry all the time.



</question>



<additional details>



p.s. I cannot talk to my family or friends, it's complicated, nor do I have any money or intention to see a psychiatrist. or taking drugs-pharmaceutical, recreational. (i'm very anti-drugs)



</additional details>



<answer from>



active open programming
Member since: 10 May 2007

<answer>



You might think differently from other people.  I did as a kid back in school (was very "gifted"), and recognized I did think very differently compared to other people.  Isolating in a way.  I needed to speak to my peers in a much different way than I could with adults, and it took some time to find intellectual peers.  In time you will meet or at least be exposed to the ideas of others who think more like you.



My advice is to not focus on perhaps being smarter than other people/thinking different from them.  Develop whatever gifts you've been given, be true to yourself, and try to connect with the people around you in as many ways as possible.  Be open to friendships with all types of people. Always be open to learning (not just in school, in all areas of life).  Don't pretend to be someone you are not (but don't rudely alienate people just because they might not seem to think the way you do).



More important than how smart you are is how much good you do in this world, and the relationships that you form.



</answer>

<question from>



lil_swee...
Member since: 06 June 2008
Total points: 170 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I'm confused...[psychology curious..]?



It is a truism that “you never forget how to ride a bicycle”. Why might this be so? Where is information about bicycle riding stored? What happens when a person has to retrieve that information after not using it for a long time?



</question>



<answer from>



sphinx
Member since: 23 October 2006
Total points: 514 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



its just like walking on your two feet again.. even if you do that after ages.. you won't need anyone to guide you.. once you know how to walk... a child needs to be taught how to walk.. not us...



once you have balanced a cycle and you ride it.. the process gets stored in your brains and you need not learn to do that again..



after years when you ride a bike it'll be like recalling the alphabets after years of not repeating it...  you already know it!



:)



</answer>



<answer from>



Andre
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 144 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



That is a complex issue. Let my just tell you short that it has to do with memory and fine motorics, which a a command send from your brain to the part of the body which is needed to execute the task. That is the simple form of explanation. I hope I could help a little.



</answer>



<answer from>



Rebecca W
Member since: 24 May 2007
Total points: 5895 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



One rarely forgets things that are stored in "mechanical" memory. These are the things that you learn mechanically, riding a bike, skating, using tools, that sort of thing. This is because you are actually using your brain to teach your body and then your body reminds your brain. This is different from cognitive memory because with cognitive memory you only use your brain and these memories if not used will fade and be replaced by newer ones.



</answer>



<answer from>



cfc1902
Member since: 22 November 2006
Total points: 404 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just to add to the others - the later/earlier you learn, the sooner/later you lose it. EG immigrants who learn a language later in life lose that before their native language.  I have a Czech friend whose father is now in an old people's home where they speak Czech, because he lost his English first.  My mother in law, who is now quite elderly, is beginning to lose her ability to drive a car because she didn't learn until she was in her 40s/  But she is still brilliant on a sewing machine, because she started work as a seamstress at the age of 14. And I am always amazed when i go to France, even though I haven't used the language for ages, it all soon comes back.



</answer>



<answer from>



Nik's mom
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 178 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm trying to remember what I learned in 'The Physiology of Behaviour' back in the day...



Now, I am not sure if this is entirely accurate, but this is how I understand it.  Information travels to and from and within your brain on a system of neurons.  Neurons are nerves that are set up like pieces of a kid's train track.  Everytime you nervous system sends a signal down a certain path of the track, the space between the "pieces of track" gets a little smaller.  The pieces of track are the neurons, and the spaces are called synapses.



When the spaces get smaller, it makes it easier for you brain to use that particular "track" next time.  This is why when you practice something, it gets easier to do.  This occurs in the spaces between the neurons in your brain, and in the spaces in the pathways of your body, too.  Over time, if those pathways are not used, the spaces get wider again.  Then it is harder for your brain to follow that path the next time you try to access it.



Okay, now getting to so-called 'muscle memory'.  If memory serves, the neurons in your body are longer, so there aren't as many spaces to depend on as in your brain.  Also, the spaces are more resilient, and need less stimulation to stay close together.  So, if a large part of your learning occurred in the synapes and neurons in your arms, a physical skill, like typing, would be less easily forgotten, then a mental skill, like long division.



I hope that helps.  Maybe someone else will be able to confirm or deny what I have already said.  It has been a while since I learned this information.



</answer>






<original file>434.html</original file>

<question>



Hates Making Decisions???  ?



Okay, I recently started dating this guy that I work with (we are co-workers and it’s recommended that co-workers don’t date) anyway, we kissed and I asked him if he wanted to start dating and he got really nervous and couldn’t decide.
I then asked him if he liked me and to forget about everything else, because taking a risk is better then doing nothing he said he did, and we decided to start dating.
But the problem is he just got out of a two year relationship and I was talking to his girlfriend (when I told him about this he got really mad) anyway she said that he can not make decisions and that is why they split, she said he even has trouble choosing a movie and relies on others.



I think are relationship may be a bad idea, but even if it is I want to help him become more independent, his ex also said this was his fathers fault for criticizing every decision he made as a child.



How can I help him to become more independent?
everyone has feelings, so lately I have been trying to get him to talk about feelings then making a decision based on that rather then facts.



</question>



<answer from>



WHO CARES
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 3906 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Why are you feeling like it's your job to fix him?? It's up to him to take the matter into his own hands and figure out what to do. And I wouldn't have liked it either if my DATE talked to my ex about me. Theres always 2 sides to a story. You haven't heard the other side.



</answer>



<answer from>



active open programming
Member since: 10 May 2007
Total points: 8489 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



The last person I would trust is a person's ex. Does it appear to you that he is capable of making decisions? It sounds to me like he might soon make a decision to end your relationship. I don't know anything about the dynamics of your relationship, so you need to decide what you want.



</answer>

(B) As soon as you notice the presence or absence of the urinals



(C) As soon as you notice that the other users are of the opposite gender



(D) As soon as the other users (of the opposite gender) or the cleaner informs you to get out.

<original file>877.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk81747.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



sharad s
Member since: 29 July 2007
Total points: 57 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why one human being hurt another? I have been hurt by someone.?



</question>



<answer from>



pool party@@
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 195 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



did you



</answer>



<answer from>



Becca101
Member since: 28 March 2007
Total points: 480 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sometimes people hurt others because they are hurt themselves. Sometimes it makes people feel better to take it out on someone else or to make someone else suffer like they did. Some just do it because they have a mental illness (that either tells them to or makes them not see how it is wrong to do that).



Either way, you should not be someone's punching bag or be the victim of someone elses pain. You need to go tell someone as soon as you can so that it doesn't happen again. Someone you trust like a teacher or a school counselor. You could also tell a friend's parent that you trust too. You don't deserve to be hurt and no one does. And the only way to prevent it from happening again is to let someone know.



Source(s):



This website has some phone numbers you can call if you just want to talk to someone about it and dont have anyone else to talk to: http://www.avhotline.org/



</answer>



<answer from>



active open programming
Member since: 10 May 2007
Total points: 8495 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



The best advice I can give is to evaluate whether it is worthwhile to maintain your relationship with the person. Often even our closest friends do hurt us from time-to-time, so keep that in mind when making your decision. Of course, if you have been harmed physically or threatened of harm then you should report it to the police.



</answer>



<answer from>



Body Technique
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 1264 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You dont need to know that.....maybe you are still in your hurting stage and need to know that to understand---closure???  If you are a good person and that has happened to you, know that you dont deserve that and whether or not you understand their reasons for hurting you, you will have no part in that dysfunction.  If it is a mental thing that the person maybe cannot help and they are serious about change, build yourself mentally to be there for them.  At one time I did not believe certain things, but experience has educated and matured me to be strong in differenet areas.  Being in a dysfunctional situation that has no intention of moving forward is not healthy nor can it help you in a positive way.



</answer>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



How do you get an ADD child to be responsable?



A boy age 11 in grade 6 , always needs to be told what to do?



</question>



<answer from>



Justine4...
Member since: 07 March 2008
Total points: 598 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Perhaps you could try getting him into a routine. For example, when he gets up in the morning, make sure he has a list of all the things he needs to do and by what time he needs to have them done. Having a routine is a good way for him to know what is expected of him.



</answer>



<answer from>



jimrich
Member since: 03 June 2006
Total points: 9343 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<question>



Could You Please Help Me Focus!!?



Ok I am Jimmy and I am 23 years old. I am 6’0 tall, brown hair and blue eyes. And I have Addison’s disease but as long as I take the hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone I live a normal life. I as well have ADHD.I myself would think of myself as a highly intelligent person. The thing is my brain goes faster than me all the time. This is very frustrating for me. I am trying to focus and retain information but I forget lots of it. It really depends on my mood I guess. Well I need your help I’m trying to read A+ CompTIA so I can finally take the exam. I am merrily hitched to this breathtaking woman who has changed my life around to the better me. We have been together now for 1yr and 3months and still day by day we learn something or educate each other on something new. My question to all of you is what can I do to be able to retain what I am reading and as well what people say. Instead of always getting distracted? Yes I know that I could take the pill. Trust me I have in the past and nothing ever worked. Now it’s like I really want to comprehend this book as well as get a career going. After all this I want to get married. Our wedding date is Aug 21. 2010. The year 2010 was chosen because that’s when my fiancée is done with college. She Is In business management and I took Computer Administration at school and finished. Currently I am in the process of thinking on going for the externship which my school provides me. I want to do all that I can do for myself very badly. I need to really read this 1200 page book lol please please assist me!! I have found many sites that you can remain relaxed all just as easy as to listening to pleasant music which creates a feeling of being somewhere tranquil.
ILL TAKE WHATEVER YOU CAN DISH OUT AT ME PLEASE HELP ME!!
Thanks!!



</question>



<answer from>



pandora3...
Member since: 13 September 2008
Total points: 139 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Hi Jimmy......While i understand how frustrating things can be i have learned from personal experience the writing detailed notes on the subject and making flash cards for my self and frequent self testing i was able to retain roughly 90% of what i was studying. With persistence it all paid off and i graduated top of my class in my CNA course passed my state exams and did this while being a single mother of an Autistic child with learning problems as well. To help yourself  do better i suggest making notes notes notes. It helped me alot and being OCD and having learning disabilities my self i can assure you it helps alot. Since you have a g/f that is supportive she can quiz you with the flash cards and i am certain you will retain much more information. As for finding a happy place in order to remain calm while you study i found just playing soft music or working outdoors say like in a park helped tremendously. There is really no perfect answer for each one of us learns and retains information differently but i think you may have success trying this. Good Luck To You and may your future be a bright one.



Source(s):



Self experience



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Very Helpful



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Gobblede...
Member since: 18 October 2008
Total points: 120 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had to study for a really boring exam once and the only way I managed to keep myself focused for long enough, was to smoke a very light joint. I retained the information for just long enough to pass the exam. It was one of the highest grades I ever got.  I was living in The Netherlands at that time, where smoking pot is not a problem.  Nowadays I keep my life simple. What I cannot remember I do not need to know. It works fine.  All this might not be the right solution for you though. I wish you the best of luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



Davy
Member since: 19 October 2008
Total points: 182 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You could read it out loud to yourself a few times.
You could take notes.
You could have a friend look at the book and make self check quizzes for you.
Lastly, you could set aside a "Quiet Time" for when you work, in a place with very few distractions, and don't look at peeling paint on the wall.



</answer>

<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



Mike
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 569 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How is it possible for some people to actually spend more time talking than breathing?



I work with someone who, I kid you not, can literally talk for HOURS without pausing for a single moment of silence.



It's like a stream of consciousness, and no matter how serious or trivial the concept is, she lets it fly, and doesn't give a second thought as to whether it actually needs to be said.



I suppose one could defend it as ADHD, or a serious personality disorder such as narcissism.  My belief is that it is a stunning level of selfishness and immaturity.



What are the reasons for someone blurting out every thought in their head?



</question>



<answer from>



peachiep...
Member since: 16 September 2006
Total points: 6290 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Your co-worker hails from the tribe of motor mouths, and therefore nothing on this earth can stop their ever gushing flow of their never ending opinions. I feel there is no escape unless you can drug them and sew up their mouths!



Source(s):



Know a few of them myself



</answer>



<asker's comment>



,



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



active open programming
Member since: 10 May 2007
Total points: 7955 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think there is anything wrong or unhealthy with speaking one's mind. Of course, if you feel uncomfortable as your comments of selfishness and immaturity imply then you should seek association elsewhere. I think that healthy relationships are found on clear communication. That said, it is possible that a person who is insecure feels obligated to share every thought in their head with the world. In which case, it isn't healthy for the person to feel that way.



</answer>



<answer from>



happygir...
Member since: 31 October 2007
Total points: 12128 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Stress can do that, make people think and problem solve out loud.



There are lots of reasons..including the ones you mentioned.



If this person is otherwise functioning well, then she may have some awful stuff happening in her private life that is making her need to hear her thoughts to drown out dwelling on the problems and function.



If that is the case she is oblivious that she does this and when the crisis is over she will lighten up a lot.
I have been doing this a bit myself since my dad died in Aug.  I can hear myself but not stop babbling anyway.
I use Y/A as a distraction to keep from just chattering random things. It is getting better, but very slowly.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lou
Member since: 16 February 2007
Total points: 8746 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



There called women, but seriously I worked with a woman like that in the end I said, " Can you just stop talking." She laughed and said "Everyone says that." she waited like 10 seconds and started talking again, sometimes you just have to tell them to shut up.



I think they think they are being friendly of have something useful to say.



</answer>



<answer from>



Hot Coco Puff
Member since: 22 March 2007
Total points: 53317 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



Researchers agree that if there is a chemical imbalance in these brain chemicals, then clinical states of depression result. Antidepressant medications work by increasing the availability of neurotransmitters or by changing the sensitivity of the receptors for these chemical messengers. It is believed that modifying these brain chemicals can help improve emotions.



Source(s):



HCP



</answer>



<answer from>



Macrocom...
Member since: 07 December 2007
Total points: 5075 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



The reasons that you give are very likely. It might also be associated with a lack of self-confidence.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 04 June 2007
Total points: 1816 (Level 3)

<question>



Why do I tend to infatuate?



Hey there, I am 17 years old. I am a really nice and mature guy but I feel like I tend to infatuate alot. I also have mild cerebral palsy which affects me physically, not mentally. It started 2 1/2 years ago, first it was a teacher which lasted around 1 year, then girls in my classes, first girl lasted 4 months, then another girl which lasted 3 months, and now i've crushed on a really cute/nice girl since February.
I have been crushing on this girl for nearly 9 months and used to feel like it was true love when I first crushed on her. I knew her 2 years ago and we talked and had her on facebook but I never crushed on her till last February, it was so random. I've seen pics of her before and thought she was cute but never crushed on her till now.
In February, one of her close friends told her I liked her and she started flirting with me but I dismissed that she liked me because she is a bit of a flirt. I am also a shy guy though so I was scared to flirt back. In April, I found out another guy liked her and got jealous so I tried to get attention which irritated her, she ended up blocking me on MSN and moving to another part of the class. We talked about it in June when I told her how I felt and I was sorry for what happened, we said we should move on. We still talk though.
Why do I infatuate? How can I stop infatuating? Does my disability contribute to this?



</question>

<answer>



Capt. you came to this earth school to learn to love.  Thus the infatuations.

not require easy.

that potentiality might need tlc some day is off putting.  Not every girl
is ready to contemplate that possibility at your young ages.



Eventually fate will intervene and the right one will show up.  In the meantime
enjoy infatuation all you want.  Have fun and have faith

<answer>



You either fear pregnancy or you want it. Not for your self but in your life. The fact that it was a work colleague means you have a close enough relationship with her that your subconscience could image her carrying your child. The fact that is was a WORK colleague maybe means you think pregnancy and your job are interconnected in some way, like both of them add worry or stress into your life. Maybe you worry about work , and you also worry about the fact that you could get someone pregnant, and so both of those interconnected.



If maybe you were happy during your dream maybe your subConscience is trying to make it obvious that you want something steady and firm like a job and a relationship as well as your own family. It could mean many things but really , only you know what it means. Not us.

<question>



How does this sound to you? Its for one of those "tell us about your self" type things. for an internship...?



My name is Hakim Husein, and I am attending San Jacinto College in Houston, Texas but plan on transferring to Birzeit University located in the West Bank. I am 21 years old and the youngest of six children, with a loving and caring mother and a deceased father who worked sixteen-hour days to support us. In the early days of my life, I vividly recall waking up in the middle of the night for a cup of cold milk and overhearing my parents crying while watching the Arabic news. I was too young to comprehend the situation and assumed they were watching a sad movie. As a first generation American-Arab, I have experienced first-hand the effects of the seemingly endless violence in Palestine. The  fighting between Israeli solders and Palestinian civilians would be a staple topic of my childhood. However, this life experience could be interpreted as a blessing in disguise because from that point on I knew in my heart what my true calling was, that there is absolutely nothing in the world I would rather do than render aid to people who really need it. I have dedicated myself to my community and the greater good, such as acting as a crisis counselor, and have very high aspirations on one day becoming a United States diplomat. I am a Foreign Affairs major and like the great Martin Luther King Jr., I too have a dream, that one day a Jewish and Muslim child will be playing side by side in a better world for all to prosper. It all starts with tolerance of one another, and can only end in peace.



</question>

<question from>



Nox Arc
Member since: 25 July 2007
Total points: 1274 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Do you ever hear voices in your head(that aren't your own)?



Sometimes I can hear people having conversations in my head. Often they're talking about how they could do things without getting caught or debating over the rationale of murder. Sometimes my thoughts accidentally chime in and provide them solutions and ideas for their problems.
When I was a kid I lived in a haunted house and I could physically hear the spirits conversing around me.
One such time I was sitting up in my bed, not able to sleep. I could hear them in the upper right corner of my room, near the ceiling. I was frightened and so I pulled my covers over my head. They noted it and said "She thinks we can't see her."



Sometimes I'm convinced that maybe I'm tuning into some sort of astral projection of thought on a communal level, but I'm more of a serendipitous party. I don't think they hear me or know that I here them though. It's almost as if they seem to receive my thoughts as if they were their thoughts.
For example, they may be talking about what color to paint a wall and I automatically form an opinion.
They'll act upon my thought as if the thought was theirs. They might say something like "Purple! I think purple would be nice." immediately after I thought about purple.



</question>

<answer>



Yes, with new privledges come new responsibilities that you will have to deal with. Accepting these responsibilities & making the right decisions is very difficult given the limited experience you have in dealing with your new privledges.  This is a transition phase from childhood to adulthood & will without a doubt be confusing as you watch peers attempt to deal with these issues too.



You must also learn to deal with the changes hormones are forcing on your brain chemistry & body... this is the period of huge mistakes & confusion.  I hope you have adult mentors to help you deal with this difficult period... things get better after High School & strangely those that dislike their teen years seem to do much better as adults than those that enjoyed their teen years.



</answer>

<answer>



I'm 28 and I can honestly say that looking back, while at the time I thought my teen years were hard, they weren't too bad for the most part. I'm finding now that what was so tough about it was the emotional aspect. I was unsure of who I was and tried too hard to be what I thought everyone wanted me to be. It wasn't until I was about 17 when I said "Screw it! I'm sick of playing a character all the time" and I really just let myself be me. Other than that, my teenage years were a piece of cake. I didn't have any major responsibilities outside of school (and even it was easy compared to college), I worked part time and made enough money to do the things I wanted at the time, I didn't really have any bills other then paying for gas for my car (which was only about $1.00/gal back then....dangit!), I seemed to have time to do everything I wanted like theater, soccer, hanging out with friends, etc. Now that I'm in "the real world" it can be tougher having all this responsibility, plus I have a 6 yr old daughter and a husband now, but that's the great part about getting older, you learn just what you're capable of.



</answer>

<original file>10514.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk83878.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



thereali...
Member since: 19 March 2008
Total points: 86 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



In an experiment usin rays 2 determine the effect they have on the growthof flowers the independent variabl is?



In an experiment using gamma rays to determine the effect they have on the growth of morning glory flowers, the independent variable is the_______.



a. morning glories.



b. dosage of gamma rays.



</question>



<answer from>



Andrea
Member since: 22 March 2008
Total points: 149 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Dosage of gamma rays. It would have to remain constant, though (well, for it to be a good experiment). For example, there are multiple groups of the morning glories (all kept in the same conditions except for the dosage of gamma rays) and each group gets a different dosage of gamma rays. There should also be a group of morning glories that gets no gamma rays, called the control group.
And actually, the dependent variable wouldn't be the morning glories themselves, it would be the growth of the morning glories.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks a bunch i didnt quite understand that questions, it was tricky



</asker's comment>

Do i have two personalities?

<answer>

what's wrong is that you are hiding you real personality - which is not either of those you have you described.



neither you nor anyone else is perfect in every way - and you are pretending to do the impossible. It makes you mad and rebellious, which is not your nature either.



Quit trying for perfect (pleasing someone else, your parents? God?) and explore what YOU want, and what you think is right - i think then you will find you just have 1 real personality.

<question from>



Daydream...

</question from>



<question>



Ok now my boyfriend has admitted to me that he occasionally snorts coke. How do I deal with this?



In relation to my previous question: http://uk.answers.yahoo.com/question/ind...



My boyfriend hid from me that he snorted coke. Before I got the chance to confront him he finally confessed it to me randomly out of the blue.



Ok call me crazy but he has opened up about a lot to me and I do respect him for being honest.



But....Now I know I really don't know how to handle this. My step dad is a drug addict and an alcoholic, my bro used to smoke marijuana and got violent on it so I know from experience that nagging doesn't work or trying to get them off of it; they have to do it themselves.



We have a perfect relationship (no over exaggeration). On coke or not on coke he is still a gentleman but this is still serious.



I don't want to leave him so what should I do?



</question>



<additional details>



Paul R: Good point. that is why I have never taken drugs because before it has reached the buyer many people have suffered.



I've lived with junkies so mixing with them is nothing new to me. I hate them but I can relate to them because to be honest it is all that I know.



I believe that he is a non-addict drug user but I know that even a non-addict wastes their precious money on their drug hobbie. Thanks for you answer it made me think x



</additional details>



<answer from>



Paul R
Member since: 08 July 2006
Total points: 1643 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Being honest about it, is all very well and good. But you have to take stock of the situation and decide what you want in your life. Buying drugs funds crime. There is no getting around that. And I mean serious violent crime. Even the buying of canabis funds violent crime. Drugs are moved around the county by quite shocking means. Drug users who say they are doing no-one any harm are just naive fools. So you have to think about that one first.



Your boyfriend will be mixing with drug dealers. You also have to decide if you want to have connections in your life with people like that.



You also have to find out how serious a habit your boyfriend has. Is he addicted, is his habit out of control? If it isn't out of control how close is he to being addicted? Coke is an extremely addictive and expensive drug.



So if you don't want to leave him, you have to decide, can you live with a boyfriend who has an expensive potentially addictive and dangerous habit that funds crime?



</answer>

Often all addicts need is a supproting hand. Tell him youll be there every step of the way.

<answer from>



Lanani
Member since: 14 February 2006
Total points: 17209 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Leave him.



I know this isn't what you want to hear, and it's not what I wanted to hear when I was in the same situation, but if he's a high-functioning coke addict and he's successfully hidden it from you for awhile, he's trouble.



I was with a man in college who seemed perfect--smart, handsome, responsible, had everything in common with me--but it turned out he was a coke addict. His life eventually deteriorated to the point that he couldn't function anymore, and he couldn't hide it. Cocaine is a powerful drug. It is NOT like weed, or alcohol, or cigarettes. It is not harmless.



Inevitably, your boyfriend will either quit (and I hope he does) or it will destroy him.



I assure you, it is not worth the heartache it will cost you to see him devolve into a shadow of his former self--coke will destroy his brain, and it already is. I had a child with the college boyfriend that I mentioned--I'm raising the child alone, because even though his father is clean now, he destroyed his mind with cocaine.



This is a red flag. It's unequivocal. You need to leave him now.



</answer>



<answer from>



HipOrLac...
Member since: 09 October 2008
Total points: 154 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If he is buying it you should tell him to cut it out...if it's something he comes across from time to time I would say drop it. As long as he isn't looking for it I'd say he's just living life...



Not to say that I condone drug use...but it happens.



I used to do a bunch of blow. I realized it wasn't for me and was disgusted with how much money I wasted.



If you find that all of hisclose friends blow coke...well then chances are he is a cokehead. Cocaine is one hell of a drug and it's not nearly acceptable as pot. So usually people that do it cling to some sort of group so they can pool their money and get more for cheaper.



Find out what "occasionally" is and I think your answer will become much clearer.



</answer>



<answer from>



fastbob
Member since: 03 August 2007
Total points: 1892 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Oh I know I should say counselling,gp,group therapy but you know something??.A lot of people can happily use drugs and live useful,normal lives.



I'm sure i'll get slated for saying that but it is true.The fact that your boyfriend doesn't noticeably change personalites and owned up of his own free will to you prooves that it hasn't got a hold of him.



I'd relax but then most the people I know take some drug or other cannibis and valium being the most common but well have plenty of mates that regularly use coke,while myself I'm a regular amphetamine user yet I work full time,have done for years and have normal relationships and a decent member of society.



I'd suggest you trust him ti know what needs to be done and leave it at that,he sounds like he is in control and not the coke thats the main point !!!



</answer>

<question>

<answer from>



chappie_...
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 137 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think there are 2 ways, the hard way and the soft way.



The hard way, put yourself in a situation there is no turning back. For example (extreme) drop yourself in Paris, I bet you have to approach people to askt he road to the airport :)



The soft way, you need a bit by bit. You need someone who can push you a little bit. Giving you trust, faith and confidence.



I have helped many people to be less shy. For example going to the cinema. A friend of mine is very shy. I took her out for a movie. While we were standing before the cinema, I asked her to pick which movie. She didnt respond, I keep asking her, she said I dont mind just pick any. I gave her simple choices A B or C, Still no responds...



Ok ask her to flip a coin. Head is A and Coin is B. etc etc etc. Finally she has decided.



Second time, she did it to me, flip a coin.... Darn it...



Hard way,.. I "dropped" myself in Paris, and had one bloody address. Its either you starve to death or you start asking people.



</answer>

Do a little at a time.

Often the hardest part is just getting started, and knowing i won't be spending all day makes it less of a burden.

<answer from>



cfc1902
Member since: 22 November 2006
Total points: 400 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sometimes when you procrastinate it's because unconsciously you realise that what you are supposed to be doing is wrong for you, or will have a negative outcome. Eg.: you are supposed to be filling in a form for an interview, but the job would be terrible if you got it.  Whatever anyone says (and it's a Protestant work ethic thing) daydreaming can be good for you. It's nature's way of helping you think of all the alternatives and therefore becoming more adaptable.  I am old enough to know that lots of the things I worked really hard for in my youth were a complete waste of time.  Some of the things that seemed like wasting time (writing letters, playing music) have come in really useful.  Just because you enjoy it, doesn't necessarily mean it's bad for you.  Passing the time joking with friends will stay with you for the rest of your life. But obviously, don't be a complete slob!
Best wishes to you anyway.



Source(s):



life



</answer>



<answer from>



Mike
Member since: 02 February 2007
Total points: 1342 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't know your personal situation.  Whether you are in school, what age, all the particulars.



Simply put find something that you want to do.  When you are doing something that you enjoy you wont feel the need to procrastinate.  If your goal (what you want to do) is something that just inst possible at this time you have to remind yourself that what you're doing now is to get to what you really want to do.  Sometimes we just have to do things that we don't like in order to do the things that we love.  In a society of instant gratification its easy to get lost in the moment and forget your true goals.



</answer>

<question from>



honey08
Member since: 21 August 2007
Total points: 178 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What do you do when a person you care about is feeling really bad ? ?



Ive gotten to know this guy, that has an amazing personality, he is smart, funny and caring. But he has had a really messed up relationship with his family, mostly his dad. And his mother died about five years ago. Still he is so strong and manages to live a somewhat normal life, he has an apartment and a lot of friends. But he has told me that he has a lot of anxiety, and even anxietyattacks that made him faint a few times. And trouble sleeping, and really feeling like everything is meaningless. And I really care for him, I know he likes me more than a friend, but I dont know how to handle someone who is feeling like that inside . He knows all of his issues and that he is carrying all the pain inside of him. And I just wish he would talk to me about it, and maybe in some way I could be a support for him along the way. But he doesnt want to do anything about how he feels, he doesnt have any good selfesteem, but I know that he is a wonderful person, he has showed me that. I just want to know if I could say or do something for him ? ... so that he would realize that he needs to talk about this and start loving himself instead of feeling so bad inside all the time . Im afraid he`ll get a depression if he doesnt do something soon. Any ideas or tips on how to make someone so stubborn deal with his problem ?



</question>



<answer from>



jeanie
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 204 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



just try to comfort him at his time of need!



</answer>



<answer from>



rcsi student
Member since: 09 January 2007
Total points: 2977 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



To answer this question, lets imagine (God forbid) that your mother has died and your relationship with your father was screwed up somehow i.e. you and your friend's roles have been switched, how do you think you would cope? How could the pain be possible to bear?



The answer is simple. Strong people like your friend have found some coping strategies to tax on the pain, at the price of some aspects of his life.



As long as he's strong and you make him feel that you got his back, he WON'T suffer from depression.



To hear him out, don't  interrupti him, take him out to a walk in the park (or something like that) and ask him about how life is going, how he's coping (ask him in order to trigger him into talking himself out) and when you do that, it will be a first step to sorting out this mess.



</answer>

<answer from>



Sybil C
Member since: 08 August 2008
Total points: 3302 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, every action is a reaction to something else. It's not some cosmic reason, but because of something we did or didn't do. Sometimes it is just because someone else wasn't paying attention to what they were doing and it affected us. We do learn lessons from what happens to us but I don't think it is all planned ahead of time.



Most people don't want to accept the fact that most of what happens to them are directly because of choices they make in their own lives. So their answer to everything is some cosmic "reason".



</answer>



<answer from>



Shaman
Member since: 11 August 2006
Total points: 8523 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes....  The Law of Cause and Effect.



Everything that happens (effect) happens because circumstances allow it and some domino up the line was pushed by someone or something (cause).



However, your question is probably aimed more at does everything happen for a "higher" reason aimed at helping us grow as ppl.  Alas, I have to say I agree with that phrase, "Sh** happens!"  And it does happen for a reason....  But that reason, that cause, may not be something that helps us feel better in knowing it.



It's on us to find meaning and/or give some event meaning (in a personal way) that helps us move forward or else we will stagnate and wither.



</answer>



<answer from>



alion300
Member since: 18 January 2006
Total points: 24541 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes,there is no effect without cause. However,the reason is not necessarily good or logical.



</answer>

<question from>



Claire
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 173 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why are certain people labeled as smart?



What is it about the way poeple act or look that gives people the idea that they are smart?



</question>



<answer from>



Chloe Louise #1
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 1872 (Level 3)

They keep using the excuse that they know what I look llike when I'm sick (like my dad would say: i've been raising u since u were little. <answer>



Have you ever faked it? The thermometer said 103, but was that because you ran it under hot water? If you are satisfied with your answers to all these questions, then sit your folks down and ask them why they think you are a faker. Take in everything they have to say without defending yourself. When they are done, calmly present your point of view.



Good luck!

RUTH B
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 103 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



schizophrenia onset is typically between the ages of 15 and 25 (although it can affect children younger than fourteen, with a subtype known as childhood-onset schizophrenia). The disorder can come on over a period of years (called insidious onset) or be very rapid. It affects 1% of the general population.



</answer>

How do I overcome this and suggestions?

<answer from>



Lady Canyon
Member since: 08 June 2007
Total points: 1339 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I know it's hard, but first try to let it go. Especially since you think she didn't intend to hurt your feelings. Everyone at one time or another says things that could hurt another person's feelings.



However, if she continues to say things that offend you, talk with her about it in some way or another, preferably in person or over the phone. Just breifly tell her that what she said upset you and if she's a good person that cares about you, she'll understand and apologize. And if she's still causing problems after that, it would be best to avoid her from then on.



Good luck

Member since: 01 April 2008

<answer>



You know.  She's not thinking about it.  You still are but she isn't.  She wins.



But if you're certain she didn't mean to offend you then why not just approach it rationally...and IN PERSON.  Personalize it.  Let her SEE the person she offended.  Let her SEE the look on your face when you tell her.  That will get the point across far better than email or a phone call and she'll be far more likely to understand the extent of the offense.



</answer>

<question>



Why is this guy playing games with me?



For about 2 months, this guy was flirting with me. He would find ways to touch me, compliment me often, always sit near me, glancing over, tell me personal stories, joke with me/focus on me in a crowd, etc...Then a few weeks ago, while in theatre class, his partner for a scene of his (a kissing scene) asked me if I would do it. I said I wouldn't only cause of my germ paranoia, plus it would be in front of people. Well, this one guy said something like "ooh that was harsh" or something like that. I said that I thought he was a good looking guy, I just would feel weird doing that in front of people. Later, he came from his end of the room to come sit next to me at the other end of the room. We didn't speak at all, but I spoke to another guy in front of me for a few seconds abour something. I forget what, but I wasn't flirting. At least not intentionally, maybe it looked like that to this other guy since me and the guy I was talking with were laughing.



Anyway, for about a week or two, this guy that I like and was flirting before, just stopped. He would act very distant and kind of ignore me. If he did talk to me, he would treat me like a friend. If I touched him, he would lean back afterwards and he wouldn't touch back, I would see him eyeing up or checking out other girls, etc...



Now today, since I just love halloween oh so much, I decided to give little treat bags to my theatre class (I'm in college BTW. I know, a little old for that, but oh well). Anyway, after I gave him his baggy he says "You're getting a hug later" and I didn't think much of it. After I was done giving them out. He says again, "(My name), give me a hug" or something like that, so I did. Well, later on at rehearsal for a play I noticed he was trying to get my attention more. Like if I was talking to someone, he would be walking around in circles near me and I could see him out of the corner of my eye looking at me from time to time. Or if I would enter the room he would look real quick. Also, I tested touching him again. And I noticed he would reciprocate. Not immediately, but after a few minutes he would play with the strings on my shirt or joke around with me (like physical movements), and he would start telling me personal stories of his again.



So what is going on? Why is he acting like this? It almost seems as if he's interested again when I do something different (like if I wear a crazy outfit for example). I have a tendency to dress a little...odd, lol. And lately I've been lazy and wearing more black, but as soon as I wear something crazy again and seem more cheerful and stuff,
he "takes notice" i guess you could say. I don't know if it has anything to do with that, I just noticed that he suddenly seemed closer now that I dressed differently today and was more "happy". Confusing, I know. Any help would be greatly appreciated.



Sorry this was so long. Thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



wolfex16
Member since: 13 August 2008
Total points: 236 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



He obviously likes you. Go up and give him a big kiss.



</answer>



<answer from>



binhducd...
Member since: 27 August 2006
Total points: 904 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I just sounded like you were giving him messages about how far you wanted your relationship to go with him.



"It's okay to joke around and stuff, but we can't kiss, and definitely if it's not in public" was apparently what he got from that situation.



Obviously it's been a few days, and you've been acting normal to him so maybe he's gotten the idea that you've eased up on him, and he can be more friendly to you like before.



It's not too confusing. You just gotta know the steps in this little dance we call social interactions.



If he takes the lead and you say no, well then he has to back off so that he doesn't get embarrassed, if you happen to make a scene.  Now that things are a bit better, he can lean a little bit into the lead again with you.



If you really, like this guy you should definitely drop some hints his way. Although it seems as though you guys have a little game going on between each other. Someone seems to be chasing someone else.



He obviously very friendly with you and enjoys your time with him. And you seem to care a little bit about him, if you're asking others of their opinions on the situation.



You guys seem to have a fun relationship going on. You guys could be more without actually saying it. A lot of relationships I've seen have had a steady backbone of the guys trying hopelessly get the girl. The chase after all, is half the fun. You guys could still joke around but on a more personal level. And when you do feel it's time you guys could step it up, you guys definitely have the choice to do that.



Hoped this helped, good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



Kennedy
Member since: 17 August 2006
Total points: 941 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

Psychology



</category>



<question from>



mister?
Member since: 06 November 2007
Total points: 9 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What's the difference between an addiction and an obsession?



Can an addiction turn into an obsession and can an obsession turn into an addiction?



</question>



<additional details>



This is my take on the definitions:  An obsession can be an unwanted thought that sticks in your brain and you have to perform certain rituals to alleviate the stress and anxiety produced from it for example, your unwanted thought is that your hands are germ infected and therefore you never stop washing your  hands.  Whereas an addiction is something you actually get a pleasure out of doing and don't realize the negative affects of it.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Sunshine L
Member since: 12 August 2008
Total points: 165 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i would have to say yes..to both because an addition to say drugs can become an Obsession  because once you need something so much you depend upon it and then it becomes known as an Obsession!
i hope i helped!



</answer>



<answer from>



tomara koi d
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 136 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I know a source of your answer.



Source(s):



http://oracle-4u.blogspot.com



</answer>



<answer from>



Kiwi --x Melon*
Member since: 26 May 2008
Total points: 3907 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think an addiction is something that you have grown to rely on and need it to go through each day. And I think an obsession is something you really love and want. You don't need it, you just probably can't stop thinking about it.



</answer>



<answer from>



gwen r
Member since: 06 November 2007
Total points: 7724 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



In casual speech, the two are interchangeable.



In clinical definition, an addiction is physical. Once addicted to a substance, the body craves it without regard to thoughts or outside influences.



Obsession is mental/emotional. There is no physical need whatsoever for me to have this season's fashion update, but I feel like I will be inadequate without it. Gimme, gimme, gimme...



</answer>



<answer from>



BluRey
Member since: 03 February 2008
Total points: 13722 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



thank you for this question. i now know, from the answers you received that in my own life i was afraid to label myself as an relationship addict. i did not like that possibility. i rather like the label relationship obsession. -blurey



</answer>



<answer from>



the believer
Member since: 23 October 2008
Total points: 23 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Addction : The condition of being habitually .



Obsession: A mental disorder.



From the second to the first easy .



</answer>

the mind is a powerfull thing, having others place labels on you weather they are correct or not can have a real impact in how you perceive yourself. in this same way what you think of your self will self manifest.-blurey

<answer from>



mamaoso
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 700 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Of course that is prooven the power of suggestion. For example if we were to use children, and sample of kids the ones that are told they are stupid, no good, example will perform significantly less then their peers who are told how great they are. Same is true for all humanity. If a human being is told enough times they have such and such mental illness, they will begin to believe it and naturally mimic the symptoms. This is why labeling is dangerous.



</answer>
