<answer from>



Micki
Member since: 06 May 2007
Total points: 6749 (Level 5)

<answer>



You need to WANT to change first of all.



Yes - you do need to clean your room first.  Make it into something that reflects YOU.  Get rid of the clothes that you don't wear or that don't fit you anymore.  Rearrange your room - that's always a good way to look at things differently.  After you're done with your room, GET OUT AND ENJOY THE DAY.  If you're new in the neighborhood, go for a walk.  Do some volunteer work!  Get a job so that you can enjoy Christmas.  The key to your bad mood is YOU.



</answer>

<answer>



Yes, of course it's normal. What you have to do to overcome it is find one thing you're good at - and do it. Play a sport, play an instrument, get out and hang out with people. You are always going to feel stupid and mad at yourself at one time or another, but you have to find a hobby and get out. Then, you will get your mind off of it.

<answer from>



cristina...
Member since: 11 October 2008
Total points: 2636 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Singles & Dating



</answer from>



<answer>



The problem with low self esteem, if it's a life-long condition, is it causes you to make bad decisions because you don't think you can do any better. Healthy self esteem is knowing you are someone of value and deserving of the best, not settling for whatever you can get.



Everyone has low moments in life but you can't let them define who you are.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mr-K-
Member since: 18 October 2006
Total points: 15296 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer from>



cheyserr m
Member since: 02 February 2008
Total points: 198 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



the way we look at ourselves stems from our experiences and on how we interpret those experiences.



having a low self-esteem is normal if the person experiences things that can cause him to see those things as self-degrading. in this case, if the person feels degraded (for example) most of the time then he is likely to develop low self-esteem.



feedbacks about ourselves from people (parents and teachers, for example) around us surely have great effects on how we see ourselves.



</answer>

Heather D

<question>



I had a really wierd dream! what dose it mean?



okay i had a dream that i was pregnant....and my husband left to go to iraq cause in my dream he was in the millitary....and my mom was the only one here with me ...and i went into labor, and she had the doctor knocked me out, and when i woke up my mom let someone adopt my baby, i know the ppl in real life, and i cried walking up and down the halls for what seemed like forever, and then i seen the people who were adopting, and they were sitting in this glass room, but it wasnt all glass, then i seen the man who was in charge of the adoption, and i told him i didnt want to give up my baby, and he told the ppl that they were going to be saving alot of money here in about 5 mins because i wasnt giving them my baby, well then i was someones house bathing her, she was really little, new born, then i was sitting on my moms couch and i said what do you think i should name her, and i said haylee faith, then i woke up....she was beautiful....any suggestions?



</question>



<answer from>



xxRomanx...
Member since: 22 March 2008
Total points: 314 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



To dream that you are pregnant, symbolizes an aspect of yourself or some aspect of your personal life that is growing and developing. You may not be ready to talk about it or act on it.  This may also represent the birth of a new idea, direction, project or goal.



To dream of giving birth or see someone else giving birth, suggests that you are giving birth to a new idea or project. It also represents a new attitude, fresh beginnings or a major  upcoming event.  Alternatively, the dream may be calling attention to your inner child and the potential for your to grow. A more direct interpretation of this dream, may represent your desires/ anxieties of giving birth or the anticipation for such an event to occur.



To dream that you or others are adopting a child, indicates that you are taking on something new and different. Ask yourself what is missing in your life that would make you happy.



....Okay i know that was alot of techinical talk but its all from the website below.



Source(s):



http://www.dreammoods.com/dreamdictionar...



</answer>

thank you



</asker's comment>

Psychology

<question from>



QuestionQueen mybloop.com/otad12
Member since: 19 February 2008
Total points: 5808 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



What's the proper way to respond & assert myself when someone tries to physically FORCE their opinions on me?



I'm 25 & have a college degree. Family or not, people always try to shove their opinions down my throat & try to control, manipulate, boss me around, tell me how to live my life, & they'll try to physically STOP me from doing what makes me content. If listening to a song I like makes me happy, why do people try to make it like I'm wrong for it? I have noise-cancelling headphones, & no one can hear my music. Even the SIMPLEST choices in my life, people try to stop me from doing it.



This frustrates me, & I feel defenseless & unable to stand up for myself, out of fear of the situation escalating. Here's an example:



Brother asks, "What are you listening to?" & I don't say, so he JERKS my CD player out of my hand & sees what album I'm playing, & then asks, "What I told u about listenin' 2 this? Huh!? Huh!?" & then smash & break my CD.



No one wants me to further my education, get married, have kids, make a family, get a job, etc. They want me to stay disabled & depend on THEM for the rest of my life, so they can feel more empowered. When I do things independently, they get upset, & they figure they need to monitor or observe me do certain things, & they treat me like a child, or even worse. They treat me like scum is worth more than me.



& those SAME people-family or not, tell me TO MY FACE that they don't give a DAMN about me!



Why can't I be free? Why don't people leave me the hell alone? & mental health case managers tell me I shouldn't stay locked up in my apt all day, every day. But I can't even leave my house without confrontation or someone harassing me.



How do I deal with this? I feel useless, hopeless, worthless, etc. I feel like I don't have any confidence or abilities. I feel like a nobody. People treat me like I don't have a right to live natural human life.



I suffer OCD, anxiety, Tourette's, & depression, & I had 2 strokes @ age 5. But I've accomplished quite a bit to have a disability & graduate high school with Honors (top 10%) & graduate college. People don't understand the symptoms of my disorders, & they just label me as crazy, & they treat me like a child They treat me like I'm too stupid to know left from right. I have to question the morality, logic, & coherence of everything I do, say, think, or feel.



Please give me some advice.



</question>



<answer from>



annalyze...
Member since: 29 January 2006
Total points: 5655 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



When people tell you what to do, simply smile and walk away.  You owe no one an explanation for your actions.  Just be yourself and listen to what others have to say, keep what you want and leave the rest.
It's really quite simple.



</answer>

<answer>



Best I can tell you, learn not to care, you'd be surprised just how freeing apathy can be. How you react to people is a choice you make. Why do you choose to give them the power (ability) to affect you on any level? As long as you allow them to affect you, the longer they will keep at you.



If you're happy with who and what you are, ignore them and get on with your life. Either that, or say something so totally offensive their ears will fall off (chances are, they will actually choose to be offended, most people that are that opinionated, that they believe their way is the best way for everyone, actually choose to give others the power to offend them. It can actually be quite amusing and usually very easy to do.). They (say they) do it because they "care" about you, when it's really all about them and being comfortable with you. And they can't be comfortable with you unless you are somewhat, if not completely, like them. Don't allow them to affect you...it's all a simple choice. The other option is patronize them, be so obviously condescending that they don't want to hazard speaking to you.



These methods have worked for me in the past, I have others, but these have rarely failed me.



But don't try any of them because I say so...they're only suggestions for you to consider...



</answer>

I have tried committing suicide before but the police found me before I was fully gone and brought me back. Im not writing this email because Im trying to stop myself because if I really want to again I will do it regardless of what Im told, but sometimes its harder than others not to do it. I have been taking care of my very ill father since I was 10 years old and a few months ago he finally passed away. I am now 18 years old and the grief is unbearable some nights. After he passed away the rest of my family seperated and no longer wants to speak to me and I have to work 5 days a week to pay my rent, plus I am still in high school. My friends have left for University and I hope to join them next year but nights like tonight make me feel like that day is never coming and Im so stressed all the time but can not do anything about it. I have to work as much as I do or I will not be able to afford rent and groceries and I have to attend school because I will not get into university if I dont attend. I have no friends or family left where I live and I have tried to talk to people that can help but it always makes me feel worse. Im just not sure what to do anymore because nothing I try is working and I feel like life just isnt worth living and even when I dont believe I will try it again I always have the want in the back of my head and it drives me insane.



CAN ANYONE HELP ME WITH ADVICE I CAN GIVE THEM



</question>



<additional details>



From the comments it sounds like some of you are thinking I am thinking about killing myself, which I am not...



I have given them the number to hotlines they say their school counselor has already tried that and the hotlines did not help them at all



Here's the situation the father was keeping everyone together. His mother and brother really did not help with the care of his father. Once his father died his mother said he was a mistake and she left, his brother said they were too different to stay in contact so he left.



I currently live in the US; he lives in Canada. (i've never met this kid in real life; I just happened to come across this while online)



But I am in the process to see if maybe I could get the funds together to go to Canada maybe the week of thanksgiving or see if I could fly them down where I live....Maybe it will give him something to look fwd too and thanksgiving is a terrible time to be alone (esp. in his situation)



</additional details>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



okay idk it my answer is going to that diff from the others, but i myself have gone through things like this and still have that feeling of no self worth.



the more he stays busy the better, ask him if he has any other kids in high school that he could pal around with, or make new friends there?
by the way you are already helping him by just talking to him. some times if your just someones friend it is enough. he is someone he can talk to connect with make it through the day.
as for hotlines don't really work he could try sites on the web. you could do research and find some. unfortunately hotlines are usually a recording or they are ppl like you and me that don't have any real backgrounds to help.



keep reminding him of all the good things in his life. such as: work, high school, college, clothes, roof over his head, food on the table, he gets enjoy the beautiful weather, see ranibows, flower opening up, birds singing, and Earth. even though there is a lot of hate and destruction in the world., there is still a lot of good in the world. then talk about how good of person he is and what he brings to the world.
such as: he goes to work and does his job well (find out what he does first that would make this statement easier). make a scenerio if there was a puppy that needed some help would you help it. if he says yes than say see you are a good person and life w/o you would be unbearable.



if his family disowned him then so what, yes it is hard but that is there choice not have good in there life. he did a wonderful thing by caring for his ill father. i'm not much for religion myself, but if he believes in it pressure him to go to church. if he is not religious i would say walk around in a park and take in all the beauty, walk around your neighborhood look at all the different ppl, look at life as a whole not just what goes on his life.



it is very hard and overwhelming to live life by yourself at such a young age but he has made it this far and he will be able to longer. he has to so he can see all his friends in college again, and he has you his new online friend to chew that fat with.



i hope this helps, have a good day and your doing a good thing!

<answer>



As a psychology major, I agree you should notify someone trained that can help. The suicide hotline (number given by the first answerer) is also good if the person wants to talk.
I will also say this: Don't say anything negative about it. Statements like "You're not thinking of killing yourself, are you?" and "Why would you want to do that?" are not good. It promotes a negative tone, which isn't a good thing when someone is considering suicide. I noticed they also said they're not writing the e-mail because they're trying to stop themselves. Something tells me that's not true. If someone truly wants to kill themselves, they're not likely to tell other people about it.



</answer>

<answer>



If you really want to commit suicide, set a date at least three months away. If in those three months you never have any doubts, then find a safe, effective way to end your life and do it.



It's you're life and you have the right to end it, but make sure you're not doing it because of a bad week. Death is permanent so make sure you're not making a rash decision.



(Most people will have plenty of doubt in the three months and realize they really do want to live)

Social Science

<question from>



Sully
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Psychology? Is it worth it?



I'm thinking of studying psychology in university but I'm far more interested in the theory side rather than the science side. I was wondering if as a career it is more focused on the science aspect or theory?



</question>



<answer from>



reasonab...
Member since: 27 March 2008
Total points: 136 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You might like to think of it this way. There is Research Psychology and Applied Psychology. The research approaches are built upon assumptions about how we get to know things (epistemology) and typically much psychological research is based on a positivist approach that seeks hard facts about peoples behaviour. Commonly this is called the scientific approach. Alternative approaches include 'interpretative' approaches that enquire about people's meaning making. You will be unable to study psychology without some appreciation of the research that has been conducted and the theories that have resulted from that research.



There are also several 'flavours' of psychology - behaviorism (a bit passe now) focussing only on observed behaviour and things like conditioned learning, there is cognitive psychology which explores how the mind makes sense of the world, their is social psychology exploring the workings of relationships between people and groups.



Applied psychology draws from the Theoretical research and 'applies' it to a particular context. So psychology can be applied to mental health, extreme cases such as trauma, depression, psychosis ranging from extreme mental health work through to counselling, it can be applied to organisational life in areas like coaching and mentoring, it can apply to work such as negotiation, advertising, selling and so on, even pet psychology. Specific applications of psychology can be followed such Neuro Linguistic Programming (NLP).Transactional Analysis, Cognitive Affective Therapy (CAT) etc.



My suggestion would be have an idea of the context you would like to work. Theory development is very academic, the applied stuff relates to jobs.



I believe psychological understanding is very much worth it as it relates to how people learn and change, their motivations, their sense making, and how we socially influence. There is much written about attitudes, attitude change, persuasion, and resistance to persuasion too. So even working for a political party or a charity involves psychology



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks for the info. Especially since Im extremely indecisive about my future at the moment.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



PsyGuy
Member since: 28 January 2006
Total points: 9784 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Without science there would be no theories.  There would only be numerous hypothesis.
Psychology is a very interesting profession but you have to decide what you want to do with it.  From a clinical aspect you don't have to deal with the science side of psychology but you do have to know and understand that part of it.  You can't just pick a theory and treat clients; you have to know the scientific details of what that theory means.  It would be like building a house without a foundation.
Start with your general psychology classes and proceed from there.



Source(s):



See my profile&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;&lt;



</answer>

mj_puce

Total points: 6227 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ok I've never been raped, but I believe it would be like anything traumatic that happens to you, like a death in the family for example, in the sense that the memory will never go away, and it will change your life. Yet over time, the memory will not be so overwhelming, but become just part of your life story. Hopefully if you get good counselling and support, the healing process will give you deeper insights.  I have no doubt it's possible to be happy again, in time. Human beings can be extremely resilient. When people never seem to recover from traumatic events, it's usually because they block their recovery with other things like alcohol.



</answer>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



How can I improve my Speech/ The way I talk???? Please help.?



I've been noticing the reason why some people don't take me seriously whatsoever, its because of the way I talk! First and foremost, I am Tall, very Attractive, Smart, Intelligent, Positive person, I have a unique personality. BUT For as long as I can remember people never take me seriously and some people actually think i'm slow, dumb, incompetent or mentally crazy!!!!!! This really has gotten to my head and honestly my self esteem has gone down, I find myself questioning my own intelligence and my own self worth. I think people around me look at me this way because when I talk i sound "slow" and sound almost childish and naive, as if I'm new in this world. I think when I talk I sound childish and extremely naive, WHEN I'M NOT. When i speak I sometimes don't speak clearly, sometimes stutter (not badly). This is something I myself have recently noticed, no one has told me this. This is something that came to my awareness a couple months ago. Is there any way I can improve and strengthen my speech??? Speak with authority and confidence and not sound slow or mentally incompetent. (by the way do any of you think I'm mentally incompetent by reading this??, answer honestly) Thanks.

This has nothing to do with my intelligence at all. I have a vocabulary for days. lol. It has to do with the way I speak and how I sound when I speak.

<answer>



I am confused.  You describe yourself glowingly and with great aplomb.. yet you are concerned about how you "sound"...?????
A little non-cohesive I'd say...
However, my Mom used to do this when I was a kid, and it's something I keep up to this day with friends and co-workers...learn a new word a week...(write it down on an index card)...by the end of the week, you should have made  this word part of your regular vocabulary.
This will increase your "appearance" of intelligence which seems to be important to you...next, I would employ a speech therapist to address any issues about how you "sound" and work on helping you to project the image you desire...how you "sound" to others is beyond the scope of help here, since we cannot "hear" you...

I think that what your counselor did is very special. How sweet to extend herself to you this way.  She obviously feels you are trustworthy to do that. I doubt that many would do that but there are many of us available to folk like you here too.



If I may help you with one line - you mentioned you can contact her when you get stressed and down.  When those times come refuse to get into a negative place.  You see I call that place the pit of negativity, self-pity and deception.  Always bear in mind that negative draws more negative to it, so when one goes in that direction, you are opening yourself to more negative things. Take for example hurt.  Someone says something that hurts you, so you either let it go due to the circumstance that promoted the action or you entertain it and next comes anger...how dare they!  Then comes remorse because you think about what was said and it upsets you and you start doubting yourself (doubt is next) and so the things get worse and worse until you go into a decline and want to commit suicide because of one stupid remark.  Do you see how the mountain begins to build itself until it is all that you see and blocks you from progress. So, always consider what you are going to do with your hurt or anything negative thrown your way. You are the only one who can choose. Immaturity always chooses negative, but maturity makes you stop and think and choose the right thing. Everything in life is about the choices we make and no one can be blamed for you making those choices but you.  The good news is that even if you have erred, there is always a way out. We just have to bear in mind that every choice has a consequence.  We only have one life and one huge race of time to run.  If I can encourage you to include God in that race, you wont regret it.  God roots for you all the way.  If you fall he picks you up .  If the road gets tough, God carries you and when he gets to where the road is smooth again he gives you the strength to carry on. When you reach the goal posts he is waiting for you with his arms open wide ready to catch you and say: "Well done my angel, I knew you would make it!" Take care and be happy for all the help you are getting from your therapist.  Shes making time for you and that is really special.

Masturbation (as one person mentioned) will reduce your sexual drive for a time but it is like a drug, you'll need to do it more often to reduce the urge.



As for waiting it is a good thing to due. I made the mistake of not waiting.  I met a girl in college and I thought she was the girl I was going to spend the rest of my life with. Things got carried away one night and we both stopped before all of the closes were off.  Unfortunately we kept pushing the boundaries until one of us was naked, then both, then the sex.



Long story short she was not the girl for me and we broke up about 4 months later.  When I did met the girl of my dreams (which I did marry) my x-girlfriend attempted to ruin it by telling my fiance that we had had sex.  It just about destroyed my relationship with my fiance and cost me the woman of my dreams.



Wait until you are married because you can only give away your virginity once. If you give it to the wrong person you can't ask for it back and it can destroy the relationship that you really want.



Some people also wear a promise ring. This is to remind them that they are waiting until they are married for sex. It is another physical reminder to wait and why they are waiting. So, create reminders to remind you to wait.

<question>



Feeling depressed any advice? ?



i only see my boyfriend every 2 weeks as he's away at uni. i miss him so much i get so depressed. does anyone ave any advice for me :(

<answer from>



WHO CARES
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 3952 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Get out and hang with your friends. You need to keep active and not sit around moping about something you can't do anything about. It's not helping you at all. So get out and stay busy. You'll think less often.



</answer>



<answer from>



rougejol...
Member since: 29 June 2007
Total points: 344 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



find a new boyfriend!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Nik's mom
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 178 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



When we were first dating, my boyfriend worked nights and I was in school during the day, AND I worked weekends, so we didn't get as much 'face time' as I would've liked.  It was my first year of university, and I found the entire year really stressful.  I felt depressed and anxious a lot of the time, and my emotions were difficult to control.



Let me see...  My boyfriend eventually became my husband, so obviously we got through it.. ;-)  I think what helped me the most was staying in touch with my boyfriend through e-mail, and staying active in the other relationships in my life with family members and friends.  I also talked to a counselor a few times (I was covered through my part-time job) and that helped, too.  On days when I was feeling especially low, I avoided things that made me feel worse (for me it was being alone) and tried to keep my thoughts (and self-talk) positive.



Being busy also helped.  Feeling like I was contributing to something or accomplishing something did wonders to get my mind off of missing him, and helped me to feel better.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jai_tota...
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 111 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You have to find something to keep you occupied, something that can steer your attention.  Find a great job, or volunteer, I don't know if you are in school or not, but find your own niche.



One answerer was right that going out with friends is a great way to brighten your mood, reading a good book, etc.



Missing your boyfriend is normal, but do not let him define who you are.  Because he is taking care of his business and staying focused, you have to do your own thing too!



Source(s):



Life Coach



</answer>

<answer from>

<answer>



Yes, I think you are most definitely on to something here.



If you truly find it within yourself to love those who hate you, nothing they can do will have the same effect. If you believe in the afterlife, this even includes those who kill us. They may destroy your body, but you rob them of the power to defeat your soul.



</answer>

<answer from>



Dr. Bob
Member since: 23 January 2008
Total points: 19318 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



"Love" and "hate" are feelings, and as such are (1) chosen, and (2) supported by thoughts. Neither is a "thing" in itself, separate from the lover or hater. Neither has any "power" in the sense of ability to do anything or change anything.



It may be nice and poetic to think of feelings as actual things, like a rock or a banana. And I know that, in the '60s, it was common in "sensitivity training" circles to speak of "feelings as facts," but the fact is they are chosen, they are passing, and they can be changed in the blink of an eye.



We say we "fall in love" or that "love lasts forever," but as we know from observing real life, we also "fall out of love" and know that love does NOT last...hence, we get married and then divorced, etc.



-- Dr. Bob



</answer>



<answer from>



Evil Laurie
Member since: 07 November 2007
Total points: 2796 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<answer>



In my country November 11 is "Remembrance Day." I remember my grandfather and all the suffering he and his friends went through just so that I could be what I am. I couldn't help myself, but I found myself crying for all those people that sacrificed their lives so that the rest of us could enjoy the freedoms that we have. I don't want to sound corny, but when I think of what those people did for me I start to think that there isn't enough for us to do to show our appreciation.



And you know what is the best thing about it is? I have never ONCE heard any of those people complain. Not ONCE. So I guess that they've learned a little bit about life. I've learned enough to realize that shedding a tear for those who didn't come back is the best way to honour them.



It makes me sad that in this day and age people still have to give their lives for an ideal that everyone accepted many years ago. We just haven't got it right yet...



</answer>

<question from>



Adama D
Member since: 24 August 2008
Total points: 70 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Help me resolve my crisis...?



Im so scared. I love my boyfriend more than my life, but Im afraid one major difference we have will be a great obstacle. Im very intellectual, and need to talk about my ideas and feelings a lot or i will feel unhappy. Hes totally rational and calculated, and only talks about facts, and has no real emotions, or philosophical/intellectual thoughts. Im afraid that I will be unhappy for that. On the other hand im too intellectual, that Im becoming a daydreamer, and being like I am will not get me anywhere in my life. I hate that attribute of mine, and WANT to change it, and Im really uncomfortable with it. I need to start doing more instead of just talking. Now Im having serious anxiety attacks because im really confused. Were both 21. Together for over 2.5 yrs..



</question>



<additional details>



Just to add, he really likes me for who I am...but I think thats myabe because he got used to me or so...but he thinks were fine:)



Thanx everyone...this problem has seriously taken a toll on me, and its probably major stress that makes me think this way. And I see everything that happenes as the worst possible thing...thanx for your answers...



</additional details>



<answer from>



Daedalus
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 124 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ask yourself what started your anxiety in the first place. Are you different now than you were 2.5 years ago? Is he? If yes, what changed and why? Change isn't always bad - don't force it and don't fight it.
If you two haven't changed, then I'm guessing there was an event that made you think about this, or a series of events. Think about what it was and try and deal with that specific issue, rather than reanalyzing your entire relationship. Hope this helps.



</answer>



<answer from>



aspen
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 105 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



This may sound harsh, and it may be hard, but if he does not appreciate who you are and what you are as a person, maybe he just isn't the right guy for you. You should talk to him about your feelings and ideas, it's the way of a healthy relationship. If you're unhappy you NEED to talk to him, or I guarantee your relationship will change from bad to worse.



Being intellectual is a good attribute, don't let that get to you. Don't change who you are, you are beautiful just the way you are. I don't understand the details, but I'm sure that's why your boyfriend chose you in the first place, because you were smart and caring, and sensitive.



And most of all, daydreaming is not bad. It's how we focus on our goals and fantasies. About the anxiety attacks, if you ever feel them coming, just stop whatever you're doing, talking or whatever, take a deep breath, and calm down. Close your eyes and just take a deep breath. It'll work. If not, drink some fluids (water is the best) to calm it down.



I hope it helped. :D



</answer>



<answer from>



Blueberr...
Member since: 11 July 2008
Total points: 717 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I believe that if you get some air, or some perspective by stepping back and watching your life. Don't get stressed, relax, breath and think about your life at the moment. Ask yourself, what do you want? What don't you want out of your life? Are you studying, are you working? Do you enjoy these things.



Everyone is different, that's maybe you are with your guy as you are different and so is but together the picture is complete. We are all going to have differences, its about how work together. But it is good that you are questioning if you can be with him because of that point of difference. If this difference is really bothering you then you have to either see past this difference and keep going or stop and really think if you want to be with him, if this difference really bothers you.



Your attribute of being an intellectual daydreamer is a good thing. Means you are creative, you are thinking of deeper things....these are all excellent things. Try and put these things to good use. You are still young at 21 and that is good that you want to start 'doing' more than talking. Being aware of this, like you are, is a good thing because you will be more aware of taking action more. Don't be confused, just slow down, write down things that mean a lot to you and what you would like to accomplish, even if it is the smallest thing. Write it down and start doing. Life is for living so keep going. Good luck.



</answer>

<answer from>



pasquale garonfolo
Member since: 21 December 2006
Total points: 10333 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your cousin should never ignore his father. He should listen carefully to whatever his father says, and so try and be more thoughtful or brightly reflective about the admonitions from his own father.



His father may be all too concerned about the doings and the learnings and the future of his own off-spring, this cousin of yours.



By asking his son to go and study, the father may mean that your cousin should try and be more diligent, more carefully dedicated about whatever learning assignments there may be.



To study, and to study well, may be a proud working at building up some good glowing memories for the future.



Allow me to wish you and your cousin more chances of great laughs in your life and in your studies.



</answer>

<answer from>



Tom E
Member since: 27 April 2006
Total points: 18178 (Level 6)

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Yes and no. Losing my brother in a drowning accident and then losing my health to a skull fracture a few years later, means my health and happiness quotient has dropped, not to mention my income. I have no living relatives and I'm not healthy enough to support a family. I live like a pauper when I'm used to much better. A good education and life experiences doesn't guarantee a comfortable retirement. I'm looking forward to being reunited with my family in a few decades. I'm too young to be put out to pasture!



Source(s):



life 101

<question>



Do I have Multiple Personality Disorder?



A lot recently, I've been having blackouts. People will come to talk to me about things I have no recollection of, and people will ask me if I'm in "a better mood" than yesterday. I will have no idea what they're talking about and I'm so scared.



I'll find myself somewhere with no idea how I got there, or I'll "wake up" to find myself doing something I would never do, eg. Writing something nasty or saying something rude.



Recently I was told that someone has been sending a teacher of mine personal information about me. But then they said they think it was me because the person sending the emails knew too much about me.



I used to email this teacher until recently, and then I broke off contact. I had no idea what they were talking about.



Usually, the last thing I can remember before a blackout is either a) a thud in my head, like someones hit me, b) an extremely sharp pain somewhere in my head, or sometimes I'll get a huge wave of pain in my head. Sometimes I'll just black out.



I think I have multiple personality disorder, and I don't know what to do. Please help!



</question>

<question>



Is it normal to change every year?



you're not the same as you were last year. or the year before.



</question>



<answer from>



Heisenbe...
Member since: 26 February 2008
Total points: 19843 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I'm not the same as I was two months ago. That's called growth. Yes, it's normal



</answer>



<asker's comment>



k



</asker's comment>



<comments>



pasquale garonfolo



We have about two aspects of "normal" life, one of immediate almost no directly perceptible change, and another one of a deferred change giving dreams of perpetuity. But changes are ever urging. But we are not sure of what we will be changed into or be ending like. We have glowing hopes, intuitions.



</comments>



<answer from>



The Unloved
Member since: 27 September 2008
Total points: 1238 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Of course it's normal! Those who would disagree either believe they have nothing to change or they are in denial about who they are and who others are.



The person I am today is not the same person I was last week, and definitely not the same person I was last year. The only thing that stays the same is the list of people I truly love. It can grow, but it never does get lower. You think you love someone today, but next year you realize it wasn't real. When it's real, you always remember the people. Even if your's old and dying.



</answer>



<answer from>



la_ti_da...
Member since: 20 March 2007
Total points: 2268 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes. Your experiences shape you as a person into who you are, so yes, you would change.



Also, obviously, changes in your life can change how you are - you might meet a new person and fall in love, you might be much happier, you might go through hardships, become more mature, or maybe you just like marmite now.



Short answer; yes.



</answer>



<answer from>



BeatingT...

</answer from>

<question>



What kind of disorder do I have?



I'm not sure. I feel I have a little bit of everything.



-I can barely eat or relax my mind, just by simply not knowing who won best supporting actress the year of 1996.
-I have to remind myself over and over that I've seen a movie, even if I had seen it 100 times
-I set my alarm clock at 4 in the morning on school days, and I reset it ten minutes later every time it goes off until about 7.  On the weekends, I don't care I just sleep in till late.



-Whenever I'm hyper I try to organize the letters of any word I think about mentally on a wall
-I can remember most of the days in the past few years, give me a date and I'll tell you what I did on that day
-I have to check at least five times if I had put something in the mail, if not more, I always have to check everything multiple times



-One hour I can feel like the worst person on the world, so guilty, so depressed, so unwilling to enjoy life and wondering why I'm even on this planet and listen to a song that reflects this mood, and the next hour I can feel like the best person on earth, so happy and jumping up and down to a song I like even hyper (this happens multiple times during the day)
-I always count down the days and cannot stop thinking about the past, I am unwilling to accept the fact that any day in my past life is wasted and that I will make each following day perfect, I will be the best human being ever, then I find out this is never the case
-I feel that it is difficult for me to identify any human being as a friend, even with those I've hung out with for ten years,  I feel that it would be impossible for anyone to identify me as their friend.  I have a very difficult time separating friend and acquaintance
-I feel as if I don't have a natural right to be respected, as if I am a bad person, even though I can relate to a lot of other people with similar problems, I feel in some way I always have an exception, therefore unsure if I really deserve to be treated well
-I feel as if I am responsible for everything and am concerned highly about what others think, I am always worried if my friends or "friends" will discontinue their relationship with me if I said something wrong or what not



These are only some of them.  I'm just wondering if anyone have some of the same ideas, cause I feel I have every disorder in the book.



</question>

<answer>



Personality disorders are not an exact science  they consist of loads of overlapping symptoms - It is almost a negotiation between your self and a psychologist and often they are not named - look up information here.



http://www.rcpsych.ac.uk/mentalhealthinf...



Ask to be referred to  a psychologist as aspergers could be in the mix.



I share a lot of your symptoms and have a disorder on the dissociative scale but as i said they are a jumble and you would need to take tests.

<answer>



I have a lot of the same problems.



I am always counting down to a particular date or event, especially ones that make me nervous. It feels like everything after that date is on the other side of a wall that I'm afraid of reaching.



I also have to keep reminding myself I've done something, or I have to redo it over and over. I've sometimes spent minutes reading the same few words over and over again, or spelling the words in my head instead of reading them.
I've had people tell me I'm somewhat OC, and these things get worse when I'm stressed or upset about something.



Honestly the best way I've found to get over it is to just become indifferent. It's kind of hard, but if you can convince yourself that you really don't care, then it really doesn't matter.

<answer>



I don't allow it to bother me, I realize that there are (can be) many reasons for a person not to "like" me, but it all comes down to a choice they make...regardless of the reason they make it. I just don't care who does, or doesn't, like me, or why. I'm unaffected.



Acceptance is not approval, consent, permission, authorization,  agreement, compliance, sympathy, endorsement, support, ratification, assistance, advocating, backing, maintaining, authenticating, reinforcing, encouraging, promoting, aiding, abetting, or even liking



what is.



Acceptance is simply seeing something exactly the way it is and saying,  "That's the way it is." Great philosophers from Gertrude Stein ("A rose is a rose is a rose") to Popeye ("I am what I am") understood acceptance.



</answer>



<answer from>

Total points: 533 (Level 2)

So don't worry about it :)

<question>



Should you have to convince someone to be your boyfriend/in a relationship or should they want it equally too?



I'm confused.



I've been "hanging out" with this boy I really like. I consider our outings as "dates".



But I guess it's not considered "dating" him because in order to be "dating" him we would have to be in a relationship as boyfriends right?



So I cant say I "dated" him but i can say we went out on a few dates?? right?



Anyways, I want to ask him to be my boyfriend and to be in a relationship because im in love with him.



i want us to be "together" and "official".



I want us to be dating.



i want us to exclusive.



i want to be a couple.



i want to go out with him.



Should I have to convince him to want all that stuff too, or shouldnt he naturaly want to be i na relationship with me also?



How should I ask him to be my boyfriend? What should I do if he says no?



Ive neevr had a boyfriend before and want him to be my first.



What reactions and typical responses should I expect?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Learn to be more open and communicative with him.  Don't be afraid to say exactly what you think.  If he doesn't like wtf you have to say, then get rid of him.  Tell him, I'd like you to be my boyfriend, than ask what he thinks.  If he's not sure, don't freak out and don't push him, just don't be to cozy w/ him and don't put out, (have sexual contact).  If he wants you as his bf, take things slow, you don't need to exchange passwords and read each others text messages right away, but don't assume he's telling you the truth.  Many guys will f*ck than disappear.  Not because they want to hurt you, just because they don't know how to handle relationships.  So be prepared for the worst and remember your the sh*t, not him.  Don't ever feel embarrassed.  Millions of gays out there.  If one doesn't work out, it's not the end of the world.



P.S.  ALWAYS USE CONDOMS!!! NO MATTER WHAT!!!  SO MANY PEOPLE HAVE STDS.  THEY LOOK NORMAL AND HEALTHY THEN WHEN IT BURNS FOR YOU TO PEE YOU WILL REGRET IT.



</answer>

<original file>7396.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk96541.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



xXx Crystaillee The Second xXx
Member since: 16 October 2008
Total points: 444 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



I had twins three years ago - one died of SIDS - will this affect the surviving twin later in life?



On June 13th, 2005 I gave birth to twins, Kidia and Khauna. On June 16th, our son died of SIDS (what they're calling SIDS at least - Khauna stopped breathing and they weren't able to resuscitate him). I've spoken to both my daughters doctor and mine, and they've both said time will tell on this - so I need opinions from those who've been through it.



I've heard stories about one twin passing away and the other twin having a "withdrawal". Do you think my daughter will be effected by this at any point in her life? If you've lost one twin, but the other survived - did your child ever go through this? What age where they at? Does she still feel connected to him, even though he was only alive for a few days?



My husband and I have twin boys now as well, who are two, do you think having siblings so close to her age will help my daughter in any grief she may feel in the future.



This isn't an issue now - she's never said anything about or asked about Khauna - and we only have three or four pictures of him, all of which are in our bedroom. So I may just be worrying about something that will never happen. But I wanted help anyway.



Thank you.



</question>



<additional details>



Any suggestions are welcome! Thank you!



</additional details>



<answer from>



Dr. Bob
Member since: 23 January 2008
Total points: 19318 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



In the study of sibling relations and numerical position (you know, "first, second/middle, last, etc.") there is also the question of "psycho-social" influences on sibling position. A major influence is the sex of the siblings, another is how the parents compare them with each other, and so on.



Anyway, one influence is called the "ghost child," which happens a lot in families, in which a child dies (miscarriage, in infancy, etc.) and a parent, usually the mother, keeps that child "alive" by referring to it through the years. This often happens on the anniversary of the child's birthday. At such a time, the mother wonders what that child would have been like if he or she had lived. Often, this is seen (by the mother) as the "ideal child" (in contrast with the actual child who survived).



I don't mean to be so academic about this, but you are facing a future in which this could be how your daughter is influenced by the death of



your son, her brother.



I would say find someone to talk with about this, your best bet being someone trained in Adlerian psychology (since such a person best understands the ins and outs of siblings relationships).



--  Dr. Bob, Adlerian Psychologist



Source(s):



For more on Adlerian psychooo9gy: http://www.lifecourseinstitute.com



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you VERY much.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



nysenutz
Member since: 26 December 2007
Total points: 16333 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Kidia will be fine.  My nephew is the lone survivor of triplets. The other 2 were still born.  He has an older step brother and a younger adopted brother, both 4 or five years apart.  He does have his quiet moments when he reflects on how lucky he was.  We have spoken about it, and it is no big issue with him.



</answer>



<answer from>



girlieex...
Member since: 03 September 2008
Total points: 197 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Once she gets older, explain to her that everything happens for a reason, and Khauna going to heaven was something you couldn't control. Convince her that he's watching over her and keeping her safe, and that you are so grateful that she is a strong, healthy and growing up girl. Make sure you reassure her often and let her know that you love her. Good luck and sorry about your loss.



</answer>



<answer from>



john carlo
Member since: 12 February 2008
Total points: 9429 (Level 5)



</answer from>

I'm sure with all the love and understanding your little girl will be fine.



Good luck to you and your family.

<original file>8425.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk97685.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Psychology



</category>



<question from>



Floss
Member since: 14 August 2007
Total points: 650 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Can animals commit suicide?



</question>



<answer from>



Haley+St...
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 199 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Animals, too, experience a profound feeling of sadness when their play/hunt/sex partner dies. Those studying the behavior of wild and domestic animals come with an increasing number of cases proving that animals are capable of pure sorrow when they lose someone close to them. Somehow, this behavior is linked to self-conscience, thus only "brainy" animals, like mammals and some birds, consciously commit suicide.



It is hard to say if animals commit suicide. An animal will not do this because of a sudden dread, or an excessive emotion. As they cannot ... speak, it's difficult to assess if there is a true suicide.



But when a dog or a cat, following the death of their master, refuse food dying of hunger, we can conclude that this is an unwitting consequence of the pain they feel. But when the animal throws itself from a height, it's hard to believe this is a casual act or the effect of its anxiety.



Source(s):



http://news.softpedia.com/news/Do-Animal...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks for the detailed answer :-D



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



r
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 548 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Interesting question, i think animals are just like us.



</answer>

unknown
Member since: 10 September 2007
Total points: 3109 (Level 4)



</answer from>

If you were in that motorcycle and it's in a stormy night then that may mean you should watch out on your decisions.



But if you were in it in a bright sunny day then that's a good sign that something good will come soon.



Dreams would often tell you something you haven't achieved while you were conscious. So might as well be careful in making any choices in your life=)



</answer>



<answer from>



octogen
Member since: 22 February 2008
Total points: 7757 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



All dreams mean something from your past and take place, not in the conscious mind, but in the subliminal mind where these feelings lay dormant until needed. You do not state riding,or pillion, this can make a difference. Riding you are in charge. Passenger you are trying to get away from, or come to terms, with a situation that you are probably not aware of.  As you are only13 it will fall into a common dream that young people have and is nothing but an awakening to facts unknown to you. What you always called home was not your home, it is in fact your parents home. You have always had to ask for what you  wanted while watching your parents each doing exactly what they wanted without having to ask. This builds up a resentment even at a very early age. Now you know the dream will fade, or may not even occur again.



Source(s):



Training in dream couselling and interpretation



</answer>

<answer from>

<answer>



Run faster than at least 1 person.
Dont go back for the screaming woman who tripped over.
Find somewhere secure to hide and stay quiet.
Loot anything useful.
Follow the bloke who looks like Steven Segal.
Dont ignore emergency news reports.
Dont go and check to see what the noise was in the attic/basement.
Safety in numbers.
Give up vegetarianism if the only food is a cute fwuffy bunny.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ivan R
Member since: 09 November 2006
Total points: 20758 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hello,



(ANS) No.1 One of the most important aspects of a survival situation is to remain as calm as possible, & to think clearly and rationally. i.e. keep a cool head. Its good thinking skills that will ultimately save your life.



No.2 Try to find shelter i.e. get out of the wind, the rain, or the heat.



No.3 Try to stay dry as far as possible (or cool if in desert terrain).



No.4 Food sources (look for the most available food sources around you within the natural environment). Fish from rivers or the sea, berries, roots, edible plants if you know which they are. You might have to resort to eating insects or lizards or snakes or small birds if it would keep you alive.



No.5 Always use whats around you in the natural environment.



Ivan



</answer>

<answer from>



Special Edition
Member since: 23 May 2008
Total points: 1001 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Firstly, you'd need a strong will to live. And I guess it depends on the situation for the rest...



Being able to navigate you way around is important, whether it be with the sun, a map, a compass etc. and you'd need to avoid or at least defend yourself against dangerous animals or plants or people.



In terms of mental preparation, you would need to have a brave personality to overcome the fear of being in a life threatening situation. If your too overwhelmed by fear you can't think straight. For example, I'm scarred of spiders, but if I was lost in the rain-forest I'd need to overcome that fear to survive.
You would also need to be able to remain calm and not get angry. In a situation where things are most likely to go wrong it is easy to imagine that tempers will flare. Getting angry can cause loss of energy and rationalisation, and (if in a group) can spark off arguments and break down team spirit. Teamwork is highly important in order to live, because as humans we are stronger working together.



Having said that another emotion you'd need to overcome would be guilt. Even though we are storngest as a team, it is still everyone for himself, if that makes any sence? For example, if your in a burning building and one screaming person trips up you cannot go back for them because it would endanger your own life, you cannot feel guilty about that and have too keep on surviving.This is called "survivor's guilt".
And lastly depression. In a desperate situation you'd have too keep pushing forward if you have any chance of surviving. To overcome this you would have to stay possitive and think happy thoughts because it is esay to give up hope. It seems that while humans are physically trying to improve their lives, by means of building a fire, making shelter, gathering water or food, there is less tendency to become depressed.



PS: OMG, I love your work! I think your amazing!!! Seriously, when I grow up I wanna be a frilm director because you have inspried me so much!!! :D



</answer>



<answer from>



L
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 115 (Level 1)



</answer from>

Don't panic or become emotional. Find supplies and somewhere safe. Find other people.



</answer>

hisssed

<answer>



Answer hidden due to its low rating



I would have to say to become more religious.  When one has had a brush with death it causes them to reevaluate their lives and to realize what they have.



Another tip would be to live life more fully.  Take the trip you wanted.  Tell loved ones that you love them everyday.  Visit an old friend.  Make amends to those we have wronged.  Go to confession.  Tidy up our lives so to speak.

<question from>



debonair...

</question from>



<question>



Does a depressed person think like this?



For example a person doesnt do anything like everyday just day dreaming and all.. she knows she has a problem but probably its just too big to face and but whenever she thinks about Christmas the day that is very important to every one she feels like there's no time to waste she already gotta do something about her problem or else she will be spending that very important day feeling BLAH.. does a depressed think about that?



</question>



<answer from>



EvilUs
Member since: 08 May 2007
Total points: 170 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm not a doctor but a depressed person doesn't day dream. A depressed person is one who can't kickstart the day off. Feels overwhelmed by day to day activities. Has trouble deciding what to do first. Feels they can't do anything right. Hope this helps. If you are feeling this way or even questioned depression, seek professional help. Don't just get medicated. Get counseling. It works! Good Luck



</answer>



<answer from>

<question from>



abigbrig...
Member since: 15 October 2007

<question>



How can I stop feeling like an isolated fragment in an uncaring world?



</question>



<answer from>



Tom W

<answer>



i use to feel abandoned, to feel alone. sometimes, when i see my friends were so happy, i started to feel lonely.



actually, i am not really sure how do you feel right know. but we cannot expect that friends will come to you most of the time. we, on the other hand, have to approach them ourselves. its like if you don't greet them, say hello to them, offer help to them (in various possible ways) & do not expect that they will come to you easily.



my point is, to be happy, we have to work for it. we have to socialize. we have to be active in community.



anyway, i wish all of us are happy. and i hope that my answer is helping. XOXO



</answer>



<answer from>



Executive Producer2000
Member since: 26 May 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Glad that you asked that question.  First, to set things straight, the world is not uncaring.  The reason you believe that is because you are listening to the headlines, the media, newspapers and television news. Once you drown yourself in those things, you will feel like you are isolated in an uncaring world.  First remedy, turn off all the news that you usually listen to.  Do not read the newspapers or listen to the daily news on tv.



Want to still be informed? Read these instead:  US News and World report magazine, Time Magazine, Readers Digest, Psychology Today, Psychologies, or other magazines like that.  By reading any of these or all of these, you will still be informed on the latest, yet these will not depress you as the tv news and radio news will.  (These magazines present the news but do not overwhelm your senses with gore, killing and disgusting details of news stories).



Second, know that you are not alone. Every single person in this world has a God, and if the God is a true God, that God is always with you.  If your God is not always with you, then try Jesus Christ who is all present, omnipresent and here to be with you.



Third, and this is a very important step, you need to get a volunteer job of some sort and that will help you be connected and help you see that the whole world is not uncaring. Individuals who are willing to work for free--for no money, are caring people. So be with caring people and you will see that the world is not uncaring.  Volunteer today.



Volunteer in these kinds of places and in these areas:



Be a television studio volunteer. Contact the nearest community access station and volunteer there.



Volunteer in the botanic gardens, zoos, or other natural settings and help save the planet.



Volunteer in a senior's organization or in a hospital.  Volunteer to help care for newborns in hospitals or nurseries.



Almost anywhere people work for money, usually accepts volunteers.



The first way you stop feeling isolated is by thinking of someone other than yourself.  So, go do it.  If you are under age, you need your parent's or guardian's permission to volunteer.  Go for it.



Source(s):



Having had many volunteer jobs in the past, I have learned that there are many caring people in this world.  You can learn that too. Just volunteer.



</answer>

<question from>



it's a CHOICE
Member since: 11 August 2007
Total points: 170 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I'm 19, but I don't *feel* 19!?



I only just turned 19 a few days ago, so it would make sense if it was just that I still felt 18. However, even when I was eighteen I still felt like I hadn't yet caught up to that age or something. I didn't feel a specific age younger but, are we supposed to feel officially older or something once we've reached adulthood? I still feel like I'm not there yet and I always felt this way growing up as a teenager, like, "how can we possibly be in grade 11 yet, we were only just in grade 8!?". I'm a chick, by the way, so I've finished growing.



Now that I spilled what's bothering me, has anyone got anything to say to that?



</question>



<answer from>



axeblade...
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 115 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i feel the same way , dont really know why though, just though i would tell ya that your not alone :)



</answer>

<answer>



Perhaps you feel that you haven't progressed much since previous years. You may feel as if nothing much has changed, school is school, no matter how far in it is, so you always feel younger than you are. I'm not too sure. :S

<answer>



I'm 27, Full-time graphic designer, 1 child, married and divorced and I still feel young.



How you feel is entirely up to you, of course there are occasions when you have to "act" mature, but don't feel you have to force yourself to act mature because your "older and you should" just be yourself :)



</answer>
